title: Regenerating Soil Life with waste management
description:
The project is an innovative integration of industrial composting and increasing carbon stocks in soil. The proposed grouped project was implemented by Ambipar Environmental Solutions within the first instance located in the South of Brazil. The annual average estimation of carbon accrual is 2,337 tCO2e and 38,397 tCO2e of reduction.
Compost application in soil has the potential of contribution to the carbon cycle, where simple nutrients that return to the soil are converted by plants into organic compounds engaging sustainable agricultural land management. 
Soil carbon accrual per unit area is measured in both baseline and project scenarios based on the spatial coordinated sampling gathering data on soil carbon concentration with statistical rigor. The project activities were designed to improve soils, including changes to agricultural practices, compost application and enhance biodiversity in soils. The measurement of the stable SOC concentration was set up to quantify soil dynamics at depth. The soil layers up to 80cm were sampled to estimate changes in carbon stock, excluding the top-soil 20cm.
Prior to the implementation of this project, rural producers do not foresee regenerative agriculture due to the lack of knowledge and technical skills about how to switch to organic input, biological control of plagues and sustainable land management. The previous scenario within the project area outcome low productivity per area, soil degradation and no smart application of the compost provided through the waste management, which implied in deposition applications without potential reuse for climate change mitigation.
Nowadays, this waste gets into the circular economy by its smart reuse and social and environmental positive influence. Ambipar manages great volumes across Brazil for about 50 industrial customers. Built on the raised potential for inclusion of new project activity instances, this grouped project brings up attractive engagement for high carbon landscapes.

title: Wuwei City Afforestation Project in Gansu Province
description:
Wuwei City Afforestation Project in Gansu Province (hereafter referred to as “the project”) is located in Wuwei City, Gansu Province, People’s Republic of China. Wuwei is a prefecture-level city along the Hexi Corridor and the Silk Road where the Loess Plateau, the Tibetan Plateau and the Mongolian Plateau. The project activities involve the planting of trees and shrubs of native species on 28,817.73 hectares (or 432,234 Mu ) of deserts and other barren lands located in Liangzhou District and Gulang County administered by Wuwei City. The species include Picea asperata (Chinese spruce), Platycladus orientalis (Oriental thuja or Oriental arborvitae), Ulmus pumila (Siberian elm), Elaeagnus angustifolia (Russian olive) and Haloxylon ammodendron (saxaul). The project area was barren lands before the project and would continue to be so without the implementation of the project activities. 
The implementation of the project activity will generate GHG emission removals and mitigate climate change, improve soil and water conditions, increase the forest cover and enhance local biodiversity; the project also generates social benefits including job opportunities and technical skills training for local communities and residents.

title: Guangzhou Eastern Solid Resource Recycling Center MSW Integrated treatment Plant Project
description:
Guangzhou Eastern Solid Resource Recycling Center MSW Integrated treatment Plant Project (hereinafter referred to as the project) is located at the Solid Resource Recycling Center, Fushan Village, Jiulong Town, Luogang District, Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province, P.R China.
The purpose of the project is to treat MSW with anaerobic digesters and utilize recovered biogas for electricity generation. The project activity includes MSW collection, MSW pre-treatment system, biodiesel production system, anaerobic digester, biogas purification, electricity generation system and waste heat recovery. 
The fresh waste of the project is mainly kitchen and catering waste of the Guangzhou City and the design processing capacity of the project for the fresh waste is 2,040 tonnes per day. The biogas from anaerobic digestion will be used for electricity generation with internal combustion generators. The total installed capacity will be 10.34 MW included 4 generators with each 1.063 MW and 2 generators with each 3.044 MW. 
Before the implementation of the project activity, the fresh waste would be treated in a landfill site with a partial capture of the landfill gas (LFG) and flaring of the captured LFG. The project is to utilize the biogas produced by anaerobic digestion for power generation. The electricity generated by the project is supplied to China South Power Grid (CSPG) which is dominated by coal-fired power stations. 
In absence of the project, equivalent amount of electricity exported to the grid by the project would have otherwise been supplied by China South Power Grid (CSPG). Greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions will be reduced by avoiding CO2 emissions from those fossil fuel-based power plants connected to the grid and by avoiding GHG emissions from venting LFG into atmosphere at the landfill site.
VCS Proponent:
Guangzhou LEO-KING Environmental Technology Co., Ltd.
Guangdong Province, China

title: Zhangye Improved Grassland Management Project
description:
Zhangye Improved Grassland Management Project (hereafter as “the project”) is located in Zhangye City, the northwest of Gansu Province and in the middle of Hexi corridor where the Qinghai Tibet Plateau and Mongolia Plateau meet. The project’s aim is to restore the local degraded grassland ecosystem by seeding grass and building fence on the degraded grassland, increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local development by introducing sustainable grazing and management of grassland. 
The project covers Gaotai County, Shandan County, Mingle County, Sunan County, Ganzhou district and Shandan Racecourse. According to the baseline survey, before the implementation of the project, the grassland in the region has been facing serious degradation and even desertification due to the impact of climate change and human activities. 
Totally, 261,059.80 ha of degraded grassland have been managed scientifically by fence building and reseeding of local high-quality forage. In general, rest grazing and rotational grazing are implemented in slightly degraded areas (the total grass yield decreased by 30%-50% compared with that before degradation), and reseeding is implemented in severely degraded areas. Besides these main restoration measures, the project also alleviate soil desertification and restore grassland vegetation to improve soil carbon storage and local biodiversity through grassland management measures, such as daily management measures from other protect projects like rodent and pest control and grassland fire prevention to ensure the long-term sustainable management of the project area. The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 29,440,243 tCO2e in 40 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 736,006 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Zhangye Academy of Forestry Sciences
Gansu, China
CCB Proponent:
Zhangye Academy of Forestry Sciences
Gansu, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Saving Colombia's Cloud Forest
description:
The tropical Andes are among the most vulnerable places on earth due to the dual impacts of climate change and human population pressures. With the intense and historic livestock activity in the area, deforestation in the valleys north and south have almost completely isolated the eastern forest. The remaining habitat is an oasis of biodiversity and one of Colombia’s many national treasures. The region also contains two important watersheds: the Río San Juan Antioquia, and Río San Juan Bravo Chocó.  These watersheds provide critical ecosystem services to communities living and working throughout the area and the forests are vital to protection of the headwaters of these important sources of fresh water to the surrounding communities. Without them, landslides, silting, and flooding threaten the health and safety of thousands of residents. 

As our planet’s climate systems continue to be altered, it is highly likely that some or many of the species found in cloud forests will be lost forever. The effects of climate change are already apparent here. As a result, many cloud forest species have started to migrate upslope to maintain a favorable climate. However, their routes are often blocked by a degraded and fragmented landscape caused by agriculture moving up the mountainside and penetrating deeper into the lowlands.   

Our goal is to create a large, protected area for endemic and threatened species to shield them from imminent threats, mitigate climate impacts, and prevent extinctions. Since 2017, we have worked closely with our local partner Fundación Colibri to create a vital connection across a narrow ridgeline. This ecological corridor will safeguard endemic and endangered wildlife and offers important protection for the headwaters of a major river, the primary source of fresh water for communities throughout the region.
VCS Proponent:
Saving Nature, Inc.
North Carolina, United States
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

description: The demand for timber and other tree-based products is increasing day by day and one feasible alternative to fulfil such a demand would be adopting agroforestry practice as this is one system that can provide both wood and food while at the same time conserve and rehabilitate ecosystem. title: Voluntary Carbon Market Project for Agroforestry Plantation in Anand and Kheda, Gujarat
description: The demand for timber and other tree-based products is increasing day by day and one feasible alternative to fulfil such a demand would be adopting agroforestry practice as this is one system that can provide both wood and food while at the same time conserve and rehabilitate ecosystem. The proposed ARR VCS project plans to promote sustainable agroforestry for small-scale farmers to provide them with financial benefits and ensure GHG mitigation in the state of Gujarat, India. The project is being conducted in the Ahmedabad circle spread across Anand and Kheda district. The total project area in Anand district is 2272.75 hectares and 3096.5 hectares in Kheda district, together making a total project area of 5369.25 hectares. The agroforestry plantations done by the farmers from 2018 to 2020 have been considered. The main agroforestry species planted in each village during 2018, 2019 and 2020 in Anand comprises of Eucalyptus (Eucalyptus globulus), Arduso (Ailanthus excelsa), Malbari Limbda (Azadirachta Indica), Baval (Acacia nilotica), Teak (Tectona grandis) and Melia Dubia (Melia dubia), whereas in Kheda, the main agroforestry species planted during 2018,2019 and 2020 are Eucalyptus (Eucalyptus globulus), Arduso (Ailanthus excelsa), Malbari Limbda (Azadirachta Indica), Teak (Tectona grandis) and Melia Dubia (Melia dubia) and Mango (Mangifera indica).

description: The demand for timber and other tree-based products is increasing day by day and one feasible alternative to fulfil such a demand would be adopting agroforestry practice as this is one system that can provide both wood and food while at the same time conserve and rehabilitate ecosystem. The project is being conducted in the Godhra circle spread across Panchmahal district. The total project area is 1972 h.a. and the agroforestry plantations done by the farmers from 2018 to 2020 have been considered. The main agroforestry species planted in each village during 2018, 2019 and 2020 are Eucalyptus globulus and Tectona grandis (Teak).

title: REDD+ Project in Oro Province of Papua New Guinea
description: This REDD+ project is located in the province of Oro in Papua New Guinea. The Oro forests are among the most valuable natural resources. These forests support hundreds of rare and endemic species, making this place a “mega-biodiverse” district. These forests are also directly critical to the lives and well-being of most of our people, including the communities in this province. For decades, these areas are under tremendous stress due to logging, shifting agriculture, and plantations. The demand for unprocessed logs from these areas from the Asian market is the biggest cause of forest loss. However, for the past two decades, forest harvesting has occurred in a destructive and ecologically unsustainable fashion. Secondly, a large portion of the forests is being converted to permanent agriculture and long fallow shifting cultivation. In addition, the human population is been tremendously increased in these areas, and hence the dependence on forest resources increased. Due to the increase in the human population, the poverty among the rural areas is also increased, therefore the subsistence farmers respond to the growing needs of the population by various forms of agricultural intensification. This project is an Avoided Unplanned Deforestation and Degradation (AUD) activity. This initiative proceeds with promoting various activities to mitigate climate change and improving livelihoods.

Kanaka Management Services Private Limited
Karnataka, India

info@kms-group.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Guizhou Xintian CMM Power Generation Project
description:
Guizhou Xintian CMM Power Generation Project (hereafter referred to as “the Project”) refers to a power plant which utilizes low concentration coal mine methane (CMM) for power generation to supply electricity to the Xintian coal mine and to China Southern Power Grid (CSPG). The Project is located in Gantang Town, Qianxi County, Bijie City, Guizhou Province, People’s Republic of China.
The purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted low concentration CMM to produce electricity. No coal bed methane (CBM)  or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. It was planned that CMM power generators with a total capacity of 17.6 MW would be installed for the Project. Based on ex ante estimates, the power plant will destroy a total amount of 35.2 million m3 (under normal conditions ) of methane and export 82,720 MWh of electricity every year, when all power generators are in full operation. The generated electricity is supplied to the Xintian coal mine through the electricity distribution network in the coal mine area; part of the electricity produced by the Project is exported to CSPG after the coal mine demand is fully met.
The Project achieves emission reductions in two aspects: 1) it reduces methane emissions by capturing and destroying methane which would have been directly vented into the air in the baseline scenario; 2) it reduces CO2 emissions by displacing an amount of electricity that would otherwise have been supplied by CSPG.
VCS Proponent:
Yonggui Energy Development Co., Ltd. Xintian Branch
Guizhou Province, China
+86 021 23019950

title: IMPROVED FOREST MANAGEMENT THROUGH LOGGED-TO-PROTECTED FORESTS AND REDUCED IMPACT LOGGING IN UFA NGOMBÉ, REPUBLIC OF CONGO
description:
The Project “Improved Forest Management through Logged-to-Protected Forests and Reduced Impact Logging in UFA Ngombé, Republic of Congo (IFM - UFA Ngombé Project)” is designed to improve forest management in 583,326 ha of native Congolese forests legally designated for selective logging. The Project is situated within the UFA Ngombé forest concession which is attributed to and managed by the company Industrie Forestière de Ouesso (IFO), owned by INTERHOLCO AG (IHC). The UFA Ngombé forest concession is divided into four Forest Management Units for 1) the production of timber, 2) community development, and 3) protection and 4) conservation of biodiversity. The Project Area includes areas of High Conservation Value (HCV), including swamps and floodplains in connection with some of the largest peatland complexes in the world, the Cuvette Centrale and the Congo Basin peatland areas. These peatlands are essential for carbon storage, as peatlands store more carbon than any other natural terrestrial system. UFA Ngombé also borders the Ntokou-Pikounda National Park which is home to diverse wildlife, including one of the world’s largest western lowland gorilla populations.
The principle activities of the IFM - UFA Ngombé Project are 1) to implement Reduced Impact Logging (RIL-C) to reduce GHG emissions in one or more source categories (i.e., timber felling, skidding and hauling), and 2) to set-aside areas of Logged-to-Protected Forests (LtPF) to maintain and protect ecosystem services in forest production areas legally designated for selective logging. The Project will apply the VCS VM0035 and VM0010 methodologies to the respective RIL-C and LtPF Project Activities.
VCS Proponent:
Interholco AG
Baar, Switzerland
+41 41 767 03 03
info@interholco.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in Pinghu City
description:
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation is conducted in Pinghu City under the jurisdiction of Jiaxing City, Zhejiang Province of China, which have a total acreage of 12,545 ha for single-cropping rice. Without this project providing ditches to conduct intermittent flooded method, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission removal than the continuously flooded. 
With the project implementation, the cement ditches, reservoirs and relevant technical training are provided for these farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional continuously flooded method. During rice cultivation, controllable irrigation and drainage according to rice growth requirements can not only save water resources, but also reduce methane emission from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (in the flooded state). In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48% . Hence, this project activity is estimated to reduce 4.78 tCO2e/ha. 
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 419,489 tCO2e in the first seven-year period with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 59,927 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:

title: The ARR Cerrado Carbon Project
description:
The ARR Cerrado Carbon Project is located at the Cerrado Biome, in the state of Mato Grosso do Sul, Brazil. It is an AFOLU project, and therefore is classified within scope 14. More specifically, the project falls under the ARR category.
The ARR Cerrado Carbon Project’s purpose is to remove and reduce GHG emissions through an increase in forestry area and preservation of native vegetation in the state of Mato Grosso do Sul, at the Cerrado biome, initially near the city of Ribas do Rio Pardo. The project also includes the management and implementation of various social activities at the local communities nearby. The carbon credits are a result of the change of land use in previous pasture areas, through the plantation of Eucalyptus species in an area of 38.708 ha (ARR category).
The plantation activities will be developed in accordance with good forestry practices, and in addition, the project proponents will also seek certification under sustainable programs, such as the FSC, which can confirm the implementation of such practices.
VCS Proponent:
Suzano SA
São Paulo, Brazil
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: CONSERVATION OF NATIVE FOREST IN THE BIODIVERSITY HOTSPOT OF PAPUA NEW GUINEA
description:
The project is located on the south-western slope of the Sarawaget Range in Morobe Province. It is comprised of three regions that are based on clan affiliations and is accessible from Lae. It consists of lower montane forest with small areas of lowland tropical rainforest and covers a total area of 226,843 hectares. The project comprises an initial area of approximately 226,843 hectares stretches from Tamigidu on the coast near Lae, all the way to the Morobe/Madang border in the Wantoat/Leron LLG area. It is located on the south-western slopes of the Sarawaget range in Morobe Province, Papua New Guinea and is home to approximately 20,000 people.

Forests in the project area, however, have experienced a continued reduction in biomass due largely to illegal logging and to the establishment of crops, use of firewood, pastures, and settlements. These forests have historically been an important source of income for local families, who periodically harvest timber when the economic needs arise, or to generate income generation sources.

The climate objective of the Project is to avoid and prevent the unplanned deforestation in native forests of PNG, thus avoiding the net emission of 34,026,450 tCO2e through 30 years of Project crediting period.

title: Restoration of Degraded Mangroves and Sustainable Development in Myanmar
description: The objective of this project is to restore 1003 hectares of degraded lands in the Ayeyarwady Division of Myanmar. As per the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) category, the project falls under the ARR (Afforestation, reforestation and Revegetation) category. The project will create a healthy mangrove ecosystem in degraded lands belonging to Chaung Thar, Kangyi, and Bomie village tracts. Apart from the carbon sequestration, the project will address issues including natural disaster risk reduction, biodiversity improvement and poverty reduction with sustainable livelihoods in the coastal communities.

title: Grouped Reforestation Project by Cropzone Agro Forestry Private Limited
description:
Crop Zone Agro Forestry Limited (CZAFL) is proposing a grouped Afforestation, Reforestation and  Revegetation (ARR) in Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Karnataka and Maharashtra state of India. CZAFL is the Project Proponent (PP) whereas EKI Energy Services Limited (Enking International) is providing 
carbon credit advisory services to the PP. The CZAFL has mobilized the farmers in the selected states of India to plant various tree species on their lands. These tree species range from fruit bearing trees like Indian blackberry, Guava, Mango to commercial species like Teak, Mahogany and Sandal. Simple 
tree cultivation techniques involving planting saplings in the pits with minimum disturbance to the lands have been employed. The lands selected for the project activity is fallow agriculture land. The PP has made contract with the farmers/land owners where they will be given tree saplings and technical support. In return, the PP will reap the benefits through sale of carbon credits. Initially, 501.7 hectares of land has been selected for the first project activity instance. Through carbon sequestration by the planted trees, the project is expected to generate annual average GHG emission reductions of removals of 10,571 tCO2e.

title: Mangrove Restoration Project with Sine Saloum and Casamance communities, Senegal
description:
The proposed mangrove restoration grouped project intends to generate GHG emission removals by restoring the ecosystems through the plantation of up to 16,000 hectares of mangrove. Within the first project instance of this project, the project activities will be carried out over an area of 7,020 hectares, by planting at least 35 million of new mangrove trees. The project area is located in Sine Saloum Delta and Casamance estuary in Senegal, being most of the project area within the boundaries of Protected areas. The plantation will be carried out in places previously selected due to their ecological conditions, together with the local communities, through a design that implies the active participation of communities involved in the project.
The goal of the project is to increase the mangrove area by planting a variety of species of native mangrove, which will increase the positive functions (ecosystem services) that mangroves provide to communities and biodiversity.  The location of the project contributes to the continuity of habitats and ecosystems, since the plantation areas are close to other reforestation project and inside the area of mangrove distribution in Senegal This project is expected to bring positive benefits for different species relevant for the communities as fishes, oysters and mollusks.
WeForest is the Project Proponent and the NGO Oceanium is the Project Implementer of the restoration activities. For the community and biodiversity activities WeForest is in charge and will perform those through other implementing partners and the subsequent agreement with them. WeForest´s fundamental goal is to create social value for rural communities and contribute to their food security through the restoration of their ecosystems. WeForest provides investors access to biodiversity friendly carbon credits that aid the rural communities through large scale and social impact projects.
VCS Proponent:
WeForest ASBL
Flemish Brabant, Belgium
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: MicroEnergy Credits – Microfinance for Clean Energy Product Lines – Africa – Solar Lamps & Efficient cook stoves – 10341 –CPA - 0001
description:
The project activity involves marketing, distributing, and financing approximately 600,000 solar lighting systems (SLS), and 10,000 improved cook stoves (ICS), for low income households, community organisations and small/medium enterprises across Kenya. These products provide clean, renewable energy for cooking and lighting. 
Under the project activity, MicroEnergy Credits Corporation (MEC) works with project partners to develop a successful and diversified clean energy-lending program. The clean energy program addresses typical barriers for low-income clients including education, price, finance, and supply and aftersales service. MicroEnergy Credits Corp trains project partners to implement the clean energy lending program, as well as a robust and transparent carbon credit monitoring and tracking system to quantify and record the volume of carbon emission reductions created through the clean energy program.
State/Province: North Rift, South Rift, Western, Mount Kenya

title: Restoring Mangroves in Mexico's Blue Carbon Ecosystems
description:
Restoring Mangroves in Mexico's Blue Carbon Ecosystems grouped project (’BlueMX Project’), is a mangrove reforestation and restoration project containing many project instances spread across four Mexican states: Campeche, Nayarit, Quintana Roo and Veracruz.  The project is being developed and managed by BlueMX Mangrove A.C. in Mexico (‘BlueMX’) in collaboration with local community landowners called ejidos (including indigenous communities), private landowners, government agencies and other local partners.  

In total, the project activities will restore approximately 35,000 hectares of degraded mangrove areas thereby removing 31,278,014 tons of carbon over 30 years.  It is an Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU) project under VCS and the specific project activity referenced in this Project Design Document is Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR).  

The project instances are located in three different ecosystems: 1) the coastal plain of the Gulf of Mexico, 2) the Central Mexico Pacific coast, and 3) the Caribbean coastline on the Yucatan Peninsula.  The marshy and wetland ecosystems constitute one of the most important coastal ecological units in Mesoamerica due to their natural productivity and biodiversity. These regions have experienced significant removal and destruction of mangroves through land conversion to other uses, including industry and agricultural purposes (primarily cattle ranching and now palm oil), Aquaculture (shrimp farming), and local infrastructure development, such as road and bridge construction.

title: QianJin Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation
description:
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation is conducted in Qianxi City and Jinsha County, Guizhou Province, where located in southwestern China with a total acreage of 19,056 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the backward continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emissions decrease than the continuously flooded.
The implementation activities of the project include cement ditch construction, reservoir construction and necessary training for farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional flooded method. Controllable irrigation and drainage according to the needs of rice growth can not only save water resources, but also reduce methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (flooded state). In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48% . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 3.11 tCO2e/ha for rice is expected.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 412,713 tCO2e in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 58,959 tCO2e.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes.
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers.
- Provide more job opportunities, especially female workers.
- Use a proportion of benefits to improve the local children’s education.
VCS Proponent:
Guizhou Zhongjian’yangchen Energy Investment Co., Ltd.

Without the implementation of this project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the backward continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission less reduction than the continuously flooded.
The implementation activities of the project include cement ditch construction, reservoir construction and necessary training for the farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional continuously flooded method. Controllable irrigation and drainage according to the needs of rice growth can not only save water resources, but also reduce methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (flooded state) In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48% . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 3.17 tCO2e/ha for rice is expected.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 414,869 tCO2e in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 59,267 tCO2e.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers
- Provide more job opportunities, especially female workers
- Use a proportion of benefits to improve the local children’s education

Guizhou Xinzhanxin Agricultural Technology Co., Ltd.
Guizhou Province, China

title: Xinjiang Burqin Improved Grassland Management Project
description:
Xinjiang Burqin Improved Grassland Management Project (hereafter as “the project”) is located in Burqin County, Altai City, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, China. The project is aimed to restore the local degraded grassland ecosystem from adoption of sustainable grassland management practices, such as improving the rotation of grazing animals between summer and winter pastures, limiting the timing and number of grazing animals on degraded pastures, and restoration of severely degraded land by replanting with perennial grasses and ensuring appropriate management over the long-term.
There are two main restoration measures in the project: 1) Grass seeding was implemented in 5,000 ha of the severely degraded grasslands where grass seeds of local high-quality forage was sowed under the condition of fencing enclosure for 2 years, and then the grassland should be used reasonably and sustainably according to the local approved livestock carrying capacity. 2) Imposing grazing prohibition measures and building fences on 60,000 hectares of degraded grassland in order to strengthen the protection and improvement of the grassland and to prevent excessive cultivation, grazing or human destruction. 
Besides these main restoration measures, the project also alleviates soil desertification and restore grassland vegetation to improve soil carbon storage and local biodiversity through grassland management measures, such as daily management measures from other protect projects like rodent and pest control and grassland fire prevention to ensure the long-term sustainable management of the project area.

title: Integrated REDD+ Project in Zambia
description: This integrated REDD+ project in Zambia is located in the Lufwanyama district, Copperbelt province in Zambia. The forests in this area are good sequesters with  biodiversity. The project area is comprised of wet Miombo woodland, the major land use/land cover with important ecological functions. These forests are also directly critical to the lives and well-being of most of the community residing in this area. The communities around the project area are dependent on arable farming, semi-commercial trading, salaried employees, and charcoal production. The main livelihood of people here is arable farming and charcoal production. The integrated REDD+ Project in Zambia is an Avoided Unplanned Deforestation and Degradation. The project initiative proceeds with promoting mitigation of climate change through conservation and other activities. This REDD+ Project is basically a community based REDD+ project with no evictions and no conflicts involved.

title: Henan Shunhe CMM Power Generation Project
description:
Henan Shunhe CMM Power Generation Project (hereinafter referred to as the Project) is located in Shunhe township, Yongcheng, Shangqiu City, Henan Province, China. The purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted coal mine methane (CMM) with low concentration methane concentration to produce electricity. No coal bed methane (CBM) or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved.
Ten sets of CMM power generators will be installed with a total installed capacity of 2.1MW (3*0.7MW), destroying 4.347 million m3 of methane annually. After the full operation of the Project, the expected annual exported electricity will be 11,320 MWh, which will be supplied to the coal mine first through the electricity distribution network in Shunhe coal mine area, replacing the electricity that would otherwise have been purchased from the CCPG and displace part of the electricity generated by CCPG dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants.
The emissions reduction of the Project comes from two sources: 1) Methane (CH4) emissions as a result of the previously vented gas that will be captured and destroyed in the project scenario; 2) CO2 emissions from the production of the equivalent amount of electricity replaced by the Project that would otherwise have been purchased from the CCPG.
VCS Proponent:
Yongcheng Hongqiao Environmental Protection Energy Co. Ltd.
Henan Province, China

title: CRIMA PREDIO PUTUMAYO Y ANDOQUE DE ADUCHE REDD+  PROJECT
description:
The CRIMA Predio Putumayo y Andoque de Aduche REDD+ Project seeks the conservation of
forests located in the indigenous territories of Andoque de Aduche Indigenous Reserve, in the
municipality of Solano and Puerto Santander; and in the areas of the indigenous communities of Puerto Zábalo y Los Monos, and
Monochoa that are part of the vast Great Predio Putumayo Indigenous Reserve and that are
located in Puerto Leguizamo, Puerto Alegría, La Chorrera
and Puerto Santander municipalities. The project area has a
total area of 1.260.222 ha at the beginning of the monitoring period. The project aims to
contribute to mitigate the effects caused by climate change by reducing 27.686.867 tCO2
emissions derived from deforestation and forest degradation during the 30-year crediting period.
The main activities during the Project lifetime focus in the development of productive activities compatible with
community well-being and nature conservation, providing food security, improving social
investment, strengthening land use planning and self-government structure, monitoring biodiversity and
forest conservation. These activities aim to control and reduce the incidence of deforestation
drivers such as wood extraction, mining and illegal productive activities.
The area is characterized by its high biodiversity along with social unrest and deforestation.
Among the activities carried out by the promoters of deforestation are moving the border of
farming activities (especially subsistence agriculture and livestock), mining, wood harvesting for
commercial and community use, illegal crops and colonization processes. The social problems
are triggered by the absence of the government, lack of sanitation infrastructure, education,
health programs and shortage of technological guidance for sustainable development.
This project focuses on the AFOLU (Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Uses) sectors. Inside
the category for Reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation in developing
countries (REDD+). Its goal is to mitigate the effects caused by climate change through
reduction of CO2 emissions from deforestation and forest degradation, restauration of degraded
forest lands, promotion of the sustainable wood harvesting and carry out development activities
for the community well-being.
State/Province: Departments of Putumayo, Caquetá and Amazonas

CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: Muyuan WJZ AWMS GHG Mitigation Project in Henan Province
description:
The project introduces new animal waste management systems to treat the manure from 7 swine farms in Nanyang City and Zhumadian City, Henan Province. Each subsidiary swine farm will install one animal waste management system (AWMS), and the manure is treated on site. The purpose of the project activity is to treat the manure and wastewater to avoid methane emissions generated in the baseline uncovered anaerobic lagoons. 
The project activity uses flushing system to collect the manure automatically. All the manure and wastewater are collected and then be separated first. The solid will be treated in aerobic composting system and the organic fertilizers will be produced, the fertilizer produced in this process will be distributed to local farmers for free and the surplus will be sold in domestic market. The liquid will be treated through anaerobic digestion and the biogas generated during the treatment process will be captured for heat generation. The sludge produced from anaerobic digestion will be treated through aerobic composting together with the solid, the effluent will be supplied to the farmers living around free for agriculture irrigation.
It is estimated that approximately 1,637 tons of animal manure will be handled daily by the AWMS. The biogas released during the anaerobic digestion will be collected and used for heat production. The heat production is estimated to be 657,340GJ. Also, the generated heat will be only used for daily operation of the AWMSs and the 7 swine farms themselves and will not be provided to other users. For conservativeness, baseline emissions from heat generation are neglected.
The project activity will reduce of GHG in the atmosphere through avoiding methane emissions from anaerobic treatment of swine manure and wastewater. It is estimated that 321,663tCO2e emission reductions will be produced annually.
VCS Proponent:
Muyuan Foods Co., Ltd.
Henan Province, China
CCB Proponent:
Muyuan Foods Co., Ltd.
Henan Province, China

description:
The Rio Madeira Grouped REDD+ Project is located in the municipalities of Porto Velho, Rondônia state and Lábrea, south of Amazonas state, in the Northern region of Brazil. The region is surrounded by many rivers and its borders having direct contact with Rio Madeira.

title: The NFC Uganda Carbon Landscapes Project
description:
The New Forests Company (NFC) was founded in 2004 in Uganda with the vision of creating a sustainable timber resource in East Africa amidst significant deforestation. From the start, the Company adopted a Shared Value approach to doing business that recognizes the need for the three C’s of Conservation, Community and Commerce in order to thrive and be sustainable. Furthermore, NFC has been FSC (Forest Stewardship Council) certified continuously in Uganda since 2009, demonstrating the Company’s commitment to responsible forestry practices that benefit the environment and local communities.
Within 5 years, NFC established three greenfield commercial plantations at Namwasa, Kirinya and Luwunga. Namwasa and Luwunga are government concessions within Central Forest Reserves (CFR) that were proclaimed in the 1930s, but management of the reserves weakened  after independence. The CFRs subsequently suffered from high levels of deforestation and encroachment of subsistence farming and charcoal production. The Kirinya plantation was established on an abandoned sugar cane farm that was established in the 1970s.
VCS Proponent:
New Forests Company Holdings I Limited
Port Louis, Mauritius
+27 83 7624044
candice.taylor@newforests.earth
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: GUANGXI FANGCHENG DISTRICT IFM (CONVERSION OF LOGGED TO PROTECTED FOREST) PROJECT
description:
The Guangxi Fangcheng District IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project (hereafter “the project activity”) is implemented in Fangcheng District, Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region of China by Fangchenggang Fangcheng District Jinsui Agriculture Investment Co., Ltd, the geo-coordinate of the  project is  107°27'E -108°30'E and 20°30'N - 22°00'N, the total area is 6238 km2, which includes  the  Improved  Forest  Management  (IFM)  of  the forests in the conversion of logged to protected forest.
The area of the project activity is 8263.71 ha, including 4,250 subcompartments spreading over Dalu Town, Dongzhong Town, Fulong Town, Huashi Town, Jiangshan Town, Maoling Town, Naliang Town, Nasuo Town,Tanying Township, Shiwanshanyaozu Township, Shuiying Street, Wenchang Street, Zhuhe Street of Fangcheng District. All these forests are state-owned forests or privately-owned forests or collective-owned forests, and have the legal right to forest ownership. All the owners authorized the project proponent to access the project to their behalf. The species involved in the project are Pinus elliottii and Pinus massoniana. The forest of the project was older plantations under managing. Before the implantation of the project, the usual type of management was clearcutting.
Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged based on a valid and verifiable government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 1,899,564 tCO2e in 20 years, the average annual emission reduction is 94,978 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 1,462,648 tCO2e in 20 years, and average annual VCUs with buffer deduction is 73,132 tCO2e.
The project activity will contribute to the environment (biodiversity conservation, rocky desertification prevention and soil erosion control), thus contribute to development.
VCS Proponent:
Fangchenggang Fangcheng District Jinsui Agriculture Investment  Co., Ltd
Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, China
fcjsnt@163.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Gansu Zhangye Grouped Afforestation Project
description:
Gansu Zhangye Grouped Afforestation Project (hereafter “the project”) is located in Zhangye City, Gansu Province of China. The project’s aim is to increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by planting trees on the barren lands. The grouped project combines multiple project activity instances into a single, combined project that adds new instances over time. The project proponent sets the geographic boundaries for the grouped project, including where new project activity instances may be added (Section 2.1.7), and establishes criteria for determining the eligibility of future instances (Section 2.1.21).
For the initial project activity instance, 11,011.93 ha of forest is to be planted by direct planting on barren lands in Zhangye City, and the planted trees and shrub are all native species which including Elaeagnus angustifolia (oleaster), Armeniaca sibirica (prumus armeniaca), Populus L. (aspen), Ulmus pumila L. (elm), Picea asperata Mast. (spruce), Pinus sylvestris (mongolian pine), Haloxylon ammodendron (synonym), Caragana korshinskii Kom (caragana microphylla) . It is expected that the scope of the project will increase. For the inclusion of new eligible areas as project instances willing to participate within the grouped project, the new areas shall meet the criteria listing in Section 2.1.21. According to the project design report, 53,000 hectares of new afforestation area is expected to be added from 2021 to 2027. The implementation of the afforestation project will generate GHG emission removals and mitigate climate change; improve soil and water conservation and forest cover; enhance local biodiversity by increasing the connectivity of forests and bring income and job opportunities for local communities and residents.
VCS Proponent:
Zhangye Academy of Forestry Sciences
Gansu, China
CCB Proponent:
Zhangye Academy of Forestry Sciences
Gansu, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Boomitra Grassland Restoration in Northern Mexico
description: This project works with the ranchers of northern Mexico who raise livestock on individually owned or community-owned grasslands and enables those ranchers to adopt Improved Grassland Management (IGM). Ranchers in this region have traditionally followed practices such as continuous grazing, without any sustainable grazing or water management plans in place. This has resulted in overgrazing, leading to severe soil degradation, loss of vegetative cover and even desertification. When ranchers then become unable to sustain their livelihoods on their degraded ranches, they are sometimes forced to sell their land to farmers who convert the grasslands into croplands, resulting in further CO2 emissions and loss of natural flora and fauna. Through this project, ranchers are adopting new management practices, which include rotational grazing and a variety of water conservation measures. In rotational grazing, livestock are rotated between different sections of a pasture over the course of days, weeks, or months, while other sections of the pasture are allowed to rest. These sections are known as “paddocks”. This practice allows plants to recover and grow in the paddocks that are allowed to rest, and thus allows them to sequester carbon, gradually regenerating the land. In addition, for arid regions like northern Mexico, water conservation measures help increase the availability of water (which would otherwise be lost) for the growth of the biomass, contributing to the regeneration. The livelihoods of the communities utilizing these ranches are improved directly through the carbon credit payments, which provide an additional source of income, and indirectly through the increased productivity of their lands. The regenerated lands also become much less likely to undergo land use change, because the ranchers are better able to sustain their livelihoods. This in turn ensures that crucial habitats for the flora and fauna of the region are protected.

title: Boomitra Carbon Farming South of the Vindhyas
description:
This project works with the farmers of southern and central India to help them adopt improved agricultural practices such as residue management and enhanced cropping practices that sequester carbon while increasing productivity. This region is largely composed of small and marginal farmers, with each farming just a few hectares of land. As a result, these farmers are highly susceptible to variabilities arising from markets and weather. 
Over the last century, agriculture in the region has undergone a dramatic shift towards intensification. Since the late 1940s, yields of all staple crops have seen a several-fold increase. This increase was necessary to feed a growing population, but at the same time, it led to an increase of 150kg/ha in the amount of synthetic fertilizer applied to farms, along with similar increases in other crop inputs. An intensive agricultural process focused on maximizing yields every year has led to a gradual degradation of the soils of the region, resulting in CO2 emissions from the lost soil carbon. 
In this context, improved agricultural practices provide the opportunity and the power to reverse this land degradation and return carbon to the soil, creating carbon removals while improving overall soil health. In this project, farmers adopt a variety of improved agriculture practices. These practices are proven ways to increase soil organic carbon, and also enable farmers to improve their productivity: increases in soil organic carbon improve the ability of soils to store moisture and nutrients, and thus also help to increase yields. This project works towards helping farmers to surmount their barriers, while working with partners to create feasible and sustainable solutions that effect grass-roots behavior change. Furthermore, the financial benefits from carbon credits will provide a direct boost to the livelihoods of these farmers, many of whom are small and marginal farmers.

title: Guizhou Jinyan CMM Power Generation Project
description:
Guizhou Jinyan CMM Power Generation Project (hereinafter referred to as the Project) is located in Fengshan township, Dafang County, Bijie City, Guizhou Province, China. The purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted CMM with low concentration methane concentration to produce electricity. No coal bed methane (CBM) or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. 
Ten sets of CMM power generators will be installed with a total installed capacity of 4.8MW (8*0.6MW), destroying 8.7936 million m3 of methane annually. After the full operation of the Project, the expected annual exported electricity will be 24,816 MWh, which will be supplied to the coal mine first through the electricity distribution network in Jinyan coal mine area, and then to China Southern Power Grid (CSPG) if there is any electricity surplus, replacing the electricity that would otherwise have been purchased from the CSPG and displace part of the electricity generated by CSPG dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants.
The emissions reduction of the Project comes from two sources: 1) Methane (CH4) emissions as a result of the previously vented gas that will be captured and destroyed in the project scenario; 2) CO2 emissions from the production of the equivalent amount of electricity replaced by the Project that would otherwise have been purchased from the CSPG.
VCS Proponent:
Guizhou Jinyan Energy Technology Co., Ltd.
Guizhou Province, China

title: Forest Conservation in Boumba-et-Ngoko
description:
The project is located in one of the densest and most important forest areas in Cameroon, in the southern part of the eastern region, near the border with Congo and the Central African Republic. It is a state-owned forest granted in concession for the exploitation of wood resources, and like all neighboring areas, is of great economic interest due to the presence of high-value timber species. Since 2002, this forest unit has been managed by the company La Filière Bois (LFB), which harvests volumes of commercial timber from it, following the terms of the management plan that was drawn up at the start of management.
The VCS Improved Forest Management (IMF) - Logged to Protected Forest (LtPF) project aims to preserve a part of the forest from the exploitation of forest resources, which would anyway be used in the following years as foreseen in the documents approved by the Ministère des Forêts et de la Faune (MINFOF) - Ministry of Forests and Wildlife. The area that will be exempted from the work is approximately 44’413 ha for an estimated volume of 38 m3 /ha of forest not been harvested.
From the implementation of the Project, it is estimated that a net average of 325’885 tonnes of GHG emissions will be avoided from entering the atmosphere annually. Over the entire Project Crediting Period, it is estimated that a net total of 6’517’703 tonnes of GHG emissions will be avoided through the implementation of the Project.

CarbonSinkGroup S.R.L.
La Spezia (SP), Italy

title: Wude Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation
description:
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation is conducted in Wuxing District and Deqing County under the jurisdiction of Huzhou City, Zhejiang Province of China, which have a total acreage of 12,019 ha for single-cropping rice. Without this project providing ditches to conduct intermittent flooded method, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission removal than the continuously flooded.
With the project implementation, the cement ditches, reservoirs and relevant technical training are provided for these farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional continuously flooded method. During rice cultivation, controllable irrigation and drainage according to rice growth requirements can not only save water resources, but also reduce methane emission from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (in the flooded state). In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48%1. Hence, this project activity is estimated to reduce 4.97 tCO2e/ha.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 418,257 tCO2e in the first seven-year period with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 59,751tCO2e.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.

title: BONOS LAGUNA SÍJIL NOH-HÁ
description:
The Ejido Felipe Carrillo Puerto (from now on “the Ejido”) is in the state of Quintana Roo’s central region, in southwestern Mexico. Declared a Forest Ejido in 1947 (U'yo'olché A.C., 2005). It is currently inhabited by 288 Ejido landowners and their families. The population of the site is mostly comprised of peninsular Mayans. Since its origins, the jungle has been exploited for the extraction of chewing gum found in the chicozapote tree (Manilkara zapota). 

The principal aim of this Project is the removal of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions through activities that allow the identification, prioritisation, and execution of actions for the adequate management of dry tropical forest, the advancement of sustainable development, the establishment of local governance and the promotion of improved forest management activities.

The Project began in February 2018 and has an expected duration of 30 years; during this period, the removal of 6,459,222 CO2e is expected, this implies an average annual removal of 215,307 tCO2e.
This project will provide community benefits related to the strengthening of local governance and positive externalities to the management of forests. Meanwhile, maintaining sustainable community management practices for tropical forests, with a greater perception of the value of ecosystem services, as well as increasing employment opportunities. 

Finally, is also expected to use the CCB Program in conjunction with VCS to empower local communities and help protect endangered species.
VCS Proponent:
Ban.CO2 de Carbono Mestizo
Ciudad de México, Mexico

title: North Bandai Bamboo Reforestation Project
description:
The North Bandai Bamboo Reforestation Project is a reforestation project that is restoring 2,863 hectares of degraded forest lands within the Ashanti Region of Ghana, West Africa. It is a carbon financed project that integrates the reforestation of 1 million seedlings of sympodial bamboo with remnant standing trees, and areas set aside for biodiversity and conservation. The project area has suffered extreme historical deforestation and represents highly degraded lands that are prone to further loss of remaining tree cover in the absence of the reforestation activity. 

The project is managed alongside the adjacent Bandai Hills Bamboo Reforestation Project to represent a combined 10,681 hectare unique approach to forest landscape restoration.

title: Grassland Restoration and Stewardship in South Africa (GRASS)
description: The Grassland Restoration and Stewardship in South Africa (GRASS) grouped project is designed to unlock, upscale and incentivize the adoption of improved agricultural land management and ecosystem restoration in the grassy biomes of South Africa. The Herding for Health (H4H) model is to be employed under this project. The model includes farmer and herder empowerment through smallholder livestock value chain development to build resilience to climate change. Furthermore, the model supports rangeland restoration and greenhouse gas (GHG) sinks while reducing GHG emissions by sequestering carbon into the soil and reducing methane emissions from livestock enteric fermentation.

title: Boomitra Carbon Farming in the Indo-Gangetic Plains
description:
This project intends to help farmers adopt new improved agriculture practices in the Indo-Gangetic Plains of the Indian subcontinent. Improved agriculture practices include crop residue management, natural farming, crop rotations and more, which enable cropland soils to improve their carbon sequestration capabilities. The region contains large numbers of small and marginal farmers who are highly susceptible to reductions in yields arising from climate change, and there is a strong need for programs and interventions to help them adapt.
In this context, improved agricultural practices provide the opportunity and the power to reverse land degradation and return carbon to the soil, creating carbon removals while improving overall soil health. In this project, farmers adopt a variety of improved agriculture practices. These practices are proven ways to increase soil organic carbon, and enable farmers to improve their productivity: increases in soil organic carbon improve the ability of soils to store moisture and nutrients, and thus also help to increase yields. Boomitra’s research has shown that farmers face various barriers in the adoption of these practices, and this project works towards helping farmers to surmount these barriers, while working with partners to create feasible and sustainable solutions that promote behavioral change at the grassroots level. The financial benefits from carbon credits will provide a direct boost to the livelihoods of these farmers, many of whom are small and marginal farmers.

title: Hunan Cili IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project
description:
The Hunan Cili IFM (conversion of logged to protected  forest) Project (hereafter “the project activity”) is implemented in Cili County, Zhangjiajie City, Hunan Province of China by Hunan Cili Jiangya Forest Farm, the geo-coordinate of the  project proponent is 110°27'E -111°20'E and 29°04'N - 29°41'N, the total area is 3480 km2, which includes the Improved Forest Management (IFM) of the forests in the conversion of logged to protected forest. The project avoids emissions by converting logged forests into protected forests.
The area of the project activity is 6993.48 ha, including 1,764 subcompartments. All these forests are state-owned forests or privately-owned forests or collective-owned forests, and have the legal right to forest ownership. All the owners authorized the project proponent to access the project to their behalf. The species involved in the project are Broad-leaved tree Chinese fir and Pinus massoniana. The forest of the project was older plantations or natural forest under managing. Before the implantation of the project, the usual type of management was clearcutting.
Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged based on a valid and verifiable government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 896,881 tCO2e in 20 years, the average annual emission reduction is 44,844 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 690,585 tCO2e in 20 years, and average annual VCUs with buffer deduction is 34,529 tCO2e.
The project activity will contribute to the environment (biodiversity conservation, rocky desertification prevention and soil erosion control), thus contribute to sustainable development.
VCS Proponent:
Hunan Cili Jiangya Forest Farm
Hunan Province, China

title: Hubei Yunyang IFM (CONVERSION OF LOGGED TO PROTECTED FOREST) PROJECT
description:
The Hubei Yunyang IFM (conversion of logged to protected  forest) Project (hereafter “the project activity”) is implemented in Yunyang District, Shiyan City, Hubei Province of China by Shiyan Lvxin Guangjing New Energy Co., Ltd., the geo-coordinate of the project proponent is 110°07′22′′E -110°16′E and 32°16′N - 33°15′37′′N, the total area is 3836 km2, which includes the Improved Forest Management (IFM) of the forests in the conversion of logged to protected forest. The project avoids emissions by converting logged forests into protected forests. Protect forests for continuous carbon sequestration. During the implementation of the project, the PP and the local forestry bureau would continue to conduct a questionnaire survey among stakeholders to understand their opinions. Since the project is running normally local stakeholders have no opinion. The local forestry bureau also conducts regular training on ecological forest conservation for stakeholders to ensure better implementation of the project.
The area of the project activity is 6300.32 ha, including 869 subcompartments spreading over Baoxia Town, Chadian Town, Liubei Town, Qingqu Town, Qingshan Town, Tanjiawan Town, Yangxipu Town Chengguan Town, Hujiaying Town, Baisangguan Town, Wufeng Township, Yeda Township of Hubei Yunyang. All these forests are state-owned forests or privately-owned or collective-owned, and have the legal right to forest ownership. The species involved in the project are Pinus massoniana.
Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged based on a valid and verifiable government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 593,532 tCO2e in 20 years, the average annual emission reduction is 29,676 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 457,013 tCO2e in 20 years, and average annual VCUs with buffer deduction
VCS Proponent:
Shiyan Lvxin Guangjing New Energy Co., Ltd.
Hubei Province, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Atlantic Forest Biodiversity Conservation Limeira Project REDD
description:
The Limeira Atlantic Forest Biodiversity Conservation Project is located in the state of Paraná, south of Brazil. Its area is located within the Atlantic Forest Biome, home of a great diversity of fauna and flora, including several endemic and endangered species, including the terrestrial tapir (Tapirus terrestrial), the largest terrestrial mammal, described as (endangered, IUNC, 2011) in the Atlantic Forest due to habitat loss ( (Medici et.al., 2011). The preserved forest is an important generator of ecosystems services such as water supply, climate regulation, tourism, energy, unique maintenance , beyond the environment with unique natural beauty. This hot spot on earth suffers a great risk of being converted to non-ecological uses, as 70% of the Brazilian GDP  is concentrated in it, only 12.4% of the original forest is left in Brazil, demonstrating that they cause a huge impact on this forest, which is limited by human development and agricultural.
The project area is the home to more than 50 headwaters, which flow into the São João River, an important water resource in the region. It is part of the only region of the state of Paraná with preserved native vegetation, being an important ecological corridor for the passage of fauna between two large National Parks. Areas such as the project are subject to intense risk every day, mainly due to degradation, which happens little by little, but causes a huge impact on this biome so fragile by human development.
This project extends itself through the territory of the municipalities of Guaratuba and Morretes, inside the rural area where the economy is based on agriculture and extractivism, being bananas and peach palm the main crops. The production and trade of these products is driven by the close Limeira state highways and by the Limeira street which passes through the project’s area from North to South, so it is considered th margins of this road, areas susceptible to deforestation.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Liaoning Xinwang Swine Farm Manure Management System GHG Mitigation Project
description:
Liaoning Xinwang Swine Farm Animal Manure Management System GHG Mitigation Project (hereinafter referred to as the Project)  introduce animal waste management system (AWMS) to a group of 10 swine farms in Kangping County, Shenyang City, Liaoning Province, China, which are owned by Kangping Xinwang agriculture and animal husbandry Co., Ltd (hereinafter called” Xinwang”). The purpose of the project activity is to treat the manure and wastewater from the 10 swine farms to avoid methane emissions generated in the baseline uncovered anaerobic lagoons.

In this project, AWMS is built to replace the traditional open anaerobic lagoons, and each subsidiary swine farm installed one AWMS. The manure and waster will be collected into the anaerobic digesters and then biogas generated during the anaerobic treatment process will be captured and total 2500*104m3 biogas are expected to be generated annually. Biogas is then sent into biogas boilers for heat production. Every biogas boiler has been installed in each swine farms. All of the heat generated are used by AWMSs and the swine farms, while the rest (if any) will be burned. The sludge produced after fermentation is applied to corn fields as fertilizer, and the wastewater produced by anaerobic biogas digesters is used for agricultural irrigation.
Benefited from the “waste-biogas-fertilizer” pattern, harmlessness and ecological utilization of the swine manure can be realized. All the heat generated by the project will be used by the AWMSs and 10 swine farms. 
The project activity will reduce of GHG in the atmosphere through avoiding methane emissions from anaerobic treatment of swine manure and wastewater. The project is expected to achieve an annual emission reduction of 201,850 tCO2e and a total emission reduction of 1,412,950 tCO2e in the first crediting period.
VCS Proponent:
Kangping Xinwang agriculture and animal husbandry Co., Ltd.
Liaoning Province, China
CCB Proponent:
Kangping Xinwang agriculture and animal husbandry Co., Ltd.
Liaoning Province, China

title: Not Hot Afforestation project
description:
The Not Hot Afforestation project  is designed to afforest non-used agricultural land (meadow)
with birch (Betula pendula) species native to the area. Part of the agricultural lands are not
managed (they do not use food product production). All this time, unmanaged land has brought
virtually no benefit to landowners or to the national economy. There are still about 300 kha of
non-forested agricultural land in Latvia, which meets the criteria of low-valued areas accessible
for afforestation. About 130 thousand ha of agricultural areas have organic soils. The potential for
reducing GHG emissions in such areas are particularly high. 1
This project is a grouped project, located in Latvia.
The Not Hot Afforestation Project will generate GHG removals through sequestration living
biomass and soil organic carbon. These credits are generated using CGM methodology AR-
ACM0003: Afforestation and reforestation of lands except wetlands (version 2).
Implemented activities in the project will remove an amount of 2,203 tons CO₂ in mineral soils
and 55 tons CO₂ in organic soils within 40 years. This means an average of 55 tons CO₂ yr⁻¹ in
mineral soils and 5.87 tons CO₂ yr⁻¹ in organic soils per year. A total area of 5.06 ha activities will
remove 2,438 tCO₂ within 40 years, which means an average of 60.9 tons CO₂ yr⁻¹.
Project will result in a significant contribution to sustainable development of Latvia, mainly
through: i) increased employment and quality of employment; ii) rural development
(decentralization); iii) increased gross value of production; iv) biodiversity preservation and v)
improvement and preservation of soil quality.
VCS Proponent:
Not Hot Environmental Solutions
Ropazu nov., Latvia
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Lanao del Sur Bamboo Reforestation Project
description: The Lanao del Sur Bamboo Reforestation Project is a carbon financed landscape scale restoration project in the province of Lanao del Sur, on the island of Mindanao, Philippines. The project area covers 8,421 hectares of degraded montane landscapes. Project activities target the planting of 2.5 million clumps of native species of sympodial bamboo over a 3-4 year period. Bamboo reforestation activities are combined with the additional planting of 1 million trees of native species on areas not eligible for carbon accreditation, creating a biodiverse and holistic landscape. The project area has been chosen due to its importance as a watershed for neighboring provinces which rely on it for food production, while representing an area that has historically received little development.

title: Niger Acacia Senegal Plantation Project - CER Conversion
description:
The authorized representative of the project, EcoAct, is requesting a conversion of 44,056 CERs to VCUs.  More information on the project can be found at CDM PoA Project ID 9708: https://cdm.unfccc.int/Projects/DB/ErnstYoung1375258307.15. The relevant project documents and proof of cancellation are attached above. 

This first Nigerien ARR project activity (Niger Acacia Senegal Plantation Project, NASPP hereafter), aims to restore deforested and highly degraded land in the Sudano-Sahelian zone of the Republic of Niger by empowering rural communities to adopt sustainable agro-forestry practices by establishing plantations using native species Acacia senegalensis (Acacia Senegal). This project represents the first effort in Niger to establish Acacia Senegal plantations on a large scale in regions where dry forests are unable to regenerate by natural means. The sale of emission reduction credits from the carbon sequestered in plantations will make the project more viable by providing an additional revenue stream that will supplement income from the sale of gum arabic from the acacia trees.
VCS Proponent: Converted from other GHG program
VCS Project Status: Units Transferred from Approved GHG Program
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: OKA 2 PROJECT
description:
This savannah Land Afforestation Project on the Batéké Plateau north of Brazzaville aims to develop an alternative and renewable source of charcoal for urban use, based on the establishment of Acacia auriculiformis plantations. Furthermore, Acacia rows will be intercropped with lines of food crops (Cassava in particular), forming agroforestry plantations. 
We also know that another effective tool to combat global warming are 'carbon sink' plantations, i.e. plantations where trees are not harvested, in order to maximize greenhouse gas sequestration in the long term. Half of the project's area will therefore be dedicated to Acacia mangium plantations with the main objective of CO2 sequestration.
These plantations will be set up in anthropogenic savannahs, i.e. land with a biomass stock blocked at a very low stage due to recurrent bushfires. The savannahs are deliberately set to fire at frequent intervals (at least once a year) by villagers to facilitate agricultural, pastoral and cynegetic activities.
As a result, the Project will have several social and environmental benefits such as (1) CO2 sequestration on land that is currently non-forested and unused, (2) Less pressure on the surrounding natural forests, thanks to the production of charcoal from sustainably managed plantations, (3) Job creation in a territory heavily affected by unemployment, increased incomes. As such, the project acts as a driving force of local development and fights against rural exodus or (4) Increased farming production and productivity, contributing to the economic development of local communities.

title: Aztlan Blue Carbon Mangrove CONSERVATION project - Conserving the Marismas NACIONALES of Nayarit
description:
In Mexico, the mangrove areas in Nayarit state are significantly impacted by deforestation. Among the major drivers of the forestation throughout the region, it is possible to identify land use changes altering the hydrology of the region, illegal logging, anthropogenic fires, and shrimp farming, among others.  According to a previous study made for the project proponent, the state of Nayarit had a deforestation rate of 1.03%/year for the period of 2005-2015.

The Project activity is a REDD+ grouped project that aims to address the unplanned deforestation of private and ejidos’ owned wetland areas in the state of Nayarit.  Until this PD version, the grouped project is comprised of 17 project activity instances, being that each one is a wetland area inside an ejido or privately owned land.  In the future, more project activity instances, in state-owned, private or ejidos’ lands, will be added to this grouped project.

Conservation activities include reestablishing canals, maintaining canal structures, soil rehabilitation, deforestation monitoring, cessation of illegal shrimp farming and monitoring of biodiversity.

The project proponent has been engaging with communities in ejidos and private lands since 2016 under a participatory and inclusive approach and will also include more properties as the project is developed.

BlueMX is also conducting strong outreach efforts, conducting capacity building meetings, providing supporting materials in order to empower communities to carry out the conservation activities under a participatory approach integrating cultural, social and gender equity safeguards and in strict respect and transparency to landownership and access to natural resources from the rightful owners of the land.
VCS Proponent:
BlueMX Mangrove A.C.
Yucatan, Mexico

title: U' Balam'moo A'kalché ó Blue Carbon Mangrove Conservation Project, Conserving Coastal Ecosystems in Campeche to Support Life
description:
In Mexico, the mangrove areas in state of Campeche are significantly impacted by deforestation.  Among the major drivers of the deforestation in the region, it is possible to identify land use changes altering the hydrology of the region, illegal logging, and anthropogenic fires.  According to a study made for the project proponent, the deforestation rate for Laguna de Términos and Petenes is 2.62%/year for the period of 2005-2016.

The Project activity is a REDD+ grouped project that intents to address the unplanned deforestation of wetlands in the state of Campeche. Currently, the grouped project is comprised of 32 project activity instances, 21 in Petenes and 11 in Laguna de Términos.

Until this PD version, the 32 project activity instances are wetland area located inside federally owned, private and ejido lands, across the state of Campeche.  In the future, more project activity instances will be added to this grouped project, being that they will potentially be either in federally/nationally-owned land, private land or in an ejido owned land.

Conservation activities include but are not limited to reestablishing canals, maintaining canal structures, soil rehabilitation, deforestation monitoring, and monitoring of birds and mammals.

The project proponent has been engaging with communities in ejidos and private lands since 2016 under a participatory and inclusive approach and will also include more properties as the project is developed.
