title: Jinyujie Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation
description:
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation is conducted in Jinyujie within Jiamusi City, Heilongjiang Province of China, with a total acreage of 20,027 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction than the continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results in not only large amount of methane (CH4) emissions but also low rice productivity by replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48%1 . Hence, with the proposed project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 2.92 tCO2e/ha for single-cropping rice is expected.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 409,794 tCO2e in the first 7 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 58,542tCO2e.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.
VCS Proponent:
Harbin Huanyu Agricultural Technology Co., Ltd.
Heilongjiang, China
CCB Proponent:
Harbin Huanyu Agricultural Technology Co., Ltd.
Heilongjiang, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Paracel ARR Carbon Forestry Project
description: The proposed VCS Grouped Project PARACEL ARR Carbon Forestry Project (hereafter the Grouped Project ), represents the first large-scale private sector reforestation project in Paraguay. It promotes and implements the reforestation of Eucalyptus plantations on degraded areas that were mostly used for extensive cattle ranching for the last 30 years. The project area also encompasses a significant number of native ecosystems in different stages of conservation that will be conserved and/or restored to the original standard. The Grouped Project will consist of various Project Instances, which are project activities that combine to make a Grouped project. The Project Instances will cover plantation areas and /or restoration areas. The plantation activities are subject to the highest international standards such as the Forest Stewardship Council ( FSC ) forest management certification and the IFC Performance Standards on Environmental and Social Sustainability.

title: HENAN SHANGCAI AGRICULTURAL LAND USE MANAGEMENT PROJECT
description:
The Soil Carbon Project aims at promoting Sustainable Agriculture practices that increase soil organic carbon. In the project the farmers will adopt practices that increase capacity of the soil to sequester increased carbon they will reduce the use of synthetic fertilisers, increase activities that improve soil productivity like increasing the use of organic fertilisers, incorporate residue management, and reduce tillage thereby reducing overall greenhouse gas emissions.
In the proposed project area farmers cultivate corn, peanuts, soybeans, and rice in a no-till manner in June each year and harvests them in October of the same year. Wheat is planted by the no-till method after peanut harvest. After the corn, soybean, and rice harvest, the land will be tilled with less tillage or traditional tillage, including deep ploughing and deep loosening (vertical rototilling). After crop harvest, straw and root stubble will be returned to the land to improve soil organic matter input and enhance soil fertility. In this process, organic fertilizers will replace part of the synthetic chemical fertilizer. At the same time, no-till activities will reduce the consumption of fossil fuels when farmland is tilled.
Through these activities, the project will rebuild the organic matter of the soil, improve its properties and reduce GHG emissions from the implementation of activities such as reducing the use of N fertilizers and fossil fuel. The practices will also restore soil fertility and sequester carbon from the atmosphere, mitigating climate change.
The main objective of this proposed project is to raise farmers awareness and prove to them that there is a way to practice farming methods that are sustainable and positively impact climate change. Such practices can also be profitable to the farmers. The farmers will be assisted with technical advice on how to implement these activities, which will transition throughout the years into a sustainable farm system.

title: Wheatbelt Biodiversity Carbon Credit Project
description: The Wheatbelt Biodiversity Carbon Credit Project (WBCC) (hereafter referred to as “the Project”) is a carbon sequestration project developed by Decarbonology Pty Ltd. The initial project area is 159.3ha and consists of over 320,000 plantings, with plantings taking place on cleared and degraded former pastoral farmland. This Project focusses on ecosystem restoration of the project site and the Wheatbelt of WA more broadly. It aims to support existing primary forest patches via afforestation of matrix areas between fragments to increase native habitat area, connectivity and ecosystem functions. Plantings will consist of a mix of over 20 native species local to the region.

title: Bajo Atrato REDD+ Project
description:
The purpose of the REDD+ Bajo Atrato project is to reduce GHG emissions from deforestation and forest degradation activities, envisioning that the efforts of the communities inhabiting and owning the territories where it is located are materialized in actions that lead to forest conservation and the improvement of living conditions. The project is located in the northwest of Colombia, in the Department of Chocó, between the municipalities of Riosucio and Carmen del Darién, in the lower basin of the Atrato River, which is part of the Darién area. In the area of the project’s first instance, the following Afro-descendant communal lands are grouped: the Quiparadó River Basin Community Council, the Curbaradó River Community Council, the Salaquí River Basin Community Council, the Cacarica River Basin Community Council, the Truandó Medio La Teresita Community Council, the Bocas de Taparal Community Council, the Dos Bocas Chintado Community Council, the La Nueva Truandó Community Council, and the Clavellino Community Council.
The actions that will make possible to reduce deforestation and forest degradation in the project area are aligned with the needs and purposes  identified during the first meetings with the communities and while conducting the prior, free and informed consent process. These actions are aimed at achieving four major purposes: strengthening of governance and community management; improvement of community welfare; provision of social and community infrastructure; and boost of sustainable livelihoods and environmental protection, basic sanitation and aqueducts. The lands in the project area include tropical pluvial forests with transition to cold and very humid tropical forests. There, forests, grasslands, secondary vegetation, swampy areas and agroecosystems are found. In these areas, deforestation is associated with wood extraction, agricultural frontier expansion, illicit crop cultivation, and unplanned infrastructure construction.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Indigo Ag EU Project No.1
description: This Project is intended to promote a range of agricultural management practice changes targeted at increasing soil organic carbon (SOC) storage and reducing net emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from farms across North-Western Europe. Indigo Ag helps farmers to implement climate-smart practices through an integrated system of extension and outreach, modeling, agronomy support, and digital data collection tools. Beyond climate benefits, the Project will increase farm resilience to weather and climate change, promote diversity of the soil microbiome, and increase rural incomes.

title: CAGLAYANLAR BIOGAS PLANT
description:
Caglayanlar Biogas Plant project is a biogas to-energy project that will generate renewable energy by capturing biogas from animal manure -via anaerobic digestion- and utilizing it to produce thermal and electric energy through biogas systems. The project is being implemented by ÇAĞLAYANLAR BİYOGAZ ELEKTRİK ÜRETİM SANAYİ VE TİCARET LİMİTED ŞİRKETİ, as the Project Owner, in Mucur district, Kırsehir province, in Turkey.
Project activity has three biogas engines installed at the biogas power plant, with 4.503 MWe/e. The manure produced by 625 dairy cattle and 76,200 non-dairy cattle located on neighboring farms is collected and fed into the anaerobic digesters at the project site.
The project began to generate electricity on October 16th, 2020According to Electricity Generation License, The biogas generator system has the maximum operational capacity 9.006 MWe/h. The annual feed-in electricity is estimated to be 67,545,000 kWh. While heat generated at the plant is used at the facility to warm the digesters, the electricity generated is directly fed to the national grid.
VCS Proponent:
Çağlayanlar Biyogaz Elektrik Üretim Sanayi ve Ticaret Limited Şirketi
Kırşehir, Turkey

title: ASATIQ Vaupés Maloca REDD+ Project
description:
The ASATIQ Vaupés Maloca REDD+ Project is located within the area of the Association of Traditional Indigenous Authorities of Querarí (ASATIQ), which is part of the Great Eastern Indigenous Reservation of Vaupés in jurisdiction of the municipality of Mitú, in the department of Vaupés, Colombia. ASATIQ’s territory is located in the Colombian Amazon biome. The objective of the ASATIQ Vaupés Maloca REDD+ Project is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions coming mainly from deforestation and degradation of the Amazon Forest.
Potential activities to reduce deforestation include forest protection and monitoring, the intensification and improvement of agricultural productivity in local communities, planting of fruit and timber trees (including those used for firewood), planting of other species used as construction materials, the creation of jobs as an alternative source of income (for example, in forest monitoring) and the improvement of health and education conditions of the communities in order to offer non-extractive work options.
At the same time, actions in the medium and long terms have been defined to support the territory’s self-governance principles, as well as to promote the development of local traditional practices and ancestral education. The proposals made are framed aligned with the general action lines of the ASATIQ Life Plan.
On the other hand, between 40% and 60% of recent IDEAM deforestation early warning bulletins come from the Amazon, and the department of Vaupés appears in the first five ranks of alert. Under these circumstances, the without-project scenario presents an unplanned use of forest resources with extractive logging activities and the expansion of the agricultural frontier through subsistence crops and itinerant mining, which are being developed progressively putting at risk the ecosystem balance of the forests and the cultural traditions of the communities.
The duration of the project is proposed from January 1, 2018 to December 31, 2047.
VCS Proponent:
Association of Traditional Indigenous Authorities of Querarí (ASATIQ)
Vaupés, Colombia
CCB Proponent:
Association of Traditional Indigenous Authorities of Querarí (ASATIQ)
Vaupés, Colombia
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: ASATRIZY Vaupés Maloca REDD+ Project
description:
The ASATRIZY Vaupés Maloca REDD+ Project proposed to be implemented in the Great Eastern Reservation of Vaupés is in the Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD+) category. Development of the REDD+ project is based on the VM0009 Methodology, v3 of the VCS. This methodology is applicable to this project and is being used for other REDD+ projects in the region. It has also been used by Wildlife Works, having two types of areas of application.  The first, corresponding to the Project Area (PA) and the second to the Project Accounting Area (PAA). The PAA is the area with forest cover, where the project would implement activities to prevent deforestation and whose results would be used to calculate carbon credits.
According to the territory conditions, this is a standalone project that respects ASATRIZY’s autonomy. In the without-project scenario, the forest ecosystems in the department of Vaupés and in particular those in the territory of ASATRIZY are located in life zones of tropical humid forest. This area has been recognized as one of the most biodiverse in the country and the whole continent, being characterized by its endemic species.
The forest monitoring carried out by the Colombian Government and coordinated by IDEAM has shown a national annual deforestation average between 177,764 ha and 219,552 ha for the 2016-2017 period, with the Amazon biome representing 70% of the total deforestation. In addition, between 40% and 60% of recent IDEAM deforestation early warning bulletins come from the Amazon, and the department of Vaupés appears in the first five ranks of alert.
According to this scenario and based on data obtained from the Amazonian Scientific Research Institute (SINCHI) and through field visits carried out by WWC, it was possible to identify the unplanned use of forestry resources as the main driver of deforestation in the project area, consisting of “slash-and-burn” activities in the jungle to expand the chagras.
VCS Proponent:
Association of Traditional Indigenous Authorities of the Yapú Zone (ASATRIZY)
Vaupés, Colombia

Vaupés, Colombia

title: Origen Atrato-Baudó REDD+ Project
description: The Atrato-Baudó REDD+ Project aims to reduce GHG emissions from deforestation of natural forest. It is expected to achieve this through implementation of community actions framed in conservation, protection and sustainable management of the forest, which lead to improvements in living conditions in the territories. The area of the project’s first instance is located in the Tumbes-Chocó-Magdalena bioregion, in the municipalities of Alto Baudó, Quibdó, Lloró, Bagadó, Tadó, Río Iró (Santa Rita) and Cértegui, in the department of Chocó. The project is designed as a grouped project, initially made up of the collective territories of the following Afro-descendant communities: Community Council of San Isidro, Community Council of Villa Conto and Major Community Council of the Alto Atrato Popular Peasant Organization (COCOMOPOCA).  The project activities are aligned with the community needs and purposes identified during the process of relationship and free and informed prior consent developed with the communities. These actions are aimed at achieving four major purposes, which are: Governance and community management; social and community infrastructure; sustainable livelihoods and environmental protection, basic sanitation and aqueducts. Currently, the forests in the project area include areas of very humid tropical forest with transition to Tropical Rainforest. These ecosystem characteristics potentiate the habitat conditions of both flora and fauna, being cataloged as one of the most biodiverse areas of the country and the continent, characterized by endemism.  Deforestation that occurs in the project area are the result of a combination of complex socioeconomic and historical factors, associated with extractive processes that have directly affected biodiversity and ecosystem services. The project, as an alternative to conversion, aims to maintain carbon stocks through sustainable forest management, promoting improvements in the living conditions of local communities.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: Mbakaou Carriere Small Hydro Power Plant
description:
The purpose of the project activity is to install and operate a run-of–river, greenfield 1.49 MW hydroelectric plant at Mbakaou Carrière and electrify neighbouring communities through an isolated mini-grid. At least 75% of the clients in these communities will be households. 
The project developer and operator is IED Invest Cameroun, which aims is to develop and operate a small scale hydro power project at Mbakaou. 
By providing electricity to rural communities located around Mbakaou through a network of off-grid mini-grids, IED invest Cameroun aims to bring clean energy to the communities and thereby reduce greenhouse gases (GHGs). 
The operating mode of the particular case of the Mbakaou Quarry site can be assimilated to a low waterfall type installation with water available all year round, thanks to water regulation by Djerem dam. The turbines will harness the kinetic energy of the water and convey the energy to a generator and transformer.
VCS Proponent:
IED Invest Cameroun
Cameroon

title: CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION OF THE MANGROVE ECOSYSTEM IN THE GAMBIA THROUGH THE REDD+ MECHANISM
description: The project is a grouped project that aims to generate greenhouse gas emission removals and reductions through mangrove reforestation and avoided degradation, including wetland restoration and conservation activities. The project area covers the entire mangrove landscape (both intact and degraded areas) of The Gambia, covering more than 100,000 ha, and project activities will be included gradually on the basis of appropriateness for rehabilitation and avoided degradation of mangrove, community involvement and financial resources available. The project area covers all mangrove regions of The Gambia. The regions are: - West Coast Region (WCR) - Lower River Region (LRR) - Greater Banjul Area (GBA) - North Bank Region (NBR) - Central River Region (CRR). In 2022, 240 hectares of mangrove was planted. In 2023, it is the ambition to plant 4000 hectares.
State/Province: WCR, LRR, GBA, NBR and CRR
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Padang Tikar Landscape
description:
The Padang Tikar Landscape project is located in the Padang Tikar Landscape of the Batu Ampar subdistrict, Kubu Raya district, West Kalimantan province, Indonesia. The project consists of 10 'Village Forests', covering 76,370 hectares (ha), 58,672.7 ha of which is eligible for the reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation (REDD) project. The Village Forest of Padang Tikar is the largest 'Village Forest' permit in Indonesia and is divided
into three types of forest: protected forest (69,299 ha), limited production forest (1,985 ha), and convertible production forest (5,086 ha). The Padang Tikar Landscape project is a microcosm of the country as it has comprehensive forest ecosystems, ranging from inland forests to swamp forests (including mangrove forests and peatlands).
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: BINDONG ADJUSTED WATER MANAGEMENT IN RICE CULTIVATION
description:
The project aims to reduce a large amount of greenhouse gases (GHG) by changing the water regime from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation. The project is conducted in Suibin County, Hegang City, Heilongjiang Province of China, and involves a total acreage of 19,365ha for single-cropping rice. 
Currently, the farmers in the project area are using the continuously flooded method during the rice cultivation. Without the implementation of this project, which provides ditches and technical support to conduct intermittently flooded method, the continuously flooded method would be continued, which is also the baseline scenario. Within the project boundary, every farmer’s household owning the paddy fields is regarded as an isolate unit. With the project implementation, the cement ditches, reservoirs and relevant technical training are provided for these farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional continuously flooded method.  As the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, after the implementation of the project, the period of flooded condition will be shortened, which will have negative impact on the methane production. It means that controllable irrigation and drainage according to rice growth requirements during rice cultivation, can not only save water resources, but also reduce methane emission from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (in the flooded state). In this case, CH4 emission during the cultivation can be declined significantly. Hence, with the proposed project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 2.66~2.98  tCO2e/ha for single-cropping rice is expected.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 559,218   tCO2e in the 10-years crediting period, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 55,922 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Oasis Science &Technology Development( Beijing) Co., Ltd
Chaoyang, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in North Kaiping City
description: The project is in north of Kaiping City, Jiangmen City, Guangdong Province, which is located in southern China, including 6 towns, namely Dasha Town, Longsheng Town, Cangcheng Town, Magang Town, Shatang Town, Yueshan Town. The main goal of this project is changing the irrigation method from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded during rice cultivation. In 2019, the average annual income of each local household was only 20,703 RMB CNY and rice cultivation is the main way for local farmers to survive. In this case, they lack of financial support to build ditches for implementing intermittently flooded method. Therefore, traditional continuously flooded method still used for rice cultivation, which means there is constant pond water maintained in the field until the harvest drainage. The organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane because of anaerobic decomposition.  In contrast, rice paddies intermittently submerged and dried so that the upper soil layers switch from anaerobic to aerobic conditions several times during the crop growing season in Intermittently flooded method. Moreover, the intermittently flooded method brings many benefits, such as the higher rice yield production, the higher methane removal rate and etc. The project aims to achieve GHG mitigation goal （sustainable development goals）in project zone by utilizing intermittent flooded irrigation method. There is totally 7,359.19ha of rice paddies are switched from continuously flooded method to implementing intermittently flooded irrigation method in this project.

title: Core Carbon Sustainable Rice Productions
description:
Paddy fields are the most dominant anthropogenic sources of methane to the atmosphere (5-20% of the total emission from all anthropogenic sources ). Anaerobic decomposition of organic material in flooded rice fields produces methane, which escapes to the atmosphere primarily by transport through the rice plants. The annual amount of CH4 emitted from a given area of rice is a function of the number and duration of crops grown, water regimes before and during the cultivation period, and organic and inorganic soil amendments. Soil type, temperature, and rice cultivar also affect CH4 emissions. This CH4 emission-intensive cultivation method will be targeted by the proposed programme, that will involve the implementation of the technology/measures that result in reduced anaerobic decomposition of organic matter in rice cropping soils and thus reduced generation of methane.
The project activity comprises of grouped projects of rice fields implementing the following methods:
 (a) Rice farms that change the water regime during the cultivation period from continuously to intermittent flooded conditions and/or a shortened period of flooded conditions;
(b) Alternate wetting and drying method (AWD)
(c) Rice farms that change their rice cultivation practice from transplanted to direct-seeded rice (DSR).
Thus, the measure will consist of AWD and/or DSR in combination with adjusted water management system in rice cultivation.

title: Guangdong Huidong Afforestation Project
description:
Guangdong Huidong Afforestation Project  is located in Huidong County, Huizhou City, Guangdong Province, in the southeast of Guangdong Province and the east of Huizhou City. The project’s aim is to increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by planting trees on suitable lands  for forestation, and there has never been any activity affecting the local ecosystem. 
An area of 7,950.86  ha, which belongs to the villagers and the village committees manage the lands on behalf of villagers, have been planted on more than 600 parcels of lands since 2015. All the trees planted in the project zone are native species, including Schima superba, Castanopsis fissa, Elaeocarpus sylvestris, Liquidamba formosana, Camphor tree, Cinnamoummum bumannii, Michelia macclurei, Acacia rachii, Castanopsis hystrix, Casuarina equisetifolia Forst., Pinus elliotti, China fir. No invasive alien species or genetically modified organisms are involved.
The implementation of the project would generate GHG emission removals and improve local environment by planting trees, enhance biodiversity conservation and climate change adaptation, improve soil and water conservation in project zone, strengthening the live skills of local communities and residents by providing their relevant technical skills, training and create more permanent job opportunities for local women and increase income for local communities.

title: AGRISOLERO CARBON FARMING IN NORTHERN ITALY
description:
Agrisolero farm is located in Solero e Quargnento, Alessandria in Northern Italy. The coordinates are attached as a KML file.  Several agricultural practices will be implemented or modified on the land. Taken together, the goal is to reduce the carbon emissions currently emitted by this farm and raise the carbon stored in the soil. In addition, the selected measures will contribute to improving crop yields and soil health. 

To do so, the following methods will be applied on site; reduced amount of inorganic fertilizers,an improved fertilizer application, reduced tillage, application of organic digested fertilizer, improved water management, the use of cover crops and a reduced use of fuel.

The sectoral scope 14 – Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU) is applicable to the project. Within this sector, this project has been developed under the scope of the methodology for improved agricultural land management (VM0042 VCS methodology).

The project has been found eligible under the scope of the VCS program as it meets all requirements established by the program. 

The crediting period chosen for this project is of 33 years, renewable 3 times. The period lasts from the 1/6/2022 to the 1/6/2055. We estimated that 55tCO2/year will be stored in the soil or not emitted.

title: Core Carbon Sustainable Rice Productions 01
description:
Rice cultivation is the most important agricultural operation in Telangana State, not only in terms of food security but also in terms of livelihood and plays a major part in the economy and employment. The agriculture sector is backbone of the rural economy in Telangana. In Telangana State Paddy cultivated is 52,51,261 acres in Vanakalam and 51,71,916 acres in Yasangi and total cultaivated area for the year 2020-21 is 10.423 Million acres . The total production of rice in Telangana was 145.68 lakh tonnes in 2020-21. The district of Suryapet is one of the major producers district of rice.  
The aim of this project activity is reducing the CH4 emissions by switching traditional rice cultivation to AWD technique. 
The project activity comprises of grouped projects of rice fields implementing various water management practices located at different areas within the geographical area of India.
The proposed project activity instances involve the implementation of the various water management practices to mitigate methane emission from rice fields in regions in Suryapet District  in Telangana state, India.

title: ARAKU VALLEY REFORESTATION PROJECT
description: The project is a VCS ARR Gro up project where various horticulture species and coffee shrubs are planted. Plantation activities are done in the first 6 years (20 17 2022) as part of the first project instance . In the first project instance Coffee shrubs have been planted along with shade trees like Silver oak on 6390.9 hectares. The total project area of first instance is 6824.7 hectares where several other tree species are also planted in the remaining area. The planting activities are done on abandoned croplands and barren lands in 13 Mandal's of Vishakhapatnam district in Andhra Pradesh state. By reforesting these areas , the project instance is expected to sequester 342277 tCO2 annually. Plantation activities are done on the barren land parcels owned by tribal communities living in these area. These land parcels are pre provided to them by state as individual Plattaland's. Community were able to do only subsistence farming in a small patch of their lands because of investment constraints. Rest of the land were abandoned leading to land degradation. PP identified these land areas and plantation activities have been done here with the consent of land owners.

title: Gveibingz Water Management with Rice Cultivation
description: The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation is conducted in Guiping City, Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, where is located in southwestern China with a total acreage of 12,588 ha for double-cropping rice. The project area contains the project fields of rice merely, and the data of total area is confirmed by the Agricultural Bureau of Guiping City. The project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by replacing continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, this method can reduce the flooded time of rice in the whole growth cycle and the methane (CH4) emissions, and is more beneficial to production increase than the continuously flooded as well. Without the implementation of this project, which provides ditches to conduct intermittently flooded method, the backward continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario.

title: Future Soils and Sustainable Farming Initiative - Germany
description:
Germany's image as an industrialized country is dominated by vehicle and machinery manufacturers as well as producers of chemical products. The agricultural use of more than 50% of the country's land area is usually overlooked, although here too, successful industrial cultivation is predominant. Technical progress in fertilizers and pesticides, agricultural machinery, and cultivation methods, as well as advances in breeding and the yield-oriented transformation of agricultural landscapes have increased yields many times over in the last 100 years. However, an accompanying effect of this growth is a significant impact on the environment and the climate.

To reduce this impact while maintaining high yields, the Future Soils and Sustainable Farming Initiative aims to promote IALM (improved agriculture land management) practices in Germany. Designed as a grouped project under the VCS, the initiative’s purpose is to encourage interested farmers to participate who meet the requirements. As its initial instance, the initiative starts with a farm located southeast of Berlin in the state of Brandenburg.

By applying regenerative practices, the participating farmers do not only support the global efforts to mitigate climate change by reducing and removing GHG, but also make their own soils more resistant to upcoming challenges such as longer periods of droughts or extreme weather phenomena. Furthermore, a significant contribution is made to the conservation and promotion of biodiversity.
VCS Proponent:
everi GmbH
Hamburg, Germany
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Carpathia Forest Carbon Project
description:
The Carpathia Forest Carbon Project aims for the restoration and full protection of forests in the south-eastern Carpathians Mountains in Romania. Through land purchase and conservation agreements, the project seeks to protect primary and secondary forests in five Natura 2000 network sites and regenerate areas affected by clear cuts, spruce monocultures, and degraded riparian habitats along the mountain rivers.
The Carpathia Forest Carbon Project would create GHG emission reductions by avoiding the release of carbon associated with timber harvesting, road building and other forestry operations that would be expected to be carried out in the baseline (business-as-usual) scenario. Thus, the project includes improved forest management (IFM) practices that convert the logged forests to protected forests through conservation management activities with low level of timber removal for ecosystem/habitat enhancement and risk management in the wider Făgăraș Mountains (Natura 2000 designated site), the Piatra Craiului National Park and the Leaota Mountains. 
The broader vision of this project is to establish the foundations of a new National Park that can be recognized as the European Yellowstone Park (in reference to the Yellowstone National Park in the United States), encompassing the Carpathian Mountains; from the Olt Valley in the West to Piatra Craiului Mountain in the East.
The project area involves the lands owned by Fundatia Conservation Carpathia (FCC) as well as those managed by them and owned by their partners Wildland Ltd, Romfor Sustainable Forestry SRL, Almimax Natura, Dante International and Sanatate & Natura. The forest properties to be considered include 36 forest management plans (FMP). The total project area is 23,404 ha, of which 14,541 ha are eligible for the development of the IFM activities.
VCS Proponent:
Fundatia Conservation Carpathia
Brasov, Romania
CCB Proponent:
Fundatia Conservation Carpathia
Brasov, Romania
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: ANDRADE SUN FARMS REDD+ FAZENDA SANTA RITA
description:
Andrade Sun Farms REDD+ Fazenda Santa Rita promote forest conservation and the reduction of potential greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, based on an economic development model. place that values forest preservation through a mosaic of activities associated with the organic production of Tahiti lime (Citrus latifolia).

The Project area is located in Cerrado biome vegetation, the second largest Brazilian biome, after the Amazon, where thousands of species of animals and plants that only exist in this region live. More than 14 million people also inhabit the Cerrado, many of whom depend on agriculture and livestock to survive and help the economy grow. The “Brazilian savannah” is also the country’s water tank: it concentrates the main springs and some of the most important tributaries of the three largest hydrographic basins in South America (Amazonas, Paraguay and São Francisco).

With the approval of the REDD+ Project and the consequent issuance of carbon credits, the values measured in their sale will be destined to optimize the management directed to forest areas, both legal reserve and forest surplus, to promote high productivity in these areas. ensuring a decrease in deforestation and GHG emissions. Such actions will be linked to sustainable management of production areas.
VCS Proponent:
MATA NATIVA DO BRASIL ASSESSORIA E CONSULTORIA AMBIENTAL LTDA
State São Paulo, Brazil
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: INTEGRATED REDD+ PROJECT1 IN PAPUA NEW GUINEA
description: This REDD+ project is an Avoided Unplanned Deforestation and Degradation (AUD) activity. The REDD+ project area covers parts of four provinces namely, East Sepik, Gulf, Madang and Southern highlands in Papua New Guinea .The rainforests in the project area are among the most valuable natural resources. The forests support hundreds of rare and endemic species, making this place a “mega-biodiverse”. These forests are also directly critical to the lives and well-being of most of our people, including the communities. These areas are under tremendous stress due to logging, shifting agriculture, and plantations for decades. The major causes for forest loss in these areas are due to demand for an unprocessed log from the Asian market and, a large portion of the forests is being converted to permanent agriculture and long fallow shifting cultivation. Besides, the human population has been immensely increased in these areas which leads to poverty escalation, thus the subsistence farmers respond to the growing needs of the population by various forms of agricultural intensification. This initiative proceeds with promoting various activities to mitigate climate change and improving livelihoods.
State/Province: East Sepik, Gulf, Madang and Southern highlands

title: Boomitra Grassland Restoration in the Temperate Grasslands of South America Through Soil Enrichment
description:
This project encompasses the Pampas grasslands (known as La Pampa in Spanish and Os Pampas in Portuguese), which are vast grassland plains spread across the South American lowlands of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, and Uruguay over 750,000 sq. km. These are natural grasslands where livestock production is the key livelihood activity in the region. These grasslands are subdivided into 3 distinct ecoregions: the Uruguayan Savanna, the Humid Pampas and the Semiarid Pampas. Like other grasslands across the globe, these grasslands are under tremendous pressure from anthropogenic activities such as overgrazing and unsustainable grassland management activities. Grasslands in this region are also declining steadily due to changes in land use - the conversion of grasslands to croplands. Overgrazing and land use change has resulted in the decline of Soil Organic Carbon (SOC) across the grassland region. 
The project promotes sustainable grassland management activities that will both improve SOC in the soil and improve the livelihoods of the communities utilizing these ranches, directly through the carbon credit payments, which provide an additional source of income, and indirectly through the increased productivity of their lands. The regenerated lands also become much less likely to undergo land use change, because the ranchers are better able to sustain their livelihoods. This in turn ensures that crucial habitats for the flora and fauna of the region are protected.

title: Muskitia Pâsa Klîn Nâka sa
description: The Muskitia Pâsa Klîn Nâka (Muskitia – a source of fresh air) project is a regional community initiative, which seeks certification of actions related to the reduction of carbon emissions due to unplanned deforestation and the conservation of mangrove, broadleaf, and coniferous natural forest in about 5,000, 200,000 and 70,000 ha respectively. The initiative is a grouped project whose expansion region includes all the forests present in Gracias a Dios department (Honduras) that are legally titled to indigenous territorial councils (CTI). The project initially has two instances: the Instance I (West), corresponds to seven Miskitu councils (LAINASTA, KATAINASTA, WATIASTA, Ahuya Yari, TRUKTSINASTA, BAMIASTA, and BATIASTA) characterized for being territories surrounded by other indigenous territories. The Instance II (East) correspond to one Miskitu Council (RAYAKA) and one Pech council (Las Marías), territories bordering communities not inhabited by indigenous.

title: Developing Carbon Finance Project For Van Panchayats In Soil Conservation  Forest Division Ranikhet (Uttarakhand)
description:
Under the Uttarakhand Forest Resource Management Project (UFRMP), Uttarakhand Forest Department (UKFD) has tackled forest degradation in over 800 Van Panchayats across the state. VPs were treated in Ranikhet Soil Conservation Forest Division. Out of these Van Panchayats, 18 Van Panchayats have 
been selected for developing carbon finance project.
Anthropogenic pressures such as unsustainable extraction of fuel wood, overgrazing of cattle,anthropogenic forest fire, and unsustainable extraction of Non-Timber Forest Products (NTFPs) are responsible for forest degradation and deforestation in these Van Panchayats. Various eco-restoration activities are implemented by UFRMP with an objective to enhance restoration of the degraded forests by empowering village community. These activities include assisted natural regeneration, protection through fencing, soil and water conservation, alternative livelihood development including other better forest management practices like fire management and forest patrolling.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Blitta – Togo Solar Power Plant
description:
The 70 MW solar PV plant is the largest in West Africa and the first renewable energy facility in the country. This plant which is located in Blitta, will supply reliable, clean electricity to hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses in the country and save more than one million tonnes of CO2 emissions through its lifetime.

The current capacity of the plant is 50 MW. An additional 20 MW expansion is expected to be operational by 2023/2024 bringing the total to 70 MW.
The village of Blitta-Losso is part of the canton of Blitta village and is surrounded from north to south and from east to west by the villages of Blitta kotokoli, Boufouli boko losso, Doufouli and Oranyi.

The Blitta area has an average monthly direct normal radiation of 5.14 kWh/m²/day and an average annual solar irradiation of 1,876 kWh/m².
The project will advance the Togolese national clean energy strategy to increase the share of renewables in electrification to 50 per cent by 2025 and 100 per cent by 2030.

The project activity, which has a lifetime of 25 years, is expected to produce more than 88,000 MWh of electricity annually. The total estimated emission reductions of the proposed project are 464,040 tCO2e during the first crediting period. The ex-ante emission reduction calculation shows that the project will avoid  66,291 tCO2e on average, annually.

The project will not only reduce the GHG emissions but is expected to achieve many social benefits such as improving social services to targeted social groups and generating job opportunities. The jobs created are intended to promote sustained, inclusive, and sustainable economic growth, full and productive employment and decent work for all. The project is also crucial in ensuring that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, and gender equality.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents

title: Grouped Project Serra do Sudeste
description: The project “Serra do Sudeste” is a grouped project, falling under the Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR) category and targeting the following Verra certifications: Verified Carbon Standard (VCS), and Climate, Community & Biodiversity Standard (CCB). The Serra do Sudeste Grouped Project aims to restore forest formations that are diminished due to the expansion of other land use practices such as overgrazing on extensive cattle ranches, intensive agriculture and silviculture systems. The grouped project is located in the Pampa biome in Rio Grande do Sul, south of Brazil. Restoration is attained through forestation activities using primarily native species and includes enrichment planting with valuable species as well as assisted natural regeneration. The overarching goal of the project is to create a natural and biodiverse forest that combines carbon capture with a diversity of other economic functions such as apiculture, sustainable production of crops and exploitation of forest products.

title: METHANE EMISSION REDUCTION PROJECT THROUGH INTERMITTENT FLOODING IN RICE CULTIVATION
description: Methane emissions through flooded rice cultivation is one of the largest sources of methane into the atmosphere. Approximately 15-20% of annual total methane emissions come from the paddy fields. Methane is a potent gas with a Global Warming Potential (GWP) of 28 is significant gas in the context of climate change. Therefore, it is essential to address the methane emissions from the rice farming to mitigate climate change.  The proposed project activity aims at the reducing methane emissions from the paddy cultivation. The project has introduced direct seeded rice (DSR) technique to irrigated rice cultivation. Prior to the project activity, rice was cultivated in conventional manner with flooding of paddy farms for at least 100 days.

title: Boa Esperança Grouped REDD+ Project
description:
The primary objective of the Boa Esperança REDD+ Project is to avoid unplanned deforestation (AUD) of 8,943.38 ha of project area, consisting of 100% Amazon rainforest. The project area has 1 instance, which is located within a private property, in the municipality of Presidente Figueiredo, Amazonas State. 

Besides the ecological and carbon benefits of the project, a proportion of the carbon credits generated will be dedicated to improving social and environmental conditions for the local community around the project area, specifically contributions to environmental education and other social activities. The contribution to sustainability is being monitored through the application of the SOCIALCARBON® and CCB standards.

The present REDD project is expected to avoid a predicted 678 ha of deforestation, equating to 183,542 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime (07-March-2022 to 06-March-2052), with an annual average of 5,921 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Buritirana Grouped REDD+ Project
description:
The primary objective of the Buritirana Grouped REDD+ Project is to avoid the unplanned deforestation (AUD), consisting of Cerrado biome, known as the Brazilian savannah. Such biome is severely threatened by agriculture and cattle ranching, and, as a REDD project under VCS rules, offers the possibility to expand the conservation to other areas in the future. The project area occupies private properties, with a project area of 4,037.145 ha, located in Ponte Alta do Bom Jesus, Tocantins State, Western Amazon.

Beyond the project’s ecological and carbon benefits, a proportion of the carbon credits generated will be dedicated to improving the social and environmental conditions in the project region, specifically contributing to improving deforestation control, and developing environmental education and other social activities. The contribution to sustainability is being monitored through the application of the SOCIALCARBON® Standard.

The present REDD project is expected to avoid a predicted 1,042 ha of deforestation of Cerrado Biome in an area of 4,037.145 ha, equating to 154,467 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime (03-September-2020 to 02-September-2050), with an annual average of 5,149 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Future Carbon Consultoria e Projetos Florestais LTDA
São Paulo, Brazil
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Chengmai Water Management with Rice Cultivation
description: The project carried out changes from a continuously flooded regime to an intermittently flooded regime during rice cultivation in Chengmai County, Hainan Province, China, with a total acreage of 12,488 ha of double-cropping rice. Without the project, there would be no ditches, pumps, valves, and reservoirs to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously flooded method would be continued. The original scenario for rice cultivation by the continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded conditions can emit a large amount of methane because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittently flooded method is more conducive to saving water, increasing rice yield, and reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded method.
VCS Proponent:

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in North Wuhua County
description: The main goal of this project is changing continuously flooded irrigation to intermittent flooded irrigation in rice cultivation in the north of Wuhua County, Meizhou City, Guangdong Province of China. Wuhua County is located in east of Guangdong Province. The project includes 4 towns, namely Qiling Town, Huacheng Town, Zhuanshui town and Shuizhai town, with total double-cropping rice area is approximately 6,695.11ha. Since lack of financial support, it is very difficult to change irrigation method by local farmers. Therefore, the baseline scenario should be recognized as continuously flooded irrigation situation. Due to the anaerobic decomposition, a large amount of CH4 will be produced during continuously flooded irrigation. In contrast, rice paddies intermittently submerged and dried so that the upper soil layers switch from anaerobic to aerobic conditions several times during the crop growing season in intermittent flooded method. Moreover, the intermittent flooded method brings many benefits, such as the higher rice yield production, the higher methane removal rate, etc.

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in East Wuhua County
description: The project is in east of Wuhua County, Meizhou City, Guangdong Province, which is located in southern China, including four towns, namely Shuanghua Town, Anliu Town, Hedong Town and Guotian Town. The project changing the irrigation method from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded during rice cultivation. In 2018, the average annual income of each local household was only CNY 12,921.4 RMB CNY[ https://www.wuhua.gov.cn/xxgk/sjfb/tjgb/content/post_326941.html] and rice cultivation is the main way for local farmers to survive. In this case, they lack of financial support to build ditches for implementing intermittently flooded method. Therefore, the traditional continuously flooded method still used for rice cultivation, which means there is constant pond water maintained in the field until the harvest drainage. The organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane because of anaerobic decomposition.  In contrast, rice paddies intermittently submerged and dried so that the upper soil layers switch from anaerobic to aerobic conditions several times during the crop growing season in Intermittently flooded method. Moreover, the intermittently flooded method brings many benefits, such as the higher rice yield production, the higher methane removal rate and etc. The project aims to achieve GHG mitigation goal （sustainable development goals）in project zone by utilizing intermittent flooded irrigation method. There is totally 7,573.78 ha of rice paddies are switched from continuously flooded method to implementing intermittently flooded irrigation method in this project.

title: Tibet Ngari Improved Grassland Management Project
description:
Tibet Ngari Improved Grassland Management Project (hereafter as 'the project') is located in Ngari Region, Tibet Autonomous Region, China. The objective of the project is to restore the 'black soil beach' and degraded grassland ecosystem through reseeding native grasses and grazing management, such as rest grazing and grazing prohibition, increase carbon sequestration, and promote local development.
Totally, 373,467.02 ha of degraded grassland in Ngari have been managed sustainably including rest grazing and grazing prohibition by fence building and seeding of local high-quality forage.There are three main restoration measures: rest grazing, grazing prohibition and black soil beach restoration. 
In addition to these main restoration measures, the project also alleviates soil desertification and restores grassland vegetation through grassland management measures to improve soil carbon storage and local biodiversity, supplemented by daily management measures of other protection projects, such as grassland fire prevention and rodent control, so as to ensure long-term sustainable management of the project area.
VCS Proponent:

Shaanxi, China

title: Hongera Reforestation Project (Mt Kenya and Aberdares)
description: The Hongera Reforestation Project (Mt Kenya and Aberdares) is a reforestation and afforestation  initiative designed and funded by Dutch Green Business. The Project aims to increase tree cover in Kenya through two distinct strategies: 1) restoring degraded or deforested areas in Kenya Forest Service lands with native species, and 2) planting agroforestry crop trees on individual farms where smallholders wish to benefit from the income that perennial nuts and fruits can provide. In both cases, site-appropriate tree species will be contributing to regional wildlife habitat or corridors, improving water infiltration, controlling erosion, and sequestering carbon, among other ecosystem services. Prior to project implementation, thousands of hectares of Kenya Forest Service land have been degraded or deforested over time, without the financial resources to restore them. In some cases, reforestation efforts have been attempted, but without the dedication of enough funds to guarantee the survival of these trees when threats like livestock grazing must be constantly warded off through employed patrols. The Project aims to change this dynamic by bringing in external up-front investment made possible through the anticipated sale of Verified Carbon Units generated through project activities. Similar financial barriers are faced by individual farmers, many of whom rely on annual crops like cabbage or potato, and do not have the resources to invest in trees that they are interested in. Their farms are currently lacking in canopy cover, with perhaps a few trees on the property boundaries that are cyclically harvested for fuelwood or timber.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Ipoá REDD+ Project
description: The primary objective of the IPOÁ REDD+ Project is to avoid gross baseline emissions of 2,719,762 tCO2e (averaging 90,659 tCO2e/year), corresponding to 4,200 hectares of avoided deforestation over the 30-year project lifetime (being an average of 140 ha/year). The project operates within private areas totaling 17,386 hectares, 17,329 hectares of which are eligible for REDD+ activities, located in Amazonas State, municipality of Novo Aripuanã. The latter ranks 15th for highest deforestation rates of the municipalities within the Amazon biome according to the Brazilian national deforestation monitoring program (PRODES) as, between 2016 and 2021, it displayed an average deforestation rate of 160km²/year. Long-term, high-impact benefits for communities and biodiversity will be provided by the Ipoá project, which are duly quantified and monitored through the CCB methodological standard. The definition of the actions to be implemented was carried out through a collaborative participatory consultation with community stakeholders. The activities fall into multiple activity scopes including: healthcare, education, occupational health and safety, communication and electrification, employment, and training, within the Community Pillar; fauna and flora research and conservation activities, as well as those addressing high conservation values, in the Biodiversity Pillar; and forest conservation activities articulated under Carbonext’s Forest Integrity Plan in the Climate Pillar. These initiatives will begin as soon as possible to project start in 2022 – 2023, Monitoring Period 1 (“MR1”), and continue along the project lifetime, through MR30 in 2052.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: Nehe Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation
description:
The project aims to reduce a large amount of greenhouse gases (GHG) by changing the water regime from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation. The project is conducted in Nehe City, Heilongjiang Province of China, and involves a total acreage of 20,245ha for single-cropping rice. 
Currently, the farmers in the project area are using the continuously flooded method during the rice cultivation. Without the implementation of this project, which provides ditches and technical support to conduct intermittently flooded method, the continuously flooded method would be continued, which is also the baseline scenario. As the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, after the implementation of the project, the period of flooded condition will be shortened, which will have negative impact on the methane production. In this case, CH4 emission during the cultivation can be declined significantly. Hence, with the proposed project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 2.87 tCO2e/ha for single-cropping rice is expected per year during the 10-yr fixed crediting period.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 580,676 tCO2e in the 10-years crediting period, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 58,067 tCO2e. This project aims to sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes, save water resources; increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers and provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.

title: Arva Carbon Ready USA
description: U.S. Farmers and Ranchers represent one of the most scalable and cost-effective solutions to draw down greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and address climate change. Arva Intelligence is a producer-first, B Corporation that uses machine learning (ML) and precision agriculture to optimize sustainable practices and profitability for landowners. Arva was founded on the principle of helping farmers and their suppliers make data-informed agronomic decisions, resulting in improved environmental stewardship for the buyers and an increased efficiency in grower operations. Limited access to data and financial risk concerns have been common barriers to adopting regenerative land management practices in the U.S., and the Arva Carbon Ready USA project will bring tools to farmers and ranchers to help them overcome barriers to adoption. Arva provides solutions through its measurement, monitoring, reporting, and verification platform and will provide its cloud-based, ML-enabled software to collect, integrate, and validate data from the adoption or expansion of on-field regenerative agricultural practices. Access to low-cost, scalable, agricultural carbon offsets is limited by the industry’s disaggregated digital infrastructure. Arva’s established Carbon Ready program allows farmers to upload field boundaries and run scenarios to determine the GHG emission values for practice changes that result in GHG avoidance/reduction and soil organic carbon sequestration. A project goal is to help growers identify the practices and seed best suited for their land and to overcome scalability challenges. To facilitate the collection of soil carbon measurements and verify location, Arva will utilize its newly developed mobile app. The project is designed as a grouped project within the USA. Arva estimates that this project will result in the removal and/or avoidance of 1,000,000 tons CO2e annually by 2023. Total GHG ERRs after the first 20 years of the project are estimated at 17,020,002 tons CO2e.

title: Eastern Yan’an Afforestation Project
description:
Eastern Yan’an Afforestation Project (hereafter referred to as ‘The Project’the project”) is located in Yanchang County, Yanchuan County, Yichuan County and Zichang City  in eastern Yan’an City, Shaanxi Province, People’s Republic of China. The project aims to increase carbon sequestration and improve the local ecological environment by means of forest planting activities on degraded lands suffering from severe soil erosion.
The project activities involve the planting of trees and shrubs on 58,423.59 hectares (or 876,354 Mu ) of degraded lands located in Yanchang County, Yanchuan County, Yichuan County and Zichang City under the administration of Yan’an City. The species include Robinia pseudoacacia (black locust), Platycladus orientalis (Oriental thuja or Oriental arborvitae), Pinus tabuliformis (Chinese red pine), Armeniaca sibirica (Siberian apricot) as well as Hippophae rhamnoides (sea-buckthorn). All of them are native species except for Robinia pseudoacacia, which is native to North America; it is not considered as an invasive species in China (refer to Section 5.2 for details). The project area was degraded lands with little vegetation before the project and would continue to be so without the implementation of the project activities. 
The implementation of the project activity will generate GHG emission removals and mitigate climate change, improve soil and water conditions, increase the forest cover and enhance local biodiversity; the project also generates social benefits including job opportunities and technical skills training for local communities and residents.
VCS Proponent:
National Forestry and Grassland Administration Northwest Investigation and Planning Institute
Shaanxi, China

The project aims to increase carbon sequestration and improve the local ecological environment by means of forest planting activities on degraded lands suffering from severe soil erosion. 
The project activities involve the planting of trees and shrubs on 67,473.46 hectares (or 1,012,102 Mu ) of degraded lands located in Ansai District, Baota District, Fu County, Ganquan County, Huangling County, Luochuan County and Zhidan County under the administration of Yan’an City. The species include Robinia pseudoacacia (black locust), Platycladus orientalis (Oriental thuja or Oriental arborvitae), Pinus tabuliformis (Chinese red pine), Armeniaca sibirica (Siberian apricot) as well as Hippophae rhamnoides (sea-buckthorn) and Xanthoceras sorbifolium. All of them are native species except for Robinia pseudoacacia, which is native to North America; it is not considered as an invasive species in China (refer to Section 5.2 for details). The implementation of the project activity will generate GHG emission removals and mitigate climate change, improve soil and water conditions, increase the forest cover and enhance local biodiversity; the project also generates social benefits including job opportunities and technical skills training for local communities and residents.

title: Yan’an Aerial Seeding Afforestation Project
description:
Yan’an Aerial Seeding Afforestation Project (hereafter 'The Project') is located in Yan’an City, Shaanxi Region, China. The project aims to increase the carbon sequestration and to contribute to local sustainable development through directly aerial seeding on the barren land and barren mountain. 
Aerial seeding is a method of afforestation in which forest seeds or seed pellets are scattered on the woodlands (i.e., sown areas) by aircraft. Planting afforestation by airplane is a modern afforestation method, which has the advantages of high speed, high efficiency, saving labor and great effect. In the sparsely populated, inconvenient transportation, labor shortage of large areas of barren mountains, sand and cutting, afforestation by aerial seeding is an effective way to speed up afforestation.
31,049.40 ha of forest is to be established by direct aerial seeding on barren land and barren mountain in Yan’an city, there are 2 species selected as designated sowing seed species, Platycladus orientalis (Giant cedar) and Pinus tabuliformis (China pine), which are all native species. The implementation of the project will generate GHG emission removals and improve the Yan’an local environment, about 3,703,054.05 ha enhance the capabilities of local communities and residents by providing them with relevant technical skills and training and increase local biodiversity as a result of establishing a forest of native trees.

title: Boomitra Grassland Restoration in East Africa Through Soil Enrichment
description: This project helps pastoralists in deploying practices that contribute to the sustainable development of the Savanna grasslands of East Africa. The pastoralists of this region have largely resorted to implementing traditional grassland management methods on their lands. The grazing of grasslands by both livestock and wildlife is widely prevalent, and degradation of land due to overgrazing is a prominent issue. In this context, the opportunity to introduce improved grassland management practices, including sustainable grazing practices, will significantly help the grasslands of the region and restore carbon to their soil, creating carbon removals while improving overall soil health. In this project, pastoralists will be mobilized to take up a variety of improved grassland management practices. These practices are proven ways to increase soil organic carbon, prevent further degradation of the grasslands, and enable pastoralists to improve their productivity.

title: XiCO2e: Mexican Reforestation Project
description:
The XiCO2e: Mexican Reforestation Project is a grouped project for the afforestation, reforestation and/or revegetation (hereafter referred to as “ARR”) of lands in the states of Tabasco and Tamaulipas in Mexico. The main goals of this grouped project are:
●	To restore degraded areas through the plantation of Gmelina arborea. The project activity will prevent further deterioration of already degraded areas and address soil erosion by providing protection through vegetative cover.
●	To mitigate climate change by removing greenhouse gases (GHG) through biomass growth.
The first project activity instance of the XiCO2e project includes planting 1,014.82 hectares in the state of Tabasco and 204.18 hectares in the state of Tamaulipas, located in southeast and northeast Mexico, respectively. This totals 1,219.01 ha during the monitoring period from 2017 to 2022.
The project will achieve greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reductions through carbon sequestration by pools via the reforestation with Gmelina arborea. The estimated annual average is 3,726 tCO2e, and the estimated total GHG emissions reduction and removals amount to 111,781  tCO2e. Monitoring activities for the first verification period started on January 11, 2017 and concluded on July 30, 2022.
The scenario before the project's implementation involved degraded lands, with the previous land uses being grassland and agricultural lands, currently abandoned and degraded.”
The project proponents are ALA BOOL ALA BOOL TRUST SA DE CV and FORLIANCE GmbH. The project implementor is PROXYLO S.A.P.I DE C.V.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: XiCO2e: Mexican Peninsula Forest Project
description:
The XiCO2e: Mexican Peninsula Forest Project aims to increase carbon removal through Improved Forest Management activities in communal-land properties (ejidos) located in the Yucatán Peninsula in the southeastern state of Quintana Roo, Mexico. The project is developed under the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) methodology VM0003 v1.3 - Methodology for Improved Forest Management Through Extension of Rotation Age (IFM ERA).
The Project Area covers 70,246 hectares and is comprised of semi-evergreen tropical forest with broad species diversity, having as its primary target commercial species such as mahogany (Swietenia macrophylla), Spanish cedar (Cedrela odorata), Sapotilla (Manilkara zapota), Fiddlewood (Vitex gaumeri), Tsalam (Lysiloma bahamensis), Ramon (Brosimum alicastrum), Katalox (Swartzia cubensis), Shaving bush tree (Pseudobombax ellipticum), Copperwood (Bursera simaruba), and Chechen (Metopium brownei), among several other tropical commercial species.
The common practice of harvesting in the ejidos consists of selection cuts of tropical species in management units during the established rotation period. The project will extend the rotation cycle by +5, +4, and +2 years. Additionally, the project aims to implement a monitoring procedure to systematize and centralize information related to forest practices. The project is expected to remove 4,599,024 tonnes of CO2e over 30 years, with an annual average of 170,334 tonnes of CO2e.

title: The Last Habitat REDD+ project
description:
The Last Habitat REDD+ project is located in the Ucayali region, in the central zone of the Peruvian Amazon, one of the regions with the highest rates of deforestation in Peru (31,543.29 ha in 2021). The project area is comprised by two private estates belonging to the project proponent, BAM: the properties of Nuestro Señor Jesucristo with 8,049.87 ha and Selva Maestra with 14,176.13 ha, a total area of 22,226 ha mainly of primary floodable forests.

Located near the city of Pucallpa (Ucayali) and surrounded by deforestation pressures from agriculture, urbanization and others, the project area harbors an extraordinary ecological wealth, being the last habitat or refuge for various species of flora and fauna and a green island of outstanding ecological value. In addition, the are includes several types of valuable forest, among them the aguajales, which are the wetlands with the greatest carbon sequestration capacity in the Amazon, making this an essential ecosystem to conserve.

The Last Habitat REDD+ project is designed under the avoided planned deforestation methodology as this area was originally sold to the project proponent with the authorization to  convert the forested areas in agrarian production lands (camu camu, palm oil, piñon, and cattle ranching). Despite having the legal authorization to carry out traditional productive activities, BAM, with its own resources, has promoted the conservation of these valuable forests and its biodiversity over the years by implementing different strategies and activities such: territorial supervision with technical and legal support, forest surveillance activities, permanent work with communities for improving their capacities in sustainable forestry management, among others. Such conservation efforts will only be feasible and sustainable over time with the support of carbon revenues from the proposed REDD+ project.

title: DEVELOPING CARBON FINANCE PROJECT FOR FARMERS ADOPTING REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURE PRACTICES IN THE INDO-GANGETIC PLAINS
description: The project intends to generate additional income to the small holder farmers of Indo- Gangetic plain region for adopting improved agricultural practices such as zero till farming, cover cropping, crop diversification, farm residue incorporation, optimizing fertilizer application and efficient water management which provide a potential to not just prevent emissions into the atmosphere but also create carbon sinks through sequestration of carbon back into the soil. The project will be a grouped project. Starting with rice-wheat cropping system, the project will be further expanded to maize-wheat, sugarcane, and cotton-wheat/cotton cropping systems. Pulses and Mustard are cover crops widely interspersed in these cropping systems. The project considers 2019 as the baseline year in which the interventions started. Starting with 12 thousand hectares (~28000 Tonnes CO2 Eq. per annum) in 2019, the area will be stabilized at 2 million hectares (~7.0 million Tonnes CO2 Eq. per annum) in 2027 and maintained until 2038.

title: Developing voluntary carbon market project for Periyar Tiger Reserve in India
description: Tiger Reserves are the storehouse of ecosystem services and a majority of rural population depend on forest resources for their day-to-day livelihood. This dependence is in the form of collection of a variety of Non-Timber Forest Produce (NTFP) and collection of firewood and fodder for subsistence and livelihood purposes. Due to this dependence on forest resources and lack of sufficient infrastructure, the local communities venture in the forest areas resulting in degradation of pristine forest and causing human wildlife conflicts. This results in loss of human lives, and wild animals in a retaliatory process. Hence, there is a need to develop a dedicated finance mechanism which shall help in mitigating the conflicts in an efficient way and lead to coexistence and harmony amongst forest fringe communities and wildlife. This project will result in enhancing carbon sequestration by reducing pressures on forests from unsustainable collection of firewood through sustainable firewood management and exploring energy efficient technologies and alternative fuel in and around Periyar Tiger Reserve, Kerala.

title: XESET 2 EXTENTION HYDROPOWER PROJECT
description:
The proposed Xeset 2 Extention Hydro Power Project identified and developed by Electricite Duo Laos is located on Xeset river in the vicinity of Ban Baktheung village, Laongam district, Saravane province, Lao PDR. The proposed project activity is a run of river project has created a small reservoir for smooth operation of the project activity.

The nominal installed capacity of the project is 10 MW (the actual installed capacity is 10.454MW comprising 2 turbines with individual installed capacity 5.227MW each), with estimated annual power generation 34.38 GWh. The generated electricity from the project activity will be supplied to the regional grid consisting of Thailand power grid and the Lao power grid.

The purpose of the project activity is to produce renewable energy using hydro power for supplying to grid. In the absence of the project activity equivalent amount of electricity would have been generated by the operation of grid connected fossil fuel based power plants. The Project activity thus reduces the anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) in to the atmosphere associated with the equivalent amount of electricity generation from the fossil fuel based grid connected power plant.

The baseline scenario is that the electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition of new generation sources into the grid The estimated annual average and the total CO2e emission reduction by the project activity over the first renewable crediting period of 7 years are expected to be 19,347 tCO2e and 135,429 tCO2e respectively.

title: TERRRA SANTA
description:
The TERRRA Santa project of Improved Agriculture Land Management (IALM), according to the VM0042, will implement sustainable practices in all the project sites in order to reduce and remove GHG, support the local community, increase farmer’s income, and improve biodiversity and natural habitat – important pillars of sustainability.
The existing scenario prior to the implementation of the project was aquaculture with the use of on-land fishponds, producing fish for sale in Israel. This has been a common case in Kibbutzim (collective communities, traditionally based in agriculture) in the last 4-6 decades and currently becoming less profitable due to tax removal and cost increases, therefore some fishponds are not productive and left inactive. In addition, fishpond aquaculture makes use of technologies and practices that have large impacts in terms of, for instance, carbon footprint. 
The project will convert fishponds following rewilding concepts to increase biodiversity and vegetation growth using the earth’s “Muscle Memory”.  The project’s GHG removals will focus mainly on: 
I.	Aboveground biomass that will grow back after each harvesting.
II.	Belowground biomass, which is expected to have a high initial removal rate and small continuous increase.
III.	Soil carbon that accumulates continuously as biomass and sediments are added into the soil. 
Through this project, in collaboration with TERRRA, the Kibbutz farmers will be able to utilize the same fishpond areas to grow vegetation. These will mainly be Common Reed (Phragmites australis), Elephant Grass (Arundo donax), Castor (Ricinus communis), and/or other crops, to be harvested and used as fodder and source for renewable energy.
The IALM project is located in North Israel; it includes a portfolio of assets with a total area of around 500 hectares, which are estimated to reduce and remove 22,704 tons of GHG annually and a total of 454,080 tons over a 20 years period.

title: Developing climate resilience of the coastal communities of Sunderbans through Mangrove Afforestation
description: The project is implemented on 650 ha across several Gram Panchayats in the Sunderbans region. The project activities also include several community development initiatives that address health, livelihoods and education of the local communities in the villages under the project. The project restores degraded mangrove habitats through the plantation of diverse native mangrove species. The project sequesters carbon through biomass, above ground and below ground, and in the soil as soil organic carbon
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Participatory Mangrove Afforestation & Restoration in the west coast of India
description: The objective of the project is to restore degraded mangrove ecosystems in the estuarine islands of several rivers in coastal Karnataka, including the Aghanashini, Sharavathi and Kali rivers, and their tributaries. The three rivers form an integral part of the coastal ecosystem of Uttara Kannada District of Karnataka, India.The project objective is to restore the degarded mangrove habitats through plantation of several, diverse native mangrove and mangrove associated species, including several species which had disappeared from the region following degradation and deforestation of the mangrove habitat.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
