title: Jutaituba REDD+ Project
description:
The Jutaituba REDD+ Project is a partnership between the Biofílica Ambipar Environment and Martins Agropecuária, belonging to the Martins Group and aims to promote forest conservation and mitigate climate change by reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from changes in land use. In addition to climate benefits, the Project also aims to generate socio-environmental benefits based on sustainable economic development practices and the improvement of the well-being of surrounding communities, while preserving the culture and tradition of local peoples.
The Project Area has 129,417 ha of Amazon rainforest and is located almost entirely in the mesoregion of Marajó, in the State of Pará, covering the cities of Bagre, Portel, Baião and Oeiras do Pará. It is located near BR 422, known as the Transcametá highway, and near the rivers Pacajá, Jacundá and Tocantins. Communities that are directly or indirectly influenced by the Project were identified, either because they provide labor to Fazenda Jutaituba or are geographically close to the Project Area and depend on the forest resources present in the area, such as nuts and medicinal herbs.
The region has great relevance in relation to its biodiversity, being an ecological corridor that makes it possible to connect Conservation Units (UCs) that are nearby. The predominant vegetation is the Dense Ombrophilous Forest with a high density of medium and large trees, as well as woody and epiphytic lianas. It houses at least 24 species of fauna and flora with some degree of threat according to the IUCN Red List, some of which are endemic to the region.
Thus, the Jutaituba REDD+ Project hopes, in addition to climate impacts, to improve the well-being of communities and generate exceptional benefits for local biodiversity.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

description:

title: Bougouni-Yanfolila Forest Project, Mali
description:
This is a grouped project, with the initial Project Activity Instances make up a initial Project area of approximately 140,000 hectares of forest at risk that have the potential to reduce emissions from deforestation and degradation (REDD+) and non-forest areas with the potential to plant 60,000 hectares of afforestation/reforestation primarily for agroforestry systems. The Project Activities instances are in State Reserves which are managed by Agro-Industrie Développement SA (AID–SA) under a 30-year contract. AID-SA has been running piloting programs for local communities, working with Mali-Folkecenter Nyetaa, a national NGO) to promote sustainable income streams. However, the funding and project activities have not been able to fully address the on-going pressure on forests nor finance the full potential for new tree-based (agroforestry) income streams. The Project Activity Instances are among the last remaining stands of contiguous mature and fairly intact forests in Mali and are being threatened by various anthropogenic deforestation drivers.

The objective of the Project is to conserve and restore these forests by working with the local communities in and around these threatened forests to provide environmental education and awareness, delineation and protection of forests, development of alternative fuel wood and timber supplies, as well as alternative sustainable income generation and farming techniques for crops and non-timber forest products.  There is also the potential to expand to additional areas within the geography to potentially increase the size of this grouped project over time.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Agroforestry System  Lanquin, Alta Verapaz, Guatemala
description:
The project is located on the northern region of Guatemala (km. 268) on the route to the Lanquin Municipality, Department of Alta Verapaz. The farm’s rolling hills, and occasional low altitude mountains, surrounded by valleys originate moderate to steep slopes. This is a multifunctional and biodiverse cocoa and coffee agroforestry project. Additionally, it produces cardamom, lemons, and rubber; diversifying revenue streams and increasing landscape connectivity.

Currently, Finca Chimelb is the largest cacao farm in Guatemala with a total of 470.5 hectares of cocoa crop, and a major producer of arabica coffee, with a total of 573 hectares of specialty coffee. Likewise, in the next few years, it will become a leading producer of rubber and cardamom. The farm also has an area of eucalyptus and other tree species, plus natural forest within the property which are protected and managed. 

This grouped project has a Project area which initially has Project Activity Instances of 4,805 hectares. Out of this total area, approximately 2,740 hectares are cropland, while most of the remaining land is covered with forest. In the project area, crops are grown under regenerative agriculture principles including practices such as agroforestry, crop diversification, cover crops, and no-till. The farm’s elevation ranges from 400 meters to 1,150 meters above sea level. Thus, productive areas are distributed according to the altitude, soil’s conditions, and vegetation types. Between 400 and 900 meters above sea level, cocoa, cardamom, and coffee (Robusta) are planted in an agroforestry system under the shade of tress such as rubber, and pine. And between 900 and 1,150 meters above sea level, Arabica coffee is grown. 

The project area includes the Sepalau Lagoon and other smaller water sources that cover approximately 48 hectares of the project area. In terms of infrastructure 105.7kilometers of internal roads has been built to facilitate production activities among the plantation.
State/Province: Lanquin Municipality, Department of Alta Verapaz
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Methane avoidance in rice cultivation in South of Yunxi District
description:
Yunxi District is located in the northeast of Yueyang City and the south bank of the middle reaches of the Yangtze River. Rice cultivation is an important agricultural operation in Yunxi District, not only in terms of food security but also in terms of livelihood and plays a major part in the economy. Yunxi District has a population about 178,400, and annual household income of farmers is only CNY 42,507. The project is located in south of Yunxi District, Yueyang City, Hunan Province, China, with a total acreage of 8,059.19 ha for double-cropping rice. The project activity is designed to construction the cement ditch and reservoir to realize the reducing of methane emissions by conducting intermittently flooded method instead of continuously flooded method during the cropping season in south of Yunxi District.
In the baseline scenario, farmers in Yunxi District use continuously flooded method in rice paddies with the straw on field as the organic amendment inputs, which means fields have standing water throughout the rice growing season and only dry out for harvest. However, the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane because of anaerobic decomposition. In the project scenario, farmers in Yunxi District changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation. By controlled the irrigation and drainage according to the needs of rice growth, can save water resources. On the other hand, multiple aeration during rice cultivation can effectively reduce methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions.
VCS Proponent:
Hunan Yueyang Huabanqiao Market Development Co., Ltd.
Hunan Province, China
peng20876275@163.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: REPLACING SYNTHETIC NITROGEN FERTILIZER WITH IN-SEASON NITROGEN SOURCES THAT FIX AND SUPPLY NITROGEN TO AGRICULTURAL CROPS
description: Through this project activity, Pivot Bio will evaluate the impact of replacing synthetic nitrogen fertilizer with an in-season nitrogen source that fixes and supplies nitrogen to the roots corn and other cereal crops. One such source is nitrogen-fixing microbes which that convert atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia, a plant available form of N, supplying N to the plant during the most critical stages of growth. This treatment offers unique advantages over synthetic nitrogen fertilizer, including consistency (microbes do not leach or volatilize during weather events), accessibility (biological nitrogen fixation occurs on the root of the crop, making N readily available to the plant), and resiliency (microbes produce nitrogen throughout the growing season, matching N availability to crop needs).  Microbes can replace synthetic nitrogen fertilizer by fixing and supplying N to cereal crops in-season, allowing growers within the project boundary to apply less synthetic nitrogen on the field.  Lower applications of synthetic nitrogen fertilizer have the well-documented impact of reducing nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions, and in certain cases, growers may also see a reduction in additional GHG emissions from reduced equipment use. In total, the GHG emission reductions from reduced synthetic fertilizer use will be used to generate credits.

title: SULIGE AFFORESTATION PROJECT IN INNER MONGOLIA AUTONOMOUS REGION
description:
PETROCHINA Changqing Oilfield Company Gas Production Plant No.1 (hereafter refers to “PCOC GPP No.1”) is a Natural gas producer, which will develop an afforestation project with total area 40 hectares (ha) for a single location, Sulige Afforestation Project In Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region in the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, P. R. China. The Proposed Project aims to plant trees in Nalinhe Forest Farm, managed by the Stated-Own Wudinghe Forestry Field in the Wudinghe Town, Uxin Banner, Ordos City, sitting on the south edge of Ordos Desert in the Inner Mongolia Plateau. 
In the absence of the Proposed Project, all the project sites are barren land covering by a few of grasses. Without its implementation, all the sites might keep the same circumstances with no natural reforestation within the project area due to shortage of water and soil nutrition. The Proposed Project is a mixed stand with Pinus sylvestris var. Mongolica, Picea asperata, Populus alba, and those that do not survive will be removed and replanted in time. 
The GHG removals generated by afforestation activities is calculated ex-ante in accordance with AR-AMS0007 v03.1 developed under the UNFCCC Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) for Afforestation/Reforestation (A/R) Small-scale Methodology, which is recognized and applied by the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS).

title: CAAPII REDD+ PROJECT
description: The CAAPII REDD+ PROJECT aims to protect the Amazon Forest present in properties inserted in the municipalities of Paragominas, Ipixuna do Pará and Tomé- Açu in the Pará State, in Brazil. This region has historically high rates of deforestation, especially associated with conflicts of land tenure, and the high value of activities of other land-use such as livestock and soybean production. The illegal exploraration of timber and other illegal activities such as hunting affect the forest, the biodiversity , the climate and consequently the local population as well. The conservation of 33,766.64 hectare of Ombrophilous Dense Forest  with the CAAPII REDD+ Project will reduce more than 14 millions tCO2e of GHG emissions and bring positive impacts to the region with the project activities. The actions have as goals the preservation of the forest, as well as the improvement of the well-being of the communities, biodiversity and climate regulation. A socioeconomic diagnosis on each community involved in the project conducted the design of the project activities in order to encourage the growth of environmental awareness and the sustainable development, aligned with the conservation of the forest and fauna and flora species. With  the approval of the CAAPII REDD+ Project, the forest areas inside the properties can be protected and the project activities can be implemented aiming to bring climate, community, and biodiversity benefits.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: Udzungwa Corridor Reforestation
description:
Udzungwa Corridor Limited will reforest 7500 ha of bracken fern thicket on the Eastern Slopes of the Udzungwa Mountains in Tanzania by planting over 100 native tree species.

The project area is largely fallow farmland on steep slopes with no road access. Natural regeneration in the project area is prevented by a dense thicket of bracken fern, occasional cultivation, and hot fires when the bracken burns. The project is signing 30-year leases with the small holder farmers and village councils that own the project lands. The project covers all the costs associated with tree nursery establishment and tree planting and employs hundreds of local community members in the process. To ensure that the planted trees survive, the project is weeding around the planted seedlings 3 times a year for 3 years, clearing fire breaks around the planted areas, and employing firefighting teams.

The project is a 30-year project and will remove approximately 5,322,834 tCO2e over the project lifetime.

The project will greatly improve the local economy in the participating villages through reliable payments for leased land, creating hundreds of well-paying jobs, the provision of avocado seedlings and improved bean seed outside the planting area and funding village development projects. With 30 years of funding already secured by the project, the economic opportunities created by the project will be much more reliable than farming and thus help communities adapt to uncertain climate conditions. 

The project is located in the Eastern Arc Biodiversity hotspot and will create a forest corridor that will reconnect the Udzungwa Scarp and Kilombero Nature Reserves. The corridor will increase habitat connectivity for the endangered Sanje Mangabey, vulnerable Udzungwa Red Colobus Monkey, and several other endangered and vulnerable species. Additionally, the project is planting vulnerable tree species, thereby directly increasing the population of vulnerable species in the area.
VCS Proponent:
Udzungwa Corridor Limited
Iringa, Tanzania

title: Jiangxi Ruijin Improved Forest Management Project
description:
The Jiangxi Ruijin Improved Forest Management Project (hereafter referred to as the project) is located in Ruijin City (county-level city), Ganzhou City, Jiangxi Province, P.R.C. The geo-coordinated of the project proponent is 115°55′E, 25°49′N, total area is 13,316 ha. It is implemented by Jiangxi Tianye Biotechnology Limited (hereafter PP) to protect the once logging forest. 

Prior to the implementation of the project, the forests in the project area were harvested following the guidelines in Timber Harvest Plan approved by the local forestry bureau. In order to protect the forest ecosystem, improve the ecological environment, increase carbon sinks, reduce GHG emission reductions and slow down climate change, the project proponent decided to implement this improved forest management project activities from January 2020 to December 2049. And from the Project Start Date, PP has stopped the commercial logging in the project area. 

This project aims to protect 13,316 ha commercial forest from logging. The Forest Conservation Project activities will be focused on forest resource supervision and monitoring. In order to supervise and monitor any disturbances that may affect the whole forest, PP has established a ranger team that monitors the state of the forest with regard to diseases, illegal logging, hunting, fires etc. This ecosystem will then continue to provide its services to all the communities and entities that depend on it.

The project reduces greenhouse gas emissions and increase carbon sinks by preventing logging, avoiding any kind of commercial harvest and other linked to logging activities,.

The project is expected to generate approximately 3,471,067 tCO2e with buffer deduction during the 30 years’ crediting period, with the annual emission reductions of 115,702 tCO2e.

The project activity will significantly improve the forest management conditions within the project area, and benefit local ecological environment, address globle climate change.

Jiangxi Tianye Biotechnology Limited
Jiangxi Province, China

VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Methane avoidance in rice cultivation in Xinzhou district of Huarong county
description:
Huarong country is located in the north of Yueyang City, covers a total area of 1590.95 km2, with jurisdiction over 12 towns, 2 village.  Rice cultivation is an important agricultural operation in Huarong country, not only in terms of food security but also in terms of livelihood and plays a major part in the economy. Huarong country has a population about 713,300, and annual household income of farmers is only CNY 25,941. The project is located in Xinzhou district of Huarong country, Yueyang City, Hunan Province, China, with a total acreage of 7,861.61 ha for double-cropping rice. The project activity is designed to construction the cement ditch and reservoir to realize the reducing of methane emissions by conducting intermittently flooded method instead of continuously flooded method during the cropping season in Xinzhou district of Huarong country.
In the baseline scenario, farmers in Huarong country use continuously flooded method in rice paddies with the straw on field as the organic amendment inputs, which means fields have standing water throughout the rice growing season and only dry out for harvest. However, the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane because of anaerobic decomposition. In the project scenario, farmers in Huarong country changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation. By controlled the irrigation and drainage according to the needs of rice growth, can save water resources. On the other hand, multiple aeration during rice cultivation can effectively reduce methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions.
VCS Proponent:
Hunan Yueyang Huabanqiao Market Development Co., Ltd.
Hunan Province, China
peng20876275@163.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Methane avoidance in rice cultivation in Donggang district of Huarong county
description:
Huarong country is located in the north of Yueyang City, covers a total area of 1590.95 km2, with jurisdiction over 12 towns, 2 village.  Rice cultivation is an important agricultural operation in Huarong country, not only in terms of food security but also in terms of livelihood and plays a major part in the economy. Huarong country has a population about 713,300, and annual household income of farmers is only CNY 25,941. The project is located in Donggang district of Huarong country, Yueyang City, Hunan Province, China, with a total acreage of 8,255.11 ha for double-cropping rice. The project activity is designed to construction the cement ditch and reservoir to realize the reducing of methane emissions by conducting intermittently flooded method instead of continuously flooded method during the cropping season in Donggang district of Huarong country.
In the baseline scenario, farmers in Huarong country use continuously flooded method in rice paddies with the straw on field as the organic amendment inputs, which means fields have standing water throughout the rice growing season and only dry out for harvest. However, the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane because of anaerobic decomposition. In the project scenario, farmers in Huarong country changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation. By controlled the irrigation and drainage according to the needs of rice growth, can save water resources. On the other hand, multiple aeration during rice cultivation can effectively reduce methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions.
VCS Proponent:
Hunan Yueyang Huabanqiao Market Development Co., Ltd.
Hunan Province, China
peng20876275@163.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: MK Group Energy Biogas Plant
description:
MK Group is a Serbian holding company which has four Divisions: 1. Agribusiness (which includes: Farming, Meat, Sugar); 2 Tourism & Real State; 3. Energy; 4. Support. 
MK Group has developed a mitigation project called MKG Energy Biogas Plant. 
This is a biogas-to-energy conversion project that will generate renewable energy by capturing biogas -from organic waste- which will be the fuel to produce thermal and electrical energy through the use of a cogeneration system. The project is developed in Vrbas, Serbia. The proposed project activity has total number of two cogeneration engines installed at the biogas power plant, with the capacity of 1.2 MWe/h each. The annual feed-in electricity is estimated to be 19,920,000 KWh/a; and heat energy recovery equivalent of 19,200 MWh/a. 
The 5% of electricity generated from the project activity would be used for self-consumption. Resulting that 18,924 MWh/a of electricity will be sold up to the Serbian National Grid. With reference to thermal energy, the Biogas plant will self-consume the equivalent of 5,000 MWh/a; whilst 14,200 MWh/a, will be sent to CARNEX (a company that belongs to MK Group). The total emission reduction average for the project activity is per year.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents

title: Bugnavilla Afforestation Through High-Quality Timber Over Degraded Grasslands
description:
Bugnavilla is a grouped project located in center east region of Uruguay. The project initially comprises a total of 1.984,2 ha of land previously under extensive grazing by beef cattle, on which afforestation for obtaining high value, long lived timber products and for sequestering large amounts of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere will be established. The project ´s first instance will be in “El Tembetarí” property, in the department ( of Treinta y Tres, Uruguay. Forests are based on 25 year rotation Eucalyptus spp. plantations, mostly managed with pruning and three thinning operations, to obtain knot free, high diameter logs suitable for sawing or plywood
production. Plantation will be completed by year 1 of proje ct and forests will be replanted after clear cut harvest. The practices are not certified with the FSC standard. Although they are carried out as if they were, because in the near future it is intended to FSC certified.
VCS Proponent:
Bugnavilla SAS
Montevideo, Uruguay
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Core Carbon Sustainable Rice Productions 04
description:
Paddy fields are the most dominant anthropogenic sources of methane to the atmosphere (5-20% of the total emission from all anthropogenic sources ). Anaerobic decomposition of organic material in flooded rice fields produces methane, which escapes to the atmosphere primarily by transport through the rice plants. The annual amount of CH4 emitted from a given area of rice is a function of the number and duration of crops grown, water regimes before and during the cultivation period, and organic and inorganic soil amendments. Soil type, temperature, and rice cultivar also affect CH4 emissions. This CH4 emission-intensive cultivation method will be targeted by the proposed programme, that will involve the implementation of the technology/measures that result in reduced anaerobic decomposition of organic matter in rice cropping soils and thus reduced generation of methane.
The project activity comprises of grouped projects of rice fields implementing the following methods:
 (a) Rice farms that change the water regime during the cultivation period from continuously to intermittent flooded conditions and/or a shortened period of flooded conditions;
(b) Alternate wetting and drying method (AWD)
(c) Rice farms that change their rice cultivation practice from transplanted to direct-seeded rice (DSR).
Thus, the measure will consist of AWD and/or DSR in combination with adjusted water management system in rice cultivation.
The Project Activity Instances will be implemented in Kamareddy district in the state of Telangana.  Each instance will be of 5000 Hectares will be implemented in Kamareddy, Telangana State.
VCS Proponent:
Core CarbonX Solutions Pvt. Ltd.
Andhra Pradesh, India
00919908387772
nmohanty@corecarbonx.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
VCS Project Validator: TUV SUD South Asia Private Limited

title: Bekmezci Biogas Energy Power Plant
description:
Bekmezci Biogas Power Plant, built and operated in Çankırı Province, Şabanözü District, Gürpınar Village has an installed capacity of 4.68 MWe/ 4.818 MWm as per the generation license. The purpose of the project activity is to produce electricity from laying chicken and cattle manure with biomethanization process. The biogas that will be released during the biodegradation of organic wastes is used for electricity, hot water and heat production in the cogeneration unit. The total power of the cogeneration system to be established will be designed to be 4,818 MWm – 4,680 MWe. Bekmezci Biogas Power plant has been granted the generation license from EMRA on 10/06/2021. As per the generation license, the annual expected generation is 35,100,000 kWh/year.

It is estimated that the project help reduce the carbon emissions average by 88,251 tons annually. The total emission reduction for the whole crediting period is calculated as 882,506 tons of CO2.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents

title: Gansu Longnan Afforestation Project
description:
Gansu Longnan Afforestation Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is located in the suburbs of Cheng County, Tanchang County, Hui County, Kang County, Li County, Liangdang County, Wen County, Wudu District, and Xihe County, Gansu Province of China, whose aim is to increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by planting trees on degraded lands.
12,805.82 ha (192,087.26 Mu ) of forest is to be planted by direct planting native species and the species cultivated on local ecosystem for over 30 years  on degraded lands in Longnan City, and the planted species trees includes Platycladus orientalis (Cypress), Larix gmelinii (Pinaster), Robinia pseudoacacia (Robinia), Ulmus pumila (Elm), Picea asperata (Spruce). 
The implementation of the project would generate GHG emission removals and mitigate climate change; improve soil and water conservation and forest cover; enhance local biodiversity by increasing the connectivity of forests; bring job opportunities and increase income for local communities and residents by providing their relevant technical skills and training.

title: Henan Luoning IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project
description:
Henan Luoning IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project (hereafter referred as “the
project”) is located in Luoning County, Luoyang City, Henan Province, China. The project is to
protect forest from logging to generate GHG emission reductions and contribute to local
sustainable development. Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged
based on a government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The
implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG
emissions.
The project type is “Improved Forest Management: Logged to Protected Forest (LtPF)”. The
project start date is 01/04/2020, and the project area is 9,451.55 ha. The species of this project
are Robinia, Chinese pine, Hard Broad and Cypress.
With the implementation of the project activity, total GHG emission reductions or removals are
about 4,118,556 tCO2e in 30 years the average annual emission reduction is 137,285 tCO2e and
total GHG emission reductions or removals with buffer deduction is about 3,212,467 tCO2e in 30
years, the average annual GHG emission reductions or removals with buffer deduction is 107,082
tCO2e.

title: Heilongjiang Hulin Improved Agricultural Land Management Project
description:
Heilongjiang Hulin Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereafter as “the project”) is located in Hulin City, Jixi City, Heilongjiang Province of China. The goal of this initiative is to reduce the carbon emissions currently emitted by the farms taking part to the project and raise the carbon stored in the soil. In addition, the selected measures will contribute to improving crop yields and soil health.
The project is aimed to prevent the soil degradation through adoption of the improved crop land management practices (collectively referred to conservational tillage) to replace the conventional cultivation mode.

title: REDD Carbonflor
description: The REDD Carbonflor is a multi-activity grouped project, located in Brazil, in the Amazon and Cerrado biomes. The project is classified in scope 14 - AFOLU (Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Uses) and falls into the category Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD) in the scopes of planned (APD) and unplanned (AUDD) deforestation. The REDD Carbonflor´s main goal is to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) through the conservation of native vegetation in the Amazon and Cerrado biomes. The project is based on the conservation of the remaining forest cover of properties under pressure from deforestation and degradation.

title: Ground-Truth Australian Orchards
description:
Regenerative farming practices have been proposed as a means to reduce the climate impact and carbon footprint of agriculture by, inter alia, enhancing the ability of agricultural soils to store carbon, buffering food production systems from environmental changes, improving water and nutrient use efficiency, and removing CO2 from the atmosphere. 
For this project, which encompasses regenarative orchards in Australia, GHG reductions and removals will be achieved by the implementation of a combination of the following practice changes: 
•	Reduce the intensity of agricultural practices, specifically reducing the use of synthetic fertilisers by incorporating organic amendments, and reducing the use of chemical pesticides via improved integrated pest management 
•	Cover cropping, including promoting inter-row biomass generation and the establishment of multi-species cover crops
•	Establishment of new permanent tree crops and associated canopy growth
•	Promote specific regeneration of soil and the increase of soil organic carbon (SOC)
•	Reduce water consumption and energy use through improved irrigation management 
•	Promote carbon sequestration in the above ground biomass
•	Improved crop residue management by re-incorporating prunings and crop waste into the soil
The undertaking of this project will support a number of United Nations Sustainable Development Goals in the project area, local communities, surrounding environments, and in the supply chain. The project will contribute towards SDG 2: Zero Hunger, SDG 3: Good Health and Wellbeing, SDG 6: Clean Water and Sanitation, SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production, SDG 13: Climate Action, SDG 14: Life Below Water, and SDG 15: Life on Land.
VCS Proponent:
Carbon Friendly Pty Ltd.
Queensland, Australia
+61 417 743 402
mariki@carbonfriendly.com.au
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Qinghai Haixi Ulan Afforestation Project
description:
Qinghai Haixi Ulan Afforestation Project (hereafter as “the project”) is located in Ulan County, Haixi Mongolian and Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Qinghai Province of China. The aim of the project is to increase carbon sequestration and to contribute to the local sustainable development by planting the trees and shrubs on the degraded mountains and degraded land.
7,045.27 ha of forest is about to be planted by direct planting on the degraded mountain and degraded land in Ulan County, and the planted species are all native species including Tamarix chinensis (Chinese tamarisk), Populus (aspen), Caragana korshinskii and Artemisia desertorum. The implementation of the afforestation project will generate GHG emission removals and mitigate climate change, improve soil and water conservation and forest cover; enhance local biodiversity by increasing the connectivity of forest, and bring income and job opportunities for local communities and residents.
VCS Proponent:
National Forestry and Grassland Administration Northwest Investigation and Planning Institute
Shaanxi, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Qinghai Ulan and Delingha Improved Grassland Management Project
description:
Qinghai Ulan and Delingha Improved Grassland Management Project (hereafter referred to as “the project”) is located in Haixi Mongol and Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture , Qinghai Province, China. The project aims to restore 70,860 hectares (or 1,062,900 Mu ) degraded grasslands in Ulan and Delingha by adopting a variety of measures including grass planting, fence installation and sustainable grazing management. The project will increase carbon sequestration, reverse grassland degradation, contribute to local development and preserve cultural traditions.
The project focuses on 70,860 hectares of moderately or severely degraded grasslands in Ulan and Delingha and adopts a combination of the following measures:  
· Grass planting: native grass species Elymus nutans, Festuca sinensis, Poa crymophila are directly planted on severely degraded grassland.
· Fence installation: fences are installed to separate the project area from the rest of the land.
· Sustainable grazing management: depending on the grassland conditions and the timeline, different grazing approaches will be adopted: grazing will be prohibited for two years after the completion of grass planting and fence installation on severely degraded grassland; rotational grazing or rest periods of grazing will be introduced on moderately degraded grassland.

title: Siziwang Banner Improved Grassland Management Project
description:
Siziwang Banner Improved Grassland Management Project aims to restore the degraded grassland ecosystem through grass-planting and grazing management in the project zone. This project locates in Siziwang Banner , Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region of China. It covers the entire grassland area of Siziwang Banner, including 13 minor administrative districts under the jurisdiction of the banner. By introducing sustainable grazing measures and managing the plants properly, this project is expected to increase local carbon sequestration and contribute to the development of the local ecosystem. 
Specifically, this project anticipates scientific management of 1966396.34 ha of degraded grassland in total to mitigate and reverse the degradation. Three main restoration measures are adopted, including rotational grazing, rest grazing and grassland reseeding.
This project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 54,091,628tCO2e in 40 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 1,352,291 tCO2e.
The objectives of this project include bringing benefits to three main aspects, climate, community, and biodiversity.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: 1MTN Uganda Bamboo Planting Project
description: The 1MT Nation Uganda Bamboo Planting project -the Project is an AFOLU project, located in Uganda. The project is located on depredated land - grassland, not used for many decades and/or land that has been heavily farmed for many decades, following the clearing of the native ecosystem many decades ago. An afforestation project has been designed to plant and maintain selected species of giant clumping bamboo. The Project is a grouped project, located in Uganda. Using native bamboo species, the Project aims to restore 10,000 hectares of degraded lands that were cleared of their native ecosystem more than 10 years ago.

title: Community Restoration of Native Ecosystems in Ghana
description: Community Restoration of Native Ecosystems in Ghana is a landscape-scale reforestation project designed by Three Trees and Climate Investment Partners that aims to increase tree cover in various regions of rural Ghana by planting native species on degraded communal lands or forest reserves. This reforestation will contribute to wildlife habitat or corridors, improve water infiltration, control erosion, and sequester carbon, among other ecosystem services. This grouped project is targeting a scale of up to 50,000 hectares.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Wetlands Along the Yangtze River and Dongting Lake Restoration Project in Junshan
description:
Wetlands along the Yangtze River and Dongting Lake Restoration Project in Junshan (hereafter as “this project”) is an initiative to promote climate change mitigation and adaptation, maintain biodiversity, and create improved livelihoods, well-being, and employment for wetland-dependent communities in the Project Zone. The Project Zone is an area of 13093.19 ha located in the northeast of Junshan District, Yueyang City, Hunan Province, China. By sowing grass, cutting down invasive poplars, planting native vegetation, and digging ditches, this project is expected to increase local carbon sequestration and contribute to the development of the local wetland ecosystem.
This project anticipates mitigating or reversing the degraded wetlands and rewetting the drained wetlands in the 1,297.76 ha of wetlands in the project area. The invasive species Populus Canadensis, which may damage the wetlands, is also expected to be eliminated during the project’s lifetime.
This project anticipates the sequestration of an estimated 498,492tCO2e over its lifetime of 50 years at an estimated average of 9,774tCO2e annually.
The objectives of this project include bringing benefits to three main aspects including climate, community, and biodiversity. It will meet the Gold Level criteria for both climate change adaptation and biodiversity as demonstrated in the PD Report.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Productive Second Floor with Macaúba
description:
The “Productive Second Floor with Macaúba” is a VCS AFOLU (Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use) grouped project, Scope 14, and, specifically, it falls under the ARR (Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation) category. 
The project works with local farmers to implement integrated systems in previously degraded pastures and/or croplands. The main project activity consists of the planting of Macaúba trees. This will be done considering two possible arrangements: (i) Macaúba intercropped with pasture (silvipastoral) or (ii) macuaba intercropped with agriculture (agrisilvicultural).
Through the planting of Macaúba trees the project will contribute to an increase in carbon stocks and associated GHG removals. The project activity will also improve the livelihood of local farmers and provide other ecosystem services, such as: maintaining the local microclimate, preventing erosion, conserving soil and moisture.
State/Province: Minas Gerais, São Paulo and Pará States
VCS Proponent:
INOCAS
38700140, Brazil
contato@inocas.com.br
www.inocas.com.br
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Grouped Hydro Power Project by EKI Energy Services Limited
description: The project serves the purpose of producing clean electrical energy in a sustainable manner. The project activity involves implementation of 2 turbines of 9.51 MW Mai Beni Hydropower Project (MBHP) and 6.2 MW Lower Jogmai Khola Hydropower Project (LJKHP) which utilize potential energy available for power generation. Therefore, no fossil fuels are involved for power generation in the project activity. The proposed project activity will also reduce the anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere by avoiding business as usual operation of existing fossil fuels-based power plants to produce equivalent amount of electricity
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Validator: TUV SUD South Asia Private Limited

title: Itamarati Grouped REDD Project
description:
The Itamarati Grouped REDD Project is initially formed by 4 properties  located in the municipalities of Nova Olímpia, Denise, Barra dos Bugres, Salto do Céu and Reserva do Cabaçal in the State of Mato Grosso, Brazil. Instance 1 is located in the Amazon and Cerrado biomes. The total area of the properties is 69,207.15 ha. The project aims to avoid the unplanned deforestation (AUD) within the 22,753.36 ha project area, consisting of 64% Amazon rainforest and 36% Cerrado. The present REDD project is expected to avoid predicted 4,861 ha of deforestation, equating to 1,264,521 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime, with an annual average of 42,151 tCO2e.

In addition to the project’s ecological and carbon benefits, a proportion of the carbon credits generated will be dedicated to improving the social and environmental conditions in the project region, specifically contributing to improving deforestation control, aiming at the propagation of environmental awareness, generation of alternative sources of income and environmental education actions.
VCS Proponent:
Future Carbon Holding S.A.
São Paulo, Brazil
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Serenity Valley REDD Project
description:
The Serenity Valley REDD Project is located in three different municipalities in a private propert in the State of Pará, Brazil: Cumuaru do Norte, Santana do Araguaia and Santa Maria das Barreiras consisting of 100% Amazon rainforest. The project aims to avoid the unplanned deforestation(AUD) within the 52,644.73 ha project area. The present REDD project is expected to avoid a predicted 19,220 ha of deforestation, equating to 6,251,508 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime, with an annual average of 208,384 tCO2e.

In addition to the project’s ecological and carbon benefits, a proportion of the carbon credits generated will be dedicated to improving the social and environmental conditions in the project region, specifically contributing to improving deforestation control, aiming at the propagation of environmental awareness, generation of alternative sources of income and environmental education actions.

title: Urupianga Grouped REDD Project
description:
The project area is located within 6 private properties, located in the municipality of Vila Rica, inthe State of Mato Grosso, Brazil , inserted in an area of transition from Cerrado to Amazon biome. The project aims to avoid unplanned deforestation (AUD) in a project area of 13,351 ha. The AUD REDD project is expected to avoid predicted deforestation of 6,214.13 ha of deforestation, equating to 2,309,793 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime (01-February-2021 to 31-January-2051), with an annual average of 76,993 tCO2e.

Beyond the project’s ecological and carbon benefits, a proportion of the carbon credits generated will be dedicated to improving the social and environmental conditions in the project region, specifically contributing to improving deforestation control, and developing environmental education and other social activities.

title: Strengthening rural livelihood through carbon finance: Agroforestry practices in Lucknow Forest Circle of Uttar Pradesh
description: Agroforestry practices as an alternate to fulfil the rising demand for timber and other non-timber forest produce is promising in long term as it provides both wood and food. Agroforestry can help to conserve and rehabilitate the ecosystem along with providing better livelihood opportunities to the rural community. The proposed ARR VCS project plans to promote sustainable agroforestry for small-scale farmers to provide them with financial benefits and ensure GHG mitigation in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India.

Department of Environment, Forest and Climate Change, Government of Uttar Pradesh
Uttar Pradesh, India
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: The High Impact Soil Carbon Program of Lithuania
description:
The High Impact Soil Carbon Program of Lithuania is a joint initiative between UAB Heavy Finance (HF) farmers within the Lithuanian Republic borders. The program utilizes private capital to implement, and adopt improved agricultural land management for a long-term period, thus changing the mindset and establishing climate change mitigation and biodiversity-friendly practices.  						
It is a first-of-its-kind program in Lithuania and the Baltics. It aims to assist farmers in overcoming barriers that prevent adopting sustainable land management practices by providing scientific knowledge, training, and technical and financial support to adopt mitigating climate activities successfully. The program is designed to expand over time and cover a range of conservational farming practices in Lithuania to help drive the change from the current conventional agriculture toward resilient and sustainable agrifood systems.

UAB Heavy Finance
Vilnius, Lithuania
+37061414446

title: Sustainable coffee landscapes in indigenous rural communities of Oaxaca, Mexico
description:
This project is designed to support the livelihoods of at least 3,250 smallholder coffee producers from which at least 1,000 are women, in the State of Oaxaca, Mexico , by increasing the resilience of their coffee production systems after the impact caused by coffee rust. These producers are affi liated to the 45 cooperatives of CEPCO, The project will help CEPCO pursue and accelerate its efforts to restore coffee landscapes by focusing in areas with best potential for high adoption and technical success, around 4 main planting systems: New shade grown coffee systems set up on good potential plots (2,062 ha). Increased shade in existing coffee plots (3,300 ha). Productive forest set up (timber) in degraded land (1,031 ha). Diversification pilots on cocoa and maize/fruit trees intercropping (100 ha)
The 45 cooperatives members of CEPCO represent a total of 142 communities organized in 6 clusters: Cañada, Costa, Istmo. Mixteca, Papaloapam, Sierra Norte, Sierra Sur distributed in
several landscapes in Oaxaca state. Project beneficiaries will be farmers members of CEPCO and their families, who will join on a voluntary basis. It will consider a gender approach in which specific needs for women and youth will be identified and incorporated as much as possible in the activities and project tools. Plots will be selected in degraded and open lands, for new plantations of shaded coffee and timber plots. 3,300 hectares will be areas with already established in coffee plantations with some shade w h ere 50 trees per ha will be added to enrich the tree cover.
The Project activities are carried out according to the approved project methodology AR ACM0003 for the crediting period of 20 years. The project aims to remove ACM0003 for the crediting period of 20 years. The project aims to remove an estimated 54.675,24 tCO2e annually and 1,093.504,78 tCO2e during the crediting period.
VCS Proponent:
Livelihoods Fund SICAV SIF
Paris, France
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Bamboo Afforestation in Malawi
description:
The Malawi Bamboo Afforestation Project will distribute seedlings of giant bamboo, Dendrocalamus asper, to individual agricultural homesteads in rural Malawi. The project will also provide educational support and outreach for the long-term care of bamboo clumps. 

The project is located within the political boundary of the Republic of Malawi.

The project will generate GHG emission reductions by sequestering carbon in live above- and belowground biomass. When individual bamboo clumps reach the end of their lifespan, they will be replaced by a new clump, ensuring carbon remains sequestered over the project lifetime.

Smallholder agricultural homesteads are widespread across Malawi. A variety of trees are grown on farms, in gardens, and around homesteads to serve as fuel, timber, and other uses. However, fast-growing giant bamboo is not grown in Malawi at a large scale. 

Estimated annual average GHG emissions reductions: 174,301 tCO2e
Total GHG emission reductions: 5,054,739 tCO2e
VCS Proponent:
C-Quest Capital SG Africa Holdings Private Limited
Singapore
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Otog Front Banner sustainable grassland management project
description: Otog Front Banner Sustainable Grassland Management Project is located in Otog Front Banner, Ordos City, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region of China. The project is aimed to restore the local degraded grassland ecosystem from adoption of sustainable grassland management practices, such as improving the rotation of grazing animals between summer and winter pastures, limiting the timing and number of grazing animals on degraded pastures, and restoration of severely degraded land by replanting with perennial grasses and ensuring appropriate management over the long-term. Totally, 100,297.9 ha of degraded grassland has been managed scientifically by including by fence building and reseeding of native grass species.

description: The proposed grouped project activity is a step towards supporting the implementation and installation of solar rooftop and ground mounted projects in the premises of Lahore, Pakistan. The main goal of project activity is to implement renewable energy projects in the country and the significant importance of revenues from sale of Verified Carbon Units (VCUs) to achieve this goal forms the basis of the implementation of this project activity. title: Seringueira REDD+ Project
description: The Seringueira Project is implemented in the municipality of Ipixuna, Amazonas State, Brazil. It falls under the Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Uses (AFOLU) sector within the Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD+) category The project will conserve 2,773.79 hectares of native Amazon rainforests in a region where deforestation pressure is mainly due to pasture activities, designated to Planned Avoided Deforestation (APD). For the total area and by the end of the project, it is estimated a total avoided emissions of 1,100,000.00 tons of Greenhouse Gases (tCO2e). The project will be developed considering the CCB Standard, with benefits for Climate, Community and Biodiversity. As benefits to the climate, the maintenance of forest cover results in exceptional benefits for adapting to the impacts caused by climate change, such as changes in the rainfall regime, as the area presents a dense hydrographic network that contributes to the provision and quality of water in the Amazon River basin. As benefits to the communities, the project will implement systems of underground water collection, installation of solar panels for electricity generation, provision of satellite internet service, construction of toilets with septic tanks, training of fire brigades, training of women in entrepreneurship, provision of assistance in the formation of community associations, and construction of a school. These measures will enable water security and access to information to minimize the impacts caused by climate change in traditional, low-income extractive communities.The maintenance of forest cover ensures the conservation of biodiversity, the maintenance of ecosystem functioning (e.g., nutrient cycling) and of ecosystem services provisioning (e.g., carbon sequestration) performed by living organisms. It is noteworthy that the project includes a high priority area for biodiversity conservation, according to the CCB Gold Level vulnerability criteria.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Northeast Anhui Improved Cropland Management Project
description:
The project activity is in Suzhou City, Bengbu City and Huaibei City within the boundary ofNortheast Anhui, eastern province in China. The climate type of Northeast Anhui is seasonal
temperate semi-humid monsoon climate. The project involves 160,120 hectares of wheat field, 31,734 hectares of corn field and 181,110 hectares wheat and corn rotation field. The scenario existing prior to the project’s implementation is primarily conventional tillage with synthetic fertilizer and without straw returning, which cause greater soil disturbance, increase the loss of SOC and nitrous oxide emission. Conventional practices require a significant amount of chemical and energy input and are also more likely to weaken the ecology of a landscape
compared to the improved ALM practices advocated by this project. The estimated annual average GHG emission reductions and removals through the implementation of SALM activities in the agricultural land is 764,964 t CO2e year. Over the 20 years of the first crediting period, the project will generate an estimated removal and reduction of 15,299,274 tCO2e
VCS Proponent:

Anhui Province, China

title: Akalan Biogas Energy Power Plant
description:
Akalan Biogas Power Plant, built and operated in Denizli Province, Acıpayam Distrcit, Akalan Village has an installed capacity of 3.12 MWe/ 3.150 MWm. as per the generation licence, numbered EÜ/10274-1/04999. The purpose of the project activity is to produce electricity from poultry and cattle manure with biomethanization process which will also result in fermented products that could be utilized as fertilizers by local farmers. Akalan Biogas Power plant has been granted the generation license from EMRA on 24/06/2021. As per the generation license, the annual expected generation is 23,400 MWh/year.

The facility is planned to consist of 2 co-generation units. The first unit was commissioned on 30/06/2021, each with an installed capacity of 1.560 MWe. Accordingly, project activity start date is 30/06/2021. The remaining unit with an installed capacity of 1.560 MWe was commissioned on 09/09/2022.The facility is expected to generate 23,400 MWh/year when operational capacity is 3.12 MWe. It is estimated that the project will help reduce carbon emissions by 118,249 tons annually. The total emission reduction for the whole crediting period is calculated as 1.182.494 tCO2e.

title: Greenzone Reforestation Project
description:
Greenzone Reforestation Project is a reforestation and afforestation initiative designed, funded, and implemented by DGB Group. The project will increase tree cover in Cameroon by planting agroforestry crop trees on communal lands where smallholders wish to benefit from the income that perennial nuts and fruits, as well as indigenous trees can provide. This reforestation and afforestation will contribute to regional wildlife habitat or corridors, improve water infiltration, control erosion, and sequester carbon, among other ecosystem services.

Prior to project implementation, thousands of hectares of customary chiefdom land have been degraded to shrubby grasslands surrounding remnant islands of forest.  Individual farmers currently do not have the resources to invest in trees that they are interested in, and their farms lack canopy cover or any sort of perennial cash crops.The project activity will take place across Cameroon, starting in various sub-divisions of Mbam-et-Kim Department, and will involve communities who have access and permission to use customary chiefdom lands. At the individual farm level, the Project solicits a farmer’s needs and ascertains what crop trees are desired, and in what quantity. Contractual agreements are put in place to ensure the survival of these trees for at least forty years, and these varied agroforestry trees—such avocado, citrus, and macadamia—will provide income diversification for the farmers over time, while increasing vegetative cover on agricultural land.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Myanmar Bago 2,450 acres afforestation project
description:
Myanmar Bago 2,450 acres afforestation project of Color Park International Inc. (hereafter “the project) located in Oktwin Township, Taungoo District, Bago Region, Myanmar.
The project’s aim is to increase below benefits by planting Paulownia tomentosa:
- Providing and increasing employment opportunities
- Promoting employment opportunities for female employees
- Legal frameworks in company policy promote, enforce, and monitor any form of discrimination (e.g., discrimination based on gender, race, religion, sexual orientation or other habits) or sexual harassment with respect to the project.
- Substantially increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills
- Substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity
- Creating and developing new wooden buildings, reduce cement buildings, and enhance the meaning of sustainable coexistence between humans and nature
- Increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by planting Paulownia tomentosa
The location of the project.
The project area is located in Oktwin Township, Taungoo District, Bago Region, Myanmar. The plan for total area is 991.7 ha (2,450.6 Acre), cropland is 971.2 ha, (2,400 Acre) and 2.06% Set Aside Conservation area and staff quarters: 20.5 ha (50.6 Arce).
Using the high carbon adsorption properties of Paulownia tomentosa for large-scale planting of Paulownia tomentosa as a way to remove GHG emission.
The state of this afforestation is 10-year-old wasteland with grasses and shrubs not taller than 2.5 meters.
Annual average removals: 105,828.8 tCO2e, Total removals: 5,291,439.8 tCO2e

title: Hunan Shimen IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project
description:
The Hunan Shimen IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project (hereafter “the project activity”) is implemented in Shimen County, Changde City, Hunan Province of China by Shimen County Economic Construction Investment Development Co., Ltd, the geo-coordinate of the project proponent is 110°29'E—111°33'E and 29°16'N-30°08'N, the total area is 39,7000 ha, which includes the Improved Forest Management (IFM) of the forests in the conversion of logged to protected forest.
The area of the project activity is 6475.51 ha, including 2220 subcompartments. All these forests are state-owned forests or privately-owned forests or collective-owned forests, and have the legal right to forest ownership. The species involved in the project are Broadleaf mix and Pinus massoniana.
Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged based on a valid and verifiable government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 623,058 tCO2e in 20 years, the average annual emission reduction is 31,152 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 479,747 tCO2e in 20 years, and average annual VCUs with buffer deduction is 23,987 tCO2e.
The project activity will contribute to the environment (biodiversity conservation, rocky desertification prevention and soil erosion control), thus contribute to sustainable development.

Hunan Province, United States

title: Talihya Nord I Hydro power rural electrification
description:
The region of Butembo and Beni has one of the lowest rates of electricity access (around 3%) in the country and doesn’t have neither an electricity network nor the national electricity company services. The project is providing electricity for the first time to the population of the cities of Butembo and Beni and will be a major step for local SMEs as well. 30,000 households will use this green electricity, replacing diesel generators avai¬lable in limited numbers. Energie du Nord-Kivu SARL (ENK) is using a prepayment sys¬tem allowing the users to follow in real time their energy consumption and better manage their budget (no credit or debt collection). Within households, women are the most positively impacted by the arrival of electricity. In¬deed, they no longer have to fetch tens of kilos of char¬coal several times a week and transport them over many kilometers. They also benefit from a huge time saving when preparing meals and cooking. In addition, thanks to electricity, they can store food in fridges or freezers
The purpose of the project activity is to install and operate a run-of–river, greenfield 9.86 MW hydroelectric plant at Taliyah Nord I and electrify neighbouring communities through an isolated mini-grid, representing the consumption of up to 30,000 households and several small & medium enterprises. At least 75% of the clients in these communities will be households.
The project developer and operator of Talihya Nord Small Hydro Power Plant (SHPP) is ENK.
VCS Proponent:
Energie du Nord-Kivu SARL
Combe, Congo, The Democratic Republic of The

title: REDUCING EMISSIONS FROM DEFORESTATION DUE TO SLASH-AND-BURN CORN BY INTRODUCING CACAO FARMING IN GORONTALO PROVINCE, INDONESIA
description:
This REDD+ project, titled “Reducing Emissions from Deforestation Due to Slash-and-Burn Corn by Introducing Cacao Farming in Gorontalo Province, Indonesia” is located in Gorontalo Province on northern Sulawesi Island in Indonesia. The Project Area is 43,014 ha of forest area in Gorontalo Province, consisting of dry land primary forest and dry land secondary forest. The area of the Reference Region for Deforestation is 185,403 ha in Gorontalo Province, consisting of primary dry land forest, and secondary dry land forest. In Gorontalo Province on Sulawesi Island, food for life and sources of income are dependent on corn crops, coconut palm, cacao, and forest timber and non-timber product extraction. Commercial opportunities for local communities are limited by the unsuitable low purchase
prices practiced by corn intermediates. In the last two decades, deforestation in Gorontalo Province has been observed at a rate of 0.65% per year. The “slash-and-burn” farming of corn is known to be the main factor contributing to deforestation in Gorontalo Province. In short, the main driver of deforestation is the socio-economic condition in this area. Decreasing deforestation will be achieved through a series of activities that are designed to improve the livelihoods of local people. The principal project activity is introducing improved cacao production as an alternative source of income to the slash-and-burn farming of corn. The Project is community-based and consists of the implementation of activities in conjunction with local people. The implementation of the management structure and activities addressing deforestation drivers began on, as well partially after, 2020, together with associated investments. These investments are related to field work, capacities and other related work provided by the project proponent, as well as management work and conservation work such as capacity building, reporting and control activities.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: MANGROVE REFORESTATION IN DANZHOU, HAINAN PROVINCE
description:
The project “Mangrove Reforestation in Danzhou, Hainan Province” (hereafter the project) is located at Danzhou Bay and Xinying Mangrove National Wetland Park, Danzhou, Hainan of China. The project is a mangroves reforetation project under the Reforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation (ARR) category of the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) contributing to carbon sequestration, biodiversity conservation, climate adaptation, and sustainable livelihood. The proponent of the project is Hainan University.
The project is located at Danzhou Bay and Xinying Mangrove National Wetland Park, a hotspot of mangrove biodiversity and conservation in China. After years of protection and management, Danzhou Bay and Xinying Mangrove National Wetland Park has retained the largest area of continuous mangrove forest in western Hainan, and, through many years of popularization of science, the local people's awareness of mangrove wetland protection has increased significantly, creating a good foundation for the project to be implemented. 
The objective of this project is to reconstruct the mangrove ecosystem from previously abandoned aquaculture ponds, enhance biodiversity, increase carbon sequestration of mangroves, and mitigate risks of marine disasters to the coastal communities. The restoration of the pond to its original state will expand the area of mangroves and the mangrove forest belt in Danzhou Bay, creating a complete mangrove shelterbelt. This will also establish a complete vegetation sequence along the coastline, including sea surface, tidal flat, mangrove, semi-mangrove, and terrestrial plants, thereby enhancing the structure and function of the mangrove ecosystem. This will improve the habitat of birds and marine organisms. The mangroves will play a crucial role in maintaining the coastal ecological function and biodiversity, as well as protecting the lives and property of the villagers residing around the bay.
VCS Proponent:
Hainan University
Hainan, China
15522502486
994369@hainanu.edu.cn
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: The Carbon Farming Program of Lithuania
description: The Carbon Farming Program of Lithuania is a joint initiative between UAB Heavy Finance (HF) and farmers within the Lithuanian Republic borders. The program utilizes private capital to implement and adopt improved agricultural land management long-term, thus changing the mindset and establishing climate change mitigation and biodiversity-friendly practices. The Program aims to reward farmers for the positive results of fostering improved agricultural land management practices by sharing the revenue obtained from the sale of VCUs generated through the verified greenhouse gas emissions reductions and removals projects. Project activities are helping farmers to reach the balance in the triple bottom line - economic, environmental, and social. Improved agriculture land management refers to the techniques that focus on soil health and fertility by storing and increasing organic carbon, reducing anthropogenic gasses from excessive use of chemical fertilizers in the context of the offered program, accelerating changes to pre-existing agricultural management practices, and adopting regenerative methods.
VCS Proponent:
UAB Heavy Finance
Vilnius, Lithuania
+37061414446
violeta@heavyfinance.eu
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Combating climate change with sustainable agriculture and land use management project by Indian Farmers
description:
The proposed VCS Agricultural Land Management project activity aims to implement organic farming to reduce the greenhouse gases emission of Carbon dioxide, Methane, and Nitrous oxide through enhancing soil carbon pool, reducing use of chemical fertilizer, making compost out of biomass residue, and fuel saving through lesser consumption of agricultural machineries.  Along with the reduction of greenhouse gases, the project also aims to increase the capacity of soil to sequester carbon and enhance nutrients by mulching through organic material, and assimilation of compost and vermicomposting manure. Prior to the project implementation –The farmers in the proposed project were managing their farmlands and agriculture using conventional farming which was causing high GHG emission. 
The project started on 17 June 2020 in the Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh state of India.
The project is estimated to reduce emission by 57127 tCO2/annum and total 5,71,272 tCO2 throughout its crediting period of 10 years

title: Malatya 2 Landfill Gas Power Plant Project
description:
The Malatya Solid Waste Management System and Electricity Generation Facility (4.242 MWe) is situated in the province of Malatya, in the Merkez District, Kapıkaya neighborhood, and is owned and operated by Biotrend. The facility is designed to process municipal waste from Kapikaya province, classified as type-2 sanitary landfill, and serves a total of 8 districts. The facility consists of four key areas: a sanitary landfill, a mechanical separation facility, a compost facility, and an electricity generation facility.

The Malatya LFG plant has obtained a generation license from EMRA, with an expected annual generation of 31.815.000 kWh/year. The project's initial unit was commissioned on 27.06.2021, with an installed capacity of 1.412 MWe, marking the project's activity start date. The project's renewal crediting period is set at 7 years, with expected average annual emission reductions of 68.115,23 (tCO2e). Through this project, waste is stabilized, waste storage is minimized, electricity is produced, and negative environmental impacts are eliminated.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents

title: Seringueira II REDD+ Project
description: The Seringueira II project will be developed in the municipality of Ipixuna, Amazonas State, Brazil. It falls under the Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Uses (AFOLU) sector within the Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD+) category. The project will conserve 23,851.88 hectares of native Amazon rainforests in a region where deforestation pressure is mainly due to land use conversion activities from forests to pastures aimed at raising livestock. The project area (16,483.02 ha) will be allocated to Avoided Unplanned Deforestation (AUD), and it is estimated that at the end of the project the emission of 591,917.73 tons of Greenhouse Gases will have been avoided. The project will be developed considering the CCB Standard. As benefits to the communities, the project will implement systems of underground water collection, installation of solar panels for electricity generation, provision of satellite internet service, construction of toilets with septic tanks, training of women in entrepreneurship, provision of assistance in the formation of community associations, and construction of a school. These measures will enable water security and access to information to minimize the impacts caused by climate change in traditional, low-income extractive communities. As benefits to the climate, the maintenance of forest cover results in exceptional benefits for adapting to the impacts caused by climate change as the area presents a dense hydrographic network that contributes to the provision and quality of water in the Amazon river basin. The maintenance of forest cover also ensures the conservation of biodiversity, the maintenance of ecosystem functioning and of ecosystem services provisioning performed by living organisms. It is noteworthy that the project includes a high priority area for biodiversity conservation with species classified in the categories Endangered (EN) and Critically Endangered (CR) according to the IUCN red list.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

The project not only helps to create a healthier environment but also provides a valuable source of income for local communities, making it a truly impactful initiative. Furthermore, bamboo's versatility as a food source for wildlife, a sustainable material for construction and furniture, and a potential source of traditional medicine, makes it an invaluable resource for communities in tropical regions.

title: Shanxi Changzhi Sanyuan CMM Power Generation Project
description:
Shanxi Changzhi Sanyuan CMM Power Generation Project (hereinafter referred to as the Project) will utilize the low concentration coal mine methane (CMM) from Sanyuan coal mine for power generation to supply electricity to North China Power Grid (NCPG). The Project is located in the coal mine area of Shanxi Sanyuan Coal Industry Co., Ltd. in the south of Houxizhuang Village, Houbeizhuang Town, the suburb of Changzhi City, Shanxi Province, China.
The purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted CMM with low concentration methane to generate electricity. No coal bed methane (CBM) or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. The designed capacity is 7.6MW. Ten sets of CMM power generators will be installed with a total installed capacity of 7.6MW (6*0.6MW & 4*1MW), destroying 14.5659 million m3 of methane annually. With the full capacity operation of the Project, the expected annually exported electricity will be 40,641 MWh, which will be supplied to NCPG, displacing part of the electricity generated by NCPG which is dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants.
VCS Proponent:
Changzhi Suburb Baoneng New Energy Development Co., Ltd
Shanxi Province, China

title: Salima 60MW Solar PV Project
description:
The Salima 60MW Solar PV Project (hereinafter the “proposed project” or the “project activity” or the “project”) is a greenfield grid-connected solar photovoltaic power plant with installed capacity of 60 MWp, which is located in Kalonga Traditional Authority, Salima District, Malawi. The project owner is JCM Matswani Solar Corporation Limited.

The purpose of the project is to utilize solar resources for electricity generation through the construction of a solar PV power plant with a total capacity of 60 MW and to deliver the electricity generated from the project (157,000MWh per annum) to the power purchaser, i.e. Electrical Supply Corporation of Malawi Limited (ESCOM) and is transferred to the national grid via the existing ESCOM Nanjoka substation. The project has achieved commercial operation on 28/10/2021.

By replacing the electricity supplied by the ESCOM grid, which includes hydropower plants, diesel power plants, and coal fired power plants, with electricity generated from solar power the proposed project activity will achieve obvious greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions by avoiding CO2 emissions.
VCS Proponent:
Salima JCM Solar Corporation Limited
Lilongwe, Malawi

The project owner is Golomoti JCM Solar Corporation Limited.

The purpose of the project is to utilize solar resources for electricity generation through the construction of a solar PV power plant with a total capacity of 20 MW and to deliver the electricity generated from the project (59,000MWh per annum) to the power purchaser, i.e. Electrical Supply Corporation of Malawi Limited (ESCOM) and is transferred to the national grid via the existing ESCOM Nanjoka substation. The project has achieved commercial operation on 14/03/2022.

description:
The “Improved cropland management project in Anyang” is aimed to raise farmer's awareness on the benefits of sustainable agriculture and how to change the agricultural practices to help in climate change mitigation and adaptation. The project will assist farmers to overcome barriers that prevent adoption of improved agricultural land management practices and provide technical assistance where needed. The objectives of the project is to reduce emissions from agricultural practices and increase soil carbon storage, in order to achieve these, a package of practices that change the pre-existing agricultural management activities will be carried out, the specific activities are the following:

B. Reduce tillage/improve residue management; and
C. Improve crop planting and harvesting.

title: Guinan Grassland Sustainable Management Project
description:
Guinan Grassland Sustainable Management Project (hereafter“the project” ) is located in Hainan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Qinghai Province, China. The project aims to restore the local degraded grassland ecosystem through fence construction, degraded grassland improvement and pest control on the degraded grassland to increase carbon sink capacity, and contribute to local development by the adoption of rational grazing and sustainable management of grassland over a long time.
Totally,107,326.16 ha of degraded grassland has been managed sustainably by seeding grass, pest control and fence construction. The project implements fence construction mainly containing rotational grazing and rest grazing in the degraded grassland to achieve sustainable grassland management. Degraded grassland improvement  has been managed sustainably by the implementation of seeding, reseeding, applying fertilizer and Black soil beach management. And,the project also implemented pest control to restore degraded grassland and improve soil carbon storage.

title: Afforestation project with native and exotic species on degraded grasslands in Northeast, Argentina.
description: The project activity is an afforestation project on multiple farms of extensive grazing lands. The overreaching goal is to promote innovative afforestation management activities on degraded lands. By combining native and exotic species to produce high-quality wood and other non-woody products and, in the long term, to generate new patches of managed native species forests. The grouped Project is located in Corrientes Province, in the Northeast region of Argentina (host country) and could include areas in the contiguous south of Misiones Province.  In this region, grazing and agriculture lands have different levels of degradation due to a long history of use without sustainable management. The activities proposed in the Project could stop the degradation processes and enhance the regional environmental conditions. For the design of the plantations, specific local conditions are considered to determine where species will be planted to promote facilitation strategies between them. Exotic species have favorable competition conditions over native ones (e.g., in standing flooded areas), but in return, they help native species with their development, protecting them from frosts, wind, and high radiation. Through forest plantation of native and exotic species, the Project sequesters CO2 by generating net anthropogenic removals by sinks that can be measured, monitored, and verified with known tools and approaches, contributing to the country's sustainable development.The initial activity instance comprises 2,331 hectares of degraded grassland generating an estimated average (long-term average) of ≈775.509 tCO2e net GHG emissions reductions and removals, implying a total GHG benefit for the environment of approximately ≈19.387. tCO2e per year for the length of the project (40 years).
