title: Guizhou Zhongzhichang CMM Power Generation Project
description:
Guizhou Zhongzhichang CMM Power Generation Project (hereinafter referred to as the Project) will utilize the low concentration coal mine methane (CMM) from Zhongzhichang coal mine for power generation to supply electricity to the coal mine where the Project is located and to China Southern Power Grid (CSPG) if there is any electricity surplus. The Project is located in Hongguo Town, Panzhou City, Liupanshui City, Guizhou Province, China.
The purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted CMM with low concentration methane concentration to produce electricity. No coal bed methane (CBM) or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. Seven sets of CMM power generators will be installed with a total installed capacity of 6.4MW (2*0.7MW+5*1MW), destroying 12.1 million m3 of methane annually. At the first operation year, it is expected the installed capacity will be 3.4MW (2*0.7MW+2*1MW). After the full operation of the Project after the second operation year, the expected annual exported electricity will be 32,998 MWh, which will be supplied to the coal mine first through the electricity distribution network in Zhongzhichang coal mine area, and then to China Southern Power Grid (CSPG) if there is any electricity surplus, replacing the electricity that would otherwise have been purchased from the CSPG and displace part of the electricity generated by CSPG dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants.

title: Sepoti REDD Project
description:
The primary objective of the Sepoti REDD Project is to avoid unplanned deforestation (AUD) of a region within the municipalities of Novo Aripuanã and Borba. The first Project activity instance has 26,062 ha project area, which is within one private properties in Novo Aripuanã, consisting of 100% Amazon rainforest.

It is expected that, with the carbon project, it will be possible to expand the monitoring of the area, hiring new professionals to work on the farms. In addition to the project’s ecological and carbon benefits, a proportion of the carbon credits generated will be dedicated to improving the social and environmental conditions in the project region, specifically contributing to improving deforestation control, aiming at the propagation of environmental awareness, generation of alternative sources of income and environmental education actions.

The present REDD project is expected to avoid predicted 1,888 ha of deforestation, equating to 782,072 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime, with an annual average of 26,069 tCO2e.

description: The Hainan Grassland Sustainable Management Project is located in Hainan Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Qinghai Province, China, with a total area of 184,352.04 hectares. The local grassland environment had already been deteriorating because of overgrazing and climate change before the project was put into action. By reseeding grass and using sustainable grassland management techniques including rest grazing, rotational grazing, hazardous plant control, and insect control, the project aims to restore the local damaged grassland ecosystem. The project enhances the grassland covering, boosts carbon sequestration, and contributes to local development. With an average yearly GHG emission removal of 534,995 tCO2e, the project is expected to produce GHG emission removals of 21,399,792 tCO2e in 40 years.

title: REDD+ Café Apuí Agroflorestal
description:
The REDD+ Café Apuí Agroforestry (CAA) project aims to expand the production chain of agroforestry coffee in southeastern Amazonas and avoid deforestation of native forests on rural properties in the municipalities of Apuí, Manicoré and Novo Aripuanã, in the state of Amazonas, Brazil. In the absence of the project, forests on the participating properties would be cleared for agricultural activities, especially pastures, for income generation.

REDD+ CAA is a 30-year grouped project that will have periodic membership of new participants over the first ten years. The initial project's participants are 42 family farmers (Project Activity Instances – PAI) that totalize a PA of 3.696 hectares around the town of Apuí (50km) in Amazonas State/Brazil. The project has a defined geographical area within which instances of project activities are located, totalling 19,874 km2. This area is composed of native forests and agricultural areas, mainly planted pastures, in addition to some enclaves of non-forest pioneer formations.

The project is based on long-term (30-yr) agreements with landowners to avoid deforestation in their areas in exchange for performance-based payment for avoided deforestation. In addition to monitoring, reporting, verification, and leakage mitigation activities, VCU revenues will be invested in agroforestry implementation, technical assistance, organic certification processes, administration, and marketing of coffee and other agroforestry products. The project aims to expand agroforestry coffee production using agroecological techniques and trained personnel in organic production promoted since 2012 in the region.

The project intends to generate climate, community and biodiversity benefits under CCB standard. The payment for avoided deforestation, investment in the agroforestry coffee chain, and support for the structuring of new agroforestry product chains offer an alternative sustainable income to producers while maintaining conserved forests.
VCS Proponent:

title: Kalahari Grasslands Project
description: Cattle ranching is one of the main pillars of Botswana’s largely agrarian society: livestock is the primary source of subsistence and income for two-thirds of rural households.  Furthermore, Botswana’s urban population is rapidly growing, increasing demand for food, land and fuel. This growth has taken place in tandem with threats to natural resources in the form of  rangeland degradation, loss of grazing habitat, and the over-exploitation of wildlife. The KALAHARI GRASSLANDS PROJECT (KGP) is a grouped project located in the heart of Botswana’s Kalahari, a semi-arid grassland and shrubland ecosystems. Since 2016, Botswana has lost over 800,000+ hectares of Wildlife Management Areas (GH10, GH11, SO2, and KW6) partly due to the ongoing cycle of land degradation and encroachment into nearby areas. The central piece of legislation regulating designated land use on protected wildlife areas is the Wildlife Conservation and National Parks Act of 1992, § 3(15)(2) and enables the President to rezone and/or modify WMAs. Currently, most ranchers across Botswana operate an average ranch of 5 hectares with a few head of cattle and lack an understanding of carrying capacity resulting in overgrazing. The lack of enforcement mechanisms to prevent encroachment past communal grazing lands into WMAs coupled with Big-Agriculture interests converting rangeland into commercial cattle operations has resulted in the degradation of over 91,000 km² or 15.5% of Botswana. The KGP program was launched to provide an alternative to land conversion for landowners and game ranchers located in high-risk areas adjacent to WMAs and other wildlife corridors. By leveraging the voluntary carbon market the KGP protects both the biodiversity and sequestration potential of these critical areas. The main agents of conversion, private landowners, forego their legal right to convert native grasslands, and in doing so avoid GHG emissions totaling over 2.23M mt/CO2e over 10 years.

title: Family Forest Carbon Project
description: Family forests make up over one-third of America’s 765 million acres of forestland, according to a 2021 Congressional report. This fact puts management decisions providing clean water, recreation, and other valuable resources in the hands of everyday American families. The importance of American forests to the global ecosystem and climate is central to the work of Forest Carbon Works, PBC, a US based company that seeks to conserve and restore family-owned tracts of forestland throughout the United States. Forest Carbon Works is acutely aware of vulnerabilities particular to family forest owners. Without an alternative form of income, families face pressures to liquidate their timber to cover unforeseen expenses. By the year 2030, Forest Carbon Works anticipates protecting 500,000 acres of land owned by many individuals with durable agreements of permanent carbon storage. The project longevity shall be at minimum 60 years with possible extension to 100. Extending rotation ages on these at-risk forests increases carbon storage relative to the baseline case, as well as increases biodiversity and diversity in forest structure. Estimated average GHG emission reductions from the project are 845,991 tons CO2 equivalent per year, with total reductions over the first 25-year project crediting period of 21,149,786 tCO2e.  This is a grouped project. The geographic area of the entire project shall encompass is the contiguous United States and southern Alaska. To ensure sustainability in management, Forest Carbon Works requires enrolled forestland to be certified by the Forest Stewardship Council ® (FSC®) under the group certificate SCS-FM/COC-009247 prior to the commencement of any harvesting activities.

Several research in the past (Jarvan et all., 2017 and Chahal et all., 2020) shows that such practices are boon for the farmers as well for the environment.

title: Sichuan Yuexi IFM Project
description:
Sichuan Yuexi IFM Project (herein after referred as “The project”) is located in Yuexi County, Sichuan
Province, China. The geographical coordinates of the project area are 102.389°-102.891°E, 28.332°-
28.857°N. This project improves GHG emissions reductions from forest management practices by
increasing on-land carbon stocks by extending the rotation period of a forest or a small area of forest
before harvesting. By extending the age at which trees are felled, projects increase the average
carbon stock on the land and remove more emissions from the atmosphere.
The total area of the project is 18,959.15 ha in Yuexi County. All the trees are native species,
including Pinus armandi, Alder and Pinus yunnanensis.
The project aims to mitigate the effects of climate change by increasing the average carbon stock on the
land and removing more emissions from the atmosphere by extending the age at which trees are felled,
thereby promoting sustainable forest management, productive activities and improving community
welfare. The project also seeks to protect biodiversity and high conservation values, enhance ecological
connectivity, and protect the natural habitats of vulnerable species, both those under some kind of threat
and those of ecological interest.
Moreover, expected GHG reductions corresponds to an annual average of 239,399 tCO2, so for the
lifetime of 60 years it could demonstrate reductions up to 14,363,970 tCO2.

title: Heilongjiang Meilisi Improved Agricultural Land Management Project
description:
Heilongjiang Meilisi Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is a project that change the pre-existing agricultural manag Heilongjiang Meilisi Improved Agricultural Land Management Project ement activities (conventional tillage) to the conservation agriculture management in fields located in Meilisi Daur district, Qiqihar city, Heilongjiang province, China. 
The project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by applying the conservation agriculture management. The conservation agriculture refers to a sustainable agricultural technology that can reduce farmland soil erosion, protect farmland ecological environment and achieve coordinated development of ecological benefits, economic benefits and social benefits through comprehensive supporting measures such as less tillage, no tillage, irrigation water management, residue management, surface covering and rational planting. Since the conservation agriculture can reduce soil disturbance and reduce the loss of soil organic carbon (SOC). Moreover, the project is expected to increase SOC by straw returning, since straw contains a large amount of organic matter and trace elements such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium, returning straw to the field can effectively use organic fertilizer resources and increase soil organic matter (SOM).

The purpose of the project is to adopt improved agricultural land management practices including returning straw in fields and applying organic fertilizer, and to prevent the severe soil degradation caused by pre-existing conventional tillage in local crop land.

title: Motor Verde+Floresta Forestry Carbon Project. Portugal Central Region I
description:
Refloresta Portugal, Forestry Carbon Project (Central Region I) consists of the implementation of reforestation projects located in burned areas in Portugal. This project is part of Motor Verde, an offsetting initiative promoted by Fundación Repsol, based on Mediterranean forest reforestation and regeneration aiming for a triple goal social, environmental and economic. 
The project proponents of this single project are Grupo Sylvestris and Fundación Repsol. Sylvestris is a forestry consultancy located in Madrid, Spain, specialised in forestry restoration, rural development and environmental consulting, Spain; and Fundación Repsol is the fund responsible for Repsol’s social responsibility vocation. Both entities are connected by the fund's shareholding in Sylvestris. The project counts on Metsä, the project implementing partner, a local forestry consultancy located in Abrantes, Portugal, close to the affected areas to be restored.
The project intends to establish approximately 56,51 ha of Mediterranean forest. Plantations are being established in private-owned land located in the mid-centre of Portugal. These lands have been burned by 2017 and 2019 fires, where natural regeneration is inexistent. 
The project will generate GHG removals by the plantation growing, using native species such as Quercus suber and Pinus pinaster, among others. A total amount of 16,566 tonnes of CO2e are expected to be generated by the implementation of the project, equivalent to an average of 414 tonnes of CO2 per year, taking into account that this amount varies annually depending on the corresponding compensation.
Economic, environmental and social benefits are expected: 
-	recovering burned ecosystems with native species
-	creating jobs in the implementation areas,
-	contributing to minimise the risk of depopulation,
-	investing in natural resources, that allows a sustainable business development,
-	promoting the innovation and research for new technologies application in forestry

title: Yongji MSW Incineration Project
description:
Yongji MSW Incineration Project is located between the Xiachao Village of the Chengbei Street and the Gucheng Village of the Kaizhang town, Yongji City, Shanxi Province, P.R. China. The Project is invested, constructed and operated by Yongji Huaxinda Cleaning Energy Co., Ltd.. 
With two 300t/d MSW combustion production lines, the project will treat 600 tons of MSW per day. The combustion system is composed of two 300t/d mechanical grate incinerators, matched with one set of 12MW steam turbine generator. The project will process 250,000 tons of MSW every year, and consume 130.3 tons of 0# light diesel as auxiliary fuel. The MSW combustion line will work 8,000 hours every year, generating 72,748 MWh electricity, of which 59,972 MWh will be exported to the North China Power Grid (NCPG). The implementation of the project will meet the requirement of local MSW harmless treatment, and significantly improve local environment. Also helps reduce GHG emission that would occur in baseline scenarios such as power generating by fossil-fuel fired plants and MSW treatment at landfill.
By combusting MSW that would otherwise be disposed of at landfill, the project avoids the emissions of methane that would be generated under landfill condition. In the meanwhile, the proposed project can produce steam to generate power to replace the electricity that would otherwise be generated by fossil- fuel fired power plants which are connected to the NCPG. The baseline scenario of this project is the same as the scenario prior to the implementation of the project, namely the landfill gas is vented directly and the equivalent power is supplied by the NCPG.
It is estimated that during the 10-year fixed crediting period of the project (from 30 June 2021 to 29 June 2031), the average annual GHG emission reductions will be 63,176 tCO2e.

title: COMACO Landscape Management Project-South
description:
This project description document covers COMACO operations in part of the Central province (Mumbwa and Shibuyunji districts) and part of Southern province (Itezhi-Tezhi district) of Zambia. The COMACO Landscape Management Project – South (CLMP-South) promotes sustainable agriculture and forest management. The key objectives of the project are to increase smallholder farmer agricultural productivity, provide alternative livelihoods and reduce uncontrolled forest loss and degradation. Hence, the project comprises two components:
1. Sustainable Agricultural Land Management (SALM) component – which aims to promote widespread adoption of agricultural practices including conservation agriculture and agroforest that increases the food production per unit area and farmers’ income. The project promotes the adoption by farmers of legume-based alley cropping, residues management (e.g. mulching; cessation of residue burning), use of organic fertilizers such as composite and animal manure, and reduced tillage among other SALM practices and the intercropping of Gliricidia Sepium as part of Agroforestry to restore soil quality and sequestrate carbon.
2. REDD+ (Avoided Unplanned Deforestation) component – which aims to reduce forest loss, and protect and expand areas under natural forest, and conserve biodiversity. This is achieved primarily through land use planning and creation of Community Conservation Areas (CCAs) for protection of natural forest, coupled with sustainable non-extractive forest use, e.g. honey and mushrooms. The creation of CCAs and the enforcement of by-laws to protect them promotes the protection of ecosystems and biodiversity within and around the CCAs.
VCS Proponent: Community Markets for Conservation (COMACO)
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: PROJECT TOURBA - ADOPTION OF IMPROVED AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES TOWARDS CARBON FARMING IN MOROCCO
description:
The Carbon Credit project in Morocco initiated by Innovx proposes regenerative agricultural practices, focusing on conservation agriculture and crop nutrient stewardship. It aims to enhance agricultural soil health in six regions: Rabat-Salé-Kenitra, Beni Mellal-Khenifra, Marrakech-Safi, Tangier-Tetouan-Al Hoceima, Fes-Meknes (including the provinces of Fes, Meknes, Taounate, El Hajeb, Moulay Yacoub, Sefrou), and Casablanca-Settat (including the provinces of Casablanca, Settat, Berrechid, Benslimane, El Jaddida). The initiative covers 750,000 hectares, starting with 50,000 hectares in the first year and expanding annually.
The project targets application of regenerative agriculture at scale with the help of Employing Sustainable Agricultural Land Management (SALM) technology including conservation agriculture and reduced application of nitrogen, that results in increased crop yields, food security, diversified farmer income, and climate change mitigation through elevated soil carbon and plant biomass.
The Project is aligned with the Moroccan Ministry's goal to transition one million hectares to Zero-tillage by 2030, the project operates with a 10-year crediting period under the VCS-approved Methodology VM0017. Estimated annual average Emission Reductions (ER) reach 1402165, totalling 14021652 over the project duration. This initiative integrates environmental conservation, socio-economic development, and sustainable agriculture in Morocco's specified regions.

title: Transformational Regenerative Integrated Biodiverse Agriculture for Livelihoods (TRIBAL)
description:
The Transformational Regenerative Integrated Biodiverse Agriculture for Livelihoods (TRIBAL) Project is a landscape approach that aims to make it viable for small and marginal farmers to live off their land in a sustainable and profitable manner. 
The project will promote agroforestry and sustainable farming practices across within the Araku Valley in Vishakhapatnam District, Andhra Pradesh, India. Planned agroforestry and sustainable farming practices that will be promoted by the project include agroforestry utilizing both fruit and multi-purpose tree species, shade coffee systems, intercropping of pulses and millets, green manuring, mulching and organic composting. These activities will improve the livelihoods and well-being of the tribal landowners by achieving multiple objectives such as improved soil fertility, increased revenue generation, food security, reduced drudgery for women and increased biodiversity. Through this positive impact on climate, communities, and biodiversity the TRIBAL project aims to achieve both VCS and CCB Gold certification. 
This grouped project is being initiated in Paderu and Pedabayalu Mandals of Paderu Division in Vishakhapatnam District, with the intention of expanding to up to 11 Mandals within the Araku Valley landscape in future. The tribal people of this region were traditionally hunters and gatherers, relying on the forest for sustenance. The practice of shifting cultivation came in at the turn of the century. As the- forest began to get depleted, the tribal communities gradually become engaged in agriculture. Now, subsistence agriculture is the primary livelihood for nearly 99% of the tribes within the project region, with over 80% of the landholdings being less than one hectare in size.

The project includes a range of measures and technologies designed to reduce emissions by promoting regenerative and sustainable farming practices.The activities include efficient use of irrigation water, mulching, reduction of chemical fertilizer and pesticide use through the use of organic amendments, applying green manure, and alternative pest control methods, avoidance of crop residue burning, and minimum tillage.

title: Carbon Group Program for sustainable low carbon crop and grassland management in Argentina II
description:
The project intends to include producers dedicated to extensive agriculture (corn, soybeans, wheat, sunflower, cotton, and other crops), and extensive cattle ranching, mostly cattle and grazing grasslands, pastures, agropastoral, and silvo-pastoral. Given the characteristics of the country, farm and ranch  production dates from no more than 200 years ago.
During most of the 20th century, the farms were managed in a rather extensive manner and with aggressive tillage systems, which caused widespread declines in the organic matter content of the soils. This lasted until the end of that century, when for different reasons the producers adopted zero tillage systems, which are what predominate today (more than 90%).
The projects to be implemented are expected to mitigate climate change both by reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and by capturing atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) and storing it as stable carbon in the soil, which must be recarbonized. The greatest efforts to reduce GHG emissions will be due to the adoption of better nitrogen fertilization technologies, which include alternative sources of nitrogen and variable rate fertilization that reduce nitrous oxide (N2) emissions from fertilized soils, the intensification of agricultural rotations with greater incorporation of winter crops, nitrogen fixing species and cover crops, and improved grazing management in livestock, which increase carbon stocks and with improvements in digestibility that reduce methane (CH4) emissions due to enteric fermentation. 
It is estimated that with these improvements, which are not currently widespread even among producers, it will be possible to reduce between 0.5 and 3 tons of CO2e/ha/year. Obviously, the total amount will depend on the area committed by the producers. This area is expected to reach more than 160 thousand hectares. If this is so, it is expected to mitigate almost 2 million tons CO2e at the end of this project.

Carbon Group Agro-Climatic Solutions LLC

title: CSA Carbon
description: The C-SA Carbon Project focusses on this opportunity to restore subtropical thicket, sequester carbon and to deliver a broader range of social and ecological outcomes. The C-SA property includes a primary conservation area (in which the Kwandwe eco-tourism operation is located) as well as several severely degraded properties that have been acquired over time. The additional areas of at least 4,000 hectares were previously goat and ostrich farms and have been left in a degraded state, largely clear of vegetation and especially Portulacaria afra. The intention is to implement a landscape-scale rehabilitation project that includes the propagation and planting of Portulacaria afra as well as other species, combined with the long-term management of planted propagules and herbivory pressure. Such planting and management has led to the successful restoration of carbon stocks elsewhere in the biome. The outcome will extend beyond carbon sequestration to the delivery of further ecosystem services and a source of employment and income for local residents (in a region where such opportunities are rare). In an area that is predicted to become significantly warmer and drier over time, enhancing the resilient provision of water services to downstream communities and economies is of significant importance. Through direct restoration of over 4,000 hectares, the project is expected to sequester at least 1,078,000 tCO2e over a 40-year period or an average 26,950 tCO2e per year.

title: ARJUNA Project
description:
This project will promote tree-based wild silk production (sericulture) outside traditional forests by utilizing privately owned degraded lands that smallholder farmers currently do not significantly utilize for productive purposes. It will undertake host tree planting for the Tasar silkworm and silkworm rearing value chain development in two states in India: Jharkhand and West Bengal. Traditionally, the tribal communities in these areas depend significantly on forests for their livelihoods and have a long history of silk production from natural forests –silk is second to agriculture as a source of income/livelihoods. However, production from the forests have become uncertain due to government regulation of forest access rights and instability in the silk market. Yet there are large areas in these regions that are severely degraded, fallow, etc. that would benefit from restoring their productive capacity and biodiversity through profitable tree planting investments. Therefore, this project will undertake tree planting for Tasar production on an estimated 3,000 ha of such lands. 
The project is implemented by the Non-Governmental Organization (NGO): PRADAN - Professional Assistance for Development Action – which has a long-standing experience (50 years) in the area. It will involve the participation of ~4,000 households in 117 villages, grouped into two clusters. The project has a crediting period of 20-years renewable, and will employ the new VERRA ARR Methodology ”Methodology for Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation Projects”. Its estimated annual average and total GHG emission removals are 89,847 and 1,796,931 t CO2e respectively.
VCS Proponent:
Livelihoods Fund SICAV SIF
Paris, France
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Makueni Agroforestry Carbon Project
description:
The Makueni Agroforestry Carbon Project (hereafter, “MACP”) is a carbon project in Kenya being developed together by Eni S.p.A. and Eni Kenya b.v. 
MACP will promote the establishment of Sustainable Agricultural Land Management (SALM) practices that will generate high-quality carbon credits, through carbon sequestration. MACP will implement a package of SALM practices, by working with a range of participants to implement these sustainable methods across landscapes in Makueni County, Kenya, particularly focusing on smallholder farms. Project activities will contribute to climate change mitigation, adaptation, and food security. The project has been designed as a grouped project and is targeting to be initially implemented in about 40,000 ha across the County of Makueni, with possibility of expansion into other Counties, since this is a grouped project.
The project has a 20-year crediting period and applies the VCS approved Methodology VM0017 Adoption of Sustainable Agricultural Land Management, Version 1.0. The project’s estimated annual average and total net GHG emission reductions/removals are 155,383 and 3,107,663 tCO2e, respectively.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Chongqing Kaizhou Afforestation Project
description:
Chongqing Kaizhou Afforestation Project (hereafter “the project”) locates in Kaizhou District,Chongqing, China, covering 27 towns, 8 streets, and 5 townships. The project aims to increasethe carbon sequestration and to contribute to local sustainable development through plantingtrees on the degraded land or degraded mountain. The project proponent is National Forestry andGrassland Administration Northwest Investigation and Planning Institute (hereafter “the projectproponent”).
3,407.34 ha of forest has been planted by direct planting on degraded land and degradedmountain in Kaizhou district, there are 6 main species selected as designated tree species, theyare Cunninghamia lanceolata, Phoebe zhennan, Cupressus funebris, Acer spp., Idesia polycarpa,Houpoea officinalis, the planted trees are all native species. The implementation of theafforestation project will generate GHG emission removals and improve the Kaizhou district’slocal environment, enhance the capabilities of local communities and residents by providing themwith relevant technical skills and training and increase local biodiversity as a result ofestablishing a forest of native trees.

Shaanxi, China

title: Subei Sustainable Grassland Management Project Phase II
description: The objective of the project is to restore the degraded grassland ecosystem through the sustainable grassland management practices, such as increasing the rotation of grazing between summer and winter pastures, limiting the grazing days on degraded pastures, and replanting with perennial grasses and ensuring appropriate management over the long-term, thereby increasing carbon sequestration, and promoting local development. Totally, 317,875.91 ha of degraded grassland will be restore in Subei Mongilia Autonomous County, Jiuquan City, Gansu Province, China.

title: TIANZHU IMPROVED GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT PROJECT
description:
Tianzhu Improved Grassland Management Project (hereafter as “the project”) is located in Tianzhu County, Gansu Province of China. Tianzhu County is located in the northwest of Gansu Province and in the middle of Hexi corridor where the Qinghai Tibet Plateau and  Mongolia Plateau meet. The project’s aim is to restore the local degraded grassland ecosystem by seeding grass and building fence on the degraded grassland, increase carbon  sequestration and contribute to local development by introducing sustainable grazing and management of grassland. The project proponent is Zhejiang Zhongzheng Forestry Development Co., Ltd.
According to the baseline survey, before the implementation of the project, the grassland in the region has been facing serious degradation and even desertification due to the impact of climate change and human activities. According to the National standard documents of the people's Republic of China and Project Design Report, moderately  degraded areas refer to the total grass yield decreased by 21%-50%compared with that before degradation and the total grass yield decreased by 50% compared with that before degradation is regarded as seriously degraded grasslands.

title: DR Congo Mangrove Blue Carbon Project
description: The mangrove areas of the Democratic Republic of Congo (fall under the global category grouping of Central African mangrove eco-region. They are found within the Central Congo Province occupying an area of 23,684 hectares.Mangrove forests of DRC are crucial because of its importance in provision of goods and services which are unique to this type of forest such as shoreline protection and being a feeding and breeding ground of commercially important fisheries due to the location of these forests at the tidal estuaries ecosystems of River Congo as well as supporting a wide range of biodiversity. Despite these uses, the DRC Mangrove Forest has seen degradation and deforestation over the years. The threats facing these mangroves include the encroachment of the areas by the nearby communities leading to conversion of forest land to settlement and other land uses that is linked to population increase over the years, coupled with unsustainable harvesting for wood and firewood for varied purposes. Additionally, the loss of mangroves leads to the release o f the carbon stored by the ecosystem back into the atmosphere, thereby accelerating climate change. Through the implementation of the mangrove REDD+ project in the area the project proponents aim to conserve the mangrove areas by addressing the drivers of deforestation leading to a potential emission reduction of 689,274 tCO2e/year. Furthermore, the project proponent also aims to restore the already degraded and deforested area of 1161 ha during the project lifetime that will lead to additional emission reductions of 33,379 tCO2e/yr along with other benefits such as shoreline protection and biodiversity conservation. Thus, this REDD and RWE project is expected to avoid unplanned deforestation and degradation, along with restoration of the already degraded areas on an area of 23,684 ha equating to 21,691,891 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30 year project lifetime with an annual average of 723,063 tCO2e.

title: Guangdong Huaiji County IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project
description:
The Guangdong Huaiji County IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project (hereafter “the project activity”) is implemented in Huaiji County, Guangdong Province of China by Huaiji County Weizhou Construction Investment and Development Group Co., Ltd, the geo-coordinate of the project is 23°28′07″N～24°23′30″N, 110°52′09″E～112°30′49″E, the total area is 355,661.39 ha, which includes the Improved Forest Management (IFM) of the forests in the conversion of logged to protected forest.
The area of the project activity is 14,007.54 ha, including 3,495 subcompartments. All these forests are state-owned forests or privately-owned forests or collective-owned forests, and have the legal right to forest ownership. All the owners authorized the project proponent to access the project to their behalf. The species involved in the project are Pinus massoniana, Chinese Fir and Pinus elliottii. The forest of the project was older plantations under managing. Before the implantation of the project, the usual type of management was clearcutting.
Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged based on a valid and verifiable government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 2,142,484 tCO2e in 20 years, the average annual emission reduction is 107,124 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 1,649,703 tCO2e in 20 years, and average annual VCUs with buffer deduction is 82,485 tCO2e.
The project activity will contribute to the environment (biodiversity conservation, rocky desertification prevention and soil erosion control), thus contribute to sustainable development.
VCS Proponent:
Huaiji County Weizhou Construction Investment and Development Group Co., Ltd
Guangdong province, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: WEST SERAM REDD+ and AGARWOOD ForestWise PROJECT
description: The WSRAFP project serves to preserve natural forest within the West Seram Region of Seram Island, Maluku, Indonesia. The proposed Project intends to engage community in Technology Based Agarwood Silviculture by Afforesting 1000Ha of Agarwood on the longtime degraded grassland and protect and conserve the remaining forest area. The total Project area of 1st phase comprises of 55,000 ha of forest later can be expanded to 85,000 ha. The Project activities aim to improve the standard of living of the community and to reduce deforestation pressures and drivers. The Agarwood farming and forest conservation Project intends to establish activities that simultaneously provide environmental benefits (forest protection, wildlife management, biodiversity conservation) as well as community benefits (enhance local’s source of income, utilization of 20-30% of generated revenues in developing the community and raise their standard of living, improved agricultural practices, local development opportunities).

title: Lankao Geothermal Based Space Heating System
description:
Geothermal is a non-polluting, renewable and clean energy compared with traditional fossil energy such as coal, oil and natural gas. According to the Plan for Clean Heating in Winter in Northern China (2017-2021) (Development and Reform of Energy resources (2017) No. 2100)  , the proportion of clean heating in northern China is low, especially in some areas, where bulk burning coal is used in winter and air pollutant emissions are high, so it is urgent to promote clean heating.
At present, there is no municipal central heating system in the urban area of Lankao County, so a new central heating source is needed to ensure the heating demand. The purpose of the project activity is to introduce geothermal energy-based space heating system to realize heat supply to a series of residential buildings in Lankao County over winter season, which will displace heat supply from isolated coal-fired boilers as a business-as-usual scenario in the project area.
The project owner is Lankao Green Energy Clean Energy Co., Ltd. It can supply geothermal heat to 3,736.1 thousand m2 of newly built residential buildings with a total heating load of 112.08 MW. The scenario prior to the implementation of the proposed project activity is that heat supplied to the building areas in winter would be provided by isolated coal-fired boilers.
VCS Proponent:
Lankao Green Energy Clean Energy Co., Ltd
Henan Province, China

title: REDD+ Project Pacha Prometida
description:
The REDD+ Project Pacha Prometida is a grouped initiative that takes place in indigenous communities San Pedro (located in the Ixiamas municipality), Cachichira and Tres Hermanos (located in the San Buenaventura municipality), in Abel Iturralde province of La Paz Department, in Bolivia. Initially, it seeks to protect 11,500 hectares of primary Amazonian forest, which is strongly threatened by planned agricultural expansion and sugarcane planting activities, through:
• Reducing the threat of deforestation on the forests of the communities Cachichira, San Pedro and Tres Hermanos and, therefore, avoid the issuance of around 4.3 million of tCO2 during the first 20 years of the Project life cycle (on average 215,000 VCUs annually).
• Promoting of the social development actions to improve the quality of life of the families of the communities Cachichira, San Pedro and Tres Hermanos.
• Protecting biological diversity in flora and fauna, especially habitats of endangered wild species, found in the territories of the communities Cachichira, San Pedro and Tres Hermanos.
• Conserving and improving the focal areas where High Conservation Values are found that are identified.
State/Province: La Paz Department / Abel Iturralde province

title: Jiangsu Jiangyan Improved Agricultural Land Management Project
description:
Jiangsu Jiangyan Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is a project that change the pre-existing agricultural management activities (conventional tillage without straw incorporation) to conventional tillage with straw incorporation in fields where rice and wheat are rotated and the project located in Jiangyan district in Jiangsu province, China. The project involves 26,666 ha field where wheat and rice are rotated.
The project is expected to increase SOC by straw incorporation, since straw contains a large amount of organic matter and trace elements such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium, straw incorporation to the field can effectively increase soil organic matter (SOM). Straw incorporation to the field also can improve soil physical and chemical properties, enhance soil aggregate structure, and increase soil permeability.

title: Zano-Souri solar power
description:
The bundled project consists of the construction and operation of two greenfield solar power plants, Zano for 24MWc and Souri for 18MWc. Zano is located near the town of Tenkodogo, in Bougou region, Center- Eastern Burkina Faso and will be operated by Quadran Burkina Faso, when Souri is located near Dedougou, in the Mouhoun region, Western Burkina Faso and will be operated by Dédougou Solaire. Both involve the setting up of photovoltaic (PV) panels for a total installed capacity of 42MWc which will capture solar energy and produce electricity to be exported to the West African Power Pool.
Access to clean and inexpensive energy is a priority of Burkina Faso's Ministry of Energy, which aims to increase the national and rural electrification rates by 45% and 19% respectively by 2025. To this end, the Government of Burkina Faso has signed a concession agreement with Quadran International (now rebranded Qair), Syscom Network (the sponsors) on one hand, and Quadran Burkina Faso and Dedougou solaire on the other hand (the project SPV’s) to build and operate Zano and Souri respective solar power plants during 25 years. 
The project is a type I project activity under sectoral scope: 1, Energy Industries (renewable and non-renewable sources). The methodology ACM0002 (Version 21.0) is applied since its purpose is the installation of a new grid-connected renewable power plant (Greenfield) as the “electricity delivered to the grid by the project activity would have otherwise been generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants.” 
The average power generation of the project for the next 7 years is estimated at 80 GWh per year, resulting in emissions reductions of 45,316 tCO2e emission reductions per year and 317,217 tCO2e of emission reductions over the 7 years crediting period.
VCS Proponent:
AERA Group
Paris, France

title: Jiangsu Guanyun Improved Agricultural Land Management Project
description:
Jiangsu Guanyun Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is a project that change the pre-existing agricultural management activities (conventional tillage) to conservation agriculture management (conservative tillage) in Guanyun county, Lianyungang city, Jiangsu province, China. 
The project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by applying the conservative tillage. The conservative tillage refers that: through straw returning to the field, minimum tillage, no tillage, reduction of chemical fertilizers and pesticides application and other agriculture management measures. The conservative tillage is a sustainable agricultural technology that can reduce farmland soil erosion, protect farmland ecological environment and achieve coordinated development of ecological benefits, economic benefits and social benefits. 
Since the conservative tillage can reduce soil disturbance and reduce the loss of soil organic carbon (SOC). Moreover, the project is expected to increase SOC by applying crop residue management, since the crop residue contains a large amount of organic matter and trace elements such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium. Mulching crop residue into soil can maintain soil moisture, reduce soil temperature, increase soil microbe amount and eventually increase soil organic matter (SOM).

title: Amazon Partners 1
description:
The project area is located within 3 private properties, located in the municipalities of Vila Rica, inthe State of Acre, Brazil, inserted in an area Amazon biome. The project aims to avoid unplanned deforestation in a project area of 58,487.50 ha. The REDD+CCB project is expected to avoid predicted deforestation of 10,354,998 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime (Dec 01,2022-Nov 30,2052), with an annual average of 345,167 tCO2e.
The objective is to originate- with characteristics of a REDD+CCB initiative, following the Project Cycle of the VM0015 Methodology for Avoided Unplanned Deforestation, v1.1 Methodology. Thus, such VCUs may, in the future, be accounted for in Brazil's Nationally Determined Contributions Emission Reductions efforts, within the framework of the Paris Climate Agreement, as they are negotiated between different parties, within the framework of the voluntary markets for carbon credit negotiations.
Since the proiect will originate from the characteristics of a REDD+ initiative, it will contribute to efforts to reduce deforestation of the Amazon Biome in Brazil, resulting in the preservation of biodiversity in one of the most important tropical forests on the planet and in the restoration and preservation of the conditions of Climate Regulation of the Earth. It is therefore important that the Project is added to the methodological efforts provided for in the CCB Program- so that the VCUs eligible for the validation of the methodological quality are also valued considering the methodological efforts validated by the CCB Program.
The project's social engagement creates a support base to ensure preservation and sustainable use of the forest. Social engagement at all stages is important so the actions to be developed are inclusive and transparent, in processes that allow communities and stakeholders to actively participate to ensure that the project generates legacies with positive social and environmental impacts.

title: Jinhui sustainable grassland management project
description: Jinhui sustainable grassland management project is located in Tianjun County, Haixi Mongol and Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Qinghai Province of China. The project is aimed to restore the local degraded grassland ecosystem and black soil beach through sustainable grassland management practices, such as improving the rotation of grazing animals among rotational grazing plots, limiting the timing and number of grazing animals on degraded pastures, and reseeding with native grasses on severely degraded grassland and ensuring appropriate management over the long-term, thereby increasing carbon sequestration, and promoting local development. Totally, 297,781.30 ha of degraded grassland has been managed scientifically through rest and rotational grazing by fence building and reseeding of native grass species.

title: Jatobá REDD+ Project
description:
The Jatobá project will be developed in the municipality of Boca do Acre, state of Amazonas, Brazil, within the Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Uses (AFOLU) sector under the Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD+) category. The project will conserve 94,090.42 hectares of native Amazon rainforests in a region where deforestation pressure is mainly due to land use conversion activities from forests to pastures aimed at raising livestock. The project area (18,017.19 ha) will be allocated to Avoided Planned Deforestation (APD), and it is estimated that at the end of the project the emission of 5,440,804 tons of Greenhouse Gases (GHG) (tCO2e) will have been avoided. 
The project will be developed considering the CCB Standards, with benefits for the Climate, Community and Biodiversity. As benefits to the climate, the maintenance of forest cover results in exceptional benefits for adapting to the impacts caused by climate change.
As benefits to the communities, the project will enable water security and access to information to minimize the impacts caused by climate change in traditional, low-income extractive communities.
It is noteworthy that the project includes a high priority area for biodiversity conservation, as it is located within a Key Biodiversity Area (KBA), harboring species endemic to the Brazilian Amazon and species classified as Vulnerable (VU), Critically Endangered (CR) and Endangered (EN) with extinction according to the IUCN.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: Alter Biogas ll Project
description: WABIO Technology Holding Ltd. builds and operates its own biogas power plants for third-party companies wishing to gain access to renewable energy sources. Alter Biogas ll Project is one of those projects, which will be located on cadastral parcel no. 2906/11 in cadastral municipality of Nova Crnja, Serbia. Prior to the development of this Alter Biogas ll Project, the manure and straw from the farms is stored in open manure lagoons where it is allowed to decay anaerobically, generating greenhouse gas emissions and other negative impacts on the farm environment through soil pollution. Alter Biogas ll Project will use cow manure and corn straw as feedstock for anaerobic digestion and production of biogas. Electricity will be generated from the 999 kWe generator within the plant.

title: Jilin Zhenlai Improved Agricultural Land Management Project
description:
Jilin Zhenlai Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) implements conservation agriculture (crop residue addition and no or reduced tillage) in 60,000 hectares (or 900,000 Mu  ) of monocropping corn fields located in villages under the administration of Zhenlai County, Baicheng City, Jilin Province, China.
The project is expected to replace conventional farming practices and promote conservation agriculture, which entails incorporating crop residues in the field after the harvest and applying no or reduced tillage prior to sowing. No or reduced tillage minimizes soil disturbance; crop residues incorporated in the fields contribute to soil organic matter increase and avoid greenhouse gas emissions which would otherwise occur due to burning or other management measures.

title: Jilin Dehui Improved Crop Management Project
description:
Jilin Dehui Improved Crop Management Project (hereafter as 'the project') aims to increase soil carbon storage and decrease current carbon emissions from participating farms. By switching from the previous agricultural management practices (conventional tillage to conservational tillage), the chosen measures will also help to improve crop yields and soil health.
The project is located in Dehui City, Jilin Province of China, covers 15 towns and 2 street committees. Dehui City is a county-level city under the jurisdiction of Jilin Province, is managed by Changchun City, located in the northern part of Jilin Province and the hinterland of Songliao Plain, with an area of 3,322.24 square kilometres, and the geographic coordinates between 125°14’ and 126°24’ East longitude, 44°02’ and 44°53’ North latitude.
The conservational tillage method will be used in the project, which is projected to reduce GHG emissions. The term 'conservational tillage' refers to an environmentally friendly agricultural technique that, with the help of a variety of supplementary practices like straw return  and minimal or no tillage, can reduce soil erosion on farms, safeguard the ecological environment on farms, and achieve coordinated development of ecological, economic, and social benefits. Due to the fact that conservational tillage can lessen soil disturbance and soil organic carbon (SOC) loss. Additionally, returning straw to the field can efficiently use organic fertilizer resources and increase soil organic matter (SOM), as straw contains a significant amount of organic matter and trace elements like nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium.

title: Heilongjiang Shuangcheng Improved Agricultural Land Management Project
description:
Heilongjiang Shuangcheng Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is located in Shuangcheng District in Helongjiang Province, China. The purpose of the project is to adopt improved agricultural land management practices including returning straw in fields and applying organic fertilizer, and to prevent the severe soil degradation caused by pre-existing conventional tillage in local crop land.
Since straw contains a large amount of organic matter and trace elements such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium, returning straw to the field can effectively use organic fertilizer resources and increase soil organic matter (SOM). Straw returning to the field also can improve soil physical and chemical properties, enhance soil aggregate structure, and increase soil permeability. Applying organic fertilizer can reduce nitrous oxide emission compared to synthetic fertilizer.

title: Improved Cropland Management Project in Morin Dawa
description:
The “Improved cropland management project in Moqi” is aimed to raise farmer's awareness on the benefits of sustainable agriculture and how to change the agricultural practices to help in climate change mitigation and adaptation. The project will assist farmers to overcome barriers that prevent adoption of improved agricultural land management practices and provide technical assistance where needed. The objectives of the project is to reduce emissions from agricultural practices and increase soil carbon storage, in order to achieve these, a package of practices that change the pre-existing agricultural management activities will be carried out, the specific activities are the following:
A. Reduce fertilizer (organic or inorganic) application;
B. Reduce tillage/improve residue management; and
C. Improve crop planting and harvesting.

title: Lake Victoria Watershed Agroforestry Carbon Project
description: Trees for the Future (TREES) is developing The Lake Victoria Watershed Agroforestry Carbon Project. This project uses VERRA methodology VM0042 with CCB to develop and monitor VCUs with smallholder farmers on 75,000 hectares of land in the counties of Kisumu, Homa Bay, Migori and Siaya along the shores of Lake Victoria in Kenya. This project will involve training and implementing sustainable agroforestry practices with farmers to transform mono-cropped land into nature-based carbon sinks with above and below ground biomass and improved soils. Currently this cropland is under low yield cultivation of grain crops and is an area designated by the Kenyan Government as a target region for agroforestry development on cropland. In addition, to creating VCUs, the sustainable agroforestry techniques and extension services provided to farmers will ensure diversification of cropping systems including horticulture crops and fruit and fodder trees. The projects aims to improve nutrition, increase income and resilience, develop the sustainable growing capability of the land, and enhance biodiversity in the region. The restoration effort will generate an estimated 20.7 million Verified Carbon Units (VCUs) and help farmers adapt to the impacts of climate change.

title: Project MATANI REDD+ DIOS MAYOR DE LOS PUEBLOS CABILLARI CONSERVACION ANCESTRAL
description:
Colombia has approximately 60 million hectares of forest. Of these, 66% is located in the Amazon biome. The Forest and Carbon Monitoring System (SMByC) of the Institute of Hydrology, Meteorology and Environmental Studies (IDEAM), identified that in 2021, 174,103 ha of forest were deforested.
The name given to the Conservation Project is Project MATANI REDD+ DIOS MAYOR DE LOS PUEBLOS CABILLARI CONSERVACION ANCESTRAL, Matani is the Greatest God of the communities that make up the Association of Traditional Indigenous Captains of Vaupés (ACTIVA), made up of the communities of Altamira, Buenos aires, Cachiporro, Mutanacua, Villagladys, Cananari, Morroco, Reforma, Villareal. The Project MATANI REDD+ is located in the Department of Vaupes, corresponding to the Amazon biome of Colombia. Due to its biophysical conditions, this biogeographic zone is strategic for regulating the climate, sustaining biological cycles, conserving soil and water resources, capturing greenhouse gas emissions, and conserving the biological diversity of the region. Amazon region.
Therefore, the indigenous communities linked to the project seek, through their territorial autonomy and their right to free self-determination, to carry out conservation processes framed in sustainability criteria that have to do with the protection of natural forest areas, rescue and protection of their cultural identity and promotion of productive practices that promote the protection of biodiversity and the environmental richness of their territory.
Characteristics that are directly linked to the purpose of REDD+ projects, with the desired sustainable local development, as well as with the purpose of reducing emissions generated due to deforestation and forest degradation. The project MATANI REDD+ DIOS MAYOR DE LOS PUEBLOS CABILLARI CONSERVACION ANCESTRAL constitutes an area of 812,491 hectares.
The main objective of the project has been is to avoid the unplanned deforestation (AUD) in the Amazon rainforest.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Kayseri Biogas Plant
description:
MIR Global Enerji A.Ş. has constructed the Kayseri Biogas Plant Project. The aim of the project is to produce and supply electrical energy to the Turkish national grid.
By means of reducing dependency to the fossil fuels, environmental pollution is significantly reduced. Also, clean energy is generated by using animal manure as a source for biogas facility.
Within the scope of the project, MIR Global Enerji A.Ş constructed a biogas facility in Kocasinan District, Kayseri Province, Turkey. The facility has a capacity of 80,000 cattle, a slaughterhouse with a daily slaughter capacity of 500 and a biogas facility. The cattle manure processing capacity of the biogas plant is 2000 tons/day. Based on the applied tool, the project boundary is considered as the National Electricity Grid of Turkey. The baseline scenario refers to the energy generation from the fossil fuels.
The project includes 3 units in total as (3 x 1.540) MWm / (3 x 1.501) MWe with a total of 4.620 MWm/ 4.503 MWe. 
The first commissioning date of the project is 29/06/2021 for the first unit of 1.540 MWm / 1.501 MWe. The second commissioning date of the project is 27/04/2022 for the units 2 and 3 with the same capacities of 1.540 MWm / 1.501 MWe with a total of 3.080 MWm/ 3.002 MWe.
The total commissioned capacity is 4.620 MWm / 4.503 MWe
By avoiding the use of fossil fuels and using biogas as an energy source instead, greenhouse gas emission reductions can be achieved. Total annual electricity generation is 33,750 MWh for the installed units. As a result, total of 236,250 MWh electricity will be generated in a 7-year span between 30/06/2021 to 29/06/2028 with an average value of 33,750 MWh/year. According to this, the emission reduction is estimated around an average of 102,204 tCO2e annually. For the entire crediting period, total of 715,425 tonnes of CO2 is expected to be reduced in a total of 7 years
VCS Proponent:
MİR Global Enerji A.Ş.

The biogas that will be released during the biodegradation of organic wastes will be used for electricity, hot water and heat production in the cogeneration unit. The scope of the project will also include an organic fertilizer production facility with a capacity of 200 tons/day.
Based on the applied tool, the project boundary is considered as the National Electricity Grid of Turkey. The baseline scenario refers to the energy generation from the fossil fuels.
The project includes 2 units in total as (2 x 1.540) MWm / (2 x 1.501) MWe with a total of 3.080 MWm/ 3.002 MWe .
The first commissioning date of the project is 30/06/2021 for the first unit of 1.540 MWm / 1.501 MWe. The second commissioning date of the project is 11/08/2022 for the 2nd unit with the same capacities of 1.540 MWm / 1.501 MWe. These two commissioned units combine for a total of 3.080 MWm/ 3.002 MWe.
By avoiding the use of fossil fuels and using biogas as an energy source instead, greenhouse gas emission reductions can be achieved. Total annual electricity generation is 22,515 MWh, and a total of 157,605 MWh electricity will be generated in a 7-year span between 01/07/2021 to 30/06/2028. According to this, the emission reduction is estimated around an average of 64,670 tCO2e annually. For the entire crediting period, total of 452,688 tonnes of CO2 is expected to be reduced in a total of 7 years.

title: Sichuan Muli County REDD Project
description:
The Sichuan Muli REDD+ Project (hereafter referred as “the project”) is located in Muli Tibetan Autonomous County, Sichuan Province, China. The project zone (Including Liangshan State Liangbeiguo Forest Protection Bureau, Liangshan State Leibo key state-owned forest protection Bureau and Liangshan State Yalong River state-owned forest protection Bureau in the Muli area) has a total area of 181,681 ha. The area is characterized for its high biodiversity and subtropical humid mountain forests, but also for the presence of deforestation activities and social conflicts. Deforestation drivers include mining activities, subsistence agriculture and animal husbandry, and forest fire. Social issues include lack of sanitation, education and health infrastructure and lack of technical guidance regarding sustainable production models.
To achieve the above mentioned objectives, project activities to be developed and implemented include: (i) Development of legal economic alternatives and associated business plans that promote biodiversity protection, (ii) Management and improvement of production systems that str biodiversity conservation, iii) Strengthening land use planning and mechanisms to guarantee food security for the communities, (iii) to contribute to the monitoring and conservation of the biodiversity present in the area of the Muli Tibetan Autonomous County.
Moreover, expected GHG reductions corresponds to an annual average of 234,910 tCO2, so for the lifetime of 20 years it could demonstrate reductions up to 4,698,207 tCO2.

title: Management of Community Forests for the Reduction of Deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon
description:
The REDD + project is implemented in the area made up of 21 native communities: Junín Pablo, Nuevo Loreto, Buenos Aires, Caimito, Nuevo Egipto, Nueva Yarina, Santa Rosa de Dinamarca, Nuevo Paraiso, Santa Marta, Utucuro, Caco Macaya, San José of Pacache, Nuevo Saposoa, Santa Rosa de Aguaytía, Mariscal Cáceres, Yamino, Sinchi Roca II, El Naranajal, Nueva Alianza de Baños, Santa Teresa and Golondrinas, the first 17 communities are located in the Ucayali region and the remaining 4 in the Huánuco region. The project area has an extension of 184,773.74 hectares and its objective is to conserve the forest in the 21 communities from the advance of deforestation and degradation, as well as to conserve biodiversity stocks and improve the living conditions of the population surrounding the project area. .

The project aims to reduce the pressure to change land use in the project area through 4 components: i) Strengthening of governance and management of the territory in native communities, ii) Generation of sustainable inclusive businesses, improving income of the families of the native communities, iii) Maintenance of forest conservation objects, and iv) Strengthening of capacities for the MBC with social inclusion and gender equity.

With these actions, the project expects to avoid a total of 10,394,747.73 tCO2-e according to the base scenario projected for the first 10 years, with an annual average of net emissions of 1,039,474.77 tCO2-e. In addition, the project includes benefits for the populations involved, as well as for the conservation of biodiversity, where it seeks to contribute to the conservation of forests with high levels of biodiversity with the presence of endemic species, species in danger of extinction or with some degree of extinction. of threat, beyond the benefits of reducing GHG emissions.

title: Reflorestamento de Impacto no Brasil Project
description:
Investancia Brasil Ltda  (Investancia) is undertaking a Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) grouped reforestation project, known as Reflorestamento de Impacto no Brasil Project. The Project is planting pongamia (Pongamia pinnata) and other tree species in degraded pastures across Mato Grosso do Sul, Brazil in areas that were cleared of native forests more than ten years prior to the projects’ start date. 
Investancia is developing a business model to establish pongamia as a regional commodity in a region where agriculture, other than cattle-ranching, is extremely difficult to make work. The focus of Investancia’s business is four-fold:

1) Production of reforestation oil;
2) Maintaining cattle or hay on silvopastoral lands with improved pastures;
3) Providing protein (i.e., feed) for cattle from the pongamia seedcake; and
4) Sequestering carbon dioxide in the pongamia trees (i.e., generate carbon offset credits).

To date, Investancia has established a nursery, explored the suitability of pongamia in the region, developed protocols, assessed various genetic strains of pongamia, and spoken with numerous local landowners about leasing land. The Reflorestamento de Impacto no Brasil Project will sequester carbon dioxide and generate GHG emission removals in the planted pongamia trees and in the soil following the reforestation of degraded pasture.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Cobram Estate Olives Regenerative Farming Project
description: The Cobram Estate Olives Regenerative Farming Project, developed by Carbon Friendly, is a pioneering initiative aiming to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the agricultural sector through the adoption of regenerative farming practices. These practices, including mitigation of synthetic fertiliser usage, enhanced pest management, diversified cover cropping, soil regeneration, and refined irrigation techniques, promise to increase soil organic carbon concentrations, leading to an estimated annual GHG reduction and removal rate of 55,722 metric tonnes CO2 equivalent across the project's 6,000-hectare expanse. Beyond its primary environmental goals, the project also aligns with various United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, embodying a comprehensive commitment to sustainable agriculture, food security, health and well-being, water conservation, responsible consumption, climate action, and the preservation of terrestrial ecosystems.

description: The purpose of the project activity is to beneficially use the energy of waste flare gas for data processing. The project activity leads to upstream carbon emissions reductions. In addition to reducing energy consumed from the grid, the project activity is capturing the entire flare for beneficial energy use rather than the flare being burned in the open air, which can result in additional emissions being released or vented, compared to being combusted in an engine which is what Verde is doing.

title: Asaga Amazonas REDD+ project
description:
The Asaga Amazonas REDD+ project is located in the state of Amazonas and is comprised of 470504 hectares , near the Apuí Conservation Unit Mosaic and the Campos Amazônicos National Park, as well as being surrounded by other settlement projects, reserves, and indigenous territories and at least one other REDD+ project. This diversity provides a great opportunity for the conservation and socioeconomic development of the region.

The Apuí Conservation Unit Mosaic is composed of nine conservation units, including four state forests (Sucunduri, Aripuanã, do Apuí, and Manicoré), two state parks (Guariba and Sucunduri), two sustainable development reserves (Bararati and Aripuanã), and the Guariba Extractive Reserve. Regarding the Campos Amazônicos National Park, it presents one of the most significant Cerrado enclaves within the Amazon Forest biome. One of the reasons it has great scientific potential is the presence of endemic species.

Due to the high density of biodiversity and the many unique species of flora and fauna, the conservation of this wild habitat is extremely important. Nevertheless, the involved municipalities rank high in deforestation and wildfires, as well as facing pressure from agricultural expansion, illegal logging, mining, construction of hydroelectric plants, roads, and land grabbing. 

The region has a variety of habitats, including upland forests, flooded forests, rocky fields, and savannas, as well as waterfalls and rapids that occur along the rivers, with a great diversity of species and landscapes.

title: Regenerate Outcomes Farming Project
description:
The “Regenerate Outcomes Farming Project” developed by Regenerate Outcomes Ltd aims to support farms to transition away from intensive conventional modes of food production towards regenerative production systems via a mentoring and farm data services programme. As a result, the participating farms of this project implement several regenerative land management activities which reduce and remove GHG emissions.

Regenerate Outcomes Ltd (Regenerate Outcomes) is a registered company in the United Kingdom. Regenerate Outcomes is part of a global network bridging the gap between the finance and farming sectors. Regenerative agriculture presents opportunities to improve soil, plant and animal health, wider ecosystem processes, and the fundamental economics of farming.

“Regenerate Outcomes Farming Project - ROFP” is a grouped project with a project boundary of the UK; the project initially consists of 10 farms located in Northumberland (UK) seeking to move towards regenerative food production and better pasture and agricultural land management. The farm types range from upland (livestock only) to lowland mixed (arable and livestock) and arable-only. The project was inspired by the Environmental Impact Bonds (EIBs) pioneered in the US, such as the Forest Resilience Bond and Quantified Ventures’ Water Outcomes Funding in Washington and Ohio. 

The project seeks to provide four essential services to participating farms: 
i)	Data management, including baselining and monitoring of activities and ecological change, 
ii)	Funding support for capex requirements such as fencing and water infrastructure,
iii)	Mentoring and education from regenerative agriculture advisors, and 
iv)	Marketing and sales of environmental outcomes such as carbon bio-sequestration, biodiversity enhancement, and water quality improvements to downstream beneficiaries (payors). 

The project is developed as a grouped project.

title: CREATING LIVELIHOOD  OPPORTUNITIES  AND CARBON CREDIT INCOME FOR  SMALLHOLDER FARMERS  THROUGH  HORTICULTURAL PLANTATIONS IN  BANGLADESH
description: Agroforestry is a land use management system combining trees with crops or livestock on the same land. Agroforestry is widely practiced in Bangladesh, particularly in rural areas where it is an important component of smallholder farming systems. It is used for food production and environmental services. The project is located in Bangladesh and Chapainawabganj, Nogaon, and Rajshahi districts of Bangladesh are considered in the first instance. As we move forward, the benefits of horticulture-based agroforestry ecosystems will also be brought to other parts of the country. The country is home to many fauna and flora and has five different types of ecosystem i.e., coastal ecosystem, inland freshwater ecosystem, terrestrial forest ecosystem, and hilly ecosystem. The main aim of the project activity includes the plantation of fruit-bearing trees on the farmlands of smallholder farmers. The agroforestry systems deliver several forest products, agriculture products, and ecosystem services which may enhance the social well-being of the local farmers and national and global community. The primary activity of the project is to onboard farmers who are practicing agroforestry plantations on their farmland. The Project Proponent along with the local implementation partner will implement project activity including plantation activities, along with capacity building and training programs. The species selected for agroforestry plantation include Mango and Guava but will be diversified further over time. The implementation of the project would generate GHG emission removals and improve the local environment through growth of the trees, increasing the source of income, and enhancing the capabilities of farmers. The project is expected to generate annual average GHG emission reductions or removals of 167,587 tCO2e.

title: DEVELOPING CARBON PROJECT FOR FARMERS ADOPTING REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURAL  PRACTICES IN GUJARAT STATE
description: Globally, agriculture generated nearly 9.3 billion tons of CO2 equivalent (CO2eq) emissions in 2018, considering emissions at the farm gate and related to land use/land use change. The major contributors to these emissions are methane (CH4) and nitrous oxide (N2O) from farming activities. Projections suggest that by 2030, these emissions will increase by 15% compared to 2010 levels, reaching an annual total of nearly 7 billion tons. Varaha initiated a project to harness the substantial carbon sequestration and ecological rehabilitation potential of regenerative agriculture practices in the districts of Gujarat. The ongoing project aims to promote these practices among farms engaged in cultivating cotton, cotton-wheat, rice, legumes, maize-wheat and rice-wheat cropping system. The project aims to expedite the adoption of improved agricultural practices among Indian farmers. The project will be a grouped project, with new project activities, are being added over the lifespan of the project. The cotton-wheat/cotton cropping systems will be considered in the first instance of the project. For further instances, cotton, cotton-wheat, sugarcane, rice, legumes, maize-wheat and rice-wheat cropping system or crops will be considered. The project interventions or activities will be implemented in partnership with Aga Khan rural support program (India)-AKRSP (I). The project interventions were implemented in the year 2020. Starting with 25 thousand hectares, the area will be stabilized at 312,000 hectares in 2029 and maintained until 2040.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Developing Climate Resilience Of The Residential Society In Hyderabad Through Miyawaki Afforestation: Urban Forest Development
description:
Developing the Residential Society in Hyderabad through Miyawaki Afforestation: Urban Forest Development Project (hereafter the project activity) has been implemented in Shamshabad, Hyderabad City, India by Sow and Reap Agro Pvt. Ltd. The geographic coordinate of the project is 17°16'12.00 N and 78°20'24.00 E. Currently, the total area is 18 acres, in which plantations of only 11 acres has been done in 2021 and 7 acres will be done in the month of May or June in 2023. The land preparation has been started for the plantation of 7 acres. In future the plantations can be done across PAN India.
This residential society is a desirable luxury community that is the first of its kind in India and truly stands out from the ordinary. The entire community is inspired by and part of the natural beauty surrounding it. It is a complete ecosystem in itself, with mature forests, a self-sustaining water reservoir, shaded walkways and paths for walking or cycling, and private drives for each home, along with a host of other conveniences.
Magnificent plots complement the privacy, harmony, and luxury, situated perfectly for the best of both serene privacy and urban convenience. 76 exclusive properties are set amidst 150 different species of trees local to the area in your own self-sustaining micro forest, with paths to provide safe routes for wildlife separate from cars, bicycles, and residents out for a walk.
Poised 553 metres above the valley floor amid a natural forest of local species of trees, the land has been specifically engineered to collect and nourish the forest, while diverting moisture from the homes. There is a natural slope towards the northwest corner of the community, which acts as a collection point for rainwater, feeding the reservoir.

title: GreenShift: Catalyzing regenerative agriculture ecosystem for smallholder farmers in India, through carbon finance
description:
Currently, regenerative agriculture arises as a promising strategy to address the issues of food security and climate change. It embodies a comprehensive approach to farming that prioritizes the revitalization and enhancement of soil health, biodiversity, and ecosystem services. Through the adoption of regenerative practices, farmers have the potential to enhance both the productivity and profitability of their farms, while also playing a vital role in fostering a sustainable and resilient agricultural system that tackles the pressing challenges of our era. Varaha initiated a project to harness the substantial carbon sequestration and ecological rehabilitation potential of regenerative agriculture practices. The ongoing project aims to promote these practices among farms engaged in cultivating various crop combinations such as rice-wheat, maize-rice, rice, maize-wheat, cotton-wheat, cotton, sugarcane, millets and legumes. The project covers several states in India, including Himachal Pradesh,
Rajasthan, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Assam, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Karnataka, and Tamil Nadu. The project interventions were implemented in the year 2020. Starting with 45 thousand hectares, the area will be stabilized at 16,58000 hectares in 2030 and maintained until 2040.
