title: REDD+ Tauari Forest Conservation Project
description: The REDD+ Tauari Forest Conservation Project is a partnership between Mata Nativa BR and MyCarbon and deals with the preservation of the Amazon rainforest in line with the traditions of local populations and the sustainable development of the region, through activities that will reduce greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to the increase of global warming. The project area is located in the northern region of Brazil, more specifically in the municipality of Tarauacá, state of Acre. The 126,157.8211 ha of tropical forests that are part of the project area are located in the Amazon biome. Avoiding a scenario of logging in 85% of the area, a truly sustainable economic activity was sought, which discards the suppression, even if authorized, of the existing vegetation, and also preserves the existing biodiversity in the glebe, with the cooperation of the local populations, through this project. The activities designed here aim to ensure that forest areas belonging to the project are preserved, continuing the important work of generating ecosystem services there, such as climate regulation, protection of water sources, maintenance of biodiversity and genetics heritage, among others, and also ensuring that 119,812,777.36 tons of CO2 are not released into the atmosphere.

title: Land Life Reforestation and Restoration on Degraded Land in Australia
description:
The proposed ARR-VCS project is a large-scale grouped project centered on the reforestation of degraded lands in Australia. In the last 200 years, approximately 40% of Australia’s native forest cover has been lost due to human-induced land conversion. Today, much of the remaining native vegetation is highly fragmented. This grouped project aims for the long-term restoration of Australia’s forests, achieved through a mixture of direct seeding and seedling planting techniques to re-establish native flora and fauna, build ecological connectivity and reverse the deleterious impacts of land degradation. 

The project is managed by Land Life, a tech-driven reforestation company that plants trees at scale to restore degraded ecosystems globally in hubs like Europe, the US and Australia and maintains an on-the-ground presence in Australia, and collaborates closely with local partners and authorities. Local partner Cassinia Environmental brings on-the-ground expertise in forestry and conservation, supporting Land Life’s team of reforestation specialists in managing and implementing quality projects in Australia.

Project activities are implemented and monitored according to approved large scale project methodology AR-ACM0003, with more project instances to be added over the coming years (up to well over 10,000 ha expected). The first set of project instances covers 706.65 ha of degraded land across Australia, at 4 distinct planting sites: Morrl Morrl (Victoria), Moolagundi (New South Wales), Killongbutta (New South Wales), and Hillridge (South Australia). The project expects to establish 474,407 trees and to sequester at least 196,837 tCO2e over a project crediting period of 100 years. The estimated annual average of GHG emission removals over the first 43 years is 4,578 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Land Life Company B.V.
NH, Netherlands
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

description:

title: Karidja forest restoration project
description:
Karidja project consists in restoring 70,000 ha of the Haut Sassandra gazetted Forest (102,400 ha) in Côte d’Ivoire. This forest has lost over 95% of its original cover in less than 30 years.
Restoration activities are based on both assisted natural regeneration and plantation of a very diversified mix of native species, the overall aim is the permanent re-establishment of a largely natural and largely intact tropical rainforest.
Agroforestry schemes are implemented around the restored forest (over 30,000 ha) to ensure sources of sustainable livelihoods to local populations, contributing to the long-term success of the project.
Karidja project includes an important package to support sustainable economic transition, social infrastructures improvement and trainings for locals to provide long term social co-benefits.

title: Santa Nicolasa North Patagonia Regenerative Grazing Project
description:
The “Santa Nicolasa North Patagonia Regenerative Grazing Project” aims to stop and reverse the historic soil degradation process of the region by implementing regenerative grazing technics by restoring the ecological condition of ~70.000 hectares of rangeland soils on Santa Nicolasa farm. Regenerative grazing activities can increase SOC concentrations, improve natural growing grasses, decrease bare soil, and improve water infiltration, among others. An average amount of 0,4% of Soil Organic Matter, is expected to increase, which results in a net GHG emissions reduction and removals of ~ 1,400,000 tCO2e in the SOC pool, with an annual average of 71,000 tCO2e in 20 years of the project. 
In general terms, the regenerative grazing activities restrict the cattle to relatively small paddocks to generate intensive grazing in short periods, followed by long grazing resting periods. As a result, a homogeneous disturbance on all the forage species is generated, avoiding the selectivity of the cattle for the most palatable plants. This technique requires the installation of new fencing and watering infrastructure and a significant adaptation of management practices. 
The project contributes to sustainable development by promoting an integrated management scheme with the ecosystem in privately owned land, avoiding carbon emissions and restoring native ecosystems from a degradation process together with the continuity of sustainable food production; promoting sustainable practices along the region, generating labor demand from the local population, and making improvements in infrastructure; generating knowledge on current SOC concentrations data and monitoring the effects of regenerative grazing management in the region; developing and improving a new mechanism to finance projects in the sustainable livestock production sector; the conservation of a unique ecosystem, that despite the severe degradation, still conserves the original land use and the natural ecosystem structure.
VCS Proponent:
Solmat Agropecuaria SA
Buenos Aires, Argentina
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Kijani Forestry smallholder farmer forestry project
description:
Kijani Forestry is a social enterprise founded in 2019, located in Uganda. Kijani’s mission is to empower smallholder farmers to generate income and combat climate change through the establishment of sustainable wood lots. As of 2022, Kijani has planted over 5 million trees with over 8,000 farmers throughout northern Uganda. Kijani works in partnership with local communities, government agencies, international non-governmental agencies, universities, and other stakeholders to implement sustainable land use practices and agroforestry management systems. Through these partnerships, Kijani aims to build capacity and establish a foundation for sustainable development in Uganda through growing trees that provide income-generating opportunities for farmers. 
Kijani works through a network of thousands of organized small groups across Uganda to establish small-scale nurseries, train farmers in nursery management, and mobilize farmers to establish fuelwood lots on their private land. Kijani’s unique approach addresses many of the barriers faced by rural farmers who wish to plant trees; Kijani provides all inputs needed for a productive tree nursery, including properly sourced seeds, potting bags, equipment for maintenance, and materials needed to care for seedlings. Kijani’s field staff are stationed in the communities full-time, and provide regular training to groups on nursery establishment and maintenance, seedling care, pest management, agroforestry practices, and fuelwood lot establishment and management. At any given moment, a Kijani staff member is no more than a bicycle ride away from a Kijani nursery. Kiiani’s continuous presence, and strong relationships, in the community is critical to the long-term success of the project. In addition to its reforestation efforts, Kijani provides training and support to communities to help them establish sustainable forest management practices and create economic opportunities through various forest products.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Grouped Project Sul da Bahia
description: The Grouped Project Sul da Bahia falls under the Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR) category and targeting the following Verra certifications: Verified Carbon Standard (VCS), and Climate, Community & Biodiversity Standard (CCB). The project aims to restore forest formations that are diminished due to the expansion of other land use practices such as overgrazing on extensive cattle ranches, intensive agriculture and silviculture systems. The grouped project is located in the Atlantic Forest biome in the state of Bahia (Brazil). Restoration is attained through forestation activities using native and non-native species. Project activities also include harvesting and establishing agroforestry systems to diversify and maximize project benefits for all parties and communities involved. The overarching goal of the project is to create a biodiverse forest cover that combines carbon capture, biodiversity and community impacts with a diversity of economic functions such as sustainable production of crops and forest products.

title: REDD++ Manglares del Bajo Baudo
description: The Bajo Baudó Mangroves REDD++ Project is in the Pacific region in the department of Chocó, Colombia. It limits to the north with the municipality of Nuquí, to the south with the municipality of Medio Baudó, to the east with the municipality of Atrato and to the west with the Pacific Ocean. The project area is collectively owned by 5 Community Councils, which are Cuevita (R 2701/Dec 21, 2001), Pavasa (R 2695/Dec 21, 2001), Villa María de Purrichá (R 1129/May 23, 2000), Virudó (R 2698/Dec 21, 2001) and San Agustín de Terrón (R 3369/Dec 21, 2000). Although the total titled area for the 5 councils is 73,611 ha, the project area is 62,212 ha, which overlaps 51% with the DMRI Encanto de los Manglares del Bajo Baudó Management District, created through the agreement 008 of 2017. The (DRMI) is a Protected Area category that decentralizes the power of the environmental authority and allows decision-making by the communities that inhabit it. With the management of the area, new models of social and environmental territorial management have been created, however, there are several challenges in terms of governance and conservation of ecosystems. Through the DMRI declaration, sustainable management agreements have been reached with the communities and joint restoration and monitoring actions have been developed with the participation of other key institutional actors. The project area overlaps with two important ecosystems, mangrove forest (19.88% of the total project area), with an estimated average reserve of 800 tCO2e/ha, and Basal humid forest (80.12% of the total project area), with an estimated average reserve of 604 tCO2e/ha. The drivers of deforestation in the baseline have been due to the implementation of coconut crops, subsistence crops, crops for illicit use, and livestock; the drivers of degradation have been selective logging, illegal mining, fishing, and indiscriminate housing. The main objective of the project is: Reduce GHG emissions due to forest degradatio.

title: Restore Africa: Restoring trees and livelihoods in Kenya
description:
The Restore Africa: Restoring trees and livelihoods project in Kenya aims to restore the land and livelihoods of vulnerable small-scale farming households on private land and community-owned conservancies in the Kitui and Baringo counties in Kenya . This initiative, using appropriate, sustainable agriculture, forestry and agroforestry practices will enhance the sequestration of carbon and result in greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions. The integration of livelihood interventions, landscape restoration, and carbon sequestration will support climate-vulnerable communities to build resilience and adapt to climate change.
The proposed project activities will encompass afforestation, reforestation and revegetation, including direct (e.g., manual planting, broadcast seeding) and indirect (e.g., herbivory exclosures, coppicing, pollarding) activities that facilitate natural regeneration. The project will facilitate sustainable food production, enhance the functioning of ecosystems and to increase carbon storage in the landscape through the scaling up of nature-based restoration activities, including the establishment and regeneration of approximately 2.1 million trees. This will improve the livelihoods and resilience of estimated 30,000 households while restoring about 32,500 hectares in Baringo and Kitui counties. Any project intervention or activity will not compromise but rather enhance livelihoods of individual and community land holders. These activities are expected to sequester at least 1,300,000 tCO2e over a 30-year period. The Global Evergreening Alliance (GEA) program will work.
The Global Evergreening Alliance acts as project proponent. The lead implementing organisation is the International Centre for Research in Agroforestry working together with implementation partners Self Help Africa and Adventist Development and Relief Agency.
VCS Proponent:
Global Evergreening Alliance
Victoria, Australia

title: Lushan MSW Incineration Project
description:
Lushan MSW Incineration Project (hereafter referred to as the project) is located in the industry park of Lushan County which is located in the West side of Guogou Village, Zhangliang Town, Lushan County, Pingdingshan City, Pingdingshan City, Henan Province, P.R. China. The Project is invested, constructed and operated by Lushan Capital Environment Energy Co., Ltd. (hereafter referred to as the project owner).
The project will treat 600 tons of MSW per day. The combustion system is composed of one 600t/d mechanical grate incinerators, matched with one set of 12MW steam turbine generator. The project will process 219,000 tons of MSW every year, and consume 130 tons of 0# light diesel as auxiliary fuel. The MSW combustion line will work 7,446 hours every year, generating 77,934.1 MWh electricity, of which 63,905.9 MWh will be exported to the Central China Power Grid (CCPG). The implementation of the project will meet the requirement of local MSW harmless treatment, and significantly improve local environment. Also, the project fits the priority development sector of integrated utilization of resource and energy saving of China, and helps reduce GHG emission that would occur in baseline scenarios such as power generating by fossil-fuel fired plants and MSW treatment at landfill.
The project started construction in 08 July, 2019 and put into operation on 07 October 2021. It is estimated that during the 10-year fixed crediting period of the project (from 07 October 2021 to 06 October 2031), the average annual GHG emission reductions will be 60,883 tCO2e. The total amount of emission reductions is expected to be 608,829 tCO2e during the 10-year fixed crediting period.

description: The proposed project activity is a greenfield, grid connected solar PV based electricity generation project, located in the Least Developed Country (UNCTAD) of Malawi, Africa. title: Agroforestry For Livelihoods
description: The project aims to address widespread land and agro-ecosystem degradation and climate-change related hazards across the landscapes of Rulindo and Bugesera districts in northern and eastern provinces of Rwanda respectively. The project will undertake a number of activities including: 1) planting of around four million functional tree species on both smallholders’ farm plots and public suitable lands to restore degraded ecosystems, protect watersheds, sequester carbon, conserve biodiversity, and provide farmers with a diversified income streams, e.g., from fruits and timber; 2) establishing seedling nurseries to provide quality materials for tree planting 3) provide trainings to enhance knowledge to a wide range of key stakeholders, including farmer groups, the youth, community advisors, Community Extension Officers, nursery managers, project’s staff, etc. 4) promoting specific livelihoods activities, e.g., horticulture package, livestock husbandry, Village-based Savings & Loan Associations (VSLA), local investments, etc.; 5) facilitating market access for farmers products/produce by encouraging farmers to organize into cooperatives/ other community structures, and when possible, entering into supply agreements with off-takers; 6) engaging farmers in sustainability agreements - committing them to sustain the implementation of the project activities for the long-term, beyond the project’s crediting period (≥20 years). The project activities aim to address this land and agro-ecosystem degradation and directly contribute to climate mitigation through increased carbon storage in tree biomass and in soils within the agricultural landscapes. The new VERRA’s Verified Carbon Standard carbon methodology called Methodology for Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation Projects will be used. The ex-ante annual average GHG emission reductions of the project are estimated at 117,565 tCO2e, and total GHG emission reductions over 20 years are estimated at 2,351,302 tCO2e.

Livelihoods Fund SICAV SIF
Paris, France

description:

The forest in the project consists of coniferous forest, the predominant tree species is Pinus Sylvestris.
If it were not for the implementation of the project activity, the trees would be logged based on a valid and verifiable government-approved timber harvest and management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of the project activity conserves the carbon stock in the protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions by about 8,930,874 tCO2e over the span of 30 years. The average annual emission reduction is 297,696 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 6,787,464 tCO2e over 30 years, while the average annual VCUs with buffer deduction is 226,249 tCO2e.
The project activity contributes to the preservation and protection of the natural environment (biodiversity conservation and soil erosion control), thus contributing to the sustainable development goals of the United Nations.

title: Maodeng Pasture Improved Grassland Management Project
description:
Maodeng Pasture Improved Grassland Management Project (hereinafter as “the project”) is located in Xilin Hot City, Xilingol League, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China. The Xilin Hot City geographic coordinates of the project zone are 115 °16′~117°13′E and 43°02′~44°52′N and borders Abaga Banner in the west, Zhenglan Banner in the south, Xiwu Banner and Chifeng City in the east, and Dongwu Banner in the north.
The main objective of the project is to implement sustainable grassland management measures for 10,533.33 hectares of degraded grassland through seeding, grazing prohibition and fertilization. These measures improved grassland productivity, restored vegetation, significantly increased vegetation coverage, improved biodiversity in degraded grasslands, increased the proportion of superior pasture, improved soil fertility, and enhanced the stability of grassland ecosystems.
According to the baseline survey, before the implementation of the project, due to the impact of climate change and human activities, the grassland in this area has been facing varying degrees of degradation, sandification, and sparse vegetation.
The total scale of the project is 10,533.33 hectares. Strictly ban grazing on all plots within the project area for the first five years after the completion of the project and, after five years, adopt sustainable grassland management methods according to the actual grassland restoration situation, such as rotational grazing in different pastoral areas, limits the time and number of grazing in the project area to protect the natural grassland resources, curb the deterioration of the ecological environment of the natural grassland.

title: Working Trees supporting eastern US Silvopasture, Project 1
description:
Working Trees grows trees where the interests of farmers and the climate overlap. 

The agricultural benefits of incorporating trees into active pastureland or hayland –, known as “silvopasture” or “alley cropping”,  respectively; collectively referred to as “silvopasture” –, include reduced livestock mortality, minimized heat stress, improved soil health, increased hay yield, improved water retention and infiltration. At the same time, planting trees on pastureland or hayland has been identified as the largest agricultural climate solution for carbon sequestration.

Despite these benefits, adoption has remained low due in part to high up-front costs and the multi-year delay between planting and benefits. Revenue from carbon credits presents an opportunity to overcome this imbalance. Financing from carbon markets affords farmers the opportunity to profit from sustainability enhancements and environmental services.

However, the methods used today for tree-based sequestration have mainly been accessible to large landowners. In the United States this means small landowners – who own 90% of farms and 50% of farmland – get left behind in the green economy. 

Working Trees innovative new approach to carbon-credit-supported silvopasture allows landowners of all sizes to start planting trees and reap the benefits of this practice through three key strategies: 
1. Streamlined eligibility and carbon measurement through a phone application
2. Guaranteed offtake of the generated carbon credits
3. Target geography spanning the Eastern US

title: Amazon Partners 20
description:
The objective of the Amazon Partners (AP) 20 Project is to originate -with the characteristics of a REDD+ initiative (Reduction of Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation), following the Project Cycle of the VM0015 Methodology for Avoided Unplanned Deforestation, v1.1 Methodology. Thus, such Verified Carbon Units (VCU) may, in the future, be accounted for in Brazil's Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC) Emission Reductions efforts, in the framework of the Paris Climate Agreement, as much as they are negotiated between different parties, within the framework of the voluntary markets for carbon credit negotiations.

The Project will avoid Greenhouse Gas Emissions at the Territory of Indigenous Peoples of the Shawadawa Association, in the municipality of Porto Walter, in the State of Acre, Amazon Biome of the Brazilian Territory. Since AP 20 is originating from the characteristics of a REDD+ initiative, it will contribute to efforts to reduce deforestation of the Amazon Biome in Brazil, resulting in the preservation of biodiversity in one of the most important tropical forest areas on the planet. The Project adds to the methodological efforts provided for in the Climate, Community & Biodiversity (CCB) Program – so that the VCUs eligible for the validation of the methodological quality of the project are also valued considering the methodological efforts validated by the CCB Program. The development of the integrated Amazon Partners 20 Project provides for social engagement to create a support base to ensure the preservation of the forest. Social engagement at all stages of the process is important so that the actions to be developed are inclusive and transparent, in processes that allow nearby communities and other stakeholders in the project to actively participate, closely following to ensure that the project generates legacies with positive social and environmental impacts.

title: Brazil Pastureland Regeneration with Native Palm Silvopasture
description:
This grouped project consists of planting Macaúba trees (Acrocomia aculeata) within agrosilvopastoral systems on non-forestland (primarily degraded pastureland) in the Vale do Paraíba region in São Paulo State, Brazil. 

Macaúba is a native palm tree that is drought and disease tolerant and uses 70% less water than the common commercial African palm, while still producing fruits that can be processed into commercial palm oil products (e.g. pulp and kernel oil, livestock fodder, biofuel, and fertilizer). 

The Vale do Paraíba region, located within the Atlantic Forest biome, is characterized by abundant biodiversity and endemism in its original form. However, due to extensive land-use changes that occurred over the centuries, it now exists in a fragmented state. Extensive low-productivity cattle grazing is currently the dominant land management regime in the project region. Cultivating Macaúba on those lands has the potential to slow soil erosion, store carbon in tree biomass, regulate the micro-climate, and promote biodiversity. The integration of Macaúba palm trees with cattle grazing and cropland will diversify and increase  income to local farming and ranching communities without displacing commercial or subsistence activities.  Whenever possible, the plantings will connect forest fragments to create ecological corridors that promote flux of genes through migration, dispersal, linkage and interrelation of populations of wild flora and fauna, all of which are important to biodiversity.

This project has the potential to remove on average 42,396 tCO2e annually throughout the project crediting period, with an estimated total of 847,925 tCO2e over the twenty-year crediting period in the form of aboveground and belowground tree biomass and soil organic carbon.

title: SOIL CARBON SEQUESTRATION BY ADOPTION AND MAINTENANCE OF CLIMATE-SMART AGRICULTURE PRACTICES IN DIFFERENT CROP USE AND DEGRADED PASTURE RECUPERATION.
description:
The Carbon Program by AGROROBÓTICA aims the recovery of degraded pasture and crops by adopting and maintaining several climate-smart agriculture practices and considering the specificity of each Brazilian biome: Amazon Forest, Cerrado, Caating, Atlantic Forest, Pampa, and Pantanal. In advance, it is expected to increase the sustainability of this sector and raising the life standards in rural areas. The reductions and removal of GHG emissions expected to be achieved would not have taken place without it. As this is a grouped project, as defined by the VCS standard, it includes multiple growers with multiple enrolled fields. The estimate is that the project could promote a GHG emission reduction and removal of up 2,624,400 tCO2eq promoted by more than 2,000,000 ha, in the next 20 years. The carbon credit payments will provide an additional source of income to help farmers to implement sustainable practices and improve the livelihoods of their communities.
This project is an agricultural GHG emission reduction and removal project using the methodology “VM0042: Methodology for Improved Agricultural Land Management”, v. 2.0 and the AGLIBS ® Artificial Intelligence (AI) Platform, which is specifically addressed to fulfil the need for a high-integrity and cost-efficient monitoring system (MRV- measurable, reportable, and verifiable) through the emerging technology LIBS.  The overall objective will be achieved by supporting farmers to adopt and maintain climate-smart agricultural practices through agronomic support and the monitoring of soil carbon stock change inside the farm boundary. The primary goal is to promote a range of regenerative agricultural land management practice improvements targeted to increase soil organic carbon (SOC) storage and reduce net emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from grower operations and degraded pasture area, increase farm resilience to extreme weather and climate change, and enhance yield, improve soil quality, and reduce GHG emissions.

Agrorobotica - Photonic in Agroenvironmental Certification SA
São Paulo, Brazil

title: Silvador Climate Action
description: Silvador Company SRL / Forest Capital SRL own private forestlands in Romania and are developing a forest carbon credit project to achieve greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions and removals through the deferral of harvesting on privately owned forests. The project will be implemented following the VCS VM0012 – Improved Forest Management in Temperate and Boreal Forests (LtPF), v1.2 methodology. The Group Project currently consists of a single Project Activity Instance (PAI).  The current geographic area is composed of 11 private forest parcels located in the counties of, Buzău, Dâmbovița, with future instances to be located in Arges, Prahova, and Teleorman. The PAI areas are non-contiguous area. All properties were managed for timber harvest prior to the implementation of the carbon crediting project and forest operations occurred under existing forest management plans.

title: Argentina Gran Chaco Region REDD+ Project
description:
The Project aims to protect the native forest socio-ecosystems of the Argentine Gran Chaco ecoregion. The Grouped Project will seek to reduce planned deforestation and unplanned deforestation and degradation pressures by encouraging landowners granted with large-scale agricultural and livestock production deforestation permits to set aside their land for conservation and forest regeneration. It will also implement a combination of environmental and social activities aimed at improving the livelihoods of community members living in the vicinity of the project area as well as the enhancement of the forest and biodiversity.
In Argentina, deforestation has accelerated over the past 40 years as the country's agricultural frontier has expanded, resulting in one of the highest deforestation rates in the world. This expansion of the agricultural frontier is having a major impact on native ecosystems and their biodiversity. At the same time, deforestation and land enclosure have altered the livelihoods of many indigenous and/or peasant communities who use large areas of the Forest for their activities.
For the first Project Activity Instance the project proponent, VISTA Energy, purchased part of the El Chaguaral farm (4.892 hectares) in the current boundary of the agricultural frontier. The former owner of the property had a clearing permit to transform the land for agricultural and livestock purposes. VISTA will not make use of that permit. The activities to achieve this include fencing, hiring responsible field staff to monitor the property, and developing and implementing a biodiversity conservation plan together with an action plan for fire prevention, warning and response will be implemented. Also assisted natural regeneration and enrichment planting activities will be implemented.The initial activity instance is estimated to generate ≈ 983,460 tCO2e net GHG emissions reductions and removals (≈49,173. tCO2 e per year for 20 years)

title: Poultry Litter based Biogas Power Generation Project in Nashik, Maharashtra, India
description: M/s S&P Feeders Pvt. Ltd., Maharashtra is setting up a 20 TPD Poultry Litter to Energy plant at Thengode village, Nashik District in Maharashtra. The proposed project activity is a step towards supporting the implementation of poultry waste to Energy production facility in India, through the production of Biogas. The project site is home to approximately 175,000 birds, resulting in a daily production of around 22,000 kg of poultry litter. The close proximity of the proposed land to the farm eliminates the need for transportation, ensuring a continuous and uninterrupted supply of raw material. The poultry litter is treated anaerobically in the KVIC Floating Dome Digester, producing about 1,400 m3 of biogas per day with a calorific value of 4,700 to 5,400 kcal per cubic meter. The high-efficiency biogas engine and generator installed will generate 175 kWh of electricity per hour, while also yielding a bio-organic slurry/manure with high NPK content, totaling 55,000 liters or 6,600 kg per day

title: Qitai Shuifa Improved Grassland Management Project
description:
The Qitai Shuifa Improved Grassland Management Project is located in Changji Hui Autonomous Prefecture, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, China. Changji Hui Autonomous Prefecture is located at the northern foot of the Tianshan Mountains and the southeastern edge of the Junggar Basin. Changji Hui Autonomous Prefecture borders Hami City to the east, Shihezi City to the west, Turpan City and Bayingolin Mongolian Autonomous Prefecture to the south, Tacheng and Altay Prefecture to the north, and Mongolia to the northeast. The project aims to restore local degraded grassland ecosystems by rest grazing on degraded grasslands, increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local development by introducing sustainable grazing and managing grasslands.
Totally, 64,391.13 ha of degraded grassland have been managed scientifically by rest grazing. Rest grazing requires that adopting sustainable grassland management methods, such as rotational grazing in different pastoral areas, limits the time and number of grazing in the project
area to protect the natural grassland resources, curb the deterioration of the ecological environment of the natural grassland.
In general, rest grazing is implemented in slightly degraded areas (the total grass yield decreasedby 30%-50% compared with that before degradation). In addition to this main restoration measure, the project also alleviates soil desertification and restores grassland vegetation through grassland management measures to improve soil carbon storage and local biodiversity, supplemented by daily management measures of other protection projects, such as grassland fire prevention and rodent control, so as to ensure long-term sustainable management of the project area. The
project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 5,400,253 tCO2e in 40 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 180,008 tCO2e.

title: Muara Teweh Conservation Project
description:
The logging concession is located in the heart of Borneo, the largest island in Indonesia, and will conserve 255,700 hectares of forest area. That's about two times the size of Los Angeles. This area is home to the Dayak indigenous tribes and thousands of forest-dependent communities. It's also home to a diverse range of ecosystems, including tropical rainforests, biodiversity and local communities. 

From 2023 onwards, the concessions have an RKU (logging plan) approved by the Ministry of Environment and Forestry (MoEF) to log 6.4 million m3 of timber from 171,700 hectares of forest found within its concession area. 

This is an Improved Forest Management project that is designed to completely prevent the logging activities and timber extraction from taking place. The planned project activities include forest patrolling & monitoring and the development of sustainable livelihood programs for the communities residing within and/ or around the concessions.

title: The Republic of the Congo Improved Forest Management Project
description:
The Republic of the Congo Improved Forest Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “The project”) is located in UFA Djua-Ikié, The Republic of the Congo. It is implemented by Société d’Exploitation Foresrière Yuan Dong (hereinafter referred to as “SEFYD”) as the project proponent. The project is to protect the forest that was planned to be logged.
UFA Djua-Ikié is located in the Souanké and Semé Districts of the Sangha administrative Province. The project is designed to improve forest management in 338,589 ha of native Congolese forests legally designated for logging. By avoiding previously planned logging and implementing improved forest management and conservation activities, this project will increase the carbon stock through protecting the forest.
Prior to the implementation of the project, the forests in the project area were harvested following the guidelines in Timber Harvest Plan approved by the local forestry authority. In order to protect the forest ecosystem, improve the ecological environment, increase carbon sinks, reduce GHG emission reductions and slow down climate change, the project proponent decided to stop the logging and implement this improved forest management project activities from 01-August-2020 to 31-July-2040.
The project is expected to generate approximately 53,140,400 tCO2e during the 20 years’ crediting period, with the annual emission reductions of 2,657,020 tCO2e.
The project’s climate, community and biodiversity objectives:
⚫ Reduce GHG emissions and mitigate climate change; and
⚫ Improve soil and water conservation and contribute to sustainable development; and
⚫ Provide experience of forest management and risk prevention and control for local stakeholders; and
⚫ Improvement of the biodiversity and ecological environment of the project area and its surrounding area; and
⚫ Increase employment opportunities and raise the income level of local residents; and
⚫ Protect the local tree species from being cutting down.

title: Sichuan Lizhou Improved Forest Management Project
description:
The Sichuan Lizhou Improved Forest Management Project (hereafter “the project”) is located in Lizhou District, Guangyuan City, Sichuan Province, P.R.China. It is implemented by China Carbon Sinks Holdings Limited (hereafter “PP”) to protect the once logging forest. The project has 3687.9 ha commercial forest. 

Prior to the implementation of the project, forests in the project area were harvested following the guidelines in Timber Harvest Plan approved by the local forestry authority. In order to protect the forest ecosystem, improve the ecological environment, increase carbon sinks, reduce GHG emission reductions and slow down climate change, PP decided to implement this improved forest management project activities from June 2020 to June 2050. And from the Project Start Date, PP has stopped the commercial logging in the project area.
The Forest Conservation Project activities will be focused on forest resource supervision and monitoring. This ecosystem will then continue to provide its services to all the communities and entities that depend on it.

The project reduces greenhouse gas emissions by preventing logging, avoiding any kind of commercial harvest and other linked to logging activities, as decomposition of harvested tree, bark burning, emissions due to carbon fraction sequestered from wood products over time.

The project is expected to generate approximately 1,132,711 tCO2e during the 30-year crediting period, with the annual emission reductions of 37,757 tCO2e. 

The project activity will significantly improve the forest management conditions within the project area, and benefit local ecological environment. The implementation of the project will not only achieve a reliable measurable carbon sequestration by reducing commercial timer, but also contribute to sustainable development of the local community, host country.

title: Community-Based Mangrove Conservation and Restoration in Sierra Leone
description: In Sierra Leone, mangrove forests are under severe threat from the pressures of subsistence-based harvesting for construction material and fuelwood for cooking and smoking fish. The health of mangrove ecosystems is directly tied to the social and economic well-being of local communities that depend on them for sustaining their traditional livelihoods in fishing and shellfish harvesting. Communities further depend on the mangroves for preventing erosion, which threatens coastal villages. Through a community-based and livelihood driven approach, and in collaboration with the Government of Sierra Leone, this grouped project will generate greenhouse gas emission reductions and removals through avoided deforestation and reforestation of mangrove ecosystems in the Bonthe and Moyamba districts, identified as global hotspots for biodiversity and home to some of the most marginalized communities in Sierra Leone. The project will begin with the conservation of 10,624 ha of mangroves on Sherbro Island, expanding in subsequent instances to include conservation activities in a combined total of over 74,000 ha of mangrove forests. Restoration activities will similarly expand from an initial 50 ha to an estimated total of 2,000 ha of degraded mangrove areas that are now threatened by erosion or abandoned due to saltwater intrusion.

title: THE NAGALAND 4 CHANGE REDD+ PROJECT
description:
The Nagaland 4 Change is proposing an AFOLU Project under REDD+ Category in Peren district of Nagaland, North-eastern India. Nagaland is one of the few states of India having forest cover more than 50% of its geographical area. The forests provide multiple goods and services to the local Naga communities, such as fruits, seeds, medicines and recreation. Moreover, Nagaland state is located in the Indo-Burma Biodiversity Hotspot Region, which is among the 36 most biodiverse regions of the Earth. Some of the rare and endangered species, such as Spotted Linsang (Prionodon pardicolor), Clouded Leopard (Neofelis nebulosa), and Black Softshell Turtle (Nilssonia nigricans). In addition, forests of Nagaland protect the fragile hilly ecosystems of the state by preventing soil erosion and landslides.
   
However, specifically forests in Peren are gradually reducing in size. As well as the forests are also becoming increasingly prone to the fires during the dry summer months (April, May and June). Because of high anthropogenic pressures, the forests are also under extreme stress as a result of firewood collections. Therefore, Nagaland 4 Change, the Project Proponent is proposing a forest conservation project through funding from carbon financing under Verra VCS Mechanism. The main aim of the projects are as follows:
1.	Conservation of existing forests by protecting the forest cover.
2.	Increasing the forest cover as well as increasing density of the vegetation in forests.
3.	Enhancing the capacity of carbon storage of the forests, therefore generating carbon credits revenue out of it.
4.	Monitoring and reporting of the rare and endangered flora and fauna living the forests.
5.	Providing livelihood improvement to the local Naga communities through various interventions such as improved cookstoves, clean drinking water, etc.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: SUNDARI MANGROVE RESTORATION PROJECT IN THE INDIAN SUNDARBANS
description: The Sundari Mangrove Restoration Project is a grouped project that aims to protect and restore 4.343 hectares of degraded urban mangroves located in the Sundarbans, West Bengal, India, by planting local species and rebuilding hydrological connectivity in the area. The first instance of the grouped project will be implemented in Sagar Island and Namkhana of South 24 Paraganas, and it will concern 417 ha. This project is a one of a kind, with a holistic approach ensuring successful restoration and conservation of the largest mangrove forest in the world. This project will be generating GHG emissions reductions by conserving and restoring degraded mangroves, as well as generating removals by increasing the biomass by planting millions of mangrove trees in the project area. The project is planned for an initial duration of 20 years and 4.1 million tCO2e are estimated to be removed over the crediting period, corresponding to an average of 209k tCO2 per year. Regarding the first instance of the grouped project, approx. 654K tCO2e are estimated to be removed over 20 years. Sundari aims to lower the pressure on the mangrove due to a high dependency of the populations on the mangrove forests for fuelwood collection and fishing. The project seeks to reduce these threats by conducting capacity building with local communities and improving sustainable local livelihoods to ensure the permanence of the carbon as well as the ecosystem services provided. Sundari is entirely community-based and was designed in close relationship with the local communities. The project developer, Meensou India Private Limited, is a local limited company implanted in the region with extensive expertise in mangrove ecology and carbon projects. EcoAct will act as co-project owner of the Sundari project and will oversee/help with the project validation and verification as well as administrate KPIs.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Amazônidas REDD+ AUDD Grouped Project
description:
The Amazônidas REDD+ AUDD Grouped Project (hereafter called GPD) aims to avoid unplanned deforestation in private and public properties at Amazonas State. The scalability area of the GPD was defined based on the Brazil regional division by IBGE of 20171, as the sum of the Tefé, Parintins, Manaus, and Lábrea intermediate geographic regions in the Amazonas state, excluding the immediate geographic regions of Coari, Tefé, and Tabatinga. This region has long been recognized for its alarming rates of deforestation within the Amazon biome, and its forests face an escalated risk of deforestation. Initially, the present GPD is composed of thirty-five properties with 251,706.41 hectares of forest cover, split into four municipalities: Itacoatiara, Itapiranga, Silves and Presidente Figueiredo. The climate benefits brought with this GPD are directed related to the emission reduction of 124,528 tCO2e in average per year, calculated with a 6-year jurisdictional baseline.
The actions involving the implementation of Amazônidas REDD+ AUDD GPD are complementary to the grouped projects developed by brCarbon. Through these projects, in accordance with current federal and state environmental laws, brCarbon seeks to promote integral forest conservation actions in rural properties with remaining vegetation, promote solutions based on nature in its regions of influence, generating co-benefits not only for the climate (reduction and removal of emissions), but also communities and local biodiversity. Furthermore, the Amazônidas REDD+ AUDD GPD aims to create positive economic incentives for landowners to conserve rainforests in areas that are vulnerable to degradation and deforestation, while contributing to net positive climate impacts as well as benefit to traditional communities and conserve biodiversity.

title: Leconi Agroforestry Project in Haut-Ogooue (LAPHO)
description:
The project developer is Sequoia Plantation Gabon who will implement the plantations under the modalities of lease of 20 years and renewable by 10 years, Sequoia Plantation Gabon will oversee project monitoring through the entire crediting period. The PlanGabon project aims to establish a total of 96,954 hectares of forest plantations across four initial farms. The project envisions transforming the degraded areas of these farms into forested landscapes, contributing to biodiversity conservation and the reforestation process. To achieve this goal, the project has set a specific target of establishing an average of 3,000 to 4,000 hectares of plantations per year over a duration of six years, this highlights the intended scale and pace of the establishment process over a period of 20 years (2023-2043). 
The project has five main goals. Firstly, it aims to transform non-forest areas into reforested areas. Secondly, it seeks to enhance the environmental and social conditions of rural areas, creating healthier and more sustainable communities. Thirdly, the project is dedicated to improving the income of local communities and ensuring the long-term viability of farmers by generating sustainable sources of income. Additionally, it actively contributes to mitigating climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions and promoting carbon sequestration. Lastly, the project addresses the issue of erosion, implementing measures to prevent soil erosion and protect the cover of natural forest present in the project areas. These goals collectively represent the project's commitment to forest reforestation, community development, climate resilience, and environmental conservation.
These plantations have a purpose: to restore damaged lands, produce wood sustainably, support local development, and combat climate change. They aim to revive depleted areas, ensure responsible wood production, boost local economies, and reduce carbon dioxide in the atmosphere by sequestering CO2.
VCS Proponent:
AERA Group
Paris, France
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Sodom Hanba Improved Grassland Management Project
description: Ejin Banner Improved Grassland Management (hereafter as “the project”) is located in Ejin Banner, Alashan League, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region of China. The project is aimed to restore the local degraded grassland ecosystem from adoption of sustainable grassland management practices, such as improving the rotation of grazing animals between summer and winter pastures, limiting the time and number of grazing animals on degraded pastures, and restoration of severely degraded land by replanting with perennial grasses and ensuring appropriate management over the long-term. The project proponent is Inner Mongolia Chengyao Grassland, Forestry and Animal Husbandry Ecological Technology Co., Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as the Project Proponent or PP).

title: Hubei Badong IFM PROJECT
description:
The Hubei Badong IFM Project (hereafter “the project activity”) is implemented in Badong County, Enshi Tujia and Miao Autonomous Prefecture, Hubei Province of China by Hubei Yangfan Tourism Development Co., Ltd and Guangzhou Guotan Assets Management Co., Ltd, the geo-coordinate of the  project proponent is 110°04'E -110°32'E and 30°28'N - 31°28'N, the total area is 3348.75km2, which includes the Improved Forest Management (IFM) of the forests in the conversion of logged to protected forest.
The area of the project activity is 5944.83 ha, including 750 subcompartments spreading over Bashan Forest Farm, Chadianzi Town, Dazhiping Town, Dongrangkou Town, Guandukou Town,Lvcongpo Town, Qingtaiping Town, Shuibuya Town, Xinling Town, Yanduhe Town, Yesanguan Town, Jinguoping Township, Xiqiuwan Township of Hubei Badong. All these forests are state-owned forests or privately-owned or collective-owned, and have the legal right to forest ownership. The species involved in the project are Chinese Fir, Coniferous Broad Mix and Coniferous Mix.
Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged based on a valid and verifiable government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 704,532 tCO2e in 20 years, the average annual emission reduction is 35,226 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 542,478 tCO2e in 20 years, and average annual VCUs with buffer deduction is 27,123 tCO2e.
The project activity will contribute to the environment (biodiversity conservation, rocky desertification prevention and soil erosion control), thus contribute to sustainable development.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: UÁKIRY REDD+ AUDD  GROUPED PROJECT
description:
The Uákiry REDD+ Grouped Project (hereafter called GPD), aims to avoid unplanned deforestation in private properties at Acre State. The area of deforestation involving three states in the north of Brazil has increased significantly in recent years, where before it was well preserved, the region known by the acronym AMACRO (where the states of Amazonas, Acre and Rondônia are located) has literally become no man's land. The lack of control caused cases of land grabbing and other crimes linked to the expansion of the agricultural frontier to explode. The region came to be known as the new Deforestation Frontier.
Initially the first four project activity instance is composed by four properties with 84,220 ha of forest cover, located in the Iaco River margins, one of Purus River affluents, in the Amazon basin. Through these projects, BrCarbon (hereafter known as BRC) and Yaco2 Gestão e Comércio de Carbono (Yaco2) seeks to promote integral forest conservation actions generating co-benefits not only for the climate (reduction and removal of emissions), but also communities and local biodiversity. At the validation, the climate benefits are directed related with the emission reduction of 215,021 tCO2e in average per year.
By joining BRC forest program, landowners can access funds from the carbon voluntary market to develop conservation and monitoring efforts in their forests. A partnership between BRC and landowners will result in the legal protection of forests, forest monitoring using satellite images, biodiversity inventory (including fauna e flora species), and forest biomass inventory in a broad scale, using an upscaling approach based on field collection, drone-borne and satellite sensors such as LiDAR (light detection and ranging). In addition, we will involve property surveillance, wildfire monitoring, fire prevention and fighting, threatened species protection and long-term social activities with local communities.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: Strengthening rural livelihood through carbon finance: Agroforestry practices in Bareilly Forest Circle of Uttar Pradesh
description: The proposed ARR VCS project plans to promote sustainable agroforestry for small-scale farmers to provide them with financial benefits and ensure GHG mitigation in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India. The project is being conducted in five divisions of Bareilly Forest Circle of Uttar Pradesh, namely Bareilly Social Forestry Division. The main agroforestry tree species planted by farmers for the year are Eucalyptus, Poplar, Teak, Guava and Mango. These species have higher productivity that leads to sequestration of carbon dioxide at faster pace and ultimately reduces GHG emissions.This project will also help in increasing tree outside forest (TOF) that will add in mitigating climate change. The project shall also enhance the income of farmer communities along with biodiversity conservation and improvement of soil health.

title: Anhui Zhujixi CMM Utilization Project
description:
Anhui Zhujixi CMM Utilization Project (hereinafter referred to as the Project) utilizes the low concentration coal mine methane (CMM) from Zhujixi coal mine to generate hot air to dry coal slime provided by Zhujixi coal mine. The Project is located in Hetuan Town, Panji District, Huainan City, Anhui Province, China.
The purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted CMM with low concentration methane concentration to generate hot air to dry the coal slime. The project applies flameless oxidation process. Four sets of regenerative thermal oxidizers (RTOs), each with a treatment capacity of around 30,000 Nm3/h  are installed, able to destroy 10.368 million Nm3 of methane annually and dry 400,000 tonnes of wet coal slime ideally.
VCS Proponent:
Huainan Huamei Pushi New Energy Technology Co., Ltd
Anhui Province, China

title: Shandong Zhucheng ALM Project
description:
Shandong Zhucheng ALM Project (hereafter as “the project”) is located in Zhucheng City, Weifang City, Shandong Province of China. The goal of this initiative is to reduce the carbon emissions currently emitted by the farms taking part to the project and raise the carbon storage in the soil. In addition, the selected measures will contribute to improving crop yields and soil health. The project was implemented by the Shandong Herong Agricultural Technology Group Co., Ltd. and Hainan icarbon Ecological Development Co.,Ltd. (hereafter “the project proponent”).
The project is located in the Zhucheng City, which covers 3 Streets and 10 towns. Zhucheng City is located in the southeast of Shandong Peninsula, at the junction of Taiyi Mountain Range and Jiaowei Plain. The total area of Zhucheng City is 2182.7 square kilometres, with the geographic coordinates between 35°42′23′′ and 36°21′05′′ north latitude and 119°0′19′′ and 119°43′56′′ east longitude.
The proposed project is aimed to prevent the soil degradation through adoption of the improved crop land management practices (collectively referred to conservational tillage) to replace the conventional cultivation mode.
Main activities about conservational tillage adopted in the project include： 
Organic fertilizer application (reduce inorganic fertilizer application): 54,398.5 ha of cropland have reduced the use of chemical fertilizer.
Straw incorporation (Improve crop residue management): straw in 54,398.5 ha of cropland have been buried and returned, with the depth of 30 cm.
A total of 54,398.5 ha of farmland has been managed under conservation tillage, The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 3,471,463 tCO2e from 01-Jan-2021 to 31-Dec- 2040, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 173,573 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: ALLCOT BLUE CARBON MANGROVE PROJECT IN SENEGAL (ABC  Mangrove Senegal)
description:
Allcot Blue Carbon Mangrove Restoration project in Senegal (ABC Mangrove Senegal) is a grouped project for the reforestation and conservation of mangrove ecosystems in Senegal. Through the restoration of at least 7,000 ha of mangroves, the project aims to:
o Strengthen the vegetation cover in the mangrove ecosystems.
o Improve the production and income of vulnerable groups.
o Strengthen the capacity of vulnerable groups to use land resources sustainably.
Involving the local communities since the beginning is one of the most important steps in the project. This includes providing information on all project activities and teaching basic concepts on climate change, and 
carbon sequestration projects. The project promotes a functioning family model where both women and 
men can equally participate in the project. People will show alternative livelihood opportunities that allow them to acquire and grow high-value crops, beekeeping, or ecotourism among other potential possibilities, 
which also reduces pressure on mangrove forests. An improvement of the basic infrastructure for rural communities is targeted as well.
The Project location is the Saloum Delta and the Casamance estuary respectively located in two regions (Fatick and Casamance) and 5 departments (Fatick, Foundiougne, Ziguinchor, Bignona, Oussouye), implemented in bare land, and at the end of the crediting period, the net emissions reductions are 2,241,960 tCO2 e.

title: MAHARASHTRA AND GUJARAT INITIATIVE FOR REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURE AND INCOME CREATION
description:
Grow Indigo is implementing a project in Maharashtra and Gujarat to boost smallholder farmers' income through the adoption of regenerative agriculture, resulting in reduced greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and positive environmental and economic outcomes.
The proposed project in Maharashtra and Gujarat addresses the GHG emissions caused by traditional agricultural practices in crops such as cotton, sugarcane, rice, wheat, maize, or soybean, without excluding other crops. Intensive agriculture practices in the project area have posed threats to land sustainability and contributed to increased GHG emissions.
The project aims to promote regenerative agricultural practices, such as optimized fertilizer management, cover cropping, zero- or reduced-tillage, improved water management/ irrigation, crop rotation, and agroforestry, to restore soil health, enhance biodiversity, and improve productivity.
The project takes an integrated and science-backed approach, including agricultural extension, outreach, agronomic support, digital data collection, and biogeochemical modeling.
The project will initially target 40,000 hectares in the project area and cover diverse cropping systems with regenerative agricultural practices that are known to reduce GHG emissions (N2O, CO2e, and SOC) and thus generate carbon credits.
The project also aims to link smallholder farmers to voluntary carbon markets, providing them with additional income opportunities and incentivizing the adoption of regenerative agriculture. With a cash incentive, smallholder farmers in the project boundary will adopt these practices more readily and contribute to sustainability and reduce GHG emissions.
Through these efforts, the project seeks to contribute to sustainability, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and improve the overall livelihoods of smallholder farmers in the project area.

title: GROUPED ARR PROJECT IN TELANGANA
description:
Grouped ARR Project in Telangana is an Agroforestry, Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation project being jointly developed by Tapovanam Organic Farming Systems (hereinafter referred as Tapovanam) and ClimeTrek Limited (hereinafter referred as ClimeTrek) in fallow agricultural, and wastelands owned by individual farmers and communities with low plant cover (hereinafter referred as project activity). The entire project lies within the geographical boundaries of Telangana state in India. In the first instance, the project activity is limited to the district of Nalgonda. Being a grouped project, more farmers and communities belonging to other districts of Telangana will be added as ‘future project instances. The project activity involves planting oil palm trees along with some cash crops like turmeric and groundnuts. In the first project instance, around 1,100 Ha will be covered in Nalgonda district in three years.  Future instances will cover 15 other districts of the state of Telangana. All project instances within this grouped project activity will consist of afforestation, reforestation and revegetation (ARR) primarily involving oil palm plantations with intercropping of turmeric and groundnuts. Based on ex-ante estimates the project will sequester around 1,073,817.9 tCO2e over 30-years (tree/ shrub biomass carbon and soil carbon) and an annual emissions reduction of 35,793.9 tCO2e.
Tapovanam is the coordinator for all the participating farmers and provides training to the farmers regarding the technologies/measures involved in the project activity. Tapovanam will have the right to carbon credits without any violation of farmers rights. The revenue after expenses from sale of carbon credits will be shared with the participating farmers. Clime Trek is the Carbon Project Developer. As per the agreement between Tapovanam and Clime Trek, the rights to carbon credits from the project will be transferred to ClimeTrek.Tapovanam and ClimeTrek are project pp.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURE AND CARBON PROJECT IN SPAIN
description:
The project basically consists of the application of regenerative agriculture techniques and strategies on different farms in Spain, to promote a more sustainable agronomic management, and as a result increasing the amounts of atmospheric carbon fixed in the soil.
Regenerative agriculture promotes practices such as the reduction or absence of tilling the soil, the presence of plant covers, the non-use of synthetic chemical products, organic fertilization, the optimization of water use, the improvement of by-products or waste management, and crop rotation, among others.
The project is national scope and will be carried out on all those farms within the boundaries of the Spanish State that adopt the commitment to improve their agronomic management and that meet the established requirements.
Regenerative agricultural management is focused on improving the soil’s properties and promoting conservation practices. The implementation of these measures will help to improve the health and fertility of agricultural soils which translates into an increase in the amount of organic matter (OM) in those soils. Carbon is one of the main components of OM, so increasing its percentage in soils is equivalent to increasing the amount of Soil Organic Carbon (SOC).
Each of the regenerative strategies proposed in the project has a direct or indirect effect on the reduction of Green-house Gases (GHG), either by reducing emissions or by increasing its fixation in the soil.
Although it is gaining ground in recent years, regenerative agriculture is not a common practice in the Spanish territory. Most farms are managed according to the principles of conventional agriculture, in which the soil is considered a mere support which generally has very little organic life and therefore, the amounts of OM and C are well below the levels that they could potentially contain.
The Sustainable Farming Carbon Project in Spain will be developed as a grouped project.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Myanmar Kindar Solar Power Plant Project
description:
The Myanmar Kindar Solar Power Plant Project is the construction of a new solar photovoltaic power plant project located in the south of Mandalay Division and 56km northeast to the Meiktila town, Mandalay Division, Myanmar. 
The project scenario consists of the installation of 74,592 pieces of 540Wp polycrystalline silicon PV module, providing a total capacity of 40.28MWp. The expected net annual power supply to the grid is 62,015.75MWh. The expected full load operating hours are 1,540h annually, and the plant load factor is 17.58%. The power generated by the project will be routed via an on-site step-up station to 132 kV and then connected to the Myanmar Power Grid.
By displacing fossil fuel fired power generation within the Grid by clean renewable energy, the project leads to the reduction of CO2 emissions into the atmosphere. Total annual Green House Gases emissions reduction is estimated to be of 22,402 tCO2e annually. The total emission reductions during the renewable 7-year crediting period will be 156,814 tCO2e.
State/Province: in the south of Mandalay Division

title: Symbiosis Continuous Cover Forest Project
description:
The Symbiosis Continuous Cover Forest Project is a reforestation project, proposed by Symbiosis Investimentos e Participações S.A., a company focused on the restoration of degraded land through the sustainable commercial reforestation of the Atlantic Rainforest native species.
The Atlantic Forest Biome (Mata Atlântica) is the most degraded in Brazil, with less than 12.4% left of its original area and very fragmented. The degradation started in the 16th century in the State of Bahia. Today, the same pattern of destruction is seen in the Amazon Biome, which started in the 70’s after the Atlantic Rainforest resources were depleted. In addition, plant breeding with the Atlantic Forest native species has not been implemented before.
The project is designed as a grouped project, with an initial instance at “Fazenda Novo Horizonte”, in Trancoso District of Porto Seguro municipality, Bahia State. It is situated in close proximity to Symbiosis headquarters, where seedlings are produced and where research and development activities take place. Novo Horizonte has a total area of 669.28 ha, from which 236.50 consist of the initial project area. Symbiosis expansion plans for the grouped project are focused on the South of Bahia, with projected 50,000 hectares of mixed species reforestation, in addition to 15,000 hectares of ecological restoration and 5,000 hectares of agroforestry with cocoa (also a relevant product of the region).
The land use in the region is predominantly focused on pasture, which is also the prior condition of all of the regions where the grouped project is intended to occur.
The project is designed for a 40-year crediting period, in which 27,499,184 tCO2e will be reduced/removed

title: Carbon Emission Reduction Project through Improved Water Management in Bio-farming
description:
According to information from the Ministry of the Environment of Japan, total GHG emissions from the agricultural sector in Japan in 2018 were about 32.3 million t-CO2eq. Of these, emissions from rice cultivation were the largest, at approximately 12 million t-CO2eq. , accounting for 38.2% of total emissions. The implementation of this project will reduce emissions by tCO2eq. per year and contribute to the reduction of GHG emissions from these agricultural activities.
At this project, we use VM0042 to reduce CH4 by using no pesticides, no fertilizers, and by drying the soil in the middle of the year. As for environmental impact, the absence of chemical fertilizers reduces most of the nitrous oxide generated from the soil and the carbon dioxide produced during the production and transportation of fertilizers, and the absence of animal-based fertilizers eliminates concerns about methane emissions from the fertilizer production process.

title: Enhancing Livelihoods of Farmers in Gujarat through Agroforestry Plantations by SHBVM
description:
The projected ARR VCS initiative aims to help farmers in Gujarat, India, by providing them with additional income via the sale of carbon credits created by agroforestry tree crops on their land.
Shri Hari Bhujal Vikash Mandal (SHBVM), the project's co-proponent, has supported farmers in providing quality planting material for agroforestry species. They also provide on-site help to farmers who have registered with them for plantation maintenance. The project is being implemented in six Gujarat districts: Chhota Udepur, Mahisagar, Vadodara, Bharuch, Aravalli, and Panchmahal. Roughly 15 million seedlings will be planted on an area of around 4,000 hectares.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: FST SMALL-SCALE SOLAR POWER PLANT IN KAMPHAENG PHET, THAILAND
description:
The FST solar project consists of the installation of solar photovoltaic power plants with a capacity of 9.98 MWp, located in Kamphaeng Phet Province, Thailand. 

Petroleum exploration and production required significant amounts of electricity use, baseline technology to produce electricity generate large amount of greenhouse gas (GHGs) emissions such as fossil-fuel power plant which use natural gas, diesel, and other fossil fuels used to generate electricity. The displacement of fossil fuel with solar power generation will generate GHGs emission reductions by replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy sources such as solar power. The project involves the installation of solar photovoltaic (PV) panels, which generate clean electricity without emitting GHGs emissions. In contrast, the use of fossil fuels for power generation produces significant GHGs emissions that contribute to climate change.  

Moreover, the excess solar energy generated will be stored in batteries, reducing the reliance on fossil fuel-based power generation. This will further reduce GHGs emissions associated with power generation. 

Overall, the replacement of fossil fuels with solar power generation projects will generate significant GHGs emissions reductions, contributing to fight against climate change. 

The annual emissions reduction is 13,061.87 tCO2e/annum.
VCS Proponent:
FutureTech Solar (Thailand) co. ltd
Bangkok, Thailand
+66 61 406 5757
PilinY@pttep.com

title: REDD Carbon and Biodiversity Project, Greater El Rey Area, Jujuy, Argentina
description:
Tropical rain forests with their rich fauna and flora are threatened worldwide from deforestation and forest degradation. In Argentina, deforestation rates are particularly high, caused mainly by conversion of forests to expand soy and beef production. Wintershall Dea AG, VisionNetZero GmbH and Banco de Bosques have joined forces to develop REDD+ carbon projects to conserve large forest patches with a high biodiversity in the Northwestern region of Argentina. 
The project intends to protect and conserve 24,154 hectares that are part of the Yungas forests in northwest Argentina. The main project activity is taking the property off the market to prevent agricultural development and conserve its high carbon values, rich biodiversity, and critical ecosystem functionality by avoiding planned deforestation and forest degradation. Therefore, the project intends a joint certification with CCB Standard.
The project will deliver significant carbon as well as non-carbon benefits by conserving the natural forest ecosystems of the Yungas, one of the most biodiverse natural systems in Argentina and home to nearly 50% of the country's biodiversity. Through the income of carbon revenues, forest areas with high conservation value can be purchased and conserved by donating and integrating them into national or provincial protection systems.
The development of REDD+ carbon projects contribute to climate change mitigation by reducing greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) from forest loss and forest degradation. The number of generated credits is estimated based on the comparison of the projected baseline and the effectiveness of the project activities targeting the drivers of deforestation and degradation. In the project area that would be protected, the weighted average of tons of carbon dioxide per hectare (tCO2/ha) is 884 tCO2/ha. On that basis, up to 1.8 Mio. VCUs can be expected within the duration of the project (30 years).

title: KOSHER BLUE CARBON -1
description:
The proposed Project activity intends to restore degraded mangrove habitats in the Indian Sundarbans region.  The project activity plans to restore up to 3,000 hectares of degraded mangrove ecosystems in phased manner through the plantation of diverse native mangrove tree species. The project activity is being implemented in the Indian part of Sundarbans delta situated in the West Bengal state of India. The project is implemented by the proponent in collaboration with the project implementing partner organization, site specific ground partners, and the local communities. The project activity will ensure the active participation of women in various stages of project implementation and post implementation management of the project interventions

By restoring the degraded mangrove land with the native tree species, the project activity will remove atmospheric carbon dioxide through biological carbon sequestration in the tree biomass and in the soil there by avoiding the equivalent amount of GHG emissions which would have not been occurred in the pre-project scenario as the land remains degraded land with no carbon sequestration.

title: Hainan Jinhua IFM(Coversion of logged to protected forest)  Project
description:
The Hainan Jinhua IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project is implemented in Hainan Province of China by Hainan Jinhua Forestry Co., Ltd. 
In recent years, Hainan has been promoting the construction of tropical rainforest national parks and increasing the ecological restoration of tropical rainforests. In order to support Hainan's tropical rainforest protection and biodiversity conservation, since 01-Sep-2020, Hainan Jinhua Forestry Co., Ltd has taken the initiative to incorporate part of the company's forest land into the Hainan Tropical Rainforest National Park. Since the launch of Hainan Tropical Rainforest National Park, logging has been stopped in the protected area to achieve forest protection. The area of forest land allocated to Hainan Jinhua Forestry Co., Ltd is about 14,600 ha, including two tree species,  eucalyptus and Acacia mangium. Of these, the Acacia mangium forest land is involved in the the Improved Forest Management (IFM) project of the forests in the conversion of logged to protected forest.
The area of the project activity is 4863 ha, including 126 subcompartments spreading over Baisha, Baoting, Changjiang, Ledong, Lingshui, Qiongzhong, WuzhiMountain. All these departments are 100% owned by Hainan Jinhua Forestry Co., Ltd and have the legal right to forest ownership. The specie involved in the project is Acacia mangium. This is common local tree species.
Prior to the implementation of the project activity, Hainan Jinhua Forestry Co., Ltd harvested trees in the project area in accordance with a valid timber management plan approved by the government.
The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 3,187,713 tCO2e in 30 years, the average annual emission reduction is 106,257 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 2,486,416 tCO2e in 30 years, the average annual VCUs with buffer deduction is 82,881 tCO2e.

Hainan Jinhua Forestry Co,. Ltd
Hainan, China
13858054466

title: PANÃMA REDD+ PROJECT
description: The Panãma REDD+ Project is a partnership between Biofílica Investimentos Ambientais S.A.  Fundação Jari and Jari Celulose, with the purpose of promoting forest conservation and reducing potential greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) based on a model of local economic development that values the “standing forest” through the integration of Sustainable Forest Management activities and the commercialization of environmental services. The Project is located in three municipalities: Almeirim, in the State of Pará, and Laranjal do Jari/Vitória do Jarí, in the State of Amapá. There is a very important role in this region as it serves as a home for many rural families and as an ecological corridor, with several Conservation Units (CUs) in its vicinity. It has a very rich biodiversity, its vegetation includes ten forest and non-forest formations and species of extreme ecological and social importance.
