title: Kwango River Project, Democratic Republic of Congo
description:
This afforestation project, set up in anthropogenic savannahs on the Batéké Plateau east of Kinshasa, aims to develop carbon sink plantations, i.e. plantations where wood is little or no harvested, in order to maximize greenhouse gas sequestration in the long term. The majority of the project's area will therefore be dedicated to forest plantations with this main objective. Another objective of these forest plantations will be the timber production: some trees will be cut down very selectively in order to maintain the constant volume of the forest stand over time, while sustainably a local timber sector, replacing informal logging of natural forests. We also know that another effective tool to combat deforestation is an alternative and renewable source of charcoal for urban use and agricultural products, based on the establishment of agroforestry plantations (trees rows will be intercropped with lines of food crops).
As a result, the Project will have several social and environmental benefits such as (1) CO2 sequestration on land that is currently non-forested and unused, (2) Less pressure on the surrounding natural forests, thanks to the production of charcoal and timber from sustainably managed plantations, and the sensitization of local populations to agroforestry, that is more sustainable and productive than slash-and-burn agriculture or (3) Job creation, increased incomes and local development in a territory heavily affected by unemployment.
In this project, we account for the removals of GHG that occurred through the creation of the plantations: we use the UNFCCC AR-ACM0003 CDM methodology and the VCS Guidance AFOLU Guidance: Example for Calculating the Long-Term Average Carbon Stock for ARR Projects with Harvesting (Version of the 8 March 2011). The project plans to generate carbon credits for the voluntary market under the VCS standard. The first accreditation period is 30 years. The sequestration of GHG is estimated at 5,000,075 tCO2-e.
VCS Proponent:
FRM Commitment
Mauguio, France
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Shandong Ju County ALM Project
description:
Shandong Ju County ALM Project (hereafter as “the project”) is located in Ju County, Rizhao City, Shandong Province of China. The goal of this initiative is to reduce the carbon emissions currently emitted by the farms taking part to the project and raise the carbon storage in the soil. In addition, the selected measures will contribute to improving crop yields and soil health. The project was implemented by the Ju County Urban Construction Investment Group Co.,Ltd. and Hainan icarbon Ecological Development Co.,Ltd. (hereafter “the project proponent”).
The proposed project is aimed to prevent the soil degradation through adoption of the improved crop land management practices (collectively referred to conservational tillage) to replace the conventional cultivation mode.
Main activities about conservational tillage adopted in the project include： 
Organic fertilizer application (reduce inorganic fertilizer application): 53,422 ha of cropland has reduced the use of chemical fertilizer.
Straw incorporation (Improve crop residue management): straw in 53,422 ha of cropland has been buried and returned, with the depth of 30 cm.
A total of 53,422 ha of farmland has been managed under conservation tillage, The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 2,684,200 tCO2e from 01-Jan-2021 to 31-Dec- 2040, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 134,210 tCO2e.
For the project the validation date and the specific date of the first monitoring period of this project has not been determined, and will be supplemented in the latest PD.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Regeneration Meghalaya
description: The Regeneration Meghalaya Project is a grouped project under ARR (Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation) category that aims to increase tree cover through planting a majority of indigenous trees that are suited to local conditions of the bioregion. The project is located in the Khasi, Ri Bhoi Jaintia and Garo Hills regions, in the Northeastern state of Meghalaya, India. Regeneration Meghalaya will plant trees across up to 30,000 ha of wasteland. The project aims to plant up to 40 - 64 million trees sequestering up to 23 Million tonnes of CO2e in Meghalaya. In addition, the project aims to reach a significant number of beneficiaries over a period of 35 years. The GHG (greenhouse gas) removals in the project would be created by improving the land though planting new trees and plants in the eligible project areas. The project’s broader aims are to restore ecological integrity, reduce soil erosion, improve ecological functions, increase biodiversity and improve livelihoods. In this regard, the project will monitor and report on the co-benefits for climate adaptation, biodiversity and people through the climate, community and biodiversity standard (CCB). The project taps into and is led by indigenous knowledge custodians to accelerate landscape restoration and sustainably develop both tree-based and non-tree based products to create value chains and grow sustainable livelihoods. The project goals are aligned to the local needs and existing land use systems, farmer-led species selection that prioritise indigenous and naturalised species, and customised solutions to challenges identified by local stakeholders. The project area is home to the Khasi, Jaintia and Garo tribes, and the majority of the land is held under private / clan ownership, with some community control and management.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Trees for Livelihood in Madhya Pradesh, India
description: The objective of the project is to increase the tree cover outside forest (ToF) areas through ARR activities on privately owned lands of farmers who belong to the local communities. Some plantation is also undertaken on common lands under the village or Gram Panchayat if the GP wishes to include the same. Apart from ARR activities, the project also works closely with the communities to address livelihoods. The project aims to secure the financial security of the local farming and other communities through planting of farmer friendly trees to support traditional crop-based agriculture systems and through support through supplementary community-based interventions. The PP implements the project through service providers, who work closely with farmers to assess willingness to participate in the project, engage them in project activities and undertake project activities with high levels of participation from the local communities. The project team on the ground are employed from the local community, and care is taken to ensure participation of women and other marginalized members of the community.
VCS Proponent:
Value Network Ventures Advisory Services PTE. LTD
Singapore, Singapore
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Lishu Blackland Conservation Project in Jilin Province
description:
Heilongjiang Lishu Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereafter referred to as “the project”) is located in Lishu County, Jilin Province, China. The purpose of the project is to adopt improved agricultural land management practices including no tillage/reduced tillage，returning straw in fields and applying organic fertilizer, and to prevent the severe soil degradation caused by pre-existing conventional tillage in local crop land.
Since straw contains a large amount of organic matter and trace elements such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium, returning straw to the field can effectively use organic fertilizer resources and increase soil organic matter (SOM). Straw returning to the field also can improve soil physical and chemical properties, enhance soil aggregate structure, and increase soil permeability. Applying organic fertilizer can reduce nitrous oxide emission compared to synthetic fertilizer.
The project plans to implement no tillage/reduced tillage practice, straw returning and organic fertilizer application in 15,385 ha of agricultural land in the first crediting period to increase soil organic carbon (SOC) and reduce nitrous oxide emission. The project proponent not only introduced more efficient and appropriate tillage method with Lishu County Agriculture and Rural Affairs Bureau to the farmers, but also provide technical training and support to the farmers.
The scenario existing prior to the project’s implementation is primarily conventional tillage without straw returning, which cause greater soil disturbance and increase the loss of SOM.
During the first crediting period from 20-Nov-2022 to 19-Nov-2042, the project is expected to generate GHG emission removals of 1,110,180 tCO2e, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 55,509 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Jilin Kangfu Environmental Energy Co., Ltd.
Jilin Province, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: AGROFORESTRY PLANTATIONS TO ENHANCE THE LIVELIHOOD OF RURAL COMMUNITIES IN INDIA
description: The project is an initiative of various NGOS for the plantation activities. IICare Foundation is the aggregator and would act as the project proponent. The plantation activities are based in India. Project aims to plant 1 million trees which will contribute in carbon sequestration and promote the message of ‘green living’ among local community. The project plans the introduction of trees to farms and other landscapes for multiple productive purposes which could play a key role in climate change mitigation and adaptation and help increase tree cover at the selected sites. The project started in August 2020. The project encompasses scattered parcels of land measuring about 800 hectares distributed in 14 Indian states namely Uttarakhand, West Bengal, Odisha, Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Gujarat, Telangana, Uttar Pradesh, Madhya Pradesh, Assam, Rajasthan and Haryana with over 60% on aggregate basis in just two western states of Maharashtra and Gujarat.

title: Fortaleza Ituxi II REDD+
description: The Fortaleza Ituxi II REDD+ Project aims at protecting private forests located in one of the regions having the highest deforestation rate in the Amazon Biome: the municipality of Lábrea. The south region of the municipality of Lábrea has already been reached by the “Arc of Deforestation”: for the last 10 years, Lábrea has been one of the most deforested municipalities in the Amazon Biome. Besides the damage caused to natural ecosystems, the land-use changes have provoked severe social conflicts through processes of land-grabbing and installation of agriculture and cattle ranching activities, contributing to the expulsion of family-scale forest extractives from that region. The primary objective of the Fortaleza Ituxi II REDD+ Project is to avoid planned (APD) and unplanned (AUD) deforestation in an area of 69,185.87 ha of Amazonian forest. The APD REDD project area is expected to avoid a predicted 5,153.00 ha of legal deforestation, equating to 1,721,301 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime, an annual average of 57,376 tCO2e. The AUD REDD project area is expected to avoid a predicted 64,023.44 ha of illegal deforestation, equating to 16,066,567 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime, with an annual average of 535,552 tCO2e.

Kenya 011 is a subset of the TIST project in Kenya and applies to 12,892 Small Groups, 79,089 Participants, 53,357 active Project Areas, and 23,747 hectares.  TIST farmers use a mosaic restoration approach, planting on thousands of individual farms spread across the landscape. The individual farms are found throughout Kenya and concentrated around Mt Kenya.

title: The New Zealand Indigenous Forest Regeneration Project
description: The New Zealand Indigenous Forest Regeneration Project is an Improved Forest Management, Logged to Protected Forest (LtPF) project located in New Zealand that was developed using the VM0012 methodology. The project is a grouped project, with the project area encompassing both the North and South Islands of New Zealand, with project instances geographically dispersed throughout. Project instances predominantly include properties of Pinus radiata plantations that were established with the objective of harvesting the timber for commercial purposes. New Zealand Forestry Removals Limited (an entity within the New Zealand Carbon Farming Group) will either own or have a legal right to control, such properties in order to convert the plantations into protected forests, with the long-term goal of transitioning them to permanent native forest.

title: The New Zealand Transitional Afforestation Project
description:
The New Zealand Transitional Afforestation Project is a grouped ARR; afforestation project located in New Zealand developed using the Methodology for Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation Projects. The grouped project area encompasses both the North and South Islands of New Zealand, with project instances geographically dispersed throughout. Project instances are predominantly properties of degraded, unproductive or erosion prone farmland or abandoned gorse land. The project will plant exotic species as a nursing crop to eventually transition into a permanent native forest. New Zealand Forestry Removals Limited (an entity within New Zealand Carbon Farming Group) either owns or has a legal right to control such properties in order to convert the plantations into protected forests, with the long-term goal of transitioning them to permanent native forest. 

As indigenous forest species in New Zealand are notoriously slow growing, difficult, and expensive to establish on bare land, an exotic nurse crop of Pinus radiata is planted for both initial rapid sequestration and to provide cover to enhance the regeneration of indigenous undergrowth. Over time the indigenous forest species are managed to succeed the exotic species through the creation of light wells, pest and predator eradication, seed island planting and gradual selective thinning of exotics. This process made possible through the financing of VCU sales.

Under the baseline scenario, business as usual management practices are assumed with the typical regional practices of extensive livestock grazing, and in some cases abandonment of degraded scrubland of invasive species which is reflective of broader land management practices in New Zealand, without carbon financing. The project scenario is conservation management activities, wherein an exotic nurse crop is established initially to provide ecosystem protection and indigenous species enhancement activities.
VCS Proponent:
New Zealand Forestry Removals Limited
Auckland, New Zealand

title: Improved Grazing Management in Mosaic Forest - Grasslands Landscapes in the Centre-North of Argentina.
description:
The Improved Grazing management in Mosaic Forest-Grasslands Landscapes in the centre-north of Argentina aims to remove greenhouse gases from the atmosphere by implementing regenerative grazing practices across different properties of the northern-central region of Argentina. The fundamental axis of this approach is the division of large pastures into smaller paddocks, implementing rotational grazing, which allows periods of rest and recovery for the land.
The grouped project area covers 1,212,583 km2 in the north-center of Argentina. The region is dominated by grasslands with varying degrees of tree or shrub cover, ranging from savanna ecosystems characterized by sparse tree density to mosaic landscapes of grasslands and patches of native forests. These types of ecosystems, which integrate trees, forages, and livestock, can create significant synergies that improve soil health, while sequestering significant amounts of carbon from the atmosphere.

Developing these regenerative grazing activities in areas with remnants of native trees or forests also plays and important role in the conservation of natural habitats. These productive systems mitigate climate change without the need for a change in land use, thereby safeguarding habitats that support a rich diversity of native flora and fauna. On this basis, the Project will in the future develop plans for biodiversity conservation and integration of the communities involved in each socio-ecosystem. In this way, conservation will be integrated into productive systems, encouraging landowners to change their paradigms about non-productive areas of ranches.

The first Project Activity Instance is being carried out in the “La Alicia” property, located in the province of Santa Fe. The values obtained for this PAI determined that the project activities can result in a net GHG emissions reduction and removals of ~ 231,829 tCO2e in the SOC pool, with an annual average of 11,590 tCO2e in 20 years of the project.

Vista Energy Argentina SAU

title: Lavardin Improved Forest Management through the Extension of Rotation Age
description: The Lavardin IFM (Improved Forest Management) project aims to sequester carbon through improvements in the management of commercial Eucalyptus plantations in the southeastern and central-eastern region of Uruguay. The project will implement changes in the current plantation management regime, which includes two scenarios (A and B). Scenario A involves a current management of Eucalyptus globulus plantations with a 10-year harvest cycle for pulp production, covering a total planted area of 9,436 hectares. Scenario B covers a total planted area of 5,543 hectares and involves the current management of E. globulus and E. maidenii plantations with a commercial thinning at 10 years and a final harvest for high-quality wood at 20 years. The Lavardin IFM project will be implemented following the Verra Standards and is designed to have the same environmental and social impacts as all the carbon projects presented in the VCS, which sequester carbon through commercial plantations in Uruguay. Through a substantial capital investment, Lavardin will implement a unique management regime for the region (regime C) to sequester more atmospheric carbon dioxide. This new regime involves changing the species planted, selecting new ones which will increase productivity, and adjusting the rotation ages to maximize carbon sequestration and manage forests sustainably
VCS Proponent:

title: One Mara Carbon Project
description: The One Mara Carbon Project (OMCP) is an ecosystem-level conservation initiative that aims to protect ecological resources and provide economic and social co-benefits for communities by incentivizing conservancy formation and grassland restoration in the Maasai Mara landscape in Kenya. The goal of OMCP is to restore the degraded rangelands through improved grazing management and prevent further loss of grasslands by providing alternative livelihoods for communities, build resilient conservancies, ensure biodiversity conservation, and enhance tourism. This region is world-renown for the expansive rangelands where agropastoralists and wildlife co-exist. However, historical land sub-division into small, fenced land parcels and long term extensive grazing by livestock has led to land degradation, including the gradual loss in soil organic carbon (SOC). Communities living within the ecosystem depend on the condition of the grasslands to provide livelihoods that will meet their socio-economic needs. Implementing climate change mitigation measures and halting land degradation are vital to ensuring the longevity of this world-famous conservation area.

title: Selva Norte Conservation Project (CSN+)
description:
The Selva Norte Conservation project (CSN+) is a grouped REDD+ initiative developed by Projet Café Selva Norte Eleva Finca Inc and ECOTIERRA, supported by Café Selva Norte SAC, and financed by URAPI Sustainable Land Use Fund. CSN REDD+ is pioneering and unique in its kind, working with farmer communities, local governments, conservation organizations and private forest owners to enable them to access climate finance tools and consolidate their conservation efforts.

The project aims to reduce GHG emissions related to deforestation, over 200 000 ha in the department of Amazonas, Cajamarca and San Martin, in the north of Peru. The project will also contribute to consolidate an important conservation corridor and protect key ecosystems in the region.

Over the life of the project, we aim to diversify the income of more than 20 local organizations or communities. Currently, small and medium-scale conservation areas have little investment capacity and low or no income, a situation that can influence deforestation and forest degradation, thus generating loss or reduction of carbon stocks. CSN+ will make use of technical and financial tools available for conservation to generate greater benefits and create a diversified portfolio of activities, with the objective of creating a sustainable model for conservation.

CSN+ will enable the creation of a strong partnership between the communities, URAPI  and ECOTIERRA with the objective of reducing forest degradation and deforestation processes, introducing high productivity agricultural systems, ensuring the sustainable development of value chains; empowering producers, cooperatives, associations and the community in general; creating mechanisms for enforce conservation; and increase environmental awareness of the communities.
State/Province: Cajamarca, Amazonas and San Martin regions
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: YBYRÁ REDD+ Project
description:
The YBYRÁ REDD+ Project is a unique REDD+ Project, composed by 74 rural private properties with a project area of 76,481.34 hectare of Amazon rainforest. The project is located in four municipalities: Paragominas, Ipixuna do Pará, Tomé-Açu and Ulianópolis, in the state of Pará, Brazil. The main goals are forest conservation and reduction of GHG emissions of 12,065,803.14 tCO2 in 30 years by avoiding deforestation of 38,317.74 ha in the Project area. 
Pará explores unsustainably the Amazon Forest since its historical occupation. In 2021, almost 25% deforested areas in Brazil were in Pará.  The document known as “Deforestation Arc” presented a list with 52 cities considered priority for prevention, monitoring, and control actions against deforestation  in the Amazonian region (decree nº 6.321/2007 and Ordinance n° 428 (2018) by the Ministry of Environment). The list includes Paragominas and Ulianópolis. 
The deforestation of the amazon forest in the region of the project is due to anthropic activities: timber exploration, pasture for cattle raising and agriculture. The pressure on turning forest into non-forested areas is consequence of the expansion of these economic activities, leading to invasions of private properties. For the project region, the main land use activity is the implementation of pasture for cattle raising. In relation to the social aspects, most of the communities are formed by rural farmers with social vulnerabilities, with presence of food insecurity, low income and lack of job opportunity.
Considering the aspects presented, the Project’s main goals, through conservation of forest areas and combating deforestation of the Amazon Forest, are: 1) To promote adaptations to climate change in the region; 2) To improve the quality of life of the population that lives close to the forest and 3) To conserve biodiversity and ecosystem services, through environmental education actions and foment initiatives to connect forest fragments of the PA.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: Selabam Hydropower Extension Project
description: The project is installation of 8 MW hydro project in Lao PDR. The project is being developed by EDL-Generation Public Company in Champasak province of Lao PDR.  The primary purpose of the project is to generate electricity to the Lao Power Grid. Total installed capacity of the project is 8MW, provided by two (2) Kaplan turbine and the unit capacity is 4MW. Project is commissioned on 14/12/2022 with an expected average annual electricity output of 22,640 MWh. The baseline scenario of the project is continuation of the present situation, i.e., electricity supplied from the power grid. By displacing part of the power generated by thermal power plants, the project is therefore expected to reduce equivalent CO2 emissions from grid-connected power plants.

title: Tueré REDD+ Project
description:
The Tueré REDD+ Project is a partnership between Biofílica Ambipar Environment and Brascomp  Compensados do Brasil S.A. and aims to promote forest conservation, maintain carbon stocks and mitigate climate change by reducing Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from land use changes. In addition to  climate benefits, the Project also aims to generate social benefits based on sustainable economic development practices and improving the well-being of surrounding communities, in addition to environmental benefits through actions aimed at the conservation of local fauna and flora.
The Project Area has 135,342 ha of Amazon forest, located in the mesoregion of Marajó, in the municipality of Portel, state of Pará, and is located on the banks of the Anapu and Tueré Rivers. Communities have been identified that are directly or indirectly influenced by the Project, and that are geographically close to the Project Area and depend on its ecosystem services.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: Ateles REDD+
description: The Ateles REDD+ Project is a partnership between Biofílica Ambipar Environment and AgroSB Agropecuária and aims to promote forest conservation and mitigate climate change by reducing Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from changes in land use. It is made up of a significant part of the Amazon rainforest, located in the municipality of São Félix do Xingú, in the southeast of the state of Pará. The entire project is part of the APA Triunfo do Xingu, a conservation unit with the greatest pressure from deforestation in Brazil, which over the last few decades has suffered major threats to the maintenance of its forest remnants due to large-scale illegal deforestation. Furthermore, the region is of great importance in terms of its biodiversity, as it is located in the Tapajós Endemism Center, a place with a high concentration of rare and endemic species. In addition to climate benefits, the project aims to ensure the conservation and protection of biodiversity and natural resources through mitigating and preventative measures such as strengthening asset surveillance, social inclusion and regional socio-economic development through alternative practices to deforestation and the development and strengthening of value chains, the establishment of a biodiversity conservation program, promoting in situ monitoring of fauna and flora in the Project Area, the development of strategies that seek to bring land security and territorial belonging, as well as the strengthening of local governance, stimulated mainly by the engagement and involvement of stakeholders.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: Ningxia Pengyang 2021-2023 Afforestation Project
description:
The Ningxia 2021-2023 Pengyang Afforestation Project, Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region (hereafter as ‘the project’) is located in Pengyang County, Guyuan City, Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region of China. The aim of the project is to increase carbon sequestration and to contribute to the local sustainable development by planting the trees and shrubs on the barren mountains and barren land. The project was implemented by Bureau of Natural Resources in Pengyang, who is the proponent of this project (hereafter ‘the project proponent’). The forest is to be established in the project in 10,150 hectares by direct planting various tree and shrub species on barren hills in the selected states. These tree species include Robinia pseudoacacia, Populus hopeiensis, Pinus tabuliformis, Picea, Pinus sylvestris, Red Armeniaca sibirica, Dahurian larch, Salix matsudacernegundo, Acer truncatum, Platycladus orientalis, Pinus bungeana Zucc, Salix matsudana, Chinese Robinia, Robinia, Acer negundoaurea, Ulmus pumila, Armeniaca sibirica, Prunus davidiana, and shrub species involves Shinyleaf Yellowhorn, Hippophae Fructus, Korshinsk Peashrub, Cerasus humilis, Rosa xanthina Lindl and Clove. 
The project is located in the Pengyang County, which covers 12 towns and 3 tree farms, Baiyang Town, Caomiao Town, Chengyang Town, Fengzhuang Town, Gucheng Town, Honghe Town, Jiaocha Town, Luowa Town, Mengyuan Town, Wangwa Town, Xiaocha Town, Xinji Town, Caiyang Town, and Ruhe Tree farm, Caomiao Tree farm, Xiaoyuanzi Tree farm.
The land in the project area was barren mountains and barren land, according to the baseline survey, before the implementation of the project, there was no natural or secondary forest in the project area. The implementation of the afforestation project will generate GHG emission removals and mitigate climate change improve soil and water conservation and forest cover; enhance local biodiversity by increasing the connectivity of forest.
The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 3,197,649 tCO2e in 60 years, the average annual emission reduction is 53,294 tCO2e.

title: Xinxiang Yanmai Biogas Utilization Project
description:
Xinxiang Yanmai Biogas Utilization Project (hereinafter referred to as the project) is located at Yanjin County Industrial Agglomeration Zone, Yanjin County, Xinxiang City, Henan Province, P.R. China. The project is owned and implemented by Xinxiang Yanmai Food Co., Ltd

The project will introduce new anaerobic waste water treatment system (Two anaerobic
Digesters with effective volume of 8000m3 and 5000m3 separately) to treat waste water from starch production of Xinxiang Yanmai Food Co., Ltd.. The project uses digesters to treat waste water, collect and utilized the generated biogas to avoid methane emissions. The generated biogas will be captured and used for heat generation which will be used for starch production
with 8t/h biogas boiler within the project site. The residual waste from the digester will be used for soil application. Wastewater from the waste water treatment system will be discharged to Yanjin Municipal Sewage Treatment Plant for advanced treatment. 

Prior to the implementation of the project, the waste water was treated in open anaerobic lagoon at the project site and generated methane was emitted to the atmosphere directly without any methane recovery and destruction facility. The project is expected to avoid GHG emissions of methane through recovery and destruction of biogas.
VCS Proponent:
Xinxiang Yanmai Food Co., Ltd
Henan Province, China

title: Biaofa Juancheng Animal Manure Management Project
description:
Biaofa Juancheng Animal Manure Management Project (hereafter referred to as the project) is located at Wanhua Industrial Zone, Hongchuan Town, Juancheng County, Heze City, Shandong Province, P.R.China. The project is invested, constructed and operated by Biaofa Ecological (Juancheng) Co., Ltd. 

The purpose of the project is to treat the manure to avoid methane emissions generated in the baseline uncovered anaerobic lagoons. The project will introduce a new waste management system (enclosed anaerobic digesters) to treat animal manure from 19 livestock farms in Juancheng County to replace the existing open anaerobic lagoons at the livestock farms. The treated manure is collected by tank trucks from the livestock farms to the project site and the collected manure is subsequently treated at
project site. 

By treating the manure with enclosed anaerobic digester with total effective volume of 75.360 cubic meters. The project will avoid the emissions of methane that would be generated from animal manure treatment in the existing open anaerobic lagoons at the 19 livestock farms. The biogas generated during the treatment process will be partly used for electricity generation used for operation of the project, partly used for heat generation used within the project and the rest will be supplied to users nearby for heat generation (the generated GHG emission reductions from electricity generation and heat utilization will not be claimed for conservativeness). The fermented sludge from the enclosed anaerobic digesters will be treated aerobically and used in nearby farmland as organic fertilizer. Wastewater from the treatment system will be used for agriculture irrigation.
VCS Proponent:
Biaofa Ecological (Juancheng) Co., Ltd
Shandong Province, China

title: Hive Ecosystems project
description: The Hive Ecosystems Project is a revegetation and restoration project aimed at addressing the impact of long-term degradation caused through unsustainable livestock production over the past century within the Albany Thicket Biome of South Africa.The initial project instances are located on a 7,300 hectare private landholding. The project aims to rehabilitate degraded farmlands through extensive planting and management of P. afra. Active restoration has been shown to successfully rehabilitate the vegetation type and lead to gradually recovery of carbon stocks that were released following early degradation.  The outcomes of the project extend far beyond the sequestration of carbon. A primary outcome is the rehabilitation of an indigenous, diverse vegetation type that in a functional state, provides resilient ecosystem services to both local residents and downstream urban hubs. In an area that is predicted to become warmer and drier over time and has recently experienced a protracted drought (Mahlalela et al. 2020), the climate change adaptation benefit of raising livestock and securing water in a resilient manner is perhaps of greater importance than the climate change mitigation outcome of the initiative.

title: Baviaanskloof Carbon Project
description: The Baviaanskloof Carbon Project will seek to sequestrate carbon through rehabilitation and restoration of the subtropical Albany Thicket biome The project includes a broad set of additional activities, including initial land rehabilitation (e.g., erosion control measures), the establishment of nurseries and replanting of specific indigenous species, as well as the long-term management of grazing pressure at a level that allows thicket recovery. This process leads to an increase in both biomass- and soil organic- carbon stocks, thereby gradually sequestering atmospheric carbon over time.

title: Chahar Right Rear Banner Improved Grassland Management Project
description: The Chahar Right Rear Banner Improved Grassland Management Project aims to restore degraded grassland ecosystems through grazing management in the project zone. By introducing sustainable grazing practices such as grazing prohibition and grassland-livestock balance, manual restoration measures such as fence building, rodent control, and other sustainable grassland management measures, this project is expected to enhance local carbon sequestration and contribute to the development of local ecosystems. The existing degradation and salinization area accounts for 99.67% of the local grassland. To combat and reverse this degradation, the project proposes to implement improved grassland management across 225,382.93 ha of degraded grassland.

title: Tasar Forest Carbon Project
description:
This Tasar Forest Carbon Project will promote tree-based wild silk production outside traditional forests by utilizing privately owned barren / fallow uplands of tribal farmers. The project will undertake wild silk (locally called Tasar) tree planting and promote sericulture-based livelihoods. Sericulture is a traditional livelihood, however lack of availability of host trees in natural forests constrains its expansion. Traditionally, the tribal communities in the targeted areas depend majorly on forests for their livelihoods and have a long history of wild silk production from natural forests – wild silk is second to agriculture as a source of livelihoods. However, production from the forests declined due to government regulation of forest access rights. Yet there are large areas in these regions that are severely degraded, fallow, etc. that would benefit from restoring their productive capacity and biodiversity through profitable tree planting investments. 
The project is implemented by Cognisphere Solutions Ltd. (CSL) with investment from Climate Partner Impact GmbH starting in 2022. The project will afforest 2,000 hectares of privately-owned wastelands with Tasar silk-host trees in the adjoining states of Jharkhand and West Bengal in India. The project implementation started from May 2022 and plantations were initiated in the season Jun to Oct 2022.
It will involve the participation of ~3,000 households in 125 villages, grouped into two clusters broadly in Jharkhand, and West Bengal. People in the project areas are majorly tribals with limited options to escape poverty and deprivation. Tasar host trees such as Terminalia arjuna and T. tomentosa will form the core species, accompanied with a diversity of other indigenous tree species. The planted trees will be managed as long-term agroforestry systems –integrating crop production (intercropping), Tasar silk production and associated value chain development.

title: Permaculture initiative through community participation
description:
This project aims to implement permaculture activities through community participation in 9,400 ha in the region of Moba, Democratic Republic of Congo. The specific objectives of the grouped project are:
1.	Setting up large-scale tree planting projects on 9,400 ha based on the “direct seeding” technique.
2.	Implement solutions for soil fertility, water conservation, climate change mitigation, and animal habitat.
3.	To raise awareness of climate change and adaptation strategies.
4.	Creation of permaculture schools’ farms through the implementation of a community program that fosters the training of the community on permaculture practices with native species with the aim of creating a community using self-sustaining systems.
The project contributes to the mitigation of greenhouse gases through a combination of sustainable land management practices and principles that promote carbon sequestration and reduced greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Enhancing rural livelihoods of farmers through carbon finance
description:
Agroforestry can help in the conservation and rehabilitation of ecosystems and provide better livelihood opportunities for rural communities. The proposed Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) GKF agroforestry project, titled 'Enhancing Rural Livelihoods of Small and Marginalised Farmers through Carbon Finance,’ operates in several districts across Telangana and Andhra Pradesh, situated in the southeastern region of India. The project spans five districts in Telangana, namely Bhadradri Kothagudem, Khammam, Suryapet, Karimnagar, and Mancherial, as well as six districts in Andhra Pradesh, namely West Godavari, East Godavari, Eluru, Kakinada, Konaseema, and Alluri Seetharama Raju.
The agroforestry project seeks to foster sustainable agroforestry practices among small-scale farmers in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh, India. The primary objectives are to enable farmers to attain financial benefits while also ensuring greenhouse gas (GHG) mitigation within the region.

title: Bundled Solar Power Project by AMP Energy - 02
description: The project involves installation of bundled Solar Photovoltaic (SPV) power plant with a cumulative capacity of 12.37 MW primarily to meet the captive demand of the premises owners and the rooftop, ground mounted and carport solar units are connected to the national grid through net metering mechanism. The premises owners are the customers of the power generated from the solar panels who purchase the power under long term power purchase agreements signed for 25 years. Before installation of the solar units, the Shrinath Rotopack premises and VW2 premises owners used to meet the electricity demand from the national grid of the India. The project thus replaces fossil fuel dominated grid electricity thereby reducing the equivalent amount of GHG emission. The project company for Shrinath Rotopack is AMPSolar Power Generation Private Limited and for VW2, it is AMP Energy Distributed Generation One Pvt. Ltd.

It is implemented by the representative Project Proponent Baisha Li Autonomous County Rural Revitalization and Development Co., Ltd (hereafter “Project Proponent”). Before the implementation of the project, the forest in the project area shall be planted according to the design of commercial forest, and logged annually according to the timber logging and managing plan issued by the local forest authority. title: Reforestation of Lands for Multiple Purposes as a Sustainable Development Driver
description:
The grouped project “Reforestation of lands for multiple purposes as a sustainable development driver” has as its stated goal the promotion of sustainable reforestation in Southern Brazil, specifically in the states of Paraná and Santa Catarina, aiming to achieve net removals of greenhouse gases from the atmosphere. 
The land use that has historically predominated in these states is non-forested lands, such as agriculture and cattle raising. The project proposes a change in the traditional land use of this region, promoting reforestation practices as a sustainable alternative, either to produce wood for multiple purposes based on rapid-growth species (for example, Pinus.spp or Eucalyptus.spp), and/or to restore areas based on native species of the local phytophysiognomy. The overall purpose of this initiative is to develop economically profitable reforestation system, integrating reforestation activities for the purposes of production and restoration of conservation areas, which simultaneously provides environmental and social benefits to the region. This grouped project also contemplates the possibility of silvopastoral systems implementation, nonetheless, emission removals will only be claimed for the reforestation activities.
VCS Proponent:
Klabin SA
São Paulo, Brazil
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Xinjiang Altay Improved Grassland Management Project
description:
Xinjiang Altay Improved Grassland Management Project (hereafter as ‘the project’) is located in Altay City, Altay Prefecture, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, China. The project aims to restore the local degraded grassland ecosystem by Improved sustainable grassland management measures, such as rotating grazing and grazing prohibition in the project area by building fences, and improving the degraded grassland ecosystem by reseeding high-quality local grass seeds. After the implementation of the project, the grassland will be scientifically and rationally utilized according to the health status of the local grassland ecosystem. Achieve long-term sustainable management of degraded local grasslands. The implementation of the project has significantly improved the local climate benefits, community benefits and biodiversity benefits. The project sponsor is Xinjiang Altay City Zhujin Investment Co., LTD..
The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 18,687,019 tCO2-e in 40 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 467,175.475 tCO2-e.

title: Livestock 2040/ Uruguay
description: The Livestock 2040/Uruguay project is driven and conceived by the consulting firm Profesionales SRL.It involves the participation of farmers in Uruguay who practice rotational grazing and have implemented good management practices on their property. Project is a grouped project.Rotational grazing is the primary activity of the project, which brings benefits to the ecosystem: it prevents and reduces soil erosion, improves the nutrient cycle, increases soil organic carbon (SOC) levels, and boosts pasture production. Participants also implement good practices in grass-fed livestock management with the goal of enhancing the ecosystem's well-being through the management of the plant-soil-animal relationship. Grazing management that enables higher quantity and quality of pasture to support high stocking rates while respecting animal welfare is a key component. Activities that increase biodiversity, such as the inclusion of native species and hunting prohibition, are considered relevant.Additionally, actions are proposed to reduce the use of external inputs, such as fertilizers or livestock feed, which contributes to decreasing greenhouse gas emissions. The result of these practices is an increase in organic matter in the soil, i.e., higher SOC content. Furthermore, the process of grassland degradation is reversed.The baseline consists of soils that were previously used for agriculture or extensive livestock farming. These soils have lost productive plant species, with areas of bare soil, compaction, low fertility, and a high risk of erosion.The project scenario consists of structured soils with a good amount of organic matter, high fertility levels, and enhanced plant growth. Compaction, erosion risk, and the amount of bare soil decrease.Estimations of emission reductions and absorption were made for the first project activity instant located in Sierra de las Animas, Maldonado, Uruguay. Greenhouse gas removals for this phase totaled 12,007 tCO2 over the 20 years.
VCS Proponent:
Profesionales SRL
Montevideo, Uruguay

title: Rabo Carbon Bank Trees for Farmers (TFF) Brazil ARR Grouped Project
description:
This is an afforestation, reforestation and revegetation (ARR) Grouped Project aiming at establishing, restoring and/or increasing vegetative cover through planting and assisted natural regeneration in degraded forestlands, bare soils, degraded or low productivity pasture/agricultural lands and areas undergoing regeneration, located in the Amazon, Cerrado and Atlantic Forest Biomes. The project uses a mix of native species to create biodiverse forests and woodlands, and in the future potentially complemented with a share of non-native tree plantings if it is proven to be beneficial to the ecosystem and local communities. 
The project is proposed by the Trees for Farmers initiative of the Rabobank Carbon Bank, which leads and facilitates Brazilian farmers to establish, restore and/or increase vegetative cover with financing, project management as well as technical and logistical knowledge on implementation and maintenance of reforestation activities.
The first instance will be implemented in a 68.06ha area inside Fazenda Santa Paulina which in turn has 1,962 ha in the municipality of Gaúcha do Norte, State of Mato Grosso, Brazil. Since 2018, the project area has had no agropastoral activity and gave way to an area with very little and/or slow growing patchy vegetation and bare soils.
These bare areas are being replanted by the project with a mix of native species while keeping the existing patches of woody vegetation in place. This project will utilize a (Plan Vivo approved) method with remote sensing technology, called Acorn, to monitor the biomass increments and carbon sequestration.
The TFF Brazil Project foresees a gradual expansion of planted areas throughout three Brazilian biomes between 2022 and 2062. It is expected that a total of 20.000 ha (to be expanded in the final version) planted during the project lifetime.

title: Xinjiang Habahe Improved Grassland Management Project
description:
Xinjiang Habahe Improved Grassland Management Project is located in Habahe County, Altay Region, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, China. The Project aims to reduce the duration and amount of grazing on degraded grasslands by planting pasture grasses and improving grazing practices, in order to restore local degraded grassland systems and ensure grassland sustainability.
The project implemented sustainable grassland management on 91,976.85 hectares of degraded grassland through three measures: artificial grass planting, fencing and grazing ban, and rotational grazing. The implementation of the management measures can effectively increase the carbon stock and reduce non-CO2 greenhouse gas emissions, and ultimately achieve the purpose of greenhouse gas emission reduction. 
The project is expected to generate GHG emission removals of 6,283,832 tCO2e in 40 years, with an average annual GHG emission removals of 157,096 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:

title: Tang River Improved Cropland Management Project
description:
The project changes the previous traditional agricultural management practices to multiple Improved agricultural land management practices. The project is in Tanghe County, Nanyang City, Henan province, China. It involves 94,614 ha cropland where corn and wheat are rotated.
Before implementation of the project, long-term and high-intensity deep tillage were conducted every year in the project area and no organic fertilizer was used. Additionally, no crop straw was returned to the field. The soil structure was damaged by these traditional ALM practices, which causes the loss of organic carbon in the soil, and leads to soil degradation. The project activity is expected to improve soil SOC and soil health through multiple ways of IALM practices. The intensity of tillage in the project scenario is decreased by reducing the frequency of tillage. The tillage is conducted every three years instead of each year. Organic fertilizer is used to replace part of the inorganic fertilizers. Moreover, the crop straw in the project area is returned to the field. These IALM practices can improve soil health and the SOC content will also be increased. Besides, N2O emissions are avoided due to reduced application of nitrogen fertilizer.
VCS Proponent:
Nanyang Soil and Fertilizer Station
Henan Province, China

VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Land Life Reforestation and Restoration of Degraded Land in Spain - A
description:
The proposed ARR-VCS project is a large-scale grouped project that aims for the long-term restoration of Spain’s forests, achieved through native mixed-species reforestation that reverses the impact of land degradation and the loss of flora and fauna. Land regeneration and biodiversity rejuvenation are central objectives of this reforestation project, which employs the latest technologies and planting techniques that ensure the highest tree survival rate and support the permanent establishment of native forests that complement rural communities. The project proponent is Defined B.V., a private limited liability company based in the Netherlands. Defined B.V. is an investment vehicle that holds various climate impact investments all dedicated to reducing worldwide CO2 emissions. Project activities are implemented by Land Life, a Dutch technology-driven reforestation company that grows forests by planting trees at scale.

Project activities are implemented and monitored according to the VCS-approved project methodology AR-ACM0003, with the expectation that additional project instances are to be added over the coming years. The first group of instances of the project covers 186.3 ha of degraded land in Spain, at two planting sites: Pison (52.69 ha), located in the province of Palencia, and Mata de Hoz (69.22 ha), located in Cantabria, and Agallas, in Salamanca (64.39 ha). While each project instance is expected to sequester carbon across the entire 100-year crediting period, the ex-ante estimate focuses on the initial 40 years for practical reasons to determine the annual average profile. These project instances, implemented between 2020 and 2022, are expected to sequester approximately 55,4120 tCO2e over the initial 43 years of the 100-year crediting period. The estimated annual average of GHG emission removals is 1,385 tCO2e. A total of 144,561 native trees are expected to become established in the project areas.

title: The Resilient Tarangire Ecosystem Project
description:
The Resilient Tarangire Ecosystem Project (RTEP) builds upon the prior work of Northern Tanzania Rangelands Initiative (NTRI). NTRI is a collaborative effort between The Nature Conservancy (TNC) and several local partner organizations (Ujamaa Community Resource Team and Tanzania People and Wildlife) to work with pastoralist communities to conserve rangelands and improve rangeland management in the Tarangire ecosystem of Northern Tanzania. Increasing population has led to increased pressure on rangeland resources, resulting in an overall decline in rangeland health and loss of carbon stocks over the past several decades. Simultaneously, this increased pressure on rangeland resources has exacerbated human-wildlife conflict and conflict among communities.
The project will focus on increasing soil carbon stocks through improved rangeland management in participating communities. Through RTEP, communities establish seasonal grazing areas to ensure efficient use of forage in the wet and dry seasons. These areas are then subdivided into smaller grazing blocks in which high-intensity, short-duration grazing can be implemented, leading to an increase in soil organic carbon stocks by increasing annual net primary productivity and allowing for recovery of forage species that typically decline under continuous grazing. The project will also help train and support community grazing coordinators who are responsible for overseeing implementation of these grazing plans. The expected long-term average annual emissions removals on a per area basis 0.73 t CO2-eq ha-1. The expected project size is about 830,000 ha, meaning the expected average annual emissions removal for the entire project area is 607,360 t CO2-eq resulting in a total of 12,147,200 t CO2-eq over the project’s lifetime.

title: Yvoty REDD+ Project: Forest Conservation in Eastern Paraguay
description: The Yvoty REDD project is an initiative aimed at addressing unplanned deforestation in eastern Paraguay, with its initial focus on the Mbaracayú Reserve. This reserve, spanning 64,400 hectares, houses significant biodiversity and was established in 1992 through an international treaty. However, since 2007, it has faced illegal deforestation due to cannabis cultivation, leading to increased fire incidents. The project, led by the Fundación Moises Bertoni (FMB), aims to reduce these threats by implementing management plans that enhance security, monitoring, environmental education, and community outreach. The project will be funded through carbon certification, specifically the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) and methodology VM0007, with an expected reduction of 19,466,334 tCO2e in emissions over 30 years, equivalent to 645,100 tCO2e per year.

title: Panambi REDD+ Project: Forest Conservation in the Paraguayan Chaco
description:
Paraguay, renowned for its abundant fauna and vegetation, has emerged as an area of concern regarding deforestation in Latin America. Both legal and illegal practices are slowly depleting these natural resources. Beyond their role as host of a vast biodiversity, the forests are also a crucial carbon sink.
The conversion of forests into cattle ranching, agriculture and timber production is one of the main drivers of legal deforestation in the country. Despite the Oriental Region of Paraguay has a zero-deforestation policy, the Occident, known as the Chaco Region, lost around 4.37 million hectares of forest between 2005 and 2020 to these practices (INFONA, 2022).
Under these circumstances, this project has been designed to preserve the Paraguayan Chaco forests by grouping landowners that have plans and permits to clear land but are willing to reduce this planned deforestation. Our goals include raising awareness about conservation and its positive effects, controlling logging practices and monitoring environmental and social indicators.
According to VCS Standard 4.5, eligible REDD activities are those that reduce net GHG emissions by reducing deforestation and/or forest degradation and, since the land is legally authorized to be converted to a non-forest area, project activities fall under the Avoiding Planned Deforestation category.
In the long term, specific actions related to biodiversity and community will be defined to be developed within the project framework.
Under the selected methodology, the carbon project is expected to generate a total of 45 million tCO2e in emission reductions over the course of a 30-year period. In other words, a yearly emission reduction equivalent to 1,5 million tCO2e.

Ecosecurities Group Limited

title: Carbono Rural Paraguayan Chaco
description:
The Carbono Rural Paraguayan Chaco project aims to promote sustainable grazing practices in degraded pastures in Western Paraguay, targeting farmers practicing continuous or unsustainable grazing. The project aims to enhance grazing system productivity, soil carbon sequestration, and reduce GHG emissions. Paraguayan Chaco's primary economic activity is livestock farming, with farms ranging from 1,000 ha to 60,000 ha. Traditional management includes extensive pastures, resulting in degradation due to mismanagement, pests, weed proliferation, and overgrazing, mainly due to a lack of technical advice and high costs for sustainable practices. The project leverages carbon market incentives to promote sustainable farming.

Current practices lead to severe pasture and soil degradation, reducing land productivity and carbon retention capacity. The project seeks to restore soil properties, prevent degradation, and increase livestock productivity through controlled grazing, pest and water management, and producer capacity building. Desde el Suelo, an agronomic extensionist team, will implement and monitor project activities.

Increased grassland productivity is expected to sequester carbon, improve livestock production, and bring community and biodiversity benefits: i) enhance livestock production efficiency and stability, ii) improve soil quality, iii) raise livestock farming incomes, iv) enhance soil and grassland biodiversity, v) reduce pollution, vi) strengthen community resilience, vii) boost rural employment and skills in grazing management, viii) improve rural worker well-being, and ix) enhance animal welfare. The project aligns with UN Sustainable Development Goals:

SDG Goal 2: Zero Hunger
SDG Goal 8: Decent work and economic growth
SDG Goal 13: Climate Action
SDG Goal 15: Life on Land
The project is a grouped initiative in Paraguayan Chaco, aiming to generate 445,697 tCO2e/year reductions and removals using Methodology VM0042 v2.0.

Ecosecurities Group Limited

projects@ecosecurities.com

title: Pantanal REDD+ Program
description:
The Pantanal biome is located in the center-west of Brazil, covering portions of the states of Mato Grosso and Mato Grosso do Sul. Considered the largest continuous freshwater wetland on the planet, this biome oscillates between terrestrial and aquatic phases, forming a mosaic of landscapes that provide great biodiversity of flora and fauna. Analyzing the historical context of the region where the Pantanal is located, there has been a considerable expansion of agricultural activities (the main local economic activity, mainly focused on the breeding of Pantanal cattle) and this factor, together with the high rates of forest fires in this area, results in a scenario of unsustainable exploitation of the natural resources of this biome.
Considering all the applicable legal requirements, landowners who have a surplus of native vegetation on their property and choose to preserve it, would fulfill the first requirement for obtaining economic incentives from the voluntary carbon market, through Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD) through Avoided Planned Deforestation (APD). Given all this context, the implementation of the REDD+ Carbon Program on a scale for the Pantanal biome is possible, providing a model of sustainable economic development that can help to redress the balance, reconciling the conservation of environmental services with traditional economic activities. Biofílica Ambipar, in partnership with rural landowners in the Pantanal of Mato Grosso do Sul who are committed to promoting dialogue that benefits both the environment and sustainable economic development, aims to develop economic activities linked to the conservation of environmental services and all their ecological functions through the implementation of the Pantanal REDD+ Program.

title: RESTORED PRODUCTIVE LANDSCAPES IN THE MAGDALENA RIVER MIDDLE BASIN IN COLOMBIA
description:
The main objectives of this project are: First, to recover lands degraded by land uses related to deforestation, such as cattle ranching; through ecological restoration, agroforestry systems and assisted natural regeneration, to ensure the recovery of forests inhabited by many species of flora and fauna, including endangered species such as the brown spider monkey, the blue-billed curassow, capuchin monkey, the white-faced curassow, and the night monkey. Second, by implementing restoration corridors to reconnect wild populations within a grassland matrix to increase the flow of individuals, and therefore the genetic flow, of these populations and thus increase their resilience and probability of survival in the medium and long term. And third, to recover strategic areas that are degraded, such as the banks of rivers and other bodies of water or areas where grassland productivity is low. 
FPP Colombia (project proponent) is a non-profit organization promoting biodiversity research and conservation focusing on endangered primate species. FPP initiated one of Colombia's first studies and conservation programs for the brown spider monkey. FPP operates one of the longest-running research projects in Latin America, focusing on the brown spider monkey, one of the world's most endangered primates. FPP's activities have been concentrated in the Middle Magdalena River Valley, an area relatively little studied affected by human activity and part of a global biodiversity hotspot (Tumbes-Chocó-Magdalena).
The Proyecto de Vida Silvestre, an initiative of Ecopetrol SA, Fondo Acción and WCS, seeks to conserve biodiversity in 3 regions of Colombia of biological and cultural importance, but which face increasing pressures that threaten natural resources. Through the articulation of these conservation initiatives, sustainability is sought through the development of a grouped carbon project which will generate income from carbon credits to achieve the objectives of ecosystem recovery

title: TAJIMAT PUJUT - El buen vivir - Restauración y conservación de los bosques Awajún del Alto Mayo
description:
The “Tajimat Pujut, Restoration and Conservation of the Alto Mayo Awajun Forests” is a grouped project jointly developed by the Federacion Regional Indigena Awajun del Alto Mayo (Regional Awajun Indigenous Federation of Alto Mayo - FERIAAM) and Conservation International Foundation (CI). FERIAAM is an indigenous territorial organization that groups and represents 16 indigenous Awajun communities (13 in the department of San Martin, and 3 in the department of Loreto). FERIAAM is the lead project proponent and CI is the co-proponent. The project is located in the provinces of Moyobamba, Rioja and Datem del Marañon, and covers an area of 235,455ha.
The main goal of the “Tajimat Pujut” project is to achieve the restoration and conservation of Awajun forests. In recent decades, deforestation within the Awajun communities has accelerated, with greater impact since 1990 after the opening of the Fernando Belaunde Terry highway. The increase in deforestation is mainly due to a heavy migration of people from the Andes and coastal region of Peru to the Amazon, causing a significant change in forest cover due to the expansion of the agricultural frontier and the illegal logging of high-value timber species. The forests of native communities have been replaced by commercial crops, mainly by farmers (tenants), invaders and illegal loggers. 
The project will focus on implementing strategies and activities to achieve better management of the Awajun territory, strengthen its governance and indigenous identity, restore degraded areas, and diversify sources of income and sustainable productive activities that secure wellbeing for the Awajun people. Tajimat Pujut expects to generate 8,788,206 tCO2eq over the 30 year project lifetime, with an average of 292,940 tCO2eq per year.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: WANAMEI (Árbol de vida) Conservando los bosques de Amarakaeri
description:
The “WANAMEI” Project is located in Peru, within the province of Manu (department of Madre de Dios), and the province of Paucartambo (department of Cusco). The Executor of the Administration Contract of the Amarakaeri Communal Reserve (ECA – Amarakaeri) is the lead project proponent and will work with Conservational International Foundation (CI) and the National Association of Administration Contract Executors of Communal Reserves from Peru (ANECAP) as co-proponents. The Project area includes the Amarakaeri Communal Reserve, its 10 associated indigenous communities and the Quero Haramba conservation concession, covering nearly 599,286 ha  

The Amarakaeri landscape is under high risk of deforestation as a result of the expansion of illegal gold mining into Madre de Dios. The main agents of deforestation are migrants, who come from neighboring regions in Peru due to the profitability of the mining activity. In addition, increasing migration to the region is driving an increase in deforestation through the conversion of forests to agriculture and cattle pastures.
The Project will reduce GHG emissions by implementing participatory conservation strategies with the indigenous communities’ partners of the ECA, and will be developed based on the RIA (Amazon Indigenous REDD+) guidelines established by indigenous national organizations as safeguards for carbon projects within their territories. These strategies include the strengthening of capacities for landscape monitoring and surveillance, developing sustainable economic activities, strengthening the organizations that lead the indigenous communities and ensuring financial sustainability of the initiative. The project expects to reduce 8.2 million tCO2 over the 30 year project lifetime with an average of 276,419tCO2 per year.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: BULGARIAN SUSTAINABLE FARMING CARBON PROJECT
description:
The “Bulgarian Sustainable Farming Carbon Project” aims to raise farmers' awareness on the benefits of regenerative agriculture and how changes in agricultural practices can help in climate change mitigation and adaptation. 
Regenerative agriculture land management practices refer to farming and grazing practices that aim to reverse climate change by rebuilding soil organic matter, sequestering carbon, improving degraded soil biodiversity, improving water cycle, and restoring soil fertility. Regenerative agriculture does not imply only one practice, instead, it is generally a combination of techniques.
To achieve this objectives, different regenerative agricultural practices will be implemented. These will include, among others: 
-	Promoting no tillage or minimal tillage: this practice aims to avoid soils tillage which is one of the main causes of soil losses/erosion. This practice helps not only to conserve the soil structure but also to improve it and improve the soil organic carbon levels.
-	Introducing cover crops: this practice aims to avoid having soils without vegetation cover by introducing alternative crops in-between the main productive ones. This promotes soils conservation by avoiding erosion.  For this activity, Agrovar counts with a personalized information platform that processes the soils data which comes from laboratories and satellite information and as a result provides very specialized mixes of cover crops suggested for each land area according to every specific situation.
-	Information system for optimizing farming activities.
The project is developed as a grouped project within the boundaries of Bulgaria. The project activity intends to add more instances over the upcoming years. The project implementation will result in an increase of carbon stocks and a reduction of GHG emissions.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: HEBEI WEI COUNTY IMPROVED AGRICULTURAL LAND MANAGEMENT PROJECT
description:
Hebei Wei County Improved Agricultural Land Management Project  is located in Wei County, Handan City, Hebei Province of China. The goal of this initiative is to reduce the carbon emissions currently emitted by the farms taking part to the project and raise the carbon storage in the soil. title: Mixed afforestation with native and non-native species in Argentina-I
description:
This Mixed afforestation with native and non-native species in Argentina-I project consists of the afforestation of 1,006.98 hectares with different types of pine and eucalyptus species and a 3% of the area with a mix of native species. No harvesting activity will be done, to maximize the CO2 sequestration from the atmosphere. 
The project activity will be carried out in two locations owned by Garruchos S.A and managed by Cambium. Puerto Valle Ranch and Garruchos Ranch, located in the province of Corrientes, Argentina. The area has a suboptimal quality and degraded soil due to the historical unmanaged cattle raising. 
This afforestation project will be carried out considering the existing local guidelines of Good Forest Practices and it will have the FCS certificate, which ensures that the design, planting and maintenance of the forest are carried out through a sustainable forest management program avoiding negative impacts on biodiversity, local communities, and water bodies.
The project activity converts a degraded area, where extensive livestock activity was historically carried out, into an afforestation project activity with no harvest. As the goal is carbon capture, pruning activities are also not anticipated. In addition, the afforestation will contribute to minimizing soil erosion, protecting, and restoring areas degraded by extensive cattle raising. Moreover, a native species domestication program will be implemented together with Misiones National University, aiming to further study native species´ growth demands and conditions.
The absorption of GHGs will occur through the carbon reservoirs that will be generated through afforestation, with a start date of September 1st 2022. These include aboveground biomass, belowground biomass, and soil organic carbon. The project is estimated to remove a total amount of 993,822 tCO2 over a 40-year period, which works out at an average reduction of 24,845 tCO2 per year.

title: Tamusu Improved Grassland Management Project
description: Yabu Ala Improved Grassland Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is located in Alashan Right Banner, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region of China. The project is aimed to improve the rotation of grazing animals, limit the timing and number of grazing animals on degraded pastures, and restore degraded land by replanting with grasses and ensuring appropriate management over the long-term. The project proponent is Inner Mongolia Chengyao Grassland, Forestry and Animal Husbandry Ecological Technology Co., Ltd (hereinafter referred to as the Project Proponent or PP). According to the baseline survey, before the implementation of the project, the grassland in the region has experienced serious degradation and even desertification due to the impact of climate change and human activities. Totally, 354,435.75 ha of degraded grassland has been managed properly and there are three main restoration measures namely rest grazing and rotational grazing implemented in moderate degraded area and the categorization is in line with Parameters for Degradation, Sandification and Salification of rangelands (GB19377-2003).

title: PROMOTING REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURE AND GROWTH THROUGH INCOME GENERATION
description: Grow Indigo is implementing a regenerative agriculture-based carbon project in the extensive rice cultivation states of Andhra Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Karnataka, Odisha, and Telangana in India. The project area is characterized by traditional and intensive cultivation practices within diverse ecological systems, which emit significant amounts of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. The southern region, encompassing Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, and Karnataka, excels in irrigated rice farming and cultivation in deltaic and non-deltaic regions. At the same time, Chhattisgarh and Odisha specialize in rainfed upland and lowland rice cultivation. Intensive agriculture practices in the project area have threatened food security and contributed to increased GHG emissions. The Grow Indigo project aims to incentivise farmers for adopting regenerative agriculture practices, thereby achieving the mitigation of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and fostering positive environmental and economic outcomes. Regenerative agriculture is a holistic farming system that focuses on improving soil health, biodiversity, and water quality. It can help to reduce GHG emissions by sequestering carbon in the soil. These practices include improved fertilizer management, cover cropping, crop rotation, reduced tillage, improved water management, crop residue management, agroforestry, etc. The project will also help to build the capacity of farmers to adopt regenerative agriculture practices through training and technical support. The project aims to scale up to 4 million hectares within the project area over a 5-year period. During the 20-year crediting period, it is estimated that there will be an average annual reduction and removal of 5,326,066 tCO2e. This innovative project has the potential to make a significant contribution to sustainable agriculture and climate change mitigation in India.

title: REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURE IN THE GANGA-BASIN FOR FARMER INCOME AND CLIMATE IMPACT
description: Grow Indigo is implementing a regenerative agriculture-based carbon project that spans across Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, and Uttar Pradesh. This project is taking a bold step towards environmental sustainability in the Ganga basin region of India. Common agricultural practice in these areas includes conventional methods such as heavy use of synthetic fertilizers, intensive tillage, crop residue burning, and excessive water consumption for irrigation. These practices have led to soil depletion and accelerated greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, threatening the ecosystem of the Ganga basin. The transition to regenerative agriculture is vital to counteract soil degradation, fertility loss, water pollution, and natural resource depletion. This shift is crucial to maintain the ecosystem services of the Ganga basin. The potential impact of the VCS carbon project is immense. It promises to significantly reduce GHG emissions, improve soil health, and enhance biodiversity. Beyond environmental benefits, the project aims to uplift the livelihoods of smallholder farmers and enhance the resilience of the Ganga basin ecosystem in the face of climate change. Over a five-year period, the project aims to scale up to cover 4 million hectares within the Ganga basin region of the project area. The 20-year crediting period is expected to yield an average annual emission reduction and removal of 5,048,425 tCO2e. Grow Indigo's efforts in this project exemplify a proactive and holistic approach to tackle environmental challenges, offering a ray of hope for the Ganga basin and its residents.

title: HORTICULTURE PLANTATION IN CENTRAL INDIA
description:
Project Summary

The project activity “Horticulture Plantation in Central India” is being proposed under Verra VCS Program for generation of carbon credits. It is proposed by AadharStambh Consultancy Services Private Limited, who is the Project Proponent of the project activity. It involves the planting, nurturing, and management of horticultural fruit bearing species including guava, orange, lemon, etc. The lands on which horticulture plantation is being done are owned by small-scale farmers who have voluntarily enrolled into the project activity. The project is located Mandsaur, Dhar districts of Madhya Pradesh. The project started from 2021 onwards and estimated to generate 1,15,000 tCO2e of average annual carbon emission reductions. Since then, the Project Proponent has multiple farmers for carbon credit project under Verra VCS Program. The project has applied AR-ACM0003: Afforestation and reforestation of lands except wetlands --- Version 2.0. In addition to carbon credit generation, the project also provides multiple sustainable development benefits as well (UN Sustainable Development Goals) – such as, SDG 5-Gender Equality; SDG 13-Climate Action and SDG 15 – Life on Land.

title: Vencedor Guajoya REDD+
description:
The Vencedor Guajoya REDD+ project is aimed at reducing and preventing GHG emissions from deforestation activities in the forests present in the territory of the Native Community located in the basin and right bank of the Napo River, through the development and implementation of a REDD+ strategy built in a collective and participatory manner with community members and that is also aligned with the objectives of the life plan, which is conceived as a community planning instrument that contains the worldview, history and future vision of community. Likewise, the territorial planning and environmental protection instruments of the region are taken into account.
Within the framework of the development and implementation of the project, the intervention strategy consists of the execution of actions framed in four main components: i) strengthening governance; ii) development of sustainable productive activities compatible with the conservation of biodiversity; iii) increase in social investment; iv) monitoring. This is how the REDD+ project strategy also seeks to integrate different interventions in the territory, by offering economic resources that can potentiate processes in progress or to be implemented and that in turn allows attracting greater investment to the territory for the benefit of the communities.
