title: NATURAL SILVOPASTORAL SYSTEMS IN THE COLOMBIAN ORINOQUIA REGION
description:
The project “Natural silvopastoral systems in the Colombian Orinoquia Region” is a grouped project comprising a set of activities to improve grassland management. The project primary objective is to achieve a reduction in overall emissions by focusing on carbon sequestration. This will be accomplished by enhancing livestock practices through the following project activities:

- Implementation of adaptive multi-paddock grazing with improved deep-rooted grass cultivars, specifically Urochloa humidicola,
- Human-assisted regeneration of arbustive chaparros (Curatella americana) on paddocks to harness the potential of existing natural processes of seed dispersal and resources to restore woody vegetation,
- Cease grassland burns, and 
- Natural regeneration of tropical, highland savannah vegetation in buffer zones around riparian forests, and environmental.

The project activities will take place in approximately 150,000 ha of Vichada and Meta, two of the four departments of the Orinoquia region in Colombia, referred to here as “Colombian Orinoquia”. The crediting period is 2020 to 2040 applying the VCS Methodology for Improved Agricultural Land Management VM0042 Version 2.0. An estimate of the annual average and total GHG emission reductions and removals are approximately 270,000 t CO2eq per year and 5,400,000 t CO2eq, respectively.

With its implementation, project instances will see an increase in livestock production, alongside overall emissions reduction driven by soil carbon sequestration. Prior to the implementation of the project, livestock practices in the regions are characterized by annual burning of savannas and low-quality animal feed. It is also expected substantial contribution to the sustainable development goals (SDGs) 2 Zero hunger, 8 Decent work and economic growth, 9 Industry, innovation and infrastructure, 12 Responsible consumption and production, 13 Climate action, 15 Life on land, and 17 Partnerships for the goals.

The total area is 894,128 ha, which includes the Improved Forest Management (IFM) of the forests in the conversion of logged to protected forest.
The area of the project activity is 4321.92 ha, including 450 subcompartments. The ownership and the right to use the forest land belongs to Ganluo County Xincai Forestry Plantation Co. and Jiulong County Jutiantai Forestry Development Co.. They signed Project Development Cooperation Agreement with Chengdu Haisha Technology Co.,Ltd. (hereafter referred as the project proponent). It authorized the project proponent to use the land for the forest management. The species involved in the project are Liquidambar formosana Hance, Masson Pine, soft broadleaved species, Taxodiaceae, hard broadleaved species and PopulusL. These are common local tree species.
Prior to the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged annually according to a valid and verifiable government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 1,377,720 tCO2e in 30 years, the average annual emission reduction is 45,924 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 1,074,617 tCO2e in 30 years, the average annual VCUs with buffer deduction is 35,821 tCO2e.

title: South Barito Kapuas Project
description:
The South Barito Kapuas Project (the Project) seeks to preserve and restore an estimated 39,853 ha of dryland and peatland ecosystem. 

The Project will :
•	Avoid  28,363 ha of forest clearing and conversion to an industrial forestry plantation. 
•	Avoid 8,824 ha of peatland degradation through the conservation of these wetlands and avoidance of conversion to an industrial forestry plantation. 
•	Reforestation of 195 ha of non-forest areas back into natural forest.

The Project is in the Province of Central Kalimantan. Specifically, it is in the Barito Selatan and Kapuas Regencies, in a tropical forest landscape comprising of a mixture of dryland and peatland forest made up of approximately an unallocated license area of 39,853 ha of unallocated lands assigned for conversion to plantation forest concession to PT Nusantara Solusi Raya (NRS).

title: Wuhan Jiangxia Changshankou LFG Power Project Phase I
description:
Wuhan Jiangxia Changshankou LFG Power Project Phase I (hereafter referred to as the Project ””) is a landfill gas (LFG) recovery and utilization project d is located at
Changshankou Landfill Jinkou Street Jiangxia District, Wuhan City, Hubei province, People’s Republic of China.
Prior to the implementation of the project activity, the LFG generated from Changshankou Landfill was totally released into the atmosphere; the equivalent amount of electricity supplied by the project activity was supplied by the fossil-fuel-dominated Central China Power Grid (CCPG). The baseline scenario is the same as the conditions existing prior to the implementation of the project activity.
The Project achieves emission reductions in two aspects: 1) it avoids methane emissions by capturing and destroying LFG which would have been directly vented into the atmosphere in the baseline scenario; 2) it reduces CO2 emissions by displacing part of the electricity that would otherwise have been supplied by CCPG.

title: SUSTAINABLE PERENNIAL ORCHARDS IN ISRAEL (SPOI)
description:
Climate change mitigation in the agricultural sector falls into three approaches. First, by reducing the current carbon emissions, via a better management of the carbon fluxes. Secondly, by avoiding potential emissions (e.g., by reusing the crop residues). Lastly, by enhancing the removals of carbon from the atmosphere (Smith et al., 2008). Regenerative agriculture (RA) is a farming approach which includes several practices (e.g., use of cover crops, reduced tillage) aiming at sequestrating soil carbon and contributing to those three approaches. RA also aims at implementing practices increasing biodiversity (e.g., crop diversity), improving the water cycle (e.g., use of drip irrigation) and increasing resilience to climate change. 
In the present project, the three mentioned approaches are applied in the framework of the Sustainable perennial orchards in Israel (SPOI). The goal of this initiative is to reduce the carbon emissions currently emitted and to raise the carbon stored in the soil and in the biomass. In addition, the selected measures will contribute to improving crop yields and soil health. With perennials, year-round carbon removals will increase; the land will be irrigated with more precision which will increase the micro-organism activity. The leaves and the other biomass residue will remain on the ground from pruning, increasing the organic matter in the project areas. Orchards require less monitoring by tractors, thus reducing the demand of energy and the amount of fuel required, this reduces CO2 emissions in the project area, compared with the baseline scenario. Also, intercrops will be sown to increase the soil organic content. This is a grouped project, located in Israel. The main environmental and sustainable development objectives pursued by the grouped project are: a) reduce carbon emissions from less intensive agricultural practices, b) promote regeneration of soil and the increase of soil organic carbon (SOC), c) increase carbon sequestration.
VCS Proponent:
Rivulis Pte. Ltd.
Sharon, Israel
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Regenerative Agriculture and Forestry Technologies (RAFT) 1
description: C-Quest Capital’s Regenerative Agriculture and Forestry Technologies project aims to reverse the trends of soil and land degradation by promoting project activities that sequester carbon in agricultural soils and biomass; reduce dependency on nitrogen fertilizers; increase soil organic matter, moisture retention and health; reduce erosion; and diversify crop production and agricultural income streams. Specifically, this project will support conservation agriculture (CA), intercropping of leguminous shrubs, alley cropping, and farmer managed natural regeneration (FMNR) of trees on farmland across Malawi. CA includes adopting minimum or no-till practices, retaining crop residues, and rotating or intercropping multiple crops. Intercropping practices will focus mainly on Tephrosia vogelii, an indigenous fast growing, deep rooted leguminous shrub that can be used as green manure and produces abundant firewood. For alley cropping, multi-use trees or shrubs are planted in rows between crop strips to promote soil fertility and stability as well as diversify farm products. Lastly, FMNR practices vary widely according to the preferences of individual farmers but in general involve the selective protection of trees regenerating naturally from existing rootstock or stumps on croplands. Together, these practices transfer carbon from the atmosphere to above and belowground biomass through photosynthesis, a portion of which is further transferred to the SOC pool through biomass residues and root exudates. Reduced soil disturbance from no-till further protects SOC stocks, increased soil fertility reduces fertilizer use and its associated emissions, and crop residue retention avoids emissions from biomass burning.
VCS Proponent:

title: CACHOEIRA PORTEIRA CONSERVATION PROJECT
description: The Cachoeira Porteira Conservation Project is located within the Brazilian Amazon, specifically in Oriximiná municipality in the Pará State, Brazil. The project zone, Cachoeira Porteira territory, has 225,289.53 hectares while the project area encompasses 178,450.77 hectares. Cachoeira Porteira, a remnant quilombo community, is represented by AMOCREQ-CPT, one of the project proponents. Systemica Inteligência em Sustentabilidade S.A is the other project proponent. The Cachoeira Porteira Conservation Project falls under the category of Improved Forest Management. The project activity is Logged to Protected Forest (LtPF), and it utilizes the VM0010 v.1.3 methodology. Therefore, the project shall reduce emissions and combat decreased carbon stocks by conserving the area that would be subject to planned timber harvest in the baseline scenario. The project´s crediting period is 30 years, commencing on November 7th, 2022, and it is expected to be concluded on November 6th, 2052. The estimated average net GHG emission reductions is 567,544.43 tCO2e per year, totaling 17,026,332.88 tCO2e, over the crediting period. It is noteworthy that the Cachoeira Porteira Conservation Project meets the gold level criteria for, climate, community, and biodiversity. In a comprehensive approach, seven activities have been meticulously planned, which are synergistic with the Sustainable Development Goals, including Zero Hunger, Good Health and Well-being, Quality Education, Clean Water and Sanitation, Affordable and Clean Energy, Decent Work and Economic Growth, Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure, Reduced Inequalities, and Life on Land.

title: BAULU PROJECT, DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO
description:
Located in the center of the Democratic Republic of Congo, in the “Cuvette Centrale”, the Baulu Project is designed to protect 277,131 ha of native Congolese forests legally designated for selective logging. The Project is situated within Forest Concession 009/11 – Baulu, hereinafter referred to as the Baulu Concession. Since January 2018, this concession has been managed by the company Industrie Forestière du Congo (IFCO), which harvests volumes of commercial timber from it, following the terms of the Management Plan that was drawn up at the start of management. In 2023, as part of this project, IFCO has transferred the Baulu Concession to KNCC, with the objective of converting the logging concession into a protected forest.
The main activity of the Baulu Project is to set-aside areas of Logged-to-Protected Forests (LtPF), in the timber production series of 116,181 ha, to maintain and protect ecosystem services in forest production areas legally designated for selective logging. From the cessation of timber harvesting activities, which are present in the baseline scenario, the project aims to avoid emissions generated by logging, transport, processing of raw material as well as collateral damage to vegetation caused by the fall of cut trees on surrounding plants, decomposition of material left in the forest, construction of forest tracks for transport to the storage point and other infrastructure. A further advantage that the project will bring to the area is due to the cessation of the disturbance caused by logging activities to the fauna present in this area, which is very rich and varied, thanks also to the proximity of the Lomako-Yokokala Wildlife Reserve, which includes, among other species, bonobo, forest elephant, or Bongo antelope. Community activities will also be developed in the rural development area, such as awareness raising on illegal logging and poaching activities, awareness raising and training on sustainable agricultural practices, etc.

title: National Shale Oil Low-Carbon Intelligent Demonstration Base Carbon Sink Afforestation Project
description:
National Shale Oil Low-Carbon Intelligent Demonstration Base Carbon Sink Afforestation Project (hereafter referred to as “the Proposed Project”) is located in Xinbao Village, Yule Town, Huachi County, Qingyang City, Gansu Province, People’s Republic of China.
In the absence of the Proposed Project, the sites of the project are all low-nutrient, low-supply land, and the terrain is steep, with few herbaceous plants growing. Without its implementation, all the sites will keep the same circumstances with no natural renewal and reforestation within the project area. Through the implementation of the proposed project, it enhances ecosystem services through carbon storage, and soil and water conservation. It has a significant potential to mitigate the effects of climate change effects through microclimate moderation and natural resources conservation in the short run and through carbon sequestration in the long run. It also provides employment to rural population, and promote the sustainable development of local economy and society.
The project estimates the GHG removals occurring from afforestation activities in accordance with the methodology AR-AMS0007: “Afforestation and reforestation project activities implemented on lands other than wetlands”, Version 03.1 developed under Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) for small-scale plantations. The project intends to generate carbon credits for the voluntary market under the VCS standard. The total GHG emission reduction quantified under the project for crediting period of 20 years is 13,184 tCO2e with average CO2 removal of 659.20tCO2e per year.

description: The Rio Muru REDD+ Project is a partnership between WayCarbon Soluções Ambientais e Projetos de Carbono S.A and Angelim Participações S.A, which belongs to the Perfin Group. Its main objective is to promote forest conservation and mitigate climate change by reducing greenhouse gases from deforestation and forest degradation. The project operates in two other spheres, in addition to the climate sphere: social and biodiversity. In this way, the Rio Muru REDD+ Project aims to promote socio-economic and environmental benefits, promoting activities that boost sustainable economic development and improve the community's well-being. The total project area is around 30,319 hectares and is located in the Amazon biome, in the municipality of Feijó, Acre. title: BURKINA FASO AGRICULTURAL CARBON PROJECT (BUFACAP)
description:
BUFACAP is a national program that contributes to climate mitigation and adaptation efforts set out in the country’s Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) in the Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU) sector. It promotes sustainable agricultural land management on smallholder landholdings and is implemented across all administrative regions in the country, which fall within the Sudanian and Sudano-Sahelian Agro-Ecological Zones (AEZs). The main objectives are to sustainably increase smallholders’ agricultural productivity, food security, income, and welfare, build resilience /adaptation of the agrarian landscapes to climate change, reduce land degradation, and enhance tree/forest cover in line both the National Strategy for Soil Restoration, Conservation and Reclamation in Burkina Faso (SNRCRS) 2020-2024 and the National REDD+ agenda. The improved agricultural land management (IALM) practices promoted include compost/manure application, residue management (mulching), a menu of agroforestry, natural regeneration of trees, a menu of soil and water conservation practices, e.g., erosion control structures, a menu of integrated livestock management, e.g., forage crops, livestock housing, biogas digesters, etc., and a menu of agronomic practices, e.g., mixed cropping, intercropping, crop rotation, etc.  
The BUFACAP is a grouped project as defined in the VCS Standard version 4.5, i.e., “projects structured to allow the expansion of a project activity subsequent to project validation”.  
The project is using a partnership approach with the technical lead being the REDD+ Permanent Secretariat. The activities are expected to result in increased and sustainable agricultural production, tree/forest conservation and land restoration. GHG emission reductions will be generated through increased carbon storage in tree biomass and in soils within the agricultural landscapes. VM0042 will be used to account, monitor, and quantify the project’s GHG emission reductions.

title: URSTAMM GROUPED PROJECT IFM SWITZERLAND & PILOT PROJECT KELLERAMT
description:
The Urstamm project is an Improved Forest Management (IFM) project in Switzerland. It is a grouped project. The scope of the project is set to be the entire Swiss forest territory since landowners from the whole country are invited to join the project. The registration period for landowners is organized in cohorts. The pilot project “Kelleramt” is based in the Central Plateau, or “Mittelland” of Switzerland near Zurich.

The project will apply selective logging to the parcels in accordance with the methodology VM0012 Improved Forest Management in temperate and boreal forests. The project will increase the carbon inventory by selective logging. The effectiveness and importance of this method has been confirmed by latest research and it will enable to build a climate anti-fragile or at least resilient forest population that becomes a carbon sink rather than a source.

The management plan is in accordance with the forest goals of the Swiss Confederation in terms of climate change mitigation and increased resilience of the forest to climate change. Indeed, it advises the forest managers to (i) increase biodiversity, (ii) increase structural diversity, (iii) increase genetic diversity, (iv) increase individual tree resistance to stress and (v) decrease the target Diameter at Breast Height (DBH). Selective logging allows the forest manager to actively control the development of the forest and therefore hinder the effect of climate change of the forest carbon sink. For example, this method allows the forest manager to increase light availability on the floor and promote light demanding and climate change resilient species. Also, the project is looking to increase the frequency of logging activities on each parcel in accordance with point (v) of the Swiss government and its forest strategy. 

To monitor the implementation of the sustainable forest management and provide precise information monitoring through remote sensing will be carried out (dMRV).
VCS Proponent:
Urstamm AG
CH-Switzerland, Switzerland
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Land Life Reforestation and Restoration of Degraded Land in Colorado
description:
The proposed ARR-VCS project is a large-scale grouped project centered on the reforestation of severely degraded lands in Colorado. Restoration of these lands aims to address the catastrophic destruction to nature imposed by the 2018 Spring Creek Fire, which claimed 43,724 hectares of forested landscape in southern Colorado. This grouped project aims for the long-term rejuvenation of Colorado’s forests, achieved through native mixed-species reforestation that reverses the impact of land degradation and the loss of flora and fauna. Project activities are implemented by Land Life, a Dutch technology-driven reforestation company that grows forests by planting trees at scale. Land Life uses innovative technology for the planting of native tree species by optimizing tree selection, survival, and resilience. Science-driven nature restoration activities ensure the highest tree survival rate and support the permanent establishment of native forests that complement rural communities. 

Project activities are implemented and monitored according to the VCS-approved project methodology AR-ACM0003, with the expectation that additional project instances are to be added over the coming years. The first group of instances of the project covers 581 ha of degraded land in Colorado, at five planting sites: Forbes Park (212.0 ha), Trinchera Blanca Ranch (241.96), Tres Valles (62.59 ha), Wagon Creek (29.20 ha), Pass Creek (34.67 ha). While each project instance is expected to sequester carbon across the entire 100-year crediting period, the ex-ante estimate focuses on the initial 40 years for practical reasons for each project instance to determine the annual average profile. These project instances (implemented in 2022) are expected to sequester approximately 114,386 tCO2e over the initial 40 years of the 100-year crediting period. The estimated annual average of GHG emission removals is 2,860 tCO2e. A total of 358,816 native trees are expected to become established in the project are
VCS Proponent:
Land Life Company B.V.
NH, Netherlands
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Land Life Reforestation and Restoration of Degraded Land in Portugal
description:
The proposed ARR VCS project is a grouped project focusing on the reforestation and restoration of degraded lands in Portugal. 63% of Portugal’s land is classified as vulnerable to desertification, with 32.6% in a degraded state (ICNF, 2020). Land and biodiversity regeneration are central objectives of this project, which employs the latest technologies and planting techniques to ensure the highest rate of survival of mixed-species native trees. Project activities are implemented by Land Life, a Dutch technology-driven reforestation company that grows forests by planting trees at scale and using innovative technology to optimize tree selection, survival, and resilience. Land Life maintains an on-the-ground presence through Land Life Iberia’s office in Burgos and maintains close collaboration with local partners and authorities. The long-term resilience of forest and vegetation composition will be monitored to track the success and permanence of the forests.

Project activities are implemented and monitored according to the VCS-approved project methodology AR-ACM0003, with the expectation that additional project instances are to be added over the coming years. The first group of instances of the project covers 365 ha in Portugal, at five distinct planting sites: Torre de Tavares (70.4 ha), Freguesia de Tavares (90.8 ha), Peges (35.27 ha), Carvalhais (87.8 ha) and Matança (56.27 ha). While each project instance is expected to sequester carbon across the entire 100-year crediting period, the ex-ante estimate focuses on the initial 41 years for practical reasons for each project instance to determine the annual average profile. These project instances (implemented in 2021 and 2022) are expected to sequester approximately 81,802 tCO2e over the initial 41 years of the 100-year crediting period. The estimated annual average of GHG emission removals is 1,995 tCO2e. A total of 292,908 native trees are expected to become established in the project areas.
VCS Proponent:
Land Life Company B.V.
NH, Netherlands
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Land Life Reforestation and Restoration of Degraded Land in Australia - A
description:
The proposed ARR VCS project is a grouped project focusing on the reforestation and restoration of degraded lands in Australia. Land and biodiversity regeneration are central objectives of this project, which employs the latest technologies and planting techniques to ensure the highest rate of survival of mixed-species native trees and support the permanent establishment of native flora and fauna. Project activities are implemented by Land Life, a Dutch technology-driven reforestation company that grows forests by planting trees at scale by using innovative technology to optimize tree selection, survival, and resilience. Local Australian partner Cassinia Environmental brings on-the-ground expertise in forestry and conservation, supporting Land Life’s team of reforestation specialists in managing and implementing quality projects in Australia. The long-term resilience of forest and vegetation composition will be monitored to track the effectiveness and permanence of the forests.

Project activities are implemented and monitored according to the approved project methodology AR-ACM0003. The first group of instances within this PD covers a total of 718 ha of degraded land Australia, with projects located in Victoria, New South Wales, and South Australia. The crediting period of this grouped project is 100 years as each of the initial project instances has 100 years of carbon right assigned from the land owner to the project proponent. While each project instance is expected to sequester carbon across the entire 100-year crediting period, the ex-ante estimate focuses on the initial 41 years for practical reasons to determine the annual average profile. These project instances (implemented across 2022 and 2023) are expected to sequester approximately 213,380 CO2e over the initial 41 years of the crediting period. The estimated annual average of GHG emission removals is 5,204 tCO2e. A total of 494,035 native trees are expected to become established at the sites.
VCS Proponent:
Land Life Company B.V.
NH, Netherlands
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: REDD+ PROJECT - REDDES LOCALES FOR DEVELOPMENT
description:
The REDDES Locales for Development project is a REDD+ project that aims to reduce
deforestation and degradation, as well as increase the carbon stocks by recovering natural
forest and reforestation. The project zone encompasses three departments and their
respective municipalities in Guatemala: Huehuetenango (municipalities: Nentón, Santa Ana Huista and Jacaltenango), Quiché (municipalities: Nebaj, Chajul, Ixcan and San Juan Cotzal) and Alta Verapaz (municipalities: Cobán, San Pedro Carcha, Lanquín, San Juan Chamelco, Cahabob and Tamahúl). These areas have been identified as vulnerable at the national level due to a continued reduction in forestry biomass and tree coverage.
VCS Proponent:
Calmecac, Fundacion Para El Desarrollo Integral Del Hombre y Su Entorno
Guatemala, Guatemala
+502 42182484
mmolina@fundacioncalmecac.org
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: EVERGREEN II REDD+ PROJECT
description:
The Evergreen II REDD+ project aims at protecting forests located in one of the regions with the highest deforestation rate in the Amazon Biome: the municipality of Apuí. The
South of the municipality has already been reached by the “Arc of Deforestation”. In the last 10 years, Apuí has been one of the most deforested municipalities in the Amazon
Biome. Besides the damage caused to natural ecosystems, the land-use changes have provoked severe social conflicts through processes of land-grabbing and installation of
agriculture and cattle ranching activities, contributing to the expulsion of family-scale forest extractives from that region. The primary objective of the Evergreen II REDD+ project is to avoid unplanned (AUD) deforestation in an area of 36,989.62 hectares of Amazonian forest, equating to 6,191,013.12 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime (25-November-2020 to 24-November-2050), with an annual average of 206,367.10 tCO2e. The Project Proponents will adopt additional conservation measures: remote sense monitoring of changes in the land cover using satellite images, deforestation and heat spots monitoring, increasing surveillance hiring private security, and implementing a land, water, and air vigilance plan using quads, boats, drones and a plane, build security bases and provide internet signal to improve communication for illegal deforestation complaints. Other social activities that benefit the local community will be supported, such as improving electricity infrastructure by solar photovoltaic panels, construction of groundwater wells, bioeconomy, and environmental education, improvement of rural roads and bridges, associations support, development the value chain of forest products and agriculture family production (nuts, oils, fish, fruits, legumes, and seeds). The CCB Standards is being considered to assess and monitor the project's contribution to excepcional positive impacts on biodiversity and communities.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: EKEN IFM SWEDEN NORTH #1
description:
EKEN IFM SWEDEN NORTH #1 is a grouped project located in Sweden under development using the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) methodology VM0045 – Methodology for Improved Forest Management using Dynamic Matched Baselines from National Forest Inventories. The project activities apply on conifer forests and include extension of rotation age (ERA) and commercial thinning on productive forests that are legally eligible for harvest.

In Sweden, most forest land is privately owned. Approximately 85% of the total forest area is classified as productive forest land and bound by the Swedish Forestry Act to be managed sustainably. The dominant forest management treatment in Sweden is clearcutting around the lowest legal harvesting age stipulated by the Swedish Forestry Agency. The lowest legal harvesting age is dependent on geographic location, dominant species and site productivity of a forest stand, and ranges from 45-100 years for coniferous species in the counties included in the project’s geographic area. From the clearcut biomass, typically only approximately 34% ends up as sawn wood products, while 66% feeds pulp and bioenergy supply chains.

By extending the rotation age by 15-30 years (with 40-year monitoring) on forests above the lowest legal harvesting age allowed by the Swedish Forestry Act and enforced by the Swedish Forest Agency, the project activities allow climate financing to close an economic gap for coniferous trees to grow to larger dimensions, improving the share of long-term carbon stored in sawn wood products, while also increasing volumes of standing forest carbon.

Estimated average annual GHG emission reductions or removals over the project crediting period
amounts to approximately 2.2 CO2/ha/yr.
VCS Proponent:
EKEN Financing Value Added Forestry AB
Stockholm, Sweden
004672603682
erik.ottosson@ekenfinancing.com
www.ekenfinancing.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Seringal Rio Branco REDD+ Project
description:
The Seringal Rio Branco REDD+ Project is a partnership between Biofílica Ambipar Environmental Investments S/A and Amazônia Agroindústria EIRELI, with the aim of promoting forest conservation and mitigating climate change by reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from changes in land use. In addition to the climate benefits, the project also aims to generate socio-environmental benefits based on sustainable economic development practices and improving the well-being of the surrounding communities, while preserving the culture and traditions of the local people.
The Seringal Rio Branco REDD+ Project is located in the Alto Juruá region, between the municipalities of Cruzeiro do Sul and Porto Walter, covering an area of 29,615 hectares. The Juruá River Basin is made up of four micro-basins: the igarapé do meio micro-basin, the igarapé primeiro de março micro-basin and the igarapé grande micro-basin, as well as the Valparaiso River basin (micro-basin), which is the main drainage network in the rubber plantation region.
The region is recognized as one of Brazil's Ramsar Sites, due to its international significance in terms of ecology, botany, zoology, limnology and hydrology. The Seringal Rio Branco REDD+ Project area is of extreme importance for biological conservation, as it is home to a high diversity of fauna and flora, including the presence of endemic and rare species such as the Macuru-papa-mosca bird (Micromonacha lanceolata), which  was recorded for the first time in the state of Acre, in the project area. In addition, the region is home to numerous species that are bioindicators of preserved forest in the Amazon.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: eAgronom sustainable farming in Central and Eastern Europe
description: The eAgronom Sustainable Farming in Central and Eastern Europe Project is an Agricultural Land Management (ALM) carbon offset project across Europe using the VM0042 methodology for Improved Agricultural Land Management, version 2.0. The Project focuses on increasing the soil organic carbon in annual cropping systems. The Project seeks to drive the adoption of regenerative agricultural practices to promote carbon sequestration and reduce and remove GHG emissions.
VCS Proponent:
OÜ eAgronom
Tallinn, Estonia
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Shandong Dongying alm project
description:
Shandong Dongying ALM Project (hereafter as “the project”) is located in Kenli District, Dongying City, Shandong Province of China. The goal of this initiative is to reduce the carbon emissions currently emitted by the farms taking part to the project and raise the carbon storage in the soil. In addition, the selected measures will contribute to improving crop yields and soil health. The project was implemented by the Dongying Kenli District Hehai Agricultural Tourism Development Group Co., Ltd and Hainan icarbon Ecological Development Co.,Ltd. (hereafter “the project proponent”).
The project is located in Kenli District of Dongying City, Shandong Province. The project area is 27,361.71 ha. The crop rotation system in this project is winter wheat-summer corn. Kenli District is located in the northeast of Shandong Province, between latitude 37°24'~38°10' N and longitude 118°15~119°19 E, with a total area of 2204.07 square kilometers.
The proposed project is aimed to prevent the soil degradation through adoption of the improved crop land management practices (collectively referred to conservational tillage) to replace the conventional cultivation mode.
Main activities about conservational tillage adopted in the project include：
Improve fertilizer (organic or inorganic) application 
The application of chemical Fertilizer has been reduced and substituted partially by organic fertilizer in the total area of 27,361.71 ha of cropland in the project boundry.
Reduce tillage/improve residue management   
Implementing protective tillage measures for corn no-till sowing in the total area of 27,361.71 ha. 
Crop residue retention (straw in 27,361.71 ha of cropland have been shredded and returned with the depth of 30 cm).
A total of 27,361.71 ha of farmland has been managed under conservation tillage, The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 2,645,807 tCO2e from 24-Jun-2021 to 23-Jun- 2041, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 132,290 tCO2e.
For the project the validation date and the specific date of the first monitoring period of this project has not been determined, and will be supplemented in the latest PD.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Ruvuma Wilderness Project
description:
The Ruvuma landscape is a forest corridor connecting the Nyerere National Park in southern Tanzania with the Niassa Special Reserve in Mozambique. The Ruvuma Wilderness Project area falls within the greater Miombo Ecoregion, a forest system which covers much of the ancient African plateau and is typified by rolling deciduous woodland punctuated by grassland drainage lines. 

The objectives of this project are to empower local communities through the deployment of direct revenues into existing governance structures, and support local efforts to preserve the miombo forest and biodiversity in the landscape. The Project area consists of five Wildlife Management Areas (Chingoli, Kimbanda, Kisungule, Mbarang’andu and Nalika).
VCS Proponent:
Carbon Tanzania
Kent, United Kingdom
+447838538980
jo@carbontanzania.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: ‘Qarlbo’ Afforestation Through High-Quality Timber Over Degraded Grasslands
description:
Qarlbo is a grouped project in Uruguay's central-east region, encompassing 510 hectares of land formerly used for extensive cattle grazing. The aim is afforestation with 25-year Eucalyptus grandis plantations, managed for high-value logs. Situated in Cerro Largo, the project follows FSC standards and employs a Nature-Positive Forest Management Strategy, emphasizing positive biodiversity outcomes.

Carbon sequestration occurs through plantation cultivation, with monitoring covering various carbon pools. The project addresses non-permanence risks and involves a baseline study indicating the likelihood of continued grazing. Additionality is demonstrated by a lower internal rate of return without carbon financing, and common practices analysis highlights the necessity of carbon funding for long-term afforestation.

The project, achieving net anthropogenic removals, has a long-term average GHG benefit of 281,825 tCO2e over 100 years, translating to 2,818 tCO2e/year. Financing is secured through a private investor seeking reliable returns, with carbon certification ensuring project viability.
State/Province: Cerro Largo and Treinta y Tres

Qarlbo Uruguay S.A.S.
Montevideo, Uruguay
+46 76 034 41 64
aleksandra.holmlund@qarlbo.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Ana Primavesi – Sustainable Farming and Restoration Program
description: Ana Primavesi is an initiative to support the ecological transition in the Atlantic Forest and Cerrado biomes in Brazil. The grouped project has the target of implementing 2 000 hectares of agroforestry and forest restoration over degraded land with small to medium landowners. Supporting agroecological networks and supply-chains, as well as strengthen income and participation of  women and youth. The project will also catalyze natural resources conservation of soil, water and biodiversity, essential for maintenance of life and food security. The program honours a remarkable scientist who inspired the project’s name. Born in Austria in 1920, she was one of the few women at that time to have the title of Agronomist. She moved to Brazil in 1948 where she dedicated her professional and personal life for ‘ecological agriculture’ (agroecology) studies, becoming a pioneer in the country. She taught in Brazilian Universities and became known for her dedication for soil science and its contribution for food production and nature resilience. Primavesi has written many books and inspired many scientists and farm producers. Her legacy teaches about the importance of learning and respecting natural resources as living organisms, nature laws and processes.
VCS Proponent:
Ubá Sustainability Institute
Provence, France
CCB Proponent:
Ubá Sustainability Institute
Provence, France
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Carbon Smart Orchards USA
description:
The Carbon Smart Orchards USA project is a grouped VCS AFOLU project open to perennial growers within the USA. The farms that will enroll in this project are growers of perennial crops that are mostly following traditional farming methods such as tilling, burning of crop residue and minimal cover crops and organic amendments. Crops may include but are not limited to fruit trees and nut trees. 
For this grouped project, greenhouse gas (GHG) reductions and removals will be achieved by the implementation of a combination of practice changes, including application of organic materials and mulch to reduce the reliance on synthetic fertilizers and to improve soil health; cover cropping and inter-row biomass generation; establishment of permanent tree crops; improved water management; and others. 
The undertaking of this project will support a number of United Nations Sustainable Development Goals in the project area, local communities, surrounding environments, and in the supply chain. The project will contribute towards SDG 2: Zero Hunger, SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production, and SDG 13: Climate Action.

title: Shanxi Danfeng IFM Project
description:
The Shanxi Danfeng IFM Project (hereafter “the project activity”) is implemented in Danfeng County, Shangluo City, Shanxi Province of China by Danfeng County Construction Development Group Co., Ltd (hereafter “the project proponent”). The geo-coordinate of the project proponent is 110°7'E -110°49'E and 33°21'N - 33°5'N, the total area is 240,740 ha, which includes the IFM project.
The project activity quantifies the GHG emission reductions and removals generated from improving forest management practices to increase the carbon stock on land by extending the rotation age of a forest or patch of forest before harvesting. By extending the age at which trees are cut, projects increase the average carbon stock on the land and remove more emissions from the atmosphere.
The area of the project activity is 10,900.72 ha, including 2,222 sub-compartments spreading over Caichuan Town, Dihua Town, Huapingzi Town, Longjuzhai Town, Luanzhuang Town, Shangshan Forest Farm, Shang Town, Tieyupu Town, Wuguan Town, Yuling Town of Shanxi Danfeng. All these forests are state-owned forests or collective-owned, and have the legal right to forest ownership. The species involved in the project is Pitch Pine.

The project is in Mahidol University located at the Nakhon Pathom Campus, Thailand. The purpose of this project activity is to generate electricity using renewable energy sources by harnessing the solar energy by using solar photovoltaic technology and the energy generated from the PV system will be used by the Mahidol University under a Private Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) between SPP Six Co. title: CAMERR Carbon Mangrove Ecosystem Restoration & Resilience
description: The Carbon Mangrove Ecosystem Restoration & Resilience project (CAMERR) aims to enhance carbon sequestration by restoring a minimum of 2,000 hectares of degraded mangrove ecosystems in Cameroon estuary, also called Wouri estuary. The restoration efforts will take place around the Douala municipality. The project includes the plantation of mostly three species of native mangrove species: Rhizophora racemosa, Rhizophora mangle and Avicennia germinans.Currently, the mangroves in the Cameroon estuary are severely degraded, with deforestation rates estimated to be between 1% to 1.6% per annum. Human activities, such as cutting mangroves for artisanal methods of smoking fish, for cooking and for construction are the main drivers of deforestation. As such, it is estimated that the annual consumption of wood by households in communities bordering mangroves in the Douala-Edéa area is reaching 125.60 m3. Furthermore, invasive species such as Nypa fruticans and Pandanus candelabrum have invaded many mangrove areas, which severely compromises the natural regeneration of indigenous mangrove stands.The mangrove restoration project is developed by the French NGO Planète Urgence, in collaboration with local NGOs. The project activities involve the establishment and management of nurseries and the plantation of mangrove trees, or regeneration when it is possible. All sites will be geolocated using GPS services. These activities will involve the participation of local communities, especially in the propagule collection, nursery management, and planting, under the supervision of the project's technical implementation team. In addition, the project will also support the development of community forests managed by local communities and the creation of partnerships with local governments to ensure the long-term sustainable management of mangrove ecosystems. The project implementation and design will also require the organization of multiple sensitization workshops.

description:
The solar hybrid project involves installation of 49 MWp ground – mounted solar PV tracking system, 0.99 MW gas engine using Compressed Biogas (CBG) and 136.24MWh Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) located at Aranya Prathet District, Sa Kaeo Province, Thailand. 
The purpose of this project activity is to generate electricity using renewable energy sources like by harnessing the solar energy by using of solar photovoltaic technology and using CBG for gas engine. In addition to the generation unit the project includes a BESS system to increase the efficiency .

title: Timor-Leste Mangrove Restoration Project
description:
The Timor-Leste Mangrove Restoration Project is located in the coastal areas of five municipalities of Timor-Leste : Bobonaro, Dili, Manatuto, Baucau, Viqueque, Manufahi.
The main goals of this project are: 
-To mitigate climate change by removing GHG through mangrove planting 
-To restore degraded mangrove forests and improve biodiversity
-To support the livelihood of local residents through the creation local jobs and income generation
The project aims to restore the ecosystem and support local livelihoods by planting mangrove trees in degraded mangrove ecosystems. Approximately 560 hectares of mangrove are to be restored by planting mangrove seedlings in areas where mangroves had been lost in past decades in the northern and southern coasts of Timor-Leste. According to a land cover classification model developed though the project, mangrove forest in Timor-Leste is rapidly decreasing with a 4.93% yearly deforestation rate. 
The selected project areas are suitable for the mangrove growth, firstly selected by GIS analysis, including tide zone analysis and mangrove habitats suitability index and field survey to confirm. According to the interview with local communities, threats to mangroves in project areas include seasonal sediment accumulation, illegal logging, and livestock grazing. 
The characteristic of Timor-Leste’s mangrove forest is the zoning by the distance from the shoreline influenced by the high tide, submerging periods and duration.The expected planting species and stratification is designed in accordance with the natural zoning of the mangroves. The project’s total GHG removals by sinks is estimated ex-ante as 286,652 tCO2-e over its crediting period of 30 years at an estimated average of 9,555 tCO2-e annually. The project applies VM0033 methodology and the start date for the project is January 1, 2025.
State/Province: Bobonaro, Dili, Manatuto, Baucau, Viqueque, Manufa

SK Forest
South Korea

title: Starch Plus Wastewater Treatment And Biogas Utilisation Project
description:
Starch Plus Wastewater Treatment Project (hereafter referred as the Project) is a project operated by Starch Plus Co., Ltd, located in Nakorn Ratchasima City, Thailand. The project
involves the installation of a covered lagoon system (Modified Covered Lagoon), with 6 anaerobic open lagoons, to capture methane-rich biogas from the wastewater treatment system of the starch factory. The biogas is then sent to electricity generators, with an installed capacity 2.1 MW, to generate electricity to be used in the starch factory and thermal energy to be utilized
in the thermal boilers. In the case of excess biogas or emergency, the biogas will be flared. Prior to the project activity, baseline scenario, the wastewater would have been treated in a series of anaerobic open lagoons (series of 6 open lagoons), resulting in the release of methane gas in the atmosphere, due to anaerobic digestion of organic contents in the lagoon. Furthermore, the factory utilizes fossil fuels in the thermal boilers and injects electricity from the national grid to be used in the starch factory, which is largely generated by fossil-fuel based power plants.
VCS Proponent:
Starch Plus Co., Ltd.
Thailand
+66 814101467

title: AMAZONAS APD GROUPED PROJECT
description:
The Amazonas APD Grouped Project (hereafter called GPD) aims the forest conservation on private properties located in Amazonas State (AM), a Brazilian state inside the Legal Amazon. The Amazonas State has 1,559,255.881 Km² of territory, and its capital is the city of Manaus. The State has 2.53 hab/km² as demographic density; a population of 3,941,613 habitants, 0.7 as Human Development Index (which is considered high, however, there are enormous inequalities between the 62 municipalities), and R$ 965 as monthly household income per capita.   
The Project’s Sectoral Scope is the 14, set on AFOLU project category Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD), on type Avoiding Planned Deforestation (APD).
The GPD's main goal is to create positive economic incentives to landowners for the rainforest conservation in private areas, through income generation from carbon credits commercialization. In this way, BRC expects to escalate the climate impact promoted by the implementation of carbon projects, bringing positive net benefits to communities and biodiversity. The GPD two initial project activity instances implementation will result in the direct conservation of around 26 thousand hectares of forest.
The landowners who decide to join the initiative, by giving up their right to clear their forest areas legally will be able to access financial resources from the carbon voluntary market, becoming brCarbon partners. The partnership between brCarbon (hereafter called BRC) and landowners will result in legal protection of forests, forest monitoring by satellite images, carbon stocks inventory, property surveillance, wildfire monitoring, prevention, and firefighting activities, threatened species protection, and social engagement activities with traditional communities living inside the project area.
VCS Proponent:
BRCARBON SERVICOS AMBIENTAIS LTDA
São Paulo, Brazil
+55 19 34243583
diretoria@brcarbon.com.br
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Incentivising Smallholder Farmers to Transition to Low-Emissions Agriculture and Agroforestry
description:
The project is a strategic initiative targeting social, economic, and environmental concerns through the transition of farmers toward sustainable agricultural practices. Focused on the Central Plateau, Southern Plateau, and East Coast Plains region of India, it leverages existing relationships with smallholder farmers, historically reliant on conventional agricultural methods like frequent tillage and chemical fertilisers. The initiative introduces sustainable practices like Dry-Direct Seeded Rice (DSR), Wet-DSR, and Alternate Wetting and Drying (AWD) for paddy cultivation to combat methane emissions, along with zero tillage and cover cropping to increase carbon stock. Additionally, it introduces crop residue management, improved fertiliser practices, green manuring, and agroforestry to promote carbon sequestration and reduce synthetic inputs.
The primary goal is to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions through regenerative agriculture and agroforestry, fostering sustainable land management. Anticipated benefits encompass improved soil quality, heightened biodiversity, decreased environmental degradation, and carbon sequestration. These positive outcomes aim to bolster the well-being of smallholder farmers by enhancing agricultural productivity and profitability.
VCS Proponent:
Climeverse Private Limited
India
+91 9535325097
sid@climes.io
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Expanding Green Cover though afforestation in the Himalayan Region of Uttarakhand through communities-leading towards ownership and sustainability
description: The objective of the project is to restore degraded Van Panchayat forests across 160 villages in the Himalayan state of Uttarakhand. The Van Panchayat system in mountain districts of Uttarakhand is a unique system of community led forest management system that recognizes traditional and customary rights of forest dwelling communities

title: Reducción de la deforestación y degradación en el parque nacional Bahuaja sonene en la región Puno - Perú
description:
The Puno region is located in the southeast of Peru, bordered to the north by the department of Madre de Dios, to the east by Bolivia (Department of La Paz), to the southwest by the departments of Tacna and Moquegua and to the west by the departments of Arequipa and Cusco.
The Puno region is located in the high plateau between 3,812 and 5,500 m above sea level. n. m. and between the jungle fringe and the high jungle between 4,200 and 500 m above sea level. n. m.

The REDD + project is implemented in the area corresponding to the protected natural area of the Bahuaja Sonene National Park in the Puno region. It has an area of 773,345.82 hectares and its objective is to conserve the ANP forest in the face of threats of deforestation and degradation, conserve biodiversity stocks and improve the living conditions of the population surrounding the project area.

The project proposes to reduce the pressure to change land use in the project area through 9 components: control and surveillance, biological monitoring, restoration of degraded areas, physical demarcation of the limits of the ANP, promotion of research, promotion of sustainable productive activities, strengthening of participatory management, dissemination and environmental education, implementation of environmental and social safeguards.

With these actions, the project expects to avoid a total of 1,111,430 tCO2-e according to the base scenario projected for the first 10 years, with an average annual net emissions of 111,143 tCO2-e. In addition, the project includes benefits for the populations involved, as well as for the conservation of biodiversity, where it seeks to contribute to the conservation of forests with high levels of biodiversity with the presence of endemic species, species in danger of extinction or to some degree. threat, beyond the benefits of reducing GHG emissions.

title: Improved Agriculture Land Management in Argentina
description:
The Improved Agriculture Land Management Project in Argentina aims to support sustainable agricultural practices in the Central and Northern Region of Argentina. The Project will seek to implement practices that are currently not or only partially implemented in the country with low rates. 
Agricultural activities play a central role in the grouped project area. The current agricultural system is based on simplified farming practices. These include low crop rotation, monocultures and a high dependence on chemical inputs, which has led to soil degradation and nutrient depletion. The project will implement or intensify some of the following practices: (1) crop rotation, (2) rotations between agricultural and livestock practices, (3) cover crops, (4) implementation of regenerative livestock practices, (5) improvement of pasture management, (6) application of organic amendments, (7) improvement of water management or irrigation, and/ or (8) forest strips plantation. In addition, these activities will contribute to (1) minimize tillage and (2) minimize the introduction of crops that require soil disturbance in the harvesting process. These practices aim to increase soil organic matter, reduce soil erosion, promote the fixation and recycling of nutrients, prevent the spread of soil diseases, and maintain soil fertility in the long term, among other positive environmental effects. 
The first Project Activity Instance is being carried out in the province of Buenos Aires, comprising a total of 2,691 hectares. A very conservative estimate was made based on the projection of increasing the soil organic matter by 0.55% in 20 years. This is equivalent to an increase of 2.07 TCO2eq/ha-1year-1. Thus, the project activities can result in a net GHG emissions reduction and removals of ~ 108,608 tCO2e, with an annual average of 5,430 tCO2e in 20 years of the project.
VCS Proponent:
Vista Energy Argentina SAU
Buenos Aires, Argentina
+5491161037034
florencia.groba@vistaenergy.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: ALA HONKO BLUE CARBON MADAGASCAR
description:
The ALA HONKO BLUE CARBON (AHBC) project, led by the Unima group, is a comprehensive initiative aimed at scaling up the restoration and rehabilitation of mangrove ecosystems along the northwestern coast of Madagascar. Covering three geographic areas, the project addresses environmental, biodiversity, and social impacts.
In the first project instance, 682 hectares of mangroves will be planted on Unima concessions, specifically on old fishponds and mudflats known as 'tannes'. These areas have remained barren for over 20 years, as confirmed by remote sensing analysis. The planting of mangrove trees in these areas is crucial for increasing carbon stocks in both biomass and soil.
This grouped project plans to expand to comparable areas within and beyond the current boundaries of the Unima concession. The selection of these areas will be done collaboratively with local communities and stakeholders. Bioengineering, land leveling, and canal digging methods will be employed to restore appropriate hydrologic conditions for planting the eight mangrove tree species naturally present in Madagascar.
The project aims to achieve social, economic, and environmental benefits. Local communities are actively involved through capacity building and participation in activities such as seed collection, nursery development, tree planting, and monitoring. Additionally, income-generating activities connected to the restored mangrove will be developed.
In terms of climate benefits, the first instance of the AHBC project is estimated to sequester 728,170 tCO2e over its lifetime of 40 years at an estimated average of 18,204 tCO2e annually. This reflects the project's commitment to mitigating climate change by removing greenhouse gases from the atmosphere through mangrove plantation in specific intertidal zones. The project's holistic approach underscores the importance of mangrove ecosystems in blue carbon sequestration, biodiversity enhancement, and community well-being.

title: AWA REDD+ PROJECT
description: The AWA REDD+ Project has an area of 66,443.13 hectares, belonging to the Associação dos Remanescentes de Quilombos de Gurupá (ARQMG), which is home to 12 quilombo communities in the municipality of Gurupá, Pará. The business as usual consists in slash-and-burn agriculture for cassava cultivation, a traditional practice adopted by the quilombolas, and  deforestation followed by sale of timber and implementation of pasture for cattle raising, especially near the municipalities of Gurupá and Porto de Moz. Through various actions, the project will promote forest conservation and reduce GHG emissions that would occur due to deforestation, without harming the traditional and cultural practices of the communities, such as remote satellite monitoring, ground patrolling, fire brigade trainings, trainings in good agricultural practices, delimitation and signaling of the boundaries, among others. Furthermore, the project will promote the socio-economic and environmental development. To achieve these results, four programs will be implemented in the territory: I) Territorial Management, II) Socio-bio-economic Development, III) Promotion of Community Citizenship and IV) Biodiversity Conservation. These programs, as well as their benefits and impacts, were defined and identified with the 12 communities of the territory. The definition, identification and evaluation method used participatory workshops, respecting the principles of ILO Convention 169.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: The Nkuba REDD+ Project
description: The Nkuba REDD+ Project (NRP) is designed to promote climate change mitigation, preserve biodiversity, and establish alternative livelihoods for communities through the UN-REDD+ framework. The NRP is expected to reduce an average of 256,808 t CO2e per year, The Project Zone is 105,572 ha and covers the Nkuba Conservation Area (NCA), located in North Kivu & Maniema provinces, DRC. The NRP consists mainly of primary rainforest including numerous unique species. The NCA landscape is dominated by plains, plateaus, and low mountains above small marshy valleys. It has numerous rivers and tributaries with conditions for a thriving tropical ecosystem.  The NRP consists of three forest blocks that are recognised by the Congolese authorities as community forest conservation concessions (CFCLs). The CFCLs involved in the NRP are Mbungu, Nsuhu, and Seko, with a total of six clans making up the project communities. The benefits of the NRP forest are significant, but the region continues to experience threats due to deforestation, uncontrolled hunting, artisanal mining, and nomadic activities. The lack of employment, business opportunities, limited access to infrastructure and basic services contribute to local populations exploiting the forest for income generation. In response to these threats to the NCA, the 6 clans in partnership with Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund created NRP with the following objectives: 1) Mitigate climate change caused by deforestation and degradation and develop adaptation strategies for climate variability, 2) Improve the quality of life for local communities by introducing sustainable alternatives to forest exploitation, income-generating activities, and initiatives designed to address community needs, such as health, education, and safety, 3) Contribute to preserving biodiversity through community-led forest management, better land strategies, and forest monitoring, regulation, and surveillance.
VCS Proponent:
Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund
Georgia, United States
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: SMG Solar Water Pump - Program 01
description: The goal of this project is to introduce an environmentally friendly and sustainable alternative, which represents a transformative shift in the traditional practices of farmers who rely on diesel-powered pumps for their irrigation needs. With the growing demand in agriculture sector, fossil fuel-based pump sets are a major source of air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. The introduction of solar-powered pumps takes out diesel baseline pumps, reducing the environmental impact.

title: Community Based Agroforestry Project
description: The grouped project’s aim is to undertake agroforestry on fallow/ degraded lands of the individual smallholder farmers holding 0.2 to 1 ha of land in Jharkhand, India, through the establishment of horticultural trees yielding fruits, and timber based agroforestry model and by intercropping of seasonal crops in the farmers plot. The first instance consists of afforestation of 5000 hectare (ha) of fallow lands owned by local smallholder farmers that are lying unutilized for decades owing to various reasons such as lack of financial resources, migrant labor, etc. The project entails the planting of a variety of native species depending primarily on the soil types and local (market) demand, in consultation with the community members, for example, timber yielding trees comprising Teak (Tectona Grandis) and fruit yielding types including Mango (Mangifera Indica), Guava (Psidium guajava), Orange (Citrus Sinensis), among other species. To ensure the longevity and sustainability of the project, it will be managed by the local community. The activities under the project will contribute to multiple indicators for the Sustainable Development Goals such as No poverty (SDG 1), Zero Hunger (SDG 2), Gender Equality (SDG 5), Clean Water and Sanitation (SDG 6), Decent Work and Economic Growth (SDG 9), Climate Action (SDG 13), Life on Land (SDG 15).  The overall goal of the project is to, through afforestation activities, recover and utilize fallow lands and to promote connectivity between ecosystems by providing pathways for wildlife, facilitating movement and genetic exchange between fragmented habitats. In addition the project is majorly focused on enhancing livelihoods of the local communities in the project area. Marginal farmers in Jharkhand suffer from low income due to low productivity due to existing issues such as less fertile land, less use of manure, greater dependence on monsoons, backward/ outdated and limited technology, and unproductive use of debt.

title: Rivulis Climate Row Crops in Europe (RCRC)
description:
The Rivulis Climate Row Crops in Europe (RCRC) grouped project aims to create a new sustainable farming approach for seasonal crops in Southern Europe. 
The first instances of the project are located in Northern Italy and focus on crops such as tomatoes, corn and more. 
The project is led by Rivulis Climate, as part of a global initiative developed by Rivulis, a leader in climate and irrigation solutions, to support the agriculture transition to more sustainable farming practices. 

The goals of this new initiative are as follows: a) Reduce greenhouse gases emissions by adopting more efficient irrigation methods such as drip-irrigation and decreasing usage of synthetic fertilizers through the use of fertigation solutions and organic fertilizers, b) Increase carbon storage in soils through the implementation of soil conservation practices such as cover crops, minimal tillage and better residue management, c) reduce water usage and d) improve long-term crop yields and soil health.

The project is developed according to VCS methodology - VM0042 Methodology for Improved Agricultural Land Management - and falls under VCS Sectoral Scope 14, AFOLU.
VCS Proponent:
Rivulis Pte. Ltd.
Sharon, Israel
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: OGA REDD+ PROJECT
description:
The OGA REDD+ PROJECT aims to protect 8,348.78 hectares of Amazon rainforest located in Machadinho d’Oeste municipalitiy, Rondônia State, Brazil. The project promotes forest conservation and estimates to reduce 1,884,762.84 tCO2e (average of 62,825.43 tCO2e/year) in 30 years by Avoiding Unplanned Deforestation (AUD) and Avoiding Planned Deforestation (APD) in Lote 11 property.
AUD PAI scenario: The state of Rondônia has been expressive in the expansion of the Brazilian agricultural frontier, being agriculture and livestock the central axes of its economy. In 2023 the state saw a 450% increase in deforestation, being the third state with the highest deforestation contributions in the Legal Amazon. In Machadinho d’Oeste, this expansion led to increase in illegal deforestation, mainly for livestock, also resulting in the increase of social conflicts and illegal invasions. Furthermore, it is common for private properties in the region to exceed the conversion limit (or legal deforestation) allowed by the Forest Code. The main factors that lead producers to deforest their properties beyond the limit established in the Forest Code, according to various scientific studies, are (i) the opportunity cost of conserving the forest or native vegetation and (ii) the state's lack of supervision.
APD PAIs scenario: The project area is in compliance with the Forest Code, and the proponents will waive their right to legal suppression in order to protect the standing forest, thus avoiding an economically driven planned deforestation activity.
Given project approval, measures/technologies such as fire brigade training (internal and external community), reinforcement of terrestrial and remote monitoring, training courses will be carried out to qualify the project's employees and neighbours among other social activities will be implemented.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: Asha
description:
Asha is a grouped reforestation and sustainable development project in West Bengal, India, carried out by and for smallholder farmers. The first instance aims to reforest 2,000 hectares of private lands which are no longer used by their owners for cultivation due to their low soil fertility. The project has for objective to revitalize unproductive and degraded soils, absorb carbon and provide customary forest ecosystem services to local communities. Indeed, about 10 different local species of trees are planted. The trees planted are broadly of two categories, hardwood timber or species like Tectona grandis (teak) and Gmelina arborea (Gamhar) and medicinal and horticultural species (yielding fruits, flowers, medicines, fodder, etc.) like Azadirachta indica and Artocarpus heterophyllus (Jackfruit). Plantation activities will be done over 4 years (between 2024 - 2027) as part of the first project instance in parcels totaling 500 ha/y with an additional 10% area in the 5th year. 
This project instance is expected to sequester 45,660 tCO2e annually and a total of 913,190 tCO2e considering 20 years of crediting period.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: AHU REDD+ PROJECT
description:
The AHU REDD+ Project conserves 32,326.6 ha of unique transitional forests between the Cerrado and Amazon biomes (CAT). The Project takes place in the Agrochapada farm, municipality of Paranatinga, State of Mato Grosso, Brazil. The without project scenario is illegal logging is followed by frequent fire events.  Fire is used as a tool for deforestation. It spreads quickly in the draught season and causes degradation and extinction of forest patches.
The project employs protective technologies grouped under a Forest Integrity Program and preventive measures carried out under a Community Network Program. By doing so, it will avoid 9,164 hectares of modelled deforestation in four different phytophysiognomies. The total GHG emission reduction expected throughout the project´s 30 years 1,090,225.29 tCO2, with an annual average of 35,168.56 tCO2.
As part of the CCB Standard, the objectives for climate, community and biodiversity during the project life cycle are as follows:
Climate: a) To effectively prevent and control forest fires in and around the project area; and b) To effectively prevent deforestation and improve monitoring in and around the project area.
Community:a) Increase income opportunities for women; b) Increase the thermal comfort; c) To increase opportunities for physical activities; d) Enhance preventive health measures; and e) To improve education for the internal community at all levels.
Biodiversity: a) To reduce the impact of human activities on biodiversity; b)To improve the effectiveness of the farm´s restoration actions.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

description: The project involves the installation of 60 MW solar power project in Cambodia. The electricity generated from the project will be supplied to Cambodia's national grid and thereby avoid the CO2 emission associated with electricity generation from grid-connected power plants.

title: Yiri
description:
The Yiri project, located in Guinea, aims to reforest 6,000 hectares of private lands which are no longer used by their owners for cultivation due to their low soil fertility. More precisely, the project takes place in the Beyla prefecture, located in the Guinée Forestière region (main city: Nzérékoré). 
The objective of the project is to revitalize unproductive and degraded soils in 100 villages, absorb carbon for 40 years and provide customary forest ecosystem services for local communities as well as non-timber products. Indeed, seeds from about 40 useful local species of trees are sowed, including endangered species such as Milicia excelsa. 
Village chiefs and 2,000 families organised in two main groups are beneficiaries and direct actors of this project. Seed families provide the seeds of trees belonging to the 40 species to the field families, who sow the seeds on unused plots of their land, protect these plots and manage the future trees throughout the duration of the project.  
Fondation arboRise coordinates the project with its local partner GUIDRE, responsible for operational activities on the ground with families, village chiefs and local authorities.
A pilot project demonstrated the feasibility of this participatory approach, and this created a collective enthusiasm for changing habits.
The project estimates to generate around 1.9 million tons of GHG emission removals over 20 years, hence 96,181 tonnes of CO2e annually.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: AFFORESTATION AND BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION PROJECT IN WEST BENGAL
description: The grouped project’s aim is to undertake afforestation in fallow lands in the districts of Alipurduar, Jalpaiguri and Cooch Behar in West Bengal, India, through the establishment of horticultural (trees yielding fruits, flowers, medicines, fodder, etc.) and timber plantations. The first instance consists of afforestation of 5000 hectare (ha) of fallow lands owned by local smallholder farmers, that are lying unutilized for decades owing to various reasons such as human-animal conflicts, floods, lack of financial resources, etc. The project entails the planting of a variety of native species depending primarily on the soil types and local (market) demand, in consultation with the community members, whereby the first instance of plantation will be carried out across 3 (three) years. For example, timber yielding trees will comprise Gamhar (Gmelina Arborea) and Arjuna (Terminalia Arjuna) and fruit yielding types will include Jackfruit (Artocarpus heterophyllus) and Jamun (Syzygium Cumini), among other species. Through afforestation activities to recover fallow lands, the project aims to promote connectivity between ecosystems and enhance livelihoods of the local communities. In addition, this project is expected to provide more than 200 full-time employment opportunities (with equal access to women and men) in a zone historically affected by poverty.

title: NAMI REDD+ PROJECT
description:
The NAMI REDD+ PROJECT aims to protect 83,051.40 hectares of Amazon and estimates to reduce 48,636,901 tCO2e (average of 1,215,922.52 tCO2e/year) in 40 years by Avoiding Planned Deforestation (APD) in Jataí farm.
The project area is located in the municipality of Pauini, in the southern region of the state of Amazonas. The municipality is among the 100 poorest in Brazil. 
The owners of Jataí farm, analyzing the possibilities of using the area of the property economically in a sustainable way and based on Brazilian environmental legislation, which allows the use of up to 20% of the total property , requested permission to suppress vegetation for cattle ranching. For this, the landowners hired a consultancy to prepare a Business Plan detailing the viability of cattle raising in the permitted area, concluding that the activity was feasible.
Having carried out a more detailed analysis in search of a genuinely sustainable economic activity that would avoid the removal of the forest, even legally, and the consequent loss of the biodiversity present in the region, the possibility of developing a conservation project in the area was considered.
This project aims to contribute to avoided planned deforestation (APD) under the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) development and registration standard. Given project approval, activities such as fire brigade training (internal and external community), reinforcement of terrestrial and remote monitoring, border maintenance (firebreaks and fencing), training courses will be carried out to qualify the project's employees and neighbors among other social activities will be implemented.    
Thus, the project also aims to improve the social and environmental conditions in the project region, specifically contributing to enhancing deforestation control and developing social activities.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Carbon Smart Cropping and Pasture Systems USA
description:
The Carbon Smart Cropping and Pasture Systems USA project is a grouped VCS AFOLU project open to regenerative row crop farmers and graziers within the USA. The farms that will enrol in this project are growers and graziers that have mostly been following traditional farming methods such as tilling, removal of crop residue, no or minimal cover crops and with a strong reliance on chemical inputs, but who are now motivated to reduce their impact on the environment. 
For this grouped project, greenhouse gas (GHG) reductions and removals will be achieved by the implementation of a combination of practice changes, including the application of organic amendments and supplements, such as mulch and compost to reduce the reliance on synthetic fertilisers and to improve soil health, cover cropping, pasture improvement, improvement of herd management and grazing practices, improved water use efficiency and others.  
The undertaking of this project will support a number of United Nations Sustainable Development Goals in the project area, local communities, surrounding environments, and in the supply chain. The project will contribute towards SDG 2: Zero Hunger, SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production, and SDG 13: Climate Action.

title: TIST Program in Tanzania, VCS-CCB-011
description: Since its inception in 1999, over 200,000 participants organized into over 31,000 TIST Small Groups have planted over 25 million trees in Tanzania, India, Kenya, and Uganda - accomplishing GhG sequestration through tree planting, creating a potential long-term income stream, and developing sustainable environments and livelihoods. Tanzania 011 is a subset of the TIST project in Tanzania and applies to 638 Small Groups, 3,740 Participants, 2,611 active Project Areas, and 2,882 hectares.  TIST farmers use a mosaic restoration approach, planting on thousands of individual farms spread across the landscape. The individual farms are found throughout Tanzania and concentrated around Mpwapwa and Kibondo.
State/Province: Multiple including  Mpwapwa and Kibondo areas
