title: Uganda Native Reforestation and Agroforestry Project
description: The objective of the Uganda Native Reforestation and Agroforestry Project is to reforest an area of around 10,000 hectares using two approaches: planting agroforestry tree species on agricultural lands,and planting native forest species on degraded forest reserves. Paired together, these two strategies will reforest the landscape while sequestering carbon dioxide and providing ecosystem services. The degraded land will be rehabilitated with tree canopy cover, and over time local hydrology and soil health will be restored. On smallholder farms, the agroforestry trees will also improve crop yields and diversify income streams. The grouped Project will control erosion and increase water infiltration, as well as provide local employment opportunities while contributing to the region’s food security.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Agroforestry Project of Cameroon
description: The objective of the Agroforestry Project of Cameroon is to reforest an area of around 10,000 hectares, starting with degraded plots in Cameroon currently managed as unused or under-used agricultural lands or degraded grasslands, and reforest the landscape while sequestering carbon dioxide. The degraded land will be rehabilitated with tree canopy cover, and over time local hydrology and soil health will be restored. The grouped Project will control erosion and increase water infiltration, as well as provide local employment opportunities while contributing to the region’s food security.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Forest Landscape Restoration in Panama
description: The objective of the Forest Landscape Restoration in Panama project is to reforest an area of around 25,000 hectares, starting with unused or under-used, degraded land in Panama currently managed as abandoned or cattle pasture grazed at very low densities, and restore this ecosystem with tree cover in order to sequester carbon dioxide. The degraded land will thus be rehabilitated with a forest canopy, and over time biodiversity and local hydrology will be restored. The grouped Project will control erosion, regenerate soil health, and increase water infiltration, consequently improving ground water levels in the area, as well as provide local employment opportunities. Most land being considered is in the central region of Panama, but all regions of the country with degraded cattle pasture are eligible.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Rootella Carbon
description:
Groundwork BioAg Rootella Carbon Agricultural Program (the ‘Project’) enables the adoption of improved agricultural land management (IALM) practices on continental United States and Canada, where the project instances and baseline scenarios of similar nature. The project developer (Groundwork BioAg) will facilitate this adoption through financial incentives and technical support. Landowners and tenant farmers (‘farmers’) will improve soil carbon sequestration rates by applying one or more of the following practices to increase soil carbon sequestration rates and/or reduce on-farm greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions: 
•	Soil Amendments or seed treatments 
•	Reduced Tillage and Stubble Management: 
•	Cover Crops 
•	Fertilizer Nitrogen Reductions 
•	Energy Consumption Reductions through Practice Changes 
•	Improved Crop Rotation 
•	Methane Emission Reductions 
The focus of the Project is farmers who grow crops such as, but not limited to, corn, soy or wheat using conventional farming practices. These practices vary from farm to farm but may include one or more tillage passes per year, fields are generally left bare over winter, and excessive fertilizer application.

title: NATURAL FOREST REGENERATION FOR ENHANCED CARBON STOCKS IN THE ALBERTINE RIFT (FRECAR)
description: The project 'Natural Forest Regeneration for Enhanced Carbon Stocks in the Albertine Rift' (FRECAR) focuses on the Kagombe-Bugoma areas in the Northern part of the Albertine Rift, known for their highly biodiverse tropical moist forests. The project aims to protect and restore the natural value of four Central Forest Reserves through replanting indigenous trees, addressing agricultural encroachment, reducing unauthorized access to forest resources, and promoting sustainable practices. The project is estimated to generate significant greenhouse gas reductions and removals while improving biodiversity and fostering sustainable livelihoods for local communities. These triple benefits for community, biodiversity, and climate will be achieved through establishing climate resilient and adaptative measures for communities, forest conservation through the planting of indigenous trees, and tackling human-wildlife conflicts.

title: Regenerative Development of Anlo Wetlands Project
description: The Regenerative Development of Anlo Wetlands Project is a grouped project that aims to help adapt to climate change, enhance biodiversity and ecosystem health, and improve livelihoods of communities dependent on the local mangrove ecosystem. With a potential for expansion of planting up to 9,991 hectares of mangrove in the Keta Lagoon in Ghana, the first instance covers approximately 1,536 hectares. The primary objective of the project is to expand the mangrove area through the planting of diverse native mangrove species. This aims to enhance the positive functions and ecosystem services that mangroves provide to communities and biodiversity. The project is situated in the Volta region, within the Keta Lagoon Complex Ramsar site. This site is recognised for its exceptional biodiversity and wetland ecosystems and faces a necessity of preservation. Thus, the project's location contributes to enhancing the health and connectivity of habitats and ecosystems. The project is led by Terraformation as the project proponent, with the Regenerative Development of Anlo Wetlands Foundation as the project implementer of the project activities. The project activities will take place in locations selected based on their ecological suitability, in collaboration with local communities. The project design encourages and promotes active participation from these local communities. The project plans to reverse mangrove decline, restore ecosystem services, and offer sustainable livelihood opportunities while preserving biodiversity. The project will achieve these aims through large-scale mangrove reforestation, regenerative aquaculture, and apiculture. In addition to restoring native vegetation and habitat for fish and wildlife, the project will generate GHG benefits by sequestering carbon dioxide from the atmosphere through the restoration of mangrove ecosystems.

title: Smallholder Reforestation in Malawi
description: The project is a grouped afforestation project in the Districts of Mzimba and Nkhotakota, Malawi. The project will establish smallholder woodlots on degraded land. The project will build landholder capacity to manage tree nurseries, plant trees and manage the woodlots and provide an alternative source of income to the people participating in the project. The first activity instance of this grouped project started in Mzimba with 1.8 million trees planted in 2022 and 2023.

title: Trees For Livelihoods: Agroforestry In Sonbhadra, Uttar Pradesh, India
description: The proposed project aims at increasing the tree cover outside forest (ToF) areas through ARR activities. The planting activities occur on predominantly privately owned agricultural lands and consist of planting farmer-friendly trees on the bunds of and within these plots. In some cases, planting occurs on community lands and other non-forest & non-agricultural private lands, that are used by physical structures such as schools and ashrams. Implemented in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, overall the project addresses livelihoods, the financial security of local farming and other communities through planting of farmer friendly trees in the project area along with associated community-based interventions.

title: Landscape-based approach towards the revitalization of degraded agro-ecology for livelihood generation of marginalized communities
description:
The proposed VCS project “Landscape-based approach towards the revitalization of degraded agro-ecology for livelihood generation of marginalized communities”, represents an afforestation project in the states of Odisha and Maharashtra, India. The project promotes and implements the plantation of Eucalyptus species with short rotations in privately owned lands of small and marginal farmers in the project area. 
Maharashtra (63.7% ) and Odisha (20.61% ) are among the largest contributors to the agricultural sector of the country, and are majorly dependent on rain-fed agriculture (around 75% - 80%  ) for sustenance making them vulnerable to the changing climatic conditions. Rise in temperature, unpredictable rainfall, soil erosion and increasing drought are among the major conditions that are affecting the productivity of the land leading to crop failure  . 
Urvara Krsi Private Limited (UKPL) has been promoting agroforestry with small & marginal farmers belonging to various tribal communities across the states of India. UKPL with its landscape approach is implementing plantations under models such as Block plantation, Wadi Model (NABARD), Bund Plantation etc. in agricultural areas, bunds, wasteland, community land, and barren land. They provides expert technical guidance to the farmers on the selection and maintenance of plantations and assists in creating market linkage for the sale of timber/pulp. This model not only helps in increasing the productivity of the land but also creates additional livelihood opportunities for the farmers.
The project area is estimated to carry out plantation on 13,255 ha of land between 2021 to 2024. Over a crediting period of 29 years the project will generate gross removals or net removals of 12,63,577 tCO2e and 43,571 tCO2e/yr.

title: MÜSESI project for active restoration in areas of the Sierra Nevada Santa Marta, Colombia
description:
This grouped project is designed to establish in the first stage 810.98 hectares of native species in the municipalities of Aracataca, Fundación, Santa Marta, Ciénaga, Dibuya, and El Copey, Colombia. The specific objectives of this project are:
1.	Setting up large-scale tree planting projects on 810.98 ha based on the “direct seeding” technique.
2.	Implementation of solutions for soil fertility, water conservation, climate change mitigation, and animal habitat.
3.	To raise awareness of climate change and adaptation strategies.
4.	To develop economic instruments to ensure the sustainability of the project over time.
5.	Creation of schools’ farms through the implementation of a community program that fosters the training of the community on sustainability restoration practices with native species to create a community using self-sustaining systems.
The project contributes to the mitigation of greenhouse gases through a combination of sustainable land management practices and principles that promote carbon sequestration and reduced greenhouse gas emissions planting 731,765 trees in the first instance. These plants capture and store carbon dioxide from the atmosphere through photosynthesis, effectively sequestering carbon in the biomass and soil, and will result in an annual average of 46,053 tCO2, during 30 years, thus, a total of 1,381,590 tCO2.
VCS Proponent:

Switzerland
+41 415522900
admin.ch@allcot.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Brazil Precision Agriculture Carbon Program
description:
The Brazil Precision Agriculture Carbon Program (BPACP) incentivizes the large-scale adoption of big data-driven precision agriculture in Brazil.

It is a grouped VCS project implemented by a national carbon credit cooperative society (“Carbon Coop”). The project has partnered with multiple stakeholders on a national scale, including soil laboratories, a big data analytics platform, agro-inputs and machinery dealers, local agricultural consultants and soil sampling experts, to connect with farmers and leverage the adoption of precision agriculture.

The carbon project intends to harness data analytics, remote sensing, climate and crop modelling, artificial intelligence, and in-field sensors, to help farmers make data-informed decisions that sustainably increase productivity and crop resilience (adaptation), reduce and remove greenhouse gas emissions (mitigation), and enhance achievement of global food security and national development goals.
VCS Proponent:
Enviro Carbon Serviços Ambientais Ltda
São Paulo, Brazil

thiago.camargo@envirocarbon.ag
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Fortaleza Ituxi III ALM
description:
The Fortaleza Ituxi III ALM project is located in one of the regions with the highest deforestation rate in the Amazon Biome: the municipality of Lábrea. For the last 10 years,
it has been one of the most deforested municipalities in the Amazon Biome and the south of Lábrea has already been reached by the “Arc of Deforestation”. Beside the
damage caused to natural ecosystems, the land-use changes have provoked severe social conflicts through processes of land-grabbing and installation of agriculture and
cattle ranching activities (often irregular or even illegal), contributing to the expulsion of family-scale forest extractives from that region. The main activity of the Fortaleza Ituxi III ALM project consists of growing Açaí (Euterpe oleracea) in an integrated production system intercropped with pasture for a low carbon cattle grazing. The project area is located in the municipality of Lábrea, in the state of Amazonas, in northern Brazil. The project area covers an extension of 371.52 ha, referring to the lease of the first instance and lies to the north of the Ituxi River, situated on the Nossa Senhora das Cachoeiras do Ituxi farm. The Fortaleza Ituxi III ALM is an Agriculture Land Management (ALM) project based on Improved Grassland Management (IGM) and it aims to include practices that demonstrably reduce net GHG emissions of grassland ecosystems by increasing soil carbon stocks, improving aboveground biomass and reducing N2O emissions and/or reducing CH4 emissions. The estimated GHG emission reduction is 58,099.93 tCO2e over the 20-year project lifetime (01-July-2023 to 30-June-2043), with an annual average of 2,905.00 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: OYU - Reforesting Kenya for a better tomorrow
description: This project, situated in Kenya, focuses on carbon dioxide removal within the Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation (ARR) framework of Agriculture, Forestry, and Other Land Use (AFOLU) initiatives. Its primary objective is to bolster community resilience against the adverse effects of climate change. This is achieved through the enhancement of local capacity and the adaptation of agroforestry systems, promoting both well-being and environmental sustainability. The chosen tree species for plantation are well-received by the local community and have seamlessly integrated into the surrounding ecosystem over time.

title: Sustainable Wood by NFB
description: This initiative is a carbon dioxide removal project located in Uganda, classified as a Least Developed Country (LDC) according to the UN List. The primary goal is to increase the green cover in the Jinja district and other regions that have experienced notable deforestation over the past two decades. Beyond carbon removal, the project contributes significantly by generating employment opportunities for various local communities and yielding additional co-benefits.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: OYU - Tenera Plantations by BIDCO
description: It is a carbon dioxide removal project that facilitates inclusive rural transformation through carbon financing in the oil palm industry. It strives to increase rural incomes sustainably by fostering an efficient and socially responsible oil palm sector. This involves establishing sustainable supply chains, diversifying household livelihoods, creating an enabling environment for scaling-up, and supporting alternative economic opportunities to mitigate social risks. It aims to counteract prior environmental degradation and contribute to sustainable development by converting low-productive grasslands and cropland into perennial Tenera hybrid tree cropland.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: REDD Pantanal
description:
REDD Pantanal is a multi-activity grouped project located in the Pantanal of Brazil. The project is classified under scope 14 - AFOLU and falls into the category of REDD considering planned and unplanned deforestation. Its main goal is to conserve the remaining forest cover of properties under pressure from deforestation and forest degradation, reducing GHG emissions.
Mapbiomas’ Annual Deforestation Report of Brazil indicates that Pantanal deforestation has increased by 8.2% from 2021 to 2022. The 2022 deforestation rate was 31,212 ha. The increase in deforestation in natural forests of Brazil, threatens climate change mitigation and affects provisions of energy, water, and food security in Brazil and worldwide. 
REDD Pantanal seeks landowners who opt to keep conserved areas which could be converted legally. Additionally, it will strengthen the protection of Permanent Preservation Areas (APP) and Legal Reserves (RL), which have also been targeted by illegal deforestation and degradation. ECCON will be responsible for the development, implementation across different instances, and monitoring of the climatic parameters of REDD Pantanal. Landowners are also involved in the project, who, through the signing of a contract contribute effectively to maintaining their areas under native vegetation. This commitment allows them to support the activities to be developed by the project. 
The revenue from carbon credits generated by REDD Pantanal will contribute to conservation, making the activity more appealing for the rural producers. Therefore, maintaining the standing forest will be a competitive alternative to other land uses, which poses a threat to the conversion of native vegetation in the current scenario.
REDD Pantanal activities commenced in 2021, with a 45-year crediting period, from November 18, 2021, to November 17, 2066. PAI 01 is the first instance of the project, which will prevent the emission of 1,837,304 tCO2e over 30 years.
VCS Proponent:
ECCON Solucoes Ambientais
São Paulo, Brazil
55 11 976032514
yuri@ecconsa.com.br
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: ARBRE
description: The Regenerative Agriculture-Driven Afforestation & Restoration (i.e., ARBRE is the French equivalent acronym that is the project title) is a VCS grouped ARR project being launched by a Quebec, Nature-based solutions project developer, Carbon Terre a Terre (CTaT). With the ARBRE grouped project, CTaT is strategically positioning itself and its partners, at the dynamic intersection between climate change mitigation, climate change adaption and efforts to render industrial agriculture more regenerative in the Province of Quebec. The main ARBRE project activity is to convert nonproductive degraded non-forest old fields / abandoned former agricultural fields to sugar maple producing orchards in a shelterwood arrangement that will mimic natural succession ecological processes. Some low value productive agricultural land will be afforested  The baseline scenario is the old fields staying as degraded non forest and unproductive land, with a thick herbaceous layer and/or shrub mat impeding natural tree regeneration and/or continued agricultural production of low value agricultural land.  CTaT has selected old-fields sites where the above mentioned pre-existing conditions will cause a long regeneration delay, with only marginal shrub and/or tree ingress over the crediting period.   CTaT is planning a first annual instance/pilot project of 125 hectares to be established in 2024 as part of an overall buildout of 1000 hectares from 2024 to 2029.  Total net project minus baseline sequestration over for all 5 annual instances is estimated to be approximately 500,000 tCO2e.  The ARBRE project offers multiple non carbon benefits such as enhanced wildlife corridor habitat and slope stability as well as diversified regenerative agriculture values to farmers.  The project will help to rejuvenate and augment sugar maple production in Quebec.  It offers a high level of additionality for its atmospheric decarbonation benefits without any significant risk to food security.
VCS Proponent:
Carbone Terre a Terre
QC, Canada
4502239736
sebastien.chenard@carboneterreaterre.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
Crediting Period Term: CREDITING PERIOD HAS YET TO START, 15/05/2025 - 14/05/2085

title: Project to Restore Degraded Lands by Planting Forest and Fruit Trees in Northern Cameroon
description:
The entire project lies within the geographical boundaries of Northern Cameroon that covers three regions i.e. the Adamawa, the North and Far North regions. In the first instance, the project activity is limited to the Adamawa region. Being a grouped project, the sites of the other two regions will be added as ‘future project instances.
The project activity involves planting dozens of indigenous fruit trees in the area. In the first project instance, fruit and forest trees will be planted during a period of ten years on 25,000 hectares of the Nyambaka council forest. The Nyambaka council forest is a mosaic of forest and savannah registered as part of the Country’s permanent forest estate and thus managed by the Council of Nyambaka. All project instances within this grouped project activity will consist of afforestation, reforestation and revegetation (ARR)
The grouped project activities have as objective to contribute to sustainable environmental management, community development and poverty reduction. These activities will significantly improve the livelihoods of communities through job creation. The establishment of such plantations will increase carbon sinks, thus, contributing directly to climate change mitigation and adaptation. The communities will be organized into cooperatives to develop and exploit the value chains of non-timber forest products (cashew, Arabic gum, Shea butter, mango, etc.).
VCS Proponent:
S2 Services
Littoral region, Cameroon
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Guangxi Laibin Organic Wastewater Biogas Power Generation Comprehensive Utilization Project
description:
Guangxi Laibin Organic Wastewater Biogas Power Generation Comprehensive Utilization Project (hereafter referred to as the project) is located on the east side of the paper mill area of Guangxi Xinggui Paper Industry Co., Ltd. (hereafter referred to as Xinggui paper mill), Honghe Farm, Mengcun Town, Xingbin District, Laibin City, Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, P. R. China. The project is constructed and operated by Guangxi Gangya Shengda New Energy Co., Ltd. 
The project started to construct on 05/03/2023 and started operation on 29/06/2023.The project has a total designed capacity 2MW (3*1MW, one is for back-up use) and combusts the organic wastewater biogas, which contains nearly 74.93% of methane, to generate electricity for Xinggui paper mill to consume. The project collects and utilizes the biogas generated by the anaerobic treatment section of organic wastewater to generate electricity, which would otherwise be released into the atmosphere. Methane in the organic wastewater biogas has been emitted to the atmosphere since the sewage treatment station started operation. Therefore, the project avoids methane emissions and, at the same time, electricity is generated from a renewable energy source, instead of being provided by the grid. The project activity is expected to displace 14,400 MWh of electricity per year by reducing the import from the grid to the plant. VCUs will be claimed from the methane destroyed and the grid electricity displaced. The estimated average GHG emission reduction of the project is 62,771 tCO2e and the total GHG emission reductions and removals are 627,710 tCO2e during the fixed 10 years crediting period.
VCS Proponent:
Henan BCCY Environmental Energy CO.,LTD.
Henan, China
86 371 6552 1782
lwang@bccynewpower.com

title: Solar Power Project by Dalmia Cement in Assam
description: The project involves installation of Solar Photovoltaic (SPV) Panels on ground mounted in the state of Assam, India. The sole purpose of project activity is to install solar power plant for captive purpose and surplus generated electricity can be supplied to grid. M/s. Dalmia Cement Bharat Ltd (to be referred as DCBL from here on) is installed & develop a DC capacity of 20 MW (AC capacity- 16.64 MW) ground mounted on site Solar Photovoltaic Power Project (Project) for Captive Power Consumption at Lanka- Mosoka Rd, Pipal Pukhuri No.2 village, Hojai District in the State of Assam.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents

title: Carbon Smart Cropping and Pasture Systems Australia
description:
The Carbon Smart Cropping and Pasture Systems Australia project is a grouped VCS AFOLU project open to regenerative row crop farmers and graziers within Australia. The farms that will enroll in this project are growers and graziers that have mostly been following traditional farming methods such as tilling, removal of crop residue, no or minimal cover crops and with a strong reliance on chemical inputs, but who are now motivated to reduce their impact on the environment. 
For this grouped project, greenhouse gas (GHG) reductions and removals will be achieved by the implementation of a combination of practice changes, including the application of organic amendments and supplements, such as mulch and compost to reduce the reliance on synthetic fertilizers and to improve soil health, cover cropping, pasture improvement, improvement of herd management and grazing practices, improved water use efficiency and others.  
The undertaking of this project will support a number of United Nations Sustainable Development Goals in the project area, local communities, surrounding environments, and in the supply chain. The project will contribute towards SDG 2: Zero Hunger, SDG 12: Responsible Consumption and Production, and SDG 13: Climate Action.
VCS Proponent:
Carbon Friendly Pty Ltd.
Queensland, Australia
+61 417 743 402
mariki@carbonfriendly.com.au
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Peruvian Amazon Conservation Project
description: The Peruvian Amazon Conservation Project is an Improved Forest Management Project (IFM) that will reduce greenhouse gases (GHG) by preventing commercial logging (logged to protected forest - LtPF) in 291,590 hectares of tropical rainforest. The project is implemented by 21 tribal communities in partnership with the Amazon Conservation Group (ACG) and Desarrollo Ambiental y Social Peru (DAS).  The project is located in the Purús Province in the Ucayali Region in the central Amazon rainforest of Peru. The project area is made up of several indigenous territories and represents ancient ecosystems. These ecosystems provide critical habitat to threatened fauna and flora as well as provide ecosystem services for the local communities that have lived there for millennia.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Shanxi Xiadian CMM Power Generation Project
description:
Shanxi Xiadian CMM Power Generation Project (hereinafter referred to as the Project) will utilize the low concentration coal mine methane (CMM) from Xiadian coal mine for power generation to supply electricity to the coal mine where the project is located. The project is located in the wind shaft yard of Xiadian Coal Mine on the north side of HouWangjiagou Village, Xiadian Town, Xiangyuan County, Changzhi City, Shanxi  Province, China. The central geographical coordinates are east longitude 112.911585° and north latitude 36.530075°. The Project Owner is Xiangyuan Luxin Coal Mine Methane Power Generation Co., Ltd. 
Prior to the implementation of the project, xiadian coal mine was equipped with CMM extraction facilities and all extracted CMM was vented into the atmosphere directly; the electricity consumed at coal mines was imported from NCPG; the heat was provided by waste coal boilers. For CMM treatment and heat supply, baseline scenario is the same as the scenario existing prior to the implementation of the project activity. For electricity supply, the NCPG provides the equivalent amount of electricity produced by the Project in the baseline. 
The purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted CMM with low concentration methane concentration to produce electricity. No coal bed methane (CBM) or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. Fifteen sets of CMM power generators will be installed with a total installed capacity of 7.5MW (8*0.5 MW+7*0.5 MW), destroying 16.25 million m3 of methane annually. After the full operation of the Project, the expected annual exported electricity will be 31850 MWh, which will be supplied to the coal mine first through the electricity distribution network in Xiadian coal mine area, and then to NCPG if there is any electricity surplus, replacing the electricity that would otherwise have been purchased from the NCPG and displace part of the electricity generated by NCPG dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants.
VCS Proponent:
Xiangyuan Luxin Coal Mine Methane Power Generation Co., Ltd
Shanxi Province, China

title: Longido and Monduli Rangelands Carbon Project
description: This project features implementation of rapid rotational grazing practices by dense aggregations of livestock to restore perennial grasses on degraded rangelands across 970,685 hectares in northern Tanzania. These new grazing practices are additional because they differ from the currently practiced seasonal shifts in grazing activity from wet to dry season ranges, and the new practices would not be possible without carbon revenues to support governance and monitoring of grazing activities. Rapid rotational grazing will enhance adaptation to climate change by improving soil water holding capacity, increasing surface water availability and providing grass banks as a hedge against drought. Habitat improvement from new grazing practices will result in biodiversity benefits in the form of improved habitat inside wildlife corridors between iconic High Conservation Areas such as Serengeti, Kilimanjaro, Nairobi, and Tsavo National Parks and their associated ecosystems and enhance diversity of endemic taxa of plants, birds and insects. Finally, the project will provide direct benefits to dozens of pastoralist communities in form of funds for bursaries to support women and the poorest community members as well as to construct water capture structures and infrastructure for delivering livestock to market. The project is expected to remove more than 62 million tons CO2e over the project lifetime of 40 years, or more than 1.5 million tons CO2e a year on average.
VCS Proponent:
Soils for the Future Tanzania

title: Taiping Township Waste Resource Utilization Project
description:
The Taiping Township waste resource utilization project (hereafter referred to as the proposed project) is located in Zhaodong City, Suihua City, Heilongjiang Province, China (125°58′7.24″, 45°56′4.03″), which is operated by Zhaodong Boan Environmental Protection Technology Co., Ltd., which is an affiliated company under Heilongjiang Boneng Green Energy Technology Co., Ltd. 
The proposed project is a new plant which designed to treat organic wastes through anaerobic digestion and composting to produce the natural gas and organic fertilizers. The natural gas produced will be used for distributing in a natural gas distribution grid, and organic fertilizers will be transported to the local planting market. The proposed project uses organic wastes such as straw and livestock manure as raw materials. It is expected to treat 34,500 tons of straw and 69,000 tons of livestock manure annually, producing 3,777,800 Nm3 of the natural gas and 15,769.95 tons of solid bio-organic fertilizers.
The project activities include waste pretreatment unit, anaerobic digesters unit, biogas purification unit, and organic fertilizer production workshop etc. Raw materials such as crushed straw and livestock manure are preprocessed and mixed before being sent to an anaerobic fermentation unit, where organic matter is degraded by microorganisms under anaerobic conditions. After anaerobic digestion, methane and digestate are generated. Methane will be processed through dehydration, desulfurization, decarbonization, and other processes to obtain biogas, the digestate after thorough digestion is sent to the solid-liquid separation system. The separated biogas residue is processed into solid organic fertilizer and returned to the field after being added with straw. The biogas slurry is discharged into the biogas slurry temporary storage tank for subsequent production.
VCS Proponent:
Heilongjiang Boneng Green Energy Technology Co., Ltd.
Heilongjiang Province, China

title: The Regenerative Agriculture project for Eastern European Soils
description: The Regenerative Agriculture Project for Eastern European Soils, referred to here as the Project, is an Agricultural Land Management (ALM) carbon project developed and owned by eAgronom,  implementing project activities in Ukraine and Moldova. It follows Verra’s VM0042 methodology for Improved Agricultural Land Management, version 2.0, hereafter called VM0042. The Project is dedicated to enhancing soil organic carbon levels in arable lands (which include annual croplands, temporary grasslands - i.e. grass species within a crop rotation - and fallows), perennial croplands, and permanent grasslands. Its primary goal is to encourage the adoption of regenerative agricultural practices that foster carbon sequestration while minimising and eliminating greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions

title: TAPERA AMAZONAS REDD+
description:
The Tapera Amazonas REDD+ Project in Urucará and Nhamundá, Amazonas, Brazil, combats severe deforestation. Amazonas experienced considerable forest loss, with 4,913 km² deforested in 2021 and 2,741 km² in 2022, leading to high CO2 emissions. Main causes include illegal logging, cattle ranching, and agriculture expansion. Urucará and Nhamundá, however, maintain high forest coverage, emphasizing their ecological importance. The project focuses on conservation, biodiversity protection, and sustainable practices.

Deforestation drivers in these areas are illegal logging and agricultural expansion, with Urucará particularly affected due to timber industries in nearby São Sebastião. The project, under the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) for Forestry, aims to reduce emissions from deforestation and degradation. It plans to improve monitoring, employ new staff for farm management, and use carbon credits for environmental and social enhancements.

In line with Brazil's Forest Code, the project supports maintaining 80% of forest cover in the Legal Amazon. Community benefits include water systems, solar panels, satellite internet, and training for sustainable forest product processing. A processing factory in Urucará will offer alternative income sources. Operations are expected to start in January 2025. The project is significant for biodiversity, located within a Key Biodiversity Area, home to unique and endangered species. It prioritizes ecosystem functions like nutrient cycling and carbon sequestration. Monitoring will involve satellite imagery, drone-based techniques, and fire prevention strategies, focusing on conserving forest areas against legal deforestation pressures.

Organica Consultoria LTDA
Ceará, Brazil

title: Grouped Improved Agricultural Land Management Project in Jilin Province
description:
Grouped Improved Agricultural Land Management Project in Jilin Province hereinafter referred to as “the Grouped P roject”) implements conservation agriculture (crop residue addition and reduced tillage in monocrop ping corn fields located in Jilin Province, China. The first seven instances initially included in the project design cover 572,600 hectares ( 8,589,000 MuMu1) of monocropping corn fields located in Da’an City , Gongzhuling City, Jiutai District, Nong’an County, Shuangyang District, Taobei District, Tongyu County, all of which are county level administrative divisions in Jilin Province Inclusion of new instances is possible on the condition that the new instance meets the eligibility criteria set out in Section 1.5.1.  Fujian Huanrong Environmental Protection Co., Ltd. is the project proponent.
The Grouped P roject is expected to replace conventional farming practices and promote conservation agriculture , which entails incorporating crop 
 residues in the fields after the harvest and applying reduced tillage prior to sowing. Reduced tillage minimizes soil disturbance , and crop residues incorporated in the fields contribute to soil organic matter increase and avoid greenhouse gas emissions which would otherwise occur due to burning or other management measures.
The scenario existing before the project initiation is conventional tillage without crop residue addition. The baseline scenario is the same as the conditions existing prior to the project initiation. During the first crediting period which spans for 10 years, the Grouped Project is expected to generate total GHG emission reductions and removals of 10,497,660 tCO 2 e, with annual average GHG emission reductions and removals of 1,049,766 tCO 2 e.
VCS Proponent:
Fujian Huanrong Environmental Protection Co., Ltd
Fujian, China
+8613599045362
zhongjiawei@fjhuanrong.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Brazilian ALM Carbon Program in different crop use and pasture integrated system
description: Brazilian ALM Carbon Program in different crop use and pasture integrated system aims the agricultural GHG emission reduction and removal by adopting improved ALM practices and considering the specificity of each Brazilian biome, following the “VM0042: Methodology for Improved Agricultural Land Management”, v. 2.0 and the AGLIBS ® Artificial Intelligence (AI) Platform, which is specifically addressed to fulfil the need for a high-integrity and cost-efficient monitoring system (MRV- measurable, reportable, and verifiable) through the emerging technology LIBS. The overall objective will be achieved by supporting farmers to adopt and maintain climate-smart agricultural practices through agronomic support and the monitoring of soil carbon stock change inside the farm boundary. The primary goal is to promote a range of regenerative agricultural land management practice improvements targeted to increase soil organic carbon (SOC) storage and reduce net emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O from grower operations and degraded pasture area, increase farm resilience to extreme weather and climate change, and enhance yield, improve soil quality, and reduce GHG emissions. The reductions and removal of GHG emissions expected to be achieved would not have taken place without it. As this is a grouped project, as defined by the VCS standard, it includes multiple growers with multiple enrolled fields. The estimate is that the project could promote a GHG emission reduction and removal of up 1,816,666 tCO2eq promoted by more than 2,000,000 ha, in the next 20 years. In advance, it is expected to increase the sustainability of this sector and raising the life standards in rural areas.

São Paulo, Brazil

title: MALAYSIA RENEWABLE BIOENERGY GROUPED PROJECT
description: The MALAYSIA RENEWABLE BIOENERGY GROUPED PROJECT is a grouped project which consists of projects supplying renewable electricity to the grid that are located in Malaysia. The purpose of this Grouped Project is to generate renewable electricity from sources such as biogas recovery from agricultural effluent, industrial effluent, food waste, and others, as well as biomass combustion from agro/forest biomass residues in waste streams that are sent to landfills. The electricity generated shall be supplied to the national electricity grid.

title: Yambone REDD+ Project
description: The REDD+ project is called Yambone, which in Yao, the local dialect, means 'To Make Better'. The project aims to improve various aspects of the Chipanje Chetu area in the northern part of Sanga district. The main objective is the conservation of the miombo forest, a complicated and delicate ecosystem that is the victim of illegal deforestation by farmers and charcoal burners. In addition, the project aims to improve the existence of the five local communities, helping them to develop as sustainable a path as possible, accompanying them in various areas, from improving agriculture to health, from access to energy to education. The project area covers a large area, 6500 square kilometres, and to protect it, the help of the community is needed, part of which will be taken on by the project and will be an integral part of it. The Yambone project is designed to be developed as a traditional carbon project, with the addition of specific actions and monitoring of the community and biodiversity components. Thus, not only will the carbon contained in the area and related risks be estimated and quantified, but also specific activities for some particularly fragile community categories will be implemented and improved over time, and animal and plant species of particular importance to the ecosystem will be identified and then watched over and monitored, demonstrating that the project will bring benefits in this respect as well. Objectives In summary, the main objectives of the Yambone REDD+ project are therefore as follows: • protection of forest and carbon stocks against illegal deforestation • community development, focusing on sustainable practices • biodiversity enhancement, using the presence and behaviour of key species as a proxy Finally, the Yambone REDD+ project is designed to be replicable and scalable, annexing neighbouring areas in the near future. Assessing the minimum requirements of neighbouring areas to be annexed to the project,

Carbon Sink Group s.r.l.
Firenze, Italy
+39 055 4574675

VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: PLUM Peat and Mangrove Conservation and Restoration Project (PLUM Project)
description: The PLUM Peat and Mangrove Conservation and Restoration Project (PLUM Project) is a conservation and restoration project of peat and mangrove forests located in Central Kalimantan Province, Indonesia. The project is implemented on a 23,665-hectare forest concession with Forest Utilization Business License (PBPH). Prior to the PLUM Project, the project area was legally authorized and documented to be converted into oil palm plantation. The project’s goal is to conserve the remaining forest, restore ecosystem function, protect biodiversity, and improve the well-being of communities to become resilient to climate change. The project proponent will implement activities to maximize the positive impact of the project for the climate, community and biodiversity. Forest protection activities such as forest patrols, fire prevention, construction of fire towers and guard posts and regular monitoring of biodiversity will be implemented to prevent forest loss and protect biodiversity. Peat ecosystems will be restored by blocking canals to rewet the area and avoid further peat drainage. Furthermore, the project will rehabilitate a total of 15,088 ha degraded land, composed of 424 ha of ARR in mangrove, 1,306 ha of ARR on peatland, and 13,358 ha of Assisted Natural Regeneration on peat. The project will provide tangible benefits to local communities living in the surrounding area by working to improve local livelihoods, health, education, and well-being. The project area is home to 31 globally threatened species, including the Bornean orangutan, Proboscis monkey, and the Bornean white-bearded gibbon. The project activities will contribute to the conservation of these species and their habitat, and restore the degraded peatland and mangroves to improve the habitat quality and reduce the threats to biodiversity.
VCS Proponent:
PT. Pagatan Usaha Makmur

title: Nkuba REDD+ Project
description: The Nkuba REDD+ Project (NRP) is designed to promote climate change mitigation, preserve biodiversity, and establish alternative livelihoods for communities through the UN-REDD+ framework. The NRP is expected to reduce an average of 256,808 t CO2e per year, The Project Zone is 105,572 ha and covers the Nkuba Conservation Area (NCA), located in North Kivu & Maniema provinces, DRC. The NRP consists mainly of primary rainforest including numerous unique species. The NCA landscape is dominated by plains, plateaus, and low mountains above small marshy valleys. It has numerous rivers and tributaries with conditions for a thriving tropical ecosystem.  The NRP consists of three forest blocks that are recognised by the Congolese authorities as community forest conservation concessions (CFCLs). The CFCLs involved in the NRP are Mbungu, Nsuhu, and Seko, with a total of six clans making up the project communities. The benefits of the NRP forest are significant, but the region continues to experience threats due to deforestation, uncontrolled hunting, artisanal mining, and nomadic activities. The lack of employment, business opportunities, limited access to infrastructure and basic services contribute to local populations exploiting the forest for income generation. In response to these threats to the NCA, the 6 clans in partnership with Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund created NRP with the following objectives: 1) Mitigate climate change caused by deforestation and degradation and develop adaptation strategies for climate variability, 2) Improve the quality of life for local communities by introducing sustainable alternatives to forest exploitation, income-generating activities, and initiatives designed to address community needs, such as health, education, and safety, 3) Contribute to preserving biodiversity through community-led forest management, better land strategies, and forest monitoring, regulation, and surveillance.
VCS Proponent:
Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund
Georgia, United States

title: RBML (Reliance BP Mobility Limited) EV Charging Infrastructure Project
description:
This project is to be developed by Reliance BP Mobility Limited (RBML). Reliance Industries Limited and British Petroleum Plc. have partnered to form Reliance BP Mobility Limited to combine international expertise & local strengths to spearhead the future of mobility. Electric Mobility Business operates under the brand name Jio-bp Pulse.
This project includes the installation, operation, and maintenance of EV charging stations by RBML across India through strategic partnerships with public and private sector in order to scale the EV market in the country and also act as an enabler for the Government of India’s National Electric Mobility Plan. This is a grouped project and the new instances will be added as and when the EVCS get installed across India in the future.
The use of this charging infrastructure results in the avoidance of fossil fuel powered vehicle usage and therefore a reduction in the greenhouse gas emissions from the alternative energy supply. This project includes EVCS that are installed, operated, and maintained by RBML.

title: CLEAN BIO-ENERGY INITIATIVE IN  MADHYA PRADESH AND MAHARASHTRA
description:
The projects primary objective is to change the pre-project/baseline scenario of the household cooking practices by replacing inefficient wood-fired mud stoves and three- stone stove technologies with clean, sustainable, and efficient biogas digestion unit and stoves. Each beneficiary household actively participates by utilizing cattle dung as the primary feed for the digesters, strategically curbing greenhouse gas emissions. This approach not only displaces conventional non-renewable biomass, such as firewood, with renewable biogas but also averts emissions of Methane (CH4) and Nitrogen Oxide (NO2) associated with the anaerobic decay of animal manure. Beyond emissions reduction, the initiative plays a pivotal role in enhancing rural hygiene practices through the proper
disposal of animal waste. Furthermore, the residue derived from the bio-digesters is repurposed as organic fertilizer, contributing to sustainable land applications. By replacing non-renewable energy sources with biogas generated from the biodigesters, the project aligns with the broader goals of sustainable development outlined by the United Nations.
VCS Proponent:
Ecological Restoration Organization
Madhya Pradesh, India

title: OYU - Greening India Mission (GIM)
description: OYU Green's Greening India Mission (GIM) aims to rejuvenate Assam's landscape by expanding the green cover of dormant land through a strategic agroforestry model. With farmers and landowners at the forefront, GIM focuses on long-term carbon dioxide removal by establishing Plantation Management Units (PMUs) using native tree species, thus combating climate change. The flagship initiative extends beyond carbon removal by uplifting local communities and safeguarding biodiversity.

title: COMACO South Landscape Management Project
description:
This project description document covers COMACO operations in part of the Central province (Mumbwa and Shibuyunji districts) and part of Southern province (Itezhi-Tezhi district) of Zambia. The COMACO South Landscape Management Project (CLMP-South) promotes sustainable agriculture land management and improved forest management. The key objectives of the project are to improve agricultural soil management through climate smart agricultural practices and reduce uncontrolled forest loss and degradation through community base conservation and land use planning. Hence, the project comprises two components:
1. Sustainable Agricultural Land Management (SALM) component – which aims to promote widespread adoption of agricultural practices including conservation agriculture and agroforest that increases the food production per unit area. The project promotes the adoption by farmers of legume-based alley cropping, residues management (e.g. mulching; cessation of residue burning), use of organic fertilizers such as composite and animal manure, reduced tillage and the intercropping of Gliricidia Sepium as part of Agroforestry to restore soil quality and sequestrate carbon.
2. REDD+ (Avoided Unplanned Deforestation) component – which aims to reduce forest loss, protect and expand areas under natural forest, and conserve biodiversity. This is achieved primarily through land use planning and creation of Community Conservation Areas (CCAs) for protection of natural forest, coupled with sustainable non-extractive forest use, e.g. honey and mushrooms. The creation of CCAs and the enforcement of by-laws to protect them promotes the protection of ecosystems and biodiversity within and around the CCAs.
The annual average GHG emission reductions of the project are estimated at 224,504 tCO2-e, and total GHG emission reductions over 20 years are estimated at 4,490,084tCO2-e. This estimate considers only the first 10 years of GHG emission reductions for the REDD+ component.
VCS Proponent:
Community Markets for Conservation (COMACO)
Sichuan Province, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Afforestation Project in the Tea Estates of Amalgamated Plantations Pvt Ltd., Assam and North Bengal, India
description: The current Afforestation Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR) project aims to address global climate change through trees plantations in the project area. Planting trees and expanding forest cover significantly contributes to carbon sequestration. APPL’s Tree Plantation initiative in their tea estates located in Assam and West Bengal, is a crucial component of their commitment to sustainability and environmental conservation. With a strong focus on tea estates, this project aims to enhance the region's biodiversity and combat climate change while also increasing the area under ‘Tree Outside Forests’ (TOFs).The area under project boundary consists of altogether 6,62,534 trees in the project area since 2021 in a phased manner, including the shade trees for tea cultivation as per the guidelines of Tea Board. The project is located in the 25 tea estates owned by APPL encompassing the Indian states of Assam and West Bengal. In Assam, eight districts of Charaideo, Dibrugarh, Golaghat, Jorhat, Nagaon, Sonitpur, Tinsukia and Udalguri are covered, while for the state of West Bengal, the project location entails only the district of Jalpaiguri. The project plan is to generate carbon credits for voluntary market under the VCS standard. The project aims at sequestering 5,97,515 tCO2e over 20 years from 2021 to 2040, in line with the Indian government’s goal of increasing the forest and tree cover by 2030. The project will significantly improve local biodiversity, air quality, soil conservation, and erosion control, while also contributing to carbon sequestration and the company's carbon footprint reduction. This plantation project embodies APPL's unwavering commitment to environmental sustainability and a greener future for the region.

title: Águas da Mata Atlântica
description:
Águas da Mata Atlântica forest restoration project is revitalizing degraded land in the Atlantic Forest and aiming to create ecological corridors by restoring native forests to connect two of the largest intact forest blocks in the state of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Through forest restoration, the project expects to generate 2,129,589 tCO2e in net carbon removals over 40 years while improving water infiltration and quality within the Guandu River hydrographic region, a basin that generates water and electricity for approximately 9 million citizens in Rio de Janeiro and surrounding municipalities. Together, Pachama and Instituto Terra de Preservação Ambiental (ITPA) plan to work with multiple landowners in the region to establish approximately 8 million trees—representing more than 30 different species—to restore 5,000 ha of native forest.  

The project started in October of 2023 by planting 80 ha in Paty dos Alferes in the Serra do Mar region.  Another 400 ha is scheduled for planting in 2024.  The project will use the dynamic performance benchmark approach under VM0047 to ensure additionality over time and will employ satellite-based project success monitoring to continually assess forest cover change, as well as natural and anthropogenic risks that might threaten the project area.
VCS Proponent:
Pachama, Inc.
CA, United States
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Entooma Sidai: A Maasai Mara Rangeland Restoration and Conservation Project
description:
Climate Investment Partners LLC, in partnership with Entooma Sidai Limited, aims to restore over 650,000 hectares of degraded grasslands in Narok County, Kenya via the Entooma Sidai: A Maasai Mara Rangeland Restoration and Conservation Project. The Project is estimated to generate approximately 689,731 net Verified Carbon Units (VCUs) annually over a 40-year project period for a total of over 27 million VCUs. The Project is being developed using the Verified Carbon Standard’s (VCS) VM0032 Methodology for the Adoption of Sustainable Grasslands through Adjustment of Fire and Grazing, v1.0.

Continued overgrazing in the project area has degraded grasslands and rangelands, reduced grass biodiversity, inhibited grassland regeneration, reduced grass seed banks, increased the spread of invasive species, and decreased the availability of viable forage for both livestock and wildlife. The promotion of planned rotational grazing of livestock will restore degraded grasslands and increase grassland carbon stocks by allowing grasses and plants to recover and regenerate between grazes, which in turn will aid with increasing soil carbon through increasing plant productivity and limiting soil organic matter losses. Overall, the expected impacts of widespread implementation of sustainable grazing management practices are: climate change mitigation, adaptation and increased resiliency; reduced soil erosion and run-off; reduced loss of livestock; improved water infiltration and soil health; increased household income and food security; and the expansion of wildlife habitats and increased biodiversity.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Butuo County Grassland Sustainable Management Project
description:
Butuo County Grassland Sustainable Management Project (hereafter as “the project”) is located in Butuo County,Liangshan Yi Autonomous Prefecture,Sichuan Province,China. The project’s aim is to restore 48,963.17ha of degraded grassland in Butuo County by adopting a variety of measures including grass seeding and reseeding, rotational grazing, rest grazing and grazing prohibition. The project will increase carbon sequestration, reverse grassland degradation, contribute to local development and preserve cultural traditions. The project proponent is Liangshan Modern Agricultural Silicon Valley Investment and Development Group Co.
The project focuses on 48,963.17ha of moderately or severely degraded grasslands and adopts a combination of the following measures:Grass seeding and reseeding、Rotational grazing and rest grazing、Grazing prohibition.
The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 57,030,382 tCO2e in 40 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 1,425,760 tCO2e.

title: Agroforestry in Brazilian Biomes
description: The project aims to restore degraded agricultural and pasture areas in the Amazon and Atlantic Forest biomes, employing agroforestry systems. Initially covering 2,133 hectares, with the potential to expand to 6954 hectares by 2025, it seeks to promote regenerative agriculture, reducing carbon emissions and environmental pressures. It prioritizes sustainable practices, social inclusion, and the generation of economic opportunities, while adopting policies for biodiversity preservation and prohibiting hunting in intervention areas. Located in states such as Pará, Rondônia, Mato Grosso, and Bahia, selected due to the high levels of degradation observed, the project uses strategies that include the cultivation of cocoa interspersed with native and exotic forest species, as well as short-cycle crops such as banana and cassava. This agroforestry approach not only promotes economic benefits, such as generating jobs for the local community, but also contributes to the preservation and increase of biodiversity in the region. Over 25 years, it is estimated that the project will be able to remove approximately 1,409,852 tons of CO2 equivalent (tCO2e), contributing significantly to climate change mitigation efforts. Furthermore, it will benefit around 300 families locally, providing socioeconomic and environmental improvements in their communities.
State/Province: Pará, Mato Grosso, Rondônia and Bahia

title: M/s. TATA COFFEE LIMITED (TCL) TREE PLANTATION CARBON PROJECT IN WESTERN GHATS
description:
Tata Coffee Limited's 25 estates in the Western Ghats are strategically situated across the Kodagu, Hassan, Chikamangalore and Coimbatore in Karnataka and Tamil Nadu, India. Kodagu, also known as Coorg, serves as the primary location for these estates due to its favorable climate and suitable terrain for coffee cultivation. The 25 estates are organized into four divisions, each managed efficiently to ensure sustainable and responsible coffee production. The vast combined land area of these estates spans approximately 12,000 hectares, reflecting Tata Coffee Limited's significant presence and commitment to the coffee industry in the Western Ghats region.
The area under the project boundary consists of 14,84,523 old plants which are considered under baseline calculation and 13,02,346  new plants have been planted after 2021 to 2025 in a phased manner in addition to the shade tree number required for coffee cultivation as per the guidelines of coffee board to reestablish the biodiversity of the flora and fauna in the area and to fight with climate change.
The project quantifies the GHG removals occurring from agroforestry plantations using VM0047 “Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation” Version 1.0. The project plans to generate carbon credits for the voluntary carbon market under the VCS standard. The project estimates the total emission reduction for the crediting period of 32 years i.e. from 2021-2052 to be 16,78,836 tCO2e. The length of the project was developed as per the VCS Standard-v4.5 guidelines.
VCS Proponent:
Ms. TATA COFFEE LIMITED
KARNATAKA, India

title: Shanxi Xiyang CMM Power Generation Project
description: The purpose of the project is to utilize the extracted CMM with low concentration methane concentration to produce electricity. No coal bed methane (CBM) or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. Eleven sets of CMM power generators will be installed with a total installed capacity of 24MW (12*2MW), destroying 42.14 million m3 of methane annually. The expected annual exported electricity will be 163,987 MWh, which will be supplied to the coal mine first through the electricity distribution network in Fenghui coal mine area, and then to North China Power Grid(NCPG) if there is any electricity surplus, replacing the electricity that would otherwise have been purchased from the NCPG and displace part of the electricity generated by NCPG dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants. The waste heat from the generators will be recovered by waste heat boilers to provide free hot water to the coal mines, which was provided by waste coal fired boilers before the implementation of the Project.

title: Heilongjiang Datong Improved Agricultural Land Management Project
description:
Heilongjiang Datong Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is located in Datong District, Daqing City, Heilongjiang Province, China. The purpose of the project is to adopt improved agricultural land management practices to prevent the severe soil degradation caused by pre-existing conventional tillage in local crop land.
The project plans to implement improved agricultural land management practices in 81,984 ha corn field in the first crediting period to increase soil organic carbon (SOC).The improved agricultural land management practices of the project focus on no-tillage on fields evenly mulched with crushed straw for two or three years, followed by plowing or subsoiling once and continued no-tillage for another two or three years. No-tillage can effectively reduce the loosening of the surface soil layer and soil disturbance, reduce the loss of water and nutrients in the soil, ensure the retention of organic matter in the soil, reduce the degree of compaction of the tillage equipment on the tillage soil layer, and preserve appropriate space for the growth of crops, which is convenient for ventilation and keeps the soil with good water storage capacity. The application of no-tillage sowing has solved the problem of sand blowing in bare farmland to a certain extent and played a role in windbreak and sand fixation. No-tillage can maximize the protective effect of straw mulching on soil.
VCS Proponent:
Daqing Datong District Urban Construction Investment and Development Co., Ltd. Agricultural Development Branch
Heilongjiang Province, China
+86 21 6246 2036
3542346576@qq.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Guaranatuba REDD+ AUDD Grouped Project
description:
The GUARANATUBA REDD+ AUDD Grouped Project (GPD) is an innovative initiative located in the municipalities of Urucara, Maues, and Parintins in the state of Amazonia, Brazil. The project encompasses a total area of 3,910 hectares, including 2,928 hectares of lush Amazon rainforest. The primary objectives of the project are to combat unplanned deforestation, conserve the Amazon rainforests, reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, promote sustainable forest management, enhance local livelihoods, and protect biodiversity. To achieve these goals, the project employs a multi-faceted approach that includes legal protection for forests, advanced monitoring using satellite imagery, biodiversity and biomass inventorying with LiDAR technology, wildfire monitoring and prevention, and community engagement initiatives. Based on a 6-year jurisdictional baseline, the project is estimated to achieve an average annual reduction of 5,856 tCO2e.

The GUARANATUBA project addresses the challenges of agricultural expansion, illegal logging, and the lack of conservation incentives in the region. In partnership with Organica Consultoria LTDA, the project introduces a unique financial model that offers economic incentives to landowners for forest conservation, provides access to the carbon voluntary market, and supports sustainable forest management and legal enforcement of conservation efforts. By reducing GHG emissions, preventing deforestation, protecting biodiversity, and enhancing the livelihoods of local communities, the GUARANATUBA project promotes a harmonious coexistence between economic development and environmental stewardship. This holistic approach makes the GUARANATUBA REDD+ AUDD Grouped Project a groundbreaking model for tackling climate change and environmental degradation in the Amazon rainforest through technological advancements, economic incentives, and community engagement.
VCS Proponent:
Organica Consultoria LTDA
Ceará, Brazil

title: SPEKBOOM RESTORATION PROJECT BEKA EMVA IGWANISHE - ISIXHOSA
description:
In the Eastern and Western Cape Provinces of South Africa, livestock overgrazing has played a significant role in desertification within the Subtropical Thicket Biome (STB), also known as the Albany Thicket Biome. Approximately 90% of the biome has experienced moderate to severe degradation as a result. This degradation has had detrimental impacts on critical ecosystem functions, including reduced availability of forage, increased soil erosion and runoff, decreased soil fertility and productivity, compromised water retention capacity, and loss of habitats. Consequently, farmers and agricultural workers have been experiencing declines in their livelihoods as the land can support progressively fewer animals.
The main objective of the project is to restore the functionality of 100,000 ha of degraded areas within the STB by reintroducing spekboom (Portulacaria afra), a pivotal species recognized for its effectiveness in thicket restoration. across the municipalities of the Eastern and Western Cape Provinces of South Africa, covering regions where the STB naturally occurs. The restoration efforts are expected to have far-reaching benefits, including carbon sequestration, biodiversity recovery, and improved livelihoods for participating landowners and communities.
VCS Proponent:
Imperative South Africa Projects Pte Ltd
South Africa
projects@imperativeinc.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Farm Forestry Initiatives for Promotion of Community Livelihoods and Climate Resilience in Odisha, India
description:
The purpose of this project activity is to restore the degraded farm lands through the afforestration, reforestration and revegetation activity with a parallel objective to encourage tree plantations and tree based farming system to incrase the tree cover outside the forest area (TOF).
The project activity covers 6304 ha of degraded farmlands and agriculture fallow lands through increasing the vegetative cover by planting multipurpose tree species in twelve forest divisions spanning across ten districts of Odisha State, India. By restoring the degraded farm lands with the native tree species, the project activity will remove the atmospheric carbon dioxide through biological carbon sequestration in the form of tree biomass and soil carbon.

description: The project aims to restore degraded mangrove sites in South Sulawesi, Indonesia, focusing on creating a healthy ecosystem and enhancing livelihoods. Project activities involve mangrove reforestation, developing a silvofishery model in converted areas and capacity building with local communities. Targeting 66,700 hectares of degraded and converted mangrove ecosystems, the project aligns with VCS standards to sequester an estimated 41,819,835 metric tons of CO2, contributing significantly to global climate change mitigation. Biomonitoring using eDNA assesses biodiversity changes, focusing on endangered species. Community engagement is integral,  with local stakeholders including communities as the key decision makers.

title: Nigeria Community-based Forestry Project
description:
The Nigeria Community-Based Forestry Project (henceforth, the project will be referred to as NCBF) has adopted the VCS frameworks for Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD)  and Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation (ARR) . The project aims to promote Community-Based Forestry practices on 180,000 hectares, targeting forest-dependent communities in Nigeria. Supported by CO2balance UK Ltd and City Ministries, the project seeks to promote and implement CBF  principles within forest-dependent communities and generate GHG removals through REDD. 

The project area is characterised by high levels of deforestation and poor management of natural resources, which threatens people's livelihoods. Slash-and-burn agricultural activities contribute significantly to the loss of forest cover, resulting in high forest degradation . The revised 2020 Nigerian National Forest Policy outlines strategies to mitigate environmental challenges, such as climate change resulting from population growth and its impact on forests . Therefore, the NCBF seeks to add effective measures to combat deforestation in Nigeria through REDD+ initiatives. 

The project aims to reduce a total of 2,544,975 GHG emissions over 20 years. On average, this results in an annual reduction of 127,249 GHG emissions. Therefore, the NCBF project is dedicated to contributing to both Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Specifically, the project aligns with SDG 13 (climate action) and SDG 15 (life on land) , underscoring its commitment to addressing climate change and deforestation in Nigeria.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: East Africa Soil and Biodiversity improvement project
description:
East Africa Soil and Biodiversity improvement project in Eastern Africa is a voluntary carbon project that implements Agricultural Land Management (ALM) practices developed and owned by eAgronom. This initiative is currently underway in Rwanda, Kenya, and Tanzania, with the potential for further expansion into neighbouring countries. It follows Verra's VM0042 methodology for Improved Agricultural Land Management, version 2.0, referred to as VM0042, the project is dedicated to enhancing soil organic carbon levels within annual cropping systems.
The project aims to spread adoption of regenerative agricultural practices, ultimately leading to increased carbon sequestration. By doing so, it seeks to improve soil health and deliver significant benefits to farmers. Simultaneously, the project is driven to sequester greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.
The Regenerative Agriculture Project in Eastern Africa focuses on elevating soil health, benefiting farmers, and mitigating greenhouse gas emissions and build agricultural resilience. By initiating positive changes in East Africa and contemplating expansion, the project holds the potential to become a catalyst for transformative practices in the broader region.

title: BRAZILIAN REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURE FOR CERRADO’S CARBON CREDIT (BRA-3C)
description:
In the context of carbon removal, the BRA-3C Project seeks to implement sustainable soil management practices, highlighting crop rotation to guarantee the diversification of commercial crop, cover cropping to maximize land use through the sowing of two crops in a single season, and the maintenance of plant residues and living plants in the soil, promoting carbon retention, and strengthening soil fertility. Regarding emissions, the project promotes the spread of biologicals as soil conditioners, which include fungal and microbial inoculants. Their use is expected to contribute to soil health improvement, besides establishing control over the nitrogen application's timing and dosage.
 
The BRA-3C Project aims to increase soil organic carbon (SOC) stocks and adopt input management mechanisms to reduce emissions from agricultural activities in the Cerrado biome. The project aims to implement sustainable intensification practices for agricultural land use, to increase land and food productivity, while also expanding the conservation of natural resources. In total, the BRA-3C Project is estimated to produce 10,361,853.33 tCO2e, with an annual average of approximately 259,046.33 tCO2e/year.
The grouped project location includes the geographical extension of the Cerrado Biome within the geographic boundaries of Brazil.

title: ARAGUAIA REDD+ BOCALON PROJECT
description:
NOVAAGRI, the proponent and developer of the present project, is a company founded in 2008 as a visionary and innovative player in the Agribusiness sector. We drive a strict control under the process of farmers' prospection and selection, adopting internal criteria for analysis and approval of the growing/production areas, such as compliance with the national forestry legislation and other socio-environmental regulations related to combating deforestation, work conditions and conservation of sensitive areas and indigenous lands. This control is carried out through geo-monitoring systems, by using satellite images, applied to 100% of the commercial contracts carried out at NovaAgri.

Although the development of Carbon Credits projects is not a main service of NovaAgri’s portfolio, neither intend to make it a core source of revenue to the company, these projects are totally strategic and aligned to the Group´s beliefs and philosophy, which counts on challenging targets of carbon reduction for the medium and long term – the carbon credit projects are vital to orientate the company into the carbon neutrality path, encouraging good actions among its value chain players.

The ARAGUAIA REDD+ BOCALON PROJECT is taken in Santa Terezinha, a municipality from the Mato Grosso State in Brazil. The property’s is composed by an area of 24,100 hectares in total, and its project area composes an area of 13,926 hectares of native forest. The project expects to avoid net emissions of 1,683,481.14 tCO2e, which means an average of 28,058 tCO2e per year and 10,012 hectares preserved during a horizon of 60 years, by using high level technology of satellites and geomonitoring system.  Regarding social responsability, every carbon project developed and managed by NovaAgri intends to ensure a share of the project’s financial returns to implement social actions within the local communities located in the surroundings of the project area.
