title: Yangquan Guzhuang 8MW CMM Power Generation Project
description:
Yangquan Guzhuang 8MW CMM Power Generation Project is located at the former site of Guzhuang Coal Mine Cement Plant in Yangquan, Shanxi Province. The Project utilizes coal mine methane (CMM) with a methane concentration of 16% to generate electricity, and the electricity generated is fed into the North China Power Grid for the self-consumption of the Guzhuang Coal Mine, while the heat output is recovered by a waste heat hot water boiler, replacing the original coal-fired boiler for heating in the mine area. The Project Owner is Yangquan Zhonglian Energy Technology Co.
The purpose of this project is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through the combustion of methane in the coal mine gas during the power generation process. No coal bed methane (CBM) or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. The total installed capacity of the project is designed as 8MW, with eight 1000kW gas-fired internal combustion generator sets, which utilize coal mine gas with a concentration of less than 30% to generate electricity, and utilize the waste heat hot water boiler to recover the flue gas waste heat at the tail end of the units. After running at full load, the project can consume 1,262.88*104Nm3 of pure gas per year, with an estimated annual power generation of 4800*104kWh, which will be used for the mine's self consumption through integration into the North China Power Grid, and 5.184*104GJ of residual heat per year, which will be supplied to the outside world for the heating of the buildings on the site. However, to be conservative, emission reductions will not be claimed for waste heat recovery.
During the renewable 7-year crediting period(28-Oct-2022 to 27-Oct-2029, both days included), the total GHG emission reduction of the project can reach 1,748,817 tCO2e, with an average annual emission reduction of 249,831tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Yangquan Zhonglian Energy Technology Co.
Shanxi Province, China

title: EARTH MAA LLC- BAMBOO, CASHEWNUT AND MANGO PLANTATIONS FOR FARMERS ECONOMIC UPGRADE
description:
The Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation (ARR) project is an ambitious initiative aimed at combating climate change, restoring biodiversity, and supporting sustainable development through largescale tree planting and ecosystem restoration efforts. The aim of the project is to address global climate change through promoting native forestry trees, specifically, bamboo, cashew nut and mango plantations in the project area. Bamboo, Cashew nut and Mango have a natural capacity to absorb CO2. The Bamboo has growth from 1.0 to1.2 meters per day and gain mature status within 2.5 to 3 years. All three plants; i.e. Bamboo, Cashew nut and Mango help in preventing soil erosion and restoring degraded areas caused by deforestation or natural disasters which serve various environmental benefits and have the potential impact to the fight against climate change.

The project activity has the following objectives: 

1. The activity encourages plantation of bamboo, cashew nut and mango trees as all these three contribute to carbon sequestration by absorbing carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere
during the process of photosynthesis. This not only helps mitigate the effects of climate change but also improves air quality. Mature Bamboo, Mango and Cashew trees are particularly effective
in this regard, storing significant amounts of carbon in their biomass over their lifespan, which can extend up to 50 years or more.

2. By engaging local communities, such as landowners and their families especially tribal women in plantation, this project not only helps reduce greenhouse gas emissions but also provides a
sustainable source of income and livelihood for farmer communities. 

3. The project provides a sustainable source of timber through bamboo, cashew nut and mango. Bamboo a type of grass has the special ability to keep absorbing carbon even after selective
harvesting. This=means that carbon sequestration continues, making it an effective and long lasting solution.
VCS Proponent:
EARTH MAA LLC
Uttar Pradesh, India
+91-8076878513
info@earthmaallc.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Heilongjiang Zhaoyuan Improved Agricultural Land Management Project
description:
Heilongjiang Zhaoyuan Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is located in Zhaoyuan County, Daqing City, Heilongjiang Province, China. The purpose of the project is to adopt improved agricultural land management practices to prevent the severe soil degradation caused by pre-existing conventional tillage in local crop land.
The improved agricultural land management practices of the project focus on no-tillage on fields evenly mulched with crushed straw for two or three years, followed by plowing or subsoiling once and continued no-tillage for another two or three years. No-tillage can effectively reduce the loosening of the surface soil layer and soil disturbance, reduce the loss of water and nutrients in the soil, ensure the retention of organic matter in the soil, reduce the degree of compaction of the tillage equipment on the tillage soil layer, and preserve appropriate space for the growth of crops, which is convenient for ventilation and keeps the soil with good water storage capacity. The application of no-tillage sowing has solved the problem of sand blowing in bare farmland to a certain extent and played a role in windbreak and sand fixation. No-tillage can maximize the protective effect of straw mulching on soil.  
The project plans to implement improved agricultural land management practices in 87,479 ha corn field in the first crediting period to increase soil organic carbon (SOC). The project proponent not only introduced more efficient and appropriate tillage method with Zhaoyuan Agriculture and Rural Affairs Bureau (ZARAB) to the farmers, but also provide technical training and support to the farmers.

title: Participatory Mangrove Restoration for Climate Action in Myanmar
description: The proposed project is located in Bokpyin Township, Kawthong District, Tanintharyi Region in Myanmar. Mangroves in the region are critical to the sustainability of maritime ecosystems and the food security of local inhabitants. Mangroves in the Tanintharyi Region are feeding and breeding ground for marine animals, which are a vital source of socioeconomic development of the coastal dwellers since time immemorial. The project will restore 7,000 ha and it is estimated to sequester approximately 6,803,769 tCO2e over a period of 25 years with an annual average reduction of 272,151 tCO2e.

title: ETHIOPIA AGROFORESTRY PROJECT ON SMALL-SCALE COFFEE PARCELS
description:
At present, this project is located within the area served by the Sidama Coffee Farmers’ Cooperative Union (SCFCU) in the Sidama region of Ethiopia and was started with the Bokasso Cooperative. Since then, the project area has expanded to include 11 different cooperatives as of February 2024. The project may continue to expand to other similar coffee-growing regions of Ethiopia as it grows. The project objectives include:

•	Implementing Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation (ARR) interventions, including reforestation of degraded land and agroforestry on smallholder producer coffee farms to mitigate the impacts of climate change and develop new, diverse income streams for producers; and
•	Improving yield and quality of coffee, stabilizing the productivity on enrolled farms and ensuring high taste and aroma quality.

This project will implement reforestation interventions on degraded land and agroforestry interventions on the coffee plantations of smallholder producers to generate climate, nature, and socioeconomic benefits. The majority of the greenhouse gas benefits associated with the project will come from the carbon dioxide removed by the trees planted and by the carbon sequestered within the soil as a result of improved agricultural practices by coffee farmers.

title: Açaí REDD+ Project
description:
The Açaí REDD+ project aims to promote forest conservation and reduce potential greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions from unplanned deforestation and forest degradation.The property where the project is located covers a continuous area of 16,229.09 ha of Amazon Forest, of which 15,715.82 ha are destined for Avoiding Unplanned Deforestation (AUD).
The Açaí REDD+ project is located in the municipality of Envira, in the state of Amazonas (39,90% of the project area), and in the municipality of Feijó, in the state of Acre (60,10% of the project area). 
The project will conserves 15,715.82 hectares of Amazon rainforest and its biodiversity through the surveillance of the project area by land and river performed by outsourced people and companies, monitoring of forest fires, annual monitoring of forest cover through forest inventories and satellite images, and periodic monitoring of endangered species.

title: Xinghua Improved Agriculture Land Management Project
description:
Xinghua City Improved Agriculture Land Management Project is developed by Meicun  Atmosphere Environmental Technology (Chongqing) Co, Ltd. It aims to- raise farmers' awareness of the benefits of sustainable agriculture and how to change agricultural practices to help in climate change mitigation and adaptation. The project will assist farmers to overcome barriers that prevent the adoption of improved agricultural land management practices and provide technical assistance where needed. The objectives of the project are to reduce emissions from agricultural practices and increase soil carbon storage. In order to achieve these objectives, a package of practices including improved residue management that change the pre-existing agricultural management activities will be carried-out.

The project activity is located in Xinghua City, which is a county-level city under the administration of Taizhou City in Jiangsu Province, China. The area of the project activity is 26673 ha, including farmland spreading over 17 towns. Prior to the start of the implementation of the project, there was no similar activities of carbon sequestration, GHG removals or net reduction. The baseline scenario is the continuation of pre-project agricultural land management practices including conventional tillage and straw not returned to fields, which are common agricultural practices in the project area. Over the 20 years of the first crediting period, the project will generate an estimated annual average removal and reduction of 96,236 tCO2e. and 1,924,720 tCO2e in total 20 years.

Besides climate change mitigation, the project will also result in a lot of benefits in various social and environmental aspects, such as Enhance soil quality, Reduce pollution and protect the local ecological environment, Develop sustainable local agriculture, Provide training and on-site demonstration activities on convention tillage.

title: Sakahk Papakititamo (Forest Breathes)
description:
Project Sakahk Papakititamo (Forest Breathes) is an Indigenous-owned forest carbon project that creates net climate benefits through improved forest management of lands located in northeastern Saskatchewan, Canada. Project Sakahk Papakititamo (Forest Breathes) is a grouped project which will be comprised of individual project instances brought forward by Peter Ballantyne Cree Nation (PBCN) communities. The collection of PBCN project instances will make up the grouped project as a whole. This project uses the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) VM0034 Canadian Forest Carbon Offset Methodology, V 2.0 and will apply the Climate, Community & Biodiversity (CCB) Standard. 

Under CCB this project will also emphasize the biodiversity and the community benefits of protecting native forests. This project will support and strengthen traditional, cultural, and heritage values for the PBCN members within and external to the project area. This project ensures that future generations will thrive thanks to the sustainable practices, and that Indigenous ways of knowing are being understood and valued. As a whole, this project strives to advance Reconciliation.

Under Improved Forest Management (IFM) – Logged to Protected Forest (LtPF), projects utilize practices that reduce net greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by permanently converting logged forests to protected forests. It includes forest health monitoring, and low levels of timber harvest may be required for forest health maintenance or improved forest productivity. This project’s activity will switch from a baseline of commercial clearcut harvesting to protected forest, with permissible harvesting of trees to advance conservation purposes (e.g., the removal of diseased trees) and improve forest growth and stocking density to accelerate the sequestration of additional carbon over time. As such, the PBCN project will result in significant GHG emission reductions and additional carbon sequestration.

title: ARR REWILDING HUB IN GRAN CHACO ARGENTINA
description:
The ARR Rewilding Hub spearheaded and fully owned by Forest Defense AG in northeastern Las Lajitas, Salta Province, Argentina, is set to transform 18,450 hectares into a vibrant conservation area. Using the latest methodology VM0047, this initiative is the largest and most comprehensive ecological restoration project in the region. Previously utilized for agriculture and livestock, the land will be reforested with native species to reestablish typical native forest ecosystems of the semi-arid Chaco region. This project is dedicated to long-term conservation, with plans to maintain its sanctuary status beyond the initial 40-year accreditation period.

This pioneering effort is uniquely positioned at the agricultural and cattle production frontier, set to be a game changer for the region. It promises significant ecological balance and serves as a sustainable model for similar transitions towards environmentally friendly practices across the region. The strategic location enables a substantial multiplier effect, inspiring broader shifts towards sustainability and biodiversity preservation.

Collaborations with The Nature Conservancy (TNC), the National Institute of Agricultural Technology (INTA), and universities ensure a multi-faceted approach, combining traditional practices with scientific research. As a quality-driven project, it aims to create a sustainable ecosystem that supports biodiversity and local communities, setting a new standard for conservation efforts in Argentina.

As the most extensive and quality-driven project in the region, the ARR Rewilding Hub sets a new standard for ecological restoration in Argentina, aiming to create a sustainable and resilient ecosystem that supports both biodiversity and the local community.

Forest Defense AG
Switzerland

title: Mangrove afforestation and reforestation project in Cambodia
description: The 'Mangrove Afforestation and Reforestation Project in Cambodia' (hereinafter referred to as 'the Project') aims to combat the climate crisis by expanding mangrove forest areas in Cambodia. The project begins with the establishment of 100 hectares of new mangrove forests in Kampot and Kep, Cambodia, with plans to ultimately expand to a total of 500 hectares. Additionally, the project aims to restore over 2,500 hectares of degraded mangrove forests through reforestation efforts. VM0033, a methodology certified by VERRA, is employed to quantify greenhouse gas (GHG) reductions resulting from afforestation and reforestation activities. The total GHG reduction for the initial 100 hectare afforestation phase, spanning 20 years, is estimated at 573,067 tCO2e. GHG reduction estimates for subsequent afforestation and reforestation activities will be updated as the project progresses.

title: SEIKOPAI REDD+
description:
The SEIKOPAI REDD+ project aims to reduce and prevent GHG emissions from deforestation activities in the territory of the Native Community located in the basin and right bank of the Napo River, at Santa Maria stream, through the development and implementation of a REDD+ strategy built collectively and in a participatory manner with the members of the community and also aligned with the objectives of the life plan, which is conceived as a communal planning instrument that contains the worldview, history and vision of the community. It also takes into account the territorial planning and environmental protection instruments of the region to articulate the REDD+ strategy. 

This project corresponds to the Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU) sector, in the category of Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD+). The project area is within the community territory and covers 134.228 ha of amazon humid forest. It is expected to avoid the emission of 8.780.025 tCO2 for 40 years, which corresponds to 219.500 tCO2/year. Aboveground Biomass (BA of trees and non-trees), Belowground Biomass (BS) and Soil Organic Carbon (COS) pools are taken into account in the project's carbon accounting, considering them to estimate the baseline scenario and monitor performance during project implementation.

During the last years, this amazon area has been under threat due to logging, agricultural expansion and fauna exploitation. Mining is also increasing in surrounding areas, thus representing a huge threat to the ecosystem’s conservation. The project aims to tackle forest pressures and contribute to mitigate climate change by reducing CO2 emissions derived from deforestation, restore degraded lands, promote sustainable management of forests and develop productive activities to improve community welfare. The project seeks to protect biodiversity and high conservation values, maintain ecological connectivity and secure natural habitats for vulnerable and threatened species along with other biodiversity of cultural and spiritual importance for the communities.  

The climate, community and biodiversity objectives are detailed next:

The climate objective is to mitigate climate change through measures that reduce and prevent deforestation and forest degradation activities. The expected results include decrease in illegal logging, recovery of degraded forests, reduction of forest conversion to other land uses and maintained forest carbon stocks over time.

The community objectives were defined with the members of the Vencedor community and aim to improve their living conditions in the territory and include: i) strengthening governance; ii) development of sustainable productive activities compatible with biodiversity conservation; iii) increase social investment; iv) improve monitoring and biodiversity protection initiatives.

Regarding biodiversity conservation, the project seeks to protect amazon tropical forest and its diversity, contribute to maintain the functional connectivity of this forest areas, improve knowledge and management capacities of productive systems that favour biodiversity, as compared to baseline scenario conditions.

In this way the REDD+ project generates a positive impact since it contributes to improve living conditions of the native communities and protects biodiversity to secure the provision of ecosystem services and ecological structure in the long term.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
VCS Project Validator: Colombian Institute for Technical Standards and Certification (ICONTEC)
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation
CCB Project Validator: Colombian Institute for Technical Standards and Certification (ICONTEC)

title: Tond Tenga
description:
Tree Aid (TA) is an international development non-governmental organisation (INGO) that focuses on working with people in the Sahel region of Africa to tackle poverty and the effects of climate change by growing trees, improving people's incomes, and restoring and protecting land. It is a registered charity in the UK. TA is partnering with Earthshot Labs PBC (Earthshot) and Capricorn Investment Group LLC (Capricorn) to restore degraded landscapes in Burkina Faso through enrichment planting and agroforestry activities.
TA has partnered with local communities to identify 37 sites of degraded woodland and shrublands located in 18 communes and 4 regions with the potential to become new forest sites through enrichment planting. These sites have been affected by deforestation and decades of unsustainable agricultural activity, leading to soil degradation that has prevented further agricultural activity. This has resulted in desertification and the loss of access to culturally relevant non-timber forest products (NTFPs) that are extremely significant in socio-economic terms. Thus, the project identified activities in enrichment planting and agroforestry to restore native forests and increase access to NFTPs. 
Through enrichment planting, the project will restore native tree species with high importance to the biodiversity of the area, high restoration potential and some NTFP uses. In total 12,000 ha will be targeted across these 37 forest sites. In total just over 142,500 trees will be targeted on farmland in and around the 37 forest sites.
The project is estimated to remove 3.7 million tCO2e during the project lifetime, with estimated annual GHG emission removals of 92,576.9 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Tree Aid
South West England, United Kingdom
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: KA'A PYAHU
description:
The KA’A PYAHU Project is located in Maranhão, Brazil, within the Indigenous Territory of the Guajajara ethnicity, one of the country's most populous. It aims to benefit approximately 13,000 indigenous individuals. Named after the Tupi-Guarani words meaning 'New Forest,' the Ka’a Pyahu project represents 'a new care for nature' for the community. The project area is managed by local communities in the territories of Cana Brava, Rodeador, Lagoa Comprida, and Urucu Juruá, organized around the CONSELHO SUPREMO association since 2019.

Through the establishment of the association and organizational efforts, the community has achieved significant milestones in protecting their territories. Legal actions against damages caused by projects from companies have resulted in decisions favoring the community, leading to reduced deforestation and compensation for previous degradation.

The community's history of organization and strengthened internal governance has empowered them to safeguard the forests in their territories. Additionally, they have gained familiarity with the REDD+ initiative and the carbon market through this process.
The KA’A PYAHU PROJECT aims to ensure better conditions for environmental conservation and sustainable use of forests, ultimately enhancing the quality of life for local communities, particularly in terms of clean water, sanitation, and education.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Yunnan Zhenxiong Zhujiawan CMM Power Generation Project
description:
The project is located in Banqiao Village, Chishuiyuan Town, Zhenxiong County, Shaotong City, Yunnan Province, P.R.China. The project owner is Zhenxiong Yonder New Energy Development Co., Ltd.
The purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted CMM with low concentration methane concentration to produce electricity. No coal bed methane (CBM) or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. It is expected that 13.0392 million Nm3 of methane annually will be destroyed to generate electricity. According to Feasibility Study Report (FSR) of the project, 14 sets of CMM power generators will be installed with a total installed capacity of 9.8 MW (14*700 kW).
After the full operation of the project, the expected annual exported electricity is 49,476 MWh, which is supplied to the coal mine through the electricity distribution network in Zhujiawan coal mine and to China Southern Power Grid (CSPG) if there is any electricity surplus, thus displace equivalent amount of electricity that would be supplied by CSPG dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants. 
 It is estimated that in the 10 years crediting period of the project (from 13-May-2023 to 12-May-2033), the expected average annual GHG emission reduction will be 243,241 tCO2e, with the total emission reduction of 2,432,410 tCO2e.

title: Grouped Solar Power Plant Project of Bestway Cement Ltd.
description:
Bestway Cement Limited (hereafter referred as Bestway Cement Ltd.) has installed Renewable Energy Power Plants based on Solar Photovoltaic (PV) Technology (hereafter referred as “project activity”) at various locations across Pakistan as a grouped project activity. Bestway Cement Ltd. is looking forward to earning carbon credits under VCS mechanism for these Solar PV based power plants.
The proposed grouped project activity supports development of renewable energy generation plants based on Solar PV technology in Pakistan with the objective of supplying electricity to power Bestway Cement Ltd.’s factories. The proposed grouped project is a voluntary action being undertaken by Bestway Cement Ltd. The renewable energy generation plants under the grouped project activity would generate Solar PV based electricity, which otherwise in absence of project activity would have been generated from fossil fuel fired grid connected power plants. The grouped project activity thus leads to reduction in Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions.
There are in total of six project activity instances in this group project, and all the project activity instances are owned by Bestway Cement Ltd., who is also acting as coordinating and managing entity for the grouped project activity. Since the project activity is grouped project activity, more project activity instances can be included in grouped project activity in future. Each instance of project activity under this grouped project consists of one renewable power generation plant using Solar PV technology. All the project instances i.e. renewable energy generation plants to be included in this grouped project will be from within Islamic Republic of Pakistan (hereafter referred as “Pakistan”) only. The estimated annual emission reductions over a 10 year period from initial six project activity instances are 422,719 tCO2e.

title: FX Group Biomass to Energy Project
description: The proposed project activity concerns a greenfield biomass to energy power plant at the FX Group Lothair facility, which is situated in the Mpumalanga province of South Africa. The Project will source biomass from local sawmills and biomass wastes for the generation of electricity in a power-only plant. The woody biomass will be fed into a biomass boiler to create super-heated high-pressure steam. The steam is used to spin a 4.5MW power output steam turbine and electrical generator. The renewable energy produced by the plant will displace the grid electricity, which would have been used to power the industrial facility in the absence of the biomass power plant. Electricity on the South African National grid is largely generated by the state-owned entity Eskom and is highly carbon-intensive due to the reliance on fossil-fuels such as coal and diesel.

title: TERAKA MADAGASCAR: SMALLHOLDER TREE PLANTING PROGRAM
description:
The TERAKA program is a comprehensive reforestation and sustainable development initiative in Madagascar, led by subsistence farmers. Inspired by the successful TIST model in East Africa, farmers plant and own trees on their land, receiving training from TERAKA and 70% of carbon benefits. Small Groups of farmers are empowered to combat deforestation, poverty, and drought. By integrating sustainable practices with carbon sequestration, the program supports farmers in reforestation and biodiversity preservation, creating a 'virtual' cash crop from carbon credits. 
Operating in central and eastern Madagascar, TERAKA aims to plant trees across 6,000 hectares within the initial eight years. This initial phase is expected to remove approximately 1,971,413 tonnes of greenhouse gases over 40 years, while restoring degraded land, improving the livelihoods and well-being of local communities, fostering sustainable employment, and promoting biodiversity.

title: Improved cropland management project in Aktaw and Shufu
description: The Improved cropland management project in Aktaw and Shufu is aimed to raise farmer's awareness on the benefits of sustainable agriculture and how to change the agricultural practices to help in climate change mitigation and adaptation. The purpose of the project is to adopt improved agricultural land management practices to prevent the severe soil degradation caused by pre-existing conventional tillage in local crop land. The project will assist farmers to overcome barriers that prevent adoption of improved agricultural land management practices and provide technical assistance where needed. The objectives of the project is to reduce emissions from agricultural practices and increase soil carbon storage, in order to achieve these, a package of practices that change the pre-existing agricultural management activities will be carried out, the specific activities are the following: 1) improved fertilizer(organic or inorganic) application; 2) Improved residue management; 3) Improve crop planting and harvesting.

title: Agroforestry Corridors for Multi Cropping Systems in Brazil
description:
The project aims to rehabilitate the local forest ecosystem and introduce agroforestry methods to communities within watersheds and along riverbanks across a 1.7 million hectare expanse spanning São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, and Maranhão. It plans to rejuvenate over 6,000 hectares through reforestation and will incorporate agroforestry near local farms, targeting pasturelands, deteriorated areas, and mono-crop fields. The project's core goal is to restore deforested and degraded lands, enhancing farmers' ability to sustainably produce food and generate income. 

Through agroforestry, the project offers alternative livelihoods, encouraging farmers to shift from traditional to sustainable land management practices. Agroforestry systems of coffee and cocoa will be implemented in partnership with local farmers in pastureland, degraded land, and monocultures, with capacity-building initiatives and training programs planned as part of the project.

title: Farm Resilience and Regeneration in France
description:
The grouped project “Farm Resilience and Regeneration in France” is developed by ReGeneration S.a.s. and aims to empower and derisk farmers in their transition to regenerative agriculture, enabled by individualized regenerative agronomic support and financial support.
The geographic zone is mainland France except for mountainous areas. The project accompanies farm types of arable farming, livestock farming, as well as mixed crop-livestock farming.
The project follows the VM0042 v2.0 Methodology for improved Agriculture and Land Management (ALM), and applies Approach 1: Measure and Model.
This project aims to create resilient farms by regenerating and reviving the ecosystem and the soil.
The resulting adoption of regenerative practices will generate climate benefits by sequestering carbon into the soil. It is conservatively anticipated that this would equate to annual emission removals (ERs) averaging 476,000 tCO2e/year. The project aims to accompany 6,000 farms in total over 20 years, putting 600,000 ha on a regenerative transition.
The program’s successful implementation is expected to bring about outcomes contributing to a whole set of SDGs, tracked by pre-defined indicators. Program participation improves access to knowledge and opportunities for small-scale and family farmers, implementation of resilient agricultural practices, and improved seed diversity (SDG 2), it enhances gender inclusion (SDG 5), increases water-use efficiency, and reduces water pollution from agricultural inputs (SDG 6), improves resource efficiency (SDG 8), reduces the release of chemicals to water, air, and soil (SDG 12), contributes to GHG emission reductions and fosters climate resilience and adaptive capacity (SDG 13), restores degraded land and soil and improves farm biodiversity (SDG 15), and fosters communication and partnerships between the industry, the population and the often isolated and misunderstood farming population (SDG 17).

ReGeneration
France

title: GKF AGROFORESTRY PROJECT IN TELANGANA
description:
This is an agroforestry project on minor agriculture crop land and barren land aims to promote sustainable agroforestry practices across Telangana state of India. By planting diverse range of trees the project seeks to empower smallholders and tribal communities, increase tree cover, enhance income, conserve biodiversity, improve soil health, and generate emission reductions. The targeted farmers are small landholders and the land earmarked for plantation activities is privately owned.

Encompassing a total plantation of 6,000,000 trees in 10,000 ha of land, the farmers have undertaken tree plantations, primarily featuring Mangifera indica (mango), Santalum album (sandalwood), Psidium guajava (guava), Tectona grandis (teak), Azadirachta indica (neem), Swietenia macrophylla (mahogany), Casuarina equisetifolia (horsetail she-oak), Dalbergia sissoo (Indian rosewood), Aquilaria malaccensis (agarwood), Phyllanthus emblica (amla), Punica granatum (pomegranate), and Manilkara zapota (sapota) during the years 2021, 2022, and 2023. The districts included in the project area are :  Vikarabad, Ranga Reddy, Mahabub Nager, Narayanapeta, Sanga Reddy, Jogulambha Gadwal, Wanaparthy and Medchiel.

title: Enhancing Agricultural Sustainability through Carbon Credits: Mzuri Improved Agricultural Management
description:
The proposed project ‘MZURI methodology for Improved Agricultural Land Management’ aims to reduce and sequester GHG emissions by implementing more sustainable agricultural practices on fields in northern Poland. The planned schedule of activities fits within Verra’s VM0042 standard, which comprises a range of regenerative agricultural land management practice changes targeted at reducing net emissions of CO2, CH4, and N2O by grower operations and increasing soil organic carbon (SOC) storage. This is being achieved in this project by supporting farmers to implement climate-smart agricultural land management practices through the use of innovative land machines and integrated improved agricultural practices, supported by digital data collection tools and modelling. These practices include reductions in fertilizer use, strip tillage, adapted crop rotations, and cover cropping. Overall, these practice changes seem well appropriate to reduce emissions from agricultural production, to increase farm resilience to extreme weather events and the effects of climate change, and to promote increased soil (micro-) biological diversity. Expected co-benefits of the project (other than carbon reduction and sequestration) are expressed along the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Considering the context and location of the project, its scope of activities will contribute to the achievement of:
•	SDG 2 (Zero Hunger), 
•	SDG 3 (Good Health and Wellbeing), 
•	SDG 6 (Clean Water and Sanitation), 
•	SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure), 
•	SDG 13 (Climate Action), 
•	SDG 15 (Life on Land).
The project’s scope of activities significantly lowers the GHG emissions of agricultural activities vs. baseline scenario, and enhances or restores the carbon storage capacity of the area, thereby sequestering CO2 from the atmosphere. The project meets the criteria for climate additionality as well as community and biodiversity additionality, and shows a regulatory surplus.
VCS Proponent:
Mzuri World Carbon sp. zo.o.
Śmielin, Poland
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Montana Sustainable Grazing Project
description: This grouped project implements sustainable grazing practices on ranching lands in the state of Montana, USA. The rangeland landscape includes grasslands, steppe, prairies and forests. Wildlife characteristic of the area includes grizzly bears, pronghorn antelope, bison, white-tailed deer, elk and bighorn sheep. The land management practice changes will restore grasslands, increase vegetation cover, foster native plant diversity, sequester carbon, improve water infiltration, and reduce runoff. These impacts will increase the climate resilience of the ranches and support rancher livelihoods.

title: Guizhou Bijie Yuxing CMM Power Generation Project
description:
Guizhou Bijie Yuxing CMM Power Generation Project will utilize the low concentration coal mine methane (CMM) from Yuxing coal mine which is a working coal mine for power generation to supply electricity to the coal mine where the project is located and to China Southern Power Grid (CSPG) if there is any electricity surplus. The waste heat generated by the generator replace the heat originally generated by waste coal. The project is located in Dongfeng Village, Pudi Town, Hundred—mile Azalea Management Area, Bijie City, Guizhou Province, P.R.China. The project owner is Bijie Yicheng New Energy Technology Co., Ltd.
The purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted CMM with low concentration methane concentration to produce electricity. It is expected that 60.46 million Nm3 of methane annually will be destroyed to generate electricity. According to Feasibility Study Report (FSR) of the project, 22 sets of CMM power generators will be installed with a total installed capacity of 26 MW (14*1,000 Kw + 8*1,500 Kw). After the full operation of the project, the expected annual exported electricity is 177,840 MWh, which is supplied to the coal mine through the electricity distribution network in Yuxing coal mine and to China Southern Power Grid (CSPG) if there is any electricity surplus, thus displace equivalent amount of electricity that would be supplied by CSPG dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants.
The capacity of phase 1 of the project is 14 MW and the capacity of phase 2 is 12 MW. Phase 1 started construction on 01-February-2023 and started operation on 08-May-2023. Eight sets of generators with capacity of 1.5 MW for each (12 MW in total) of phase 2 started construction on 15-October-2023 and operated in 17-March-2024.  It is estimated that in the 10 years crediting period of the project (from 08-May-2023 to 07-May-2033), the expected average annual GHG emission reduction will be 1,103,098 tCO2e, with the total emission reduction of 11,030,980 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Bijie Yicheng New Energy Technology Co., Ltd
China
+86-18303415669
wangchao@china-yonder.com

title: THE BIWAL CARBON PROJECT
description:
Bundelkhand, straddling between Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh in India, faces severe challenges  such as drought, land degradation, water scarcity, erratic rainfall, soil erosion, and unsustainable  practices, making it one of the most formidable regions in the country. The project area comprises a total 
of 8 districts; Chhatarpur, Hamirpur and Niwari districts in Madhya Pradesh and Chitrakoot, Jhansi, Lalitpur, Mahoba, and Tikamgarh in the state of Uttar Pradesh. The challenges in these districts and the Bundelkhand region are compounded by water stress, primarily caused by insufficient and erratic rainfall, 
high runoff rates, and poor soil water retention capacity, leading to declining soil fertility and productivity.

To tackle these challenges, the project proponent is dedicated to promoting enhanced Agriculture Land  Management (ALM) and improved agroforestry practices. These practices encompass a range of  interventions, including improved fertilizer management, cover cropping, crop rotation, enhanced water management, effective crop residue management, and incorporation of agroforestry plantations, among others.

title: KUZA MITI AGROFORESTRY CARBON PROJECT IN KENYA
description:
Kuza Miti is an agroforestry project that aims to promote planting and growing trees in Kenya. ‘Kuza Miti’ is Swahili for 'growing trees'. This project aims to bring together into a single framework the Kenyan horticulture and agriculture communities, farmers and forestry organizations, in order to drive sustainable development. 
This initiative will improve and inspire sustainability in (and related to) agriculture and forestry, the planet, people, and society; in particular, to promote carbon sequestration and storage through agroforestry in an economically sustainable way.
Kuza Miti is a project also designed to support companies achieve carbon removal through nature-based solutions such as growing trees. This project is designed to sequester carbon in five different pools, by implementing afforestation and reforestation activities with native species and fruit trees, thereby contributing to the mitigation of climate change. This initiative holds the dual purpose of promoting local development and education in climate change mitigation actions. The project will start with two project instances but the scale of the project is national, with an ambitious target to plant more than tens of thousands of hectares to engage local communities to ensure sustainable development and financial inclusion. The selection of tree species includes native varieties, but some species being specifically chosen for fruit and nut production but never in monoculture.
The forest management will be of two types: 1) forest without timber harvesting but fruit harvesting will be considered as part of the management plan and 2) forest with harvesting practices to generate a new source of income from biofuel or timber.

title: SHANDONG DEZHOU IMPROVED AGRICULTURAL LAND MANAGEMENT PROJECT
description: 山东德州ALM项目（以下简称项目）位于中国山东省德州市平远县。该项目的目标是通过使用东峰鱼产品来增强植物的光合作用，从而增加中层导度，从而增加根系分泌物。所选择的措施将有助于提高作物产量和土壤有机质含量。项目由福建盾丰碳汇农业科技有限公司（以下简称项目发起人）实施。该项目位于山东省平远县，占地面积22333公顷。该项目的作物轮作系统是冬小麦-夏玉米。平远县位于北纬36°57′40′′~37°16′，东经116°10′35′′~116°42′之间，总面积1047平方公里。拟议的项目旨在通过利用东丰屿改变传统耕作模式，防止土壤退化。项目采取的主要保护性耕作活动包括：在项目范围内22,333公顷农田中增加Donfongwe的施用量，减少化肥的施用和替代有机肥。该项目预计从 2024 年 5 月 26 日至 2033 年 12 月 31 日将减少 5,561,000 吨二氧化碳当量温室气体排放，年均二氧化碳当量为 556,100 吨。该项目的批准日期和第一个监测期的具体日期尚未确定，将在最新的效绩数据中增加。项目审定日期和第一个监测期的具体日期尚未确定，将在最新的效绩数据中予以补充。项目审定日期和第一个监测期的具体日期尚未确定，将在最新的效绩数据中予以补充。

title: Eastern Cape Restoration Project, South Africa - Makhanda
description: The Eastern Cape Restoration Project is a revegetation project, aimed at the landscape restoration of the native Albany thicket, within a biodiversity hotspot that has undergone extreme degradation and ecosystem loss. A multi-year drought, combined with a multiple decades of over grazing have led to a scenario whereby vast areas of land can no longer support either economic or ecological functions. The project restores ex-grazing lands with a native species, Portulacaria afra, which shows unique ecological features adapted to the semi-arid project area. Planted at high density and subsequently protected from grazing, the restoration activity facilitates a microclimate and dense canopy cover that subsequently allows for the return of the high floral biodiversity endemic to the project area. The project is a grouped project covering the sub-municipality of Makana and is implemented hand in hand with the Eastern Cape Restoration Project, South Africa - Somerset East, and the Eastern Cape Bamboo Forestry Project, for the creation of a holistic restoration strategy.

title: Selva Paranaense Vida Nativa - GS1
description:
Located in the extreme east of the province of Misiones, in San Pedro, the field of native forest where the project is located has 22,878.5 hectares and immersed in the Green Corridor. In this area, controlled logging has been carried out since the 1960s and will decrease as the NIDEPORT project progresses, with harvesting expected to be completed by the end of 2021. The project activity is improved forest management with areas that will be enriched and regenerated by planting more than 250,000 native species individuals annually and others managed to increase forest productivity (bambuacea´s control, and others). 
Although there is not any community, individual or group of people living in the project area, GS1 has been subjected to situations of intrusions and illegal occupations, with burning for planting or deforestation for rudimentary construction, there are numerous cases where the land has been colonized or exploited for agriculture or livestock, where the land is left with high levels of degradation and contamination. 
The project zone, encompassed in an area with population under poverty line, expects to work together with the community identifying risks, HCV areas and needs, in order to implement mitigation actions together. In this line, first meetings with communities have already helped to identify both biodiversity and community´s HCVs, and possible projects regarding housing improvement, health care, among other needs to be identified during the project lifetime.
The climate benefits of the project are defined as the reductions or removals of GHG emissions resulting from forest regeneration, these are expected to reach 3,106,582 tCO2e during the crediting period, averaging 103,553 tCO2e per year.

description:

The IACO REDD+ Project is an AFOLU project, and therefore is classified within scope 14. More specifically, the project falls under the Avoided Unplanned Deforestation and Avoided Planned
Deforestation (categories). If this REDD+ project is implemented, 60,805 hectares of Amazon rainforest will be conserved over the first 30 years, avoiding the emission of 26,040,427 tons of CO 2 into the atmosphere. title: Eastern Cape Bamboo Forestry Project, South Africa
description: South Africa's Eastern Cape has suffered over a century of land degradation, through a combination of clearance of the original ecosystem for livestock production, over intense grazing, and extended periods of drought. Such land degradation has gone hand in hand with increased levels of unemployment and poverty, with poverty in the province representing the highest in the country. Over the past ten years EcoPlanet has pioneered the use of a naturalized species of sympodial bamboo, Bambusa balcooa, as a tool for restoration of these degraded lands setting the framework for expansion. The proposed project activity uses a landscape approach to afforest extremely degraded farms that can no longer support agricultural activity, in a mosaic fashion. The project provides carbon removal benefits, enhanced ecosystem services, and long term job creation within a sub-municipality that current has >80% unemployment. The project is designed and managed hand in hand with the Eastern Cape Restoration Project, providing a holistic approach to restoration.

title: Cultivating Carbon Regenerative Agriculture Project
description:
The aim of the project is to facilitate the roll-out of conservation agriculture in regions of South Africa where it is not prevalent. The intention is to at a minimum, assist farmers to replace conventional cultivation practices with the three essential components of CA – no till, cultivating a variety of species and the maintenance of organic cover through the year. 

To facilitate the initial adoption as well as long-term maintenance of these essential components and potential additional activities, a broad set of activities are required that are centred around three themes or goals:
1. To address the lack of regionally specific awareness, knowledge, evidence and models. 
2. To build regional technical support programmes and peer networks based on trust and evidence, and
3. To create an attractive financial incentive package to sustain implementation over the long-term. 

In terms of a broad strategy, a bottom-up participatory approach will be followed working with existing programmes, farmer study groups, farming organisations and institutions to increase awareness and knowledge of the opportunity in an effective and efficient manner. In a similar manner, regional expertise and research will be drawn upon to develop the supporting science, monitoring methods and financial models. Such an approach not only improves the viability of the underlying activities, but creates the trust required to sustain implementation over the full project period.  

This approach is based on the proven concept of farmer innovation platforms where the engagements and interaction are farmer centred.  Farmers are seen as the principal restoration agents and practitioners.  

A grouped project approach will be taken where the intention is to add project instances over time that meet all eligibility criteria. The initial set of identified farms are expected to lead to GHG emission reduction and removals of approximately 106,000 tCO2e per year or 3,180.000 tCO2e over a 30 year project.

title: Agoro Carbon USA Cropland Program
description:
Agoro Carbon USA Cropland Program is a grouped VCS project implemented by Agoro Carbon Alliance. The program will implement a package of regenerative agricultural land management activities such as but not limited to reduced and zero tillage, cover cropping, improved nitrogen management as a means to reduce GHG and decarbonize agriculture. The implementation of these practices will lead to increases in carbon sequestration rates in the soil, reduced soil disturbance and soil erosion, improved crop residue and water management, as well as potentially reducing the total usage of fossil fuels. 
The main objective of the program is to provide the financial, agronomic and educational support needed for growers to adopt new farming practices that not only produce agricultural products in a sustainable and profitable way, but also have a positive impact on climate change.

title: Shanghe Geothermal Space Heating Project
description:
Shanghe Geothermal Space Heating Project (hereafter referred to as “the Project”) includes two sub-projects, which are Agricultural Science and Technology Park “Geothermal Plus” Heating Project (hereafter referred to as “the Project A”) and Shengkai Shijicheng Community Geothermal Heating Project (hereafter referred to as “the Project B”).
The Project is planned and designed to introduce the geothermal energy-based space heating system to realize heat supply to a series of new residential and commercial buildings in Shanghe County, Jinan City, Shandong Province over the heating season, which would have received heat supply from fossil fuel-based heat supply systems as a business-as-usual scenario.

title: Soil+ Project to Incentivize Emissions Reductions and Removals on Agricultural Land in Europe
description:
The aim of the climate protection project is to increase soil organic matter content in arable soils and simultaneously reduce agricultural greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions via a broad scale-up of regenerative agriculture. Therefore the project intends to motivate as many farmers as possible to convert from conventional farming, the most common type in Germany, to regenerative agriculture practices. This is done through financial support and in-depth knowledge transfer using digital platforms (company-owned web application & mobile application). 
Today, conventional agriculture is the predominant agricultural practice in Germany, with dramatic consequences for the overall soil fertility and the soil carbon stocks. Therefore, one focus of the project is to reduce CO2 by increasing the SOC stock. But at the same time the project considers the reduction of CO2, CH4 and N2O emissions from agricultural management activities, such as fossil fuel consumption, fertiliser use or livestock production. This enables a holistic view on the development of GHG-emissions related to regenerative management methods. Other positive side-effects of large scale project application can be taken into account, such as an overall improvement of the soil fertility and health  including i) an increase in water storage capacity, thus providing a higher drought resilience, ii) an increase in anion retention capacity of the soils, thus reducing nitrate leaching rates to aquifers and iii) an improvement of the soil structural stability and infiltration rates, thus minimising the risk of soil erosion events. The project aims to be validated according to the Methodology for Improved Agricultural Land Management (VM0042).
VCS Proponent:
Klim GmbH
Berlin, Germany

title: Xinxiang MSW Incineration Project
description:
Xinxiang MSW Incineration Project (hereafter referred to as the project) is located in Xinxiang City, Henan Province,  P.R. China. The Project is invested, constructed and operated by Xinxiang Capital Environment Energy Co., Ltd.
With two 750t/d MSW combustion production lines, the project will treat 1,500 tons of MSW per day. The combustion system is composed of two 750t/d mechanical grate incinerators, matched with one set of 35MW steam turbine generator. The project will process 547,500 tons of MSW every year, and consume 284 tons of 0# light diesel as auxiliary fuel. The MSW combustion line will work 8,000 hours every year, generating 218,830 MWh electricity, of which 179,411 MWh will be exported to the Central China Power Grid (CCPG). The implementation of the project will meet the requirement of local MSW harmless treatment, and significantly improve local environment.
By combusting MSW that would otherwise be disposed of at landfill, the project activity avoids the emission of methane that would be generated under landfill condition. In the meanwhile, by utilizing the waste heat from the combustion of MSW, the boilers can produce steam to generate power to replace the electricity that would otherwise be generated by fossil- fuel fired power plants which are connected to the CCPG. Before the implementation of the project, the local MSW was usually disposed of at nearby landfill, where no landfill gas capturing system erected and the landfill gases are released to atmosphere directly. The equivalent power generated by the project was supplied by the the CCPG. The baseline scenario identified is the same as the scenario existing prior to the start of implementation of the project activity.
It is estimated that in the first crediting period of the project (from 19 November 2020 to 18 November 2027), the average annual GHG emission reduction will be 132,263 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Xinxiang Capital Environment Energy Co., Ltd.
Henan, China

title: Sustainable Paddy Program
description: The project plans to promote improved water management practices in rice cultivation instead of using the traditional practice of continuously flooded irrigation. AWD/DSR are proven methods to reduced methane emission by as much as 48% compared to flooded conditions where large amounts of methane (CH4) gets generated because of anaerobic decomposition. This project is predicted to generate important co-benefits of reducing water usage during rice cultivation, decrease pest and disease attacks, improve soil health etc. Further they're also beneficial for reduced cost of cultivation for small land holders

title: Agoro Carbon USA Pastureland Program
description: Agoro Carbon USA Pastureland Program is a grouped VCS project implemented by Agoro Carbon Alliance. The program will implement a package of regenerative land management activities in pasturelands, these include nutrient management, increasing species diversity, rotational grazing and other regenerative practices. The implementation of these practices will lead to an increase in carbon sequestration rates in the soil, increase in forage quality, overall animal and soil health and improved water management. The main objective of this program is to provide financial, agronomic and educational support to ranchers to implement the aforementioned practices. During the project lifetime, enrolled ranchers will be assisted by the Agoro Carbon agronomic team to implement improved agricultural management practices from their current system standard to a system that capitalizes on sustainable, regenerative production.

title: Nesa Solar PV Grouped Project
description: This Nesa Solar PV Grouped Project consists of the commissioning of new, small-scale solar photovoltaic (PV) installations in the Republic of South Africa. The PV installations provide a clean, renewable source of electricity. In addition, the PV facilities increase the security of electricity supplies in South Africa. This is primarily because the national utility, Eskom, is currently unable to provide consistent electricity supplies due to aged and failing infrastructure. The quantity and duration of power cuts in 2022 is expected to be the highest since load shedding was initiated in 2007.

title: Papariko - Restoration of Degraded Mangrove Areas in Kenya
description:
The objective of this project is to reforest degraded mangroves sites in Kwale, Kilifi, and Tana River counties, in Kenya. The project will create a healthy mangrove ecosystem in degraded lands, starting by planting 220 ha in Shirazi, Bodo, Munje, and Funzi Island, in Kwale county.
The main components of the project are to provide a variety of ecosystem services, climate change mitigation, economic considerations, and active participation of the local community. Without the project, carbon stocks in the project area will continue to decline, as the mangrove ecosystems in Kenya suffer a strong degradation process resulting from anthropogenic (e.g., deforestation for wood consumption) and natural causes (e.g., sea tides).
Under this grouped project, degraded mangroves on the Kenyan coast are restored and replanted. In the first project activity up to 196.000 mangroves will be planted. The species selected for this reforestation project are indigenous and local, namely Rhizophora mucronata, Ceriops tagal and Avicennia marina.
The project will monitor soil conditions to measure changes in soil carbon content and maintain soil nutrient levels to improve water quality compared to the baseline scenario. Mangrove restoration will further increase fish populations, improve biodiversity, and provide other important ecosystem services. To measure the positive impact on biodiversity, annual biomonitoring will be conducted using eDNA.
The empowerment of the population is also central to the project. The labour requirement for the project will be fulfilled with local employment. Therefore, most of the budget for labour and an additional 50/50 share of carbon credit revenues will remain in the country. The project will promote a working family model where more than 50% of women can actively participate in the project. People are shown alternative livelihood opportunities that allow them to acquire and grow high-value crops, and invest in beekeeping or ecotourism.

title: Huinan County Afforestation Project
description: Huinan County Afforestation Project is located in Huinan county, Tonghua city, Jilin province of China. The purpose of the project is to increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by planting trees on the barren or degraded lands. Prior to the start of the project, the land in the project area was barren, no forest or wetland except some scattered shrub and grass. Under the project, an area of 13,784ha of barren land in Huinan county was planted with trees of native species, mainly including Korean pine, spruce, larch, Fraxinus mandshurica, Juglans mandshurica, etc. The implementation of the project will generate greenhouse gases (GHG) emission removals and mitigate climate change, improve soil and water conservation and forest cover, enhance local biodiversity by increasing the connectivity of forests, increase competence and capability of local residents by providing them with relevant technical skills and training, and create more permanent job opportunities for local residents especially women and increase income for local communities.  The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 19,001,754 tCO2e in 60 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 316,696 tCO2e.

title: Xingu-Araguaia Grouped REDD+ Project
description:
The primary objective of the Xingu-Araguaia Grouped REDD+ Project is to avoid the unplanned deforestation (AUD) in a 10,004.42-ha project area, consisting of 100% Amazon rainforest. The project area is in São José do Xingu and São Félix do Araguaia, in the State of Mato Grosso, Southern Amazon.

Beyond the project’s ecological and carbon benefits, a proportion of the carbon credits generated will be dedicated to improving the social and environmental conditions in the project region, specifically contributing to improving deforestation control, and developing environmental education and other social activities. The contribution to sustainability is being monitored through the application of the SOCIALCARBON® Standard.

The present REDD project is expected to avoid a predicted 4,312 ha of deforestation, equating to 1,421,408 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime (15-October-2020 to 14-October-2050), with an annual average of 47,380 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Future Carbon International LLC
Florida, United States
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Western Kenya Soil Carbon Project
description: The Western Kenya Soil Carbon Project promotes the adoption of a range of Sustainable Agricultural Land Management technologies including reduced tillage, mulching, cover crops, green manure, composting, soil & water conservation, integrated pest management, and agroforestry on croplands and surrounding areas for watershed restoration and protection. It is implemented western Kenya in three counties: Bungoma, Kakamega and Siaya. Due to its more favourable agroecology, the region is densely populated, and the lands are extensively cultivated with limited natural vegetation. Farmers practice subsistence agriculture, characterized by low inputs, low yields, and continuous loss of soil fertility. The project is managed by Soil-Carbon Certification Services Ltd (SCCS), a non-for-profit company. SCCS is contracting implementation partner (IPs) to support farmers in their land restoration efforts. The project’s main goals are improved yields, food and incomes for farmers, increased resilience to climate change, and climate change mitigation via increased carbon sequestration in soils and plant biomass. The project activities will generate carbon credits that will be certified under the VCS program and monetized and invested in the project activities to ensure sustainability of the project goals. It is a grouped project covering 32,000 ha, with total VCUs 1.87 million tCO2. Participating smallholders are organized in farmer groups for efficient extension services delivery. The groups sign agreements to be project participants after due process of local stakeholders’ consultations and are then entitled to all extension services and support from the project. The group agreements oblige them to adopt and implement SALM technologies on their lands, support project monitoring, and transfer emission reduction units to the project. The project has a 20-year crediting period and applies the VCS Methodology VM0017 Adoption of Sustainable Agricultural Land Management, Version 1.0.
VCS Proponent:
Soil-Carbon Certification Services
Nairobi, Kenya
+254 720 596 869
aaron.munzaa@sccs.co.ke
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Chaco Vivo
description:
Project Chaco Vivo will be developed under the Verified Carbon Standard and Climate, Community & Biodiversity Standards (VCS – CCBS) as an avoided planned deforestation (APD) REDD+ project. Chaco Vivo will help conserve an area of over 1,800 km2, encompassing over 187,000 hectares (464,000 acres) in Paraguay's Gran Chaco ecosystem. Despite the Gran Chaco’s regional and global significance, the region is one of the most deforested on earth, losing over 1,000 hectares (2,471 acres) of tree cover per day. Project Chaco Vivo will mitigate deforestation pressures in the region and protect this important yet critically threatened ecosystem, which provides habitats to more than 3,400 plant species, 500 bird species, 150 mammals, 120 reptiles, and approximately 100 species of amphibians - including numerous endemic and IUCN red list vulnerable, threatened, and endangered species. 

Chaco Vivo is a People Project at heart with numerous communities living within the Project's Area of Influence (AOI), including Indigenous communities of the Maskoi - an ethnolinguistic group of people of Lengua-Maskoi. The Project Area encompassed by Chaco Vivo is a High Conservation Value Area (HCVA) since it consists of natural habitats of outstanding significance and/or of critical importance due to the special biological, ecological, social, and cultural values. 

Key to Chaco Vivo is a robust social program called the L.I.F.E. Program™ (Land-use Initiatives & Forest Enterprises Program). The L.I.F.E. Program™ will provide a tangible system of socio-economic enrichment programs to improve the livelihoods of marginalized populations. The key objectives of the L.I.F.E. Program™ are to directly impact the U.N. SDGs, but also to foster community engagement, project integration, collaboration, and self-sustaining sustainable enterprise creation for generational impact, or G-Impacts™.
VCS Proponent:
Atenil S.A.
Asunción, Paraguay
CCB Proponent:
Atenil S.A.
Asunción, Paraguay
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: Veracruz Mangrove For Life Project
description:
The Veracruz Mangroves for Life Project aims to restore the ecosystems of mangroves and floodplain forests in the Alvarado lacunar system, Veracruz (ALS) contributing to its adaptation to climate change, the conservation of biodiversity and the reduction of GHG emissions. The Alvarado Lagoon System is a 267,000 h ectares wetland complex formed by the estuaries of the Papaloapan, Acula, Blanco and Limón rivers. ALS is home to tremendous biodi versity and provides a bounty of ecosystem services to the c. 130,000 people living in the area. In recognition of its high conservation priority, it is registered as a RAMSAR site and listed as an Important Bird Area.
This ecosystem has faced ALS severe historical degradation, ever since the establishment of Spanish colonizers in the 16th century who first undertook to convert its natural ecosystems into pasture and sugar cane plantations.
The project is a grouped project and will restore 2,101 hectares. This objective will be a chieved thanks to the work of different stakeholders. The project proponent (Livelihoods) will implement the project together with the local communities and the Mexican ONG Pronatura Veracruz (PNV).
The entire project area (2,101 ha) will sequester 50 902 tCO2e per year. Based on this ex ante estimate, the project will sequester 1, 2 7 2, 561 tCO2e over 25 years.
VCS Proponent:
Livelihoods Fund SICAV SIF
Paris, France
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: GHG EMISSION REDUCTION THROUGH INTERMITTENT FLOODING IN RICE FIELDS
description: The project activity is an 'Alternate wetting and drying (AWD)' activity that is a water saving strategy in irrigated rice production. The main objective of the project is to switch from continuously flooded rice fields to fields that alternately encompass flooded and non-flooded phases which can save significant amount of irrigation water. Thus, the project activity has been designed to change from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation which is conducted in different blocks in the district of Bhopal, Hoshangabad, Raisen and Sehore of the state of Madhya Pradesh, in India. A total of 8,085 hectare for single-cropping rice has been covered under the project activity. During rice cultivation, controllable irrigation and drainage according to rice growth requirements can save water resources, and also at the same time will also reduce methane emission from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (in the flooded state). Additionally, in the project activity compost will be used for soil application in the rice fields and thus replace the application of synthetic nitrogen fertilizer. It is estimated that about 58,722 tCO2e emission reductions will be generated annually across the crediting period.
VCS Proponent:

Madhya Pradesh, India

VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: AVOCADO AGROFORESTRY GROUPED PROJECT IN ISRAEL
description: The main objective of the grouped avocado agroforestry project is to be a regional GHG emissions reduction and removal initiative, pioneer in the concept of combining sustainability activities with agricultural activities for avocado planting. To our knowledge, it is an unique initiative in Israel. All projects are located in Northern Israel. The four projects currently included in the grouped project are located at the following locations; Galed, Ramat Menashe, Ramat Yohanan and Yodfat. Agricultural practices by farmers in Kibbutz in Israel have traditionally involved open field activities such as corn, cotton, and wheat crops mostly with sprinklers (for more details refer to 3.4. Baseline scenario). This situation led the land to being occupied only for a few months each year (seasonal crops) with high levels of soil erosion and energy and water inputs. The proposed grouped project activity involves replacing seasonal crops with permanent avocado plantations, changing the entire ecosystem through the implementation of regenerative agricultural practices and boosting carbon sequestration by avocado tree planting.
VCS Proponent:
Rivulis Pte. Ltd.
Sharon, Israel
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in Yuyao City
description:
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation is conducted in Yuyao City1 , under the jurisdiction of Ningbo City, Zhejiang Province of China, which have a total acreage of 12,155 ha for single-cropping rice. Without this project providing ditches to conduct intermittent flooded method, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission removal than the continuously flooded.
With the project implementation, the cement ditches, reservoirs and relevant technical training are provided for these farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional continuously flooded method. During rice cultivation, controllable irrigation and drainage according to rice growth requirements can not only save water resources, but also reduce methane emission from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (in the flooded state). In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48%2. Hence, this project activity is estimated to reduce 4.93 tCO2e/ha.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 419,888 tCO2e in the first seven-year period with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 59,984 tCO2e.

title: PROJECT MATANI REDD+ DIOS MAYOR DE LOS PUEBLOS CABILLARI
description:
Colombia has approximately 60 million hectares of forest. Of these, 66% is located in the Amazon biome. The Forest and Carbon Monitoring System (SMByC) of the Institute of Hydrology, Meteorology and Environmental Studies (IDEAM), identified that in 2021, 174,103 ha of forest were deforested.
The name given to the Conservation Project is PROJECT MATANI REDD+ DIOS MAYOR DE LOS PUEBLOS CABILLARI, Matani is the Greatest God of the communities that make up the Association of Traditional Indigenous Captains of Vaupés (ACTIVA), made up of the communities of Altamira, Buenos aires, Cachiporro, Mutanacua, Villagladys, Cananari, Morroco, Reforma, Villareal. The Jirijirimo REDD+ Project is located in the Department of Vaupes, corresponding to the Amazon biome of Colombia. Due to its biophysical conditions, this biogeographic zone is strategic for regulating the climate, sustaining biological cycles, conserving soil and water resources, capturing greenhouse gas emissions, and conserving the biological diversity of the region. Amazon region.
Therefore, the indigenous communities linked to the project seek, through their territorial autonomy and their right to free self-determination, to carry out conservation processes framed in sustainability criteria that have to do with the protection of natural forest areas, rescue and protection of their cultural identity and promotion of productive practices that promote the protection of biodiversity and the environmental richness of their territory.
Characteristics that are directly linked to the purpose of REDD+ projects, with the desired sustainable local development, as well as with the purpose of reducing emissions generated due to deforestation and forest degradation. The project MATANI REDD+ DIOS MAYOR DE LOS PUEBLOS CABILLARI  constitutes an area of 814,948 hectares.
The main objective of the project has been is to avoid the unplanned deforestation (AUD) in the Amazon rainforest.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Xinjiang Burqin Improved Grassland Management Project Phase II
description:
Xinjiang Burqin Improved Grassland Management Project Phase II (hereafter as “the project”) is located in Burqin County, Altai City, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, China. The project is aimed to restore the local degraded grassland ecosystem from adoption of sustainable grassland management practices, such as improving the rotation of grazing animals between summer and winter pastures, limiting the timing and number of grazing animals on degraded pastures, and ensuring appropriate management over the long-term.
The main restoration measure of rest and rotational grazing were implemented in 68,333.33 ha of degraded grassland. For the first five years, grazing was strictly forbidden and then, sustainable grassland management methods will be applied, such as rotational grazing in different pastoral areas, limits the time and number of grazing in the project area to protect the natural grassland resources, curb the deterioration of the ecological environment of the natural grassland. It requires that the grazing time shall be halved by dividing grasslands into seasonal grazing land according to the livestock carrying capacity of the grassland by fence building. Then based on specified grazing order, grazing cycle and zoning grazing time, the grassland is grazed area by area and used in turn. 
Besides these main restoration measures, the project also alleviates soil desertification and restore grassland vegetation to improve soil carbon storage and local biodiversity through grassland management measures, such as daily management measures from other protect projects like rodent and pest control and grassland fire prevention to ensure the long-term sustainable management of the project area.

title: Ningxiang Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation
description:
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation are conducted in Ninghai County and Xiangshan County, under the jurisdiction of Ningbo City, Zhejiang Province of China, which have a total acreage of 12,096 ha for single-cropping rice. Without this project providing ditches to conduct intermittent flooded method, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission removal than the continuously flooded.
With the project implementation, the cement ditches, reservoirs and relevant technical training are provided for these farmers to help them conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional continuously flooded method. During rice cultivation, controllable irrigation and drainage according to rice growth requirements can not only save water resources, but also reduce methane emission from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (in the flooded state). In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48%1. Hence, this project activity is estimated to reduce 4.96 tCO2e/ha.
The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 419,958 tCO2e in the first seven-year period with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 59,994 tCO2e.

title: Sichuan Muli REDD project
description:
The Sichuan Muli REDD+ Project (hereafter referred as “the project”) is located in Muli Tibetan Autonomous County, Sichuan Province, China. The project zone (Including Liangshan State Liangbeiguo Forest Protection Bureau, Liangshan State Leibo key state-owned forest protection Bureau and Liangshan State Yalong River state-owned forest protection Bureau in the Muli area) has a total area of 181,681 ha. The area is characterized for its high biodiversity and subtropical humid mountain forests, but also for the presence of deforestation activities and social conflicts. Deforestation drivers include mining activities, subsistence agriculture andTo achieve the above mentioned objectives, project activities to be developed and implemented include: (i) Development of legal economic alternatives and associated business plans that promote biodiversity protection, (ii) Management and improvement of production systems that str biodiversity conservation, iii) Strengthening land use planning and mechanisms to guarantee food security for the communities, (iii) to contribute to the monitoring and conservation of the biodiversity present in the area of the Muli Tibetan Autonomous County.

Moreover, expected GHG reductions corresponds to an annual average of 234,910 tCO2, so for the lifetime of 20 years it could demonstrate reductions up to 4,698,207 tCO2.
