title: Enhancing Rural Livelihoods through Carbon Sequestration by adopting Agro-forestry practices and Natural Climate Solutions
description:
The proposed project activity under VCS will mobilize resource-poor farmers to raise tree plantations on vacant farmlands. It proposes to link resource poor farmers and end users of wood products in order to optimize the land use and to facilitate the co-ordination of wood producers, agronomists, industry, social enterprises and non-governmental organizations to improve the livelihood opportunities of rural households. The project activity is implemented on the degraded farmlands or lands used for rainfed subsistence agriculture. 
Various environment friendly technology-based agroforestry practices and Natural Climate Solutions (NCS) will be adopted to help climate change adaptation and mitigation as part of sustainable land management.

This project will optimise the land use and generate Emission Reductions (ERs). The amount of carbon sequestered through the project activity will be measured, quantified with reference to a baseline to determine the Emission Reductions (ERs) generated. The ERs will be calculated through Above Ground Biomass, Below Ground Biomass and Soil Organic Carbon. In the absence of the project, the lands would have remained degraded and the resource poor farmers would have continued to practice subsistence agriculture. 

The participation of small and marginal farmers as part of the VCS project makes this initiative unique in contributing to their land use choice, improvement of livelihood opportunities and in promoting their capacity to organize and implement climate change mitigation initiatives.

The project implements reforestation on 13,500 ha of degraded private lands in the states of Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and Orissa. The reforestation activities under the project were initiated in 2019. 

The project is estimated to generate 94,200 credits / year on average over a period of 20 years.

title: DRC REDD+ Carbon Credit Harvesting Project
description:
The DRC REDD+ Carbon Credit Harvesting Project, located in central DRC, Africa, is a group project that will protect 13,586,379 hectares of forest from industrial logging, unsustainable fuel wood extraction and slash and burn agriculture. Carbon validation will be undertaken by the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS). The project is developed and managed in a joint venture by forest carbon leaders GEC Communities II, Inc. as General Partner to R.E.D.D. Carbon Credit Harvesting LP (GEC-C) and Global Treaty Corporation (GTC). This project will utilize the methodology, 'Methodology for Avoided Deforestation' approved by the VCS in October, 2012. 

The project will be developed as a REDD+ project with validation planned under the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS). The VCS methodology used for this project will be Wildlife Works’ VM0009 ‘Methodology for Avoided Deforestation’ v2.0, originally validated with VCS in January, 2011 (Version 1.0) with the revised version (version 3.0) receiving validation from VCS in June, 2014.

The DRC REDD+ Harvesting Project falls under VCS sectoral scope 14 - Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Uses (AFOLU), under project category Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD) and most specifically under the activity Avoiding Planned Deforestation (APD). The project falls into this category by the definition provided in the VCS AFOLU Requirements Document Version 3 published 1 February, 2012, by virtue of the fact that it prevents emissions that otherwise would have taken place under a legally commissioned logging concession.
VCS Proponent:
R.E.D.D. Carbon Credit Harvesting L.P
NJ, United States
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in Shagang Town
description:
Shagang Town is located in the central and southern part of Hubei Province, located in the hinterland of Jianghan Plain .The project is located in Shagang Town,Jiangling County, Hubei Province, China, with a total acreage of 13061 ha for single-cropping rice. The project activity is designed to construction the cement ditch and reservoir to realize the reducing of methane emissions by conducting intermittently flooded method instead of continuously flooded method during the cropping season in Shagang Town.
In the baseline scenario, farmers in Shagang Town use continuously flooded method in rice paddies , which means fields have standing water throughout the rice growing season and only dry out for harvest. However, the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition. In the project scenario, farmers in Shagang Town changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation. By controlled the irrigation and drainage according to the needs of rice growth, can save water resources. On the other hand, multiple aeration during rice cultivation can effectively reduce methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions.
Emission reductions of this project are generated by reducing methane emissions of continuously flooded during rice cultivation in baseline scenario. With the project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.49 tCO2e/ha for rice is expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity is 58,608 tCO2e/year, the total GHG emission reductions are 410,256 t CO2e in the first 7 years crediting period.

Hubei Province, China

description: The High Impact Carbon Farming Program of Lithuania is promoted, financed, and implemented by UAB Heavy Finance. “UAB Heavy Finance” main activity is providing crowdfunded loans to farmers for equipment purchases, cash flow, or other farming activities. The Sustainability department of UAB Heavy Finance is in charge of GHG project design and implementation. The project aims to promote Improved Agricultural Land Management (IALM) practices for reducing GHGs. The practices for CO2 sequestration are the following- reduced soil disturbance, tailored fertiliser management, improved (plant) residue management and cover cropping, and improved crop rotation and harvesting.

title: TAIHE COUNTY BIOGAS POWER GENERATION AND ORGANIC FERTILIZER PROJECT
description: Taihe County Biogas Power Generation and Organic Fertilizer Project is located at ShuangXing Village, Shuang fu Town, Taihe County, Fuyang City, Anhui Province, China.This project builds a new livestock and poultry manure management system and collects organic wastes such as manure from many farms to produce biogas power generation and organic fertilizer. Fermentation raw materials are managed by unified collection and transportation. Agricultural waste resources (ie, livestock and poultry wastes in this project) undergo pretreatment and anaerobic fermentation, and the generated biogas is desulfurized and then enters the generator to generate electricity. The waste heat of the generator is used to increase the temperature of the material in the homogenization tank and the fermentation tank. The mud produced by anaerobic fermentation is transported to the nearby farmland through the pipeline network to form an organic ecological cycle industry. The residue is used to produce solid organic fertilizer. The electricity generated is fed into the East China grid, reducing methane and other greenhouse gas emissions. It also avoids the CO2 emissions generated by the power generation process corresponding to the replacement of electricity, thereby achieving greenhouse gas emission reduction.The project activity will reduce GHG in the atmosphere through avoiding methane emissions from anaerobic treatment of manure. The project adopts a 10-year fixed crediting period, It is estimated that 62,834 tCO2e emission reductions will be generated annually and total emission reductions are 628,338 t CO2e in the crediting period.
VCS Proponent:
Anhui United Venture Capital Renewable Energy Technology Co.,Ltd.
Anhui Province, China

title: Giciye III Hydropower Project in Rwanda
description:
The project activity involves power generation from a 9.8 MW hydroelectric project on Giciye river located at Musneyi village, Nyagahondo Cell, Rugera Sector, Nyabihu District in Western Provide of Rwanda. The project activity is a run-of-river project being developed by RMT Energy Development Ltd. The project activity comprises 2 Numbers of vertical Pelton Turbines manufactured and supplied by Gugler, Austria each with a generator output capacity of 4,986.9 kW for generation of electricity. The project also comprises 2 sets of synchronous generator having capacity 5600KVA each manufactured and supplied by GAMESA, Spain.   
The project is allotted to the RMT Energy Development Ltd. on basis of design, develop, construct and operate for a period of 25 years. The generated electricity from the project activity will be supplied to grid under a long term (25 years) power purchase agreement signed with The Energy Utility Corporation Limited (EUCL). 
The purpose of the project activity is to produce renewable energy using hydro power and supply the generated electricity to national grid. In the absence of the project activity equivalent amount of electricity would have been generated by the operation of grid mix power plants. The Project activity thus reduces the anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) in to the atmosphere associated with the equivalent amount of electricity generation from the fossil fuel based grid connected power plant.

title: Amazon Guardians REDD+ Project
description:
The growing threats to the forests of the Peruvian Amazon, such as migratory agriculture, land trafficking illegal logging and illegal gold mining, are causing the alarming degradation of forests; the loss and in some cases the disappearance of the most important flora and fauna in the territory; and the general pollution - deterioration of the country’s most valuable ecosystems. Specifically, illegal (gold) mining have caused tragic damage to part of the Peruvian Amazon. Rivers, streams and soils have been contaminated due to this cause to such degree that it will take many years to remediate and recover -to some extent- their initial state. One of the most affected areas in Peru in terms of deforestation, and specifically due to illegal mining, is the buffer zone of the Tambopata National Reserve and the forests located on the right bank (towards Cusco) of the Interoceanic highway in the region of Madre de Dios.

REDD+ Amazon Guardians purpose is to reduce and avoid deforestation within the conservation, reforestation/afforestation, and ecotourism forest concessions located in the buffer zone of the Tambopata National Reserve and adjacent areas which are highly threatened by illegal mining and traffickers who use these areas for illegal crops. REDD+ Amazon Guardians has been designed and developed with the purpose of protecting these valuable forests and their biodiversity, generating environmental services that allow the capture of CO2 and providing opportunities to improve the quality of life for the communities that live and depend on these areas. 

The project is implemented by Bosques Amazonicos SAC (BAM) in partnership with the concessionaire families in the area, grouped in the Federation of Concessionaires of Madre de Dios, FECOMAD.

description: The Corridors for Life ARR Grouped Project aims at mitigating climate change through planting of native trees that will remove carbon from the atmosphere, environmental and biodiversity conservation through the formation of ecological corridors that promote connectivity between the remaining forest fragments and protect the soil, and the generation of employment and income through training and acquisition of products and services from local companies of the reforestation chain. With this, the project has the potential over its 50 years lifetime to reforestate 75,000 hectares and remove 29,213,780 tons of CO2e, generate at least 600 jobs, benefit at least 180 women and contribute to the conservation of 8 endangered species according to the IUCN Red List.

title: Climate Action in Myanmar through a community-based Mangrove Restoration
description: The proposed project is located in Bokpyin Township, Kawthong District, Tanintharyi Region, along Myanmar's 2800 km of coastline. Mangroves in the project region have been deteriorated at an alarming rate in recent decades due to overexploitation and other anthropogenic influences. Mangrove degradation has a negative impact on the sustainability of neighboring ecosystems as well as the social well-being of local inhabitants. As a result, Worldview International Foundation (WIF) planned to develop a project to restore degraded mangroves and stimulate socioeconomic development in the Tanintharyi coastal region. Objective of the project is to restore 12,000 ha of degraded mangrove areas in the region. The restoration areas under the project belong to Htaung Ka Met, Noet Ngwar, Han Ka Phyu and Kawt Ba Mar village tracts of Bokpyin Township in Kawthong District.

title: YICHENG -1 ADJUSTED WATER MANAGEMENT IN RICE CULTIVATION
description: The project of Yicheng -1 Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation is conducted in Yicheng City within Xiangyang City, Hubei Province of China, with a total acreage of 13,187 ha for single-cropping rice. Anaerobic decomposition of organic material in flooded rice fields produces methane, which escapes to the atmosphere primarily by transport through the rice plants. The target of this project is to solve problems of large amount of methane (CH4) emissions and low rice productivity caused by excessive water used during rice cultivation through replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method to shorten the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. Without the implementation of this project that provides technology/measures to conduct intermittently flooded method, the continuously flooded method would continue to be used and thus the baseline scenario is rice cultivated by continuously flooded method. Soil organic matter under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, therefore the intermittent flooded method is beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction compared to continuously flooded. With the project activity, the estimated amount of GHG emission reduction is 4.52 tCO2e/ha for single-cropping rice. The total GHG emissions reductions is collectively expected to 417,237 tCO2e in the first 7 years with an average annual GHG emission removal of 59,605 tCO2e. This project aims to: - Reduce greenhouse gas emission and mitigate climate changes; - Increase rice productivity to improve living standard of local farmers; - Provide more job opportunities, especially for women workers; - Use a proportion of benefits to fund education for local children.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Triunfo do Xingu Grouped REDD+ Project
description:
The Triunfo do Xingu Grouped REDD+ Project (hereinafter also referred to as “TdX”) is composed by seven rural properties located in the Municipality of Altamira, in the south region of the State of Pará. According to the geo-referencing data, the total area of the project is established at 10,636.02 ha. This project aims to be registered under the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) to avoid unplanned deforestation (AUD), combating the decreased carbon stock in the Brazilian Legal Amazon. 
The crediting period of the project is 30 years. The start date is on August 31, 2022 and, therefore, the crediting period is expected to end on August 30, 2052. The baseline scenario developed is going to be used for the first six years of the project, since, according to VCS requirements, these six years are the maximum period until a baseline scenario reassessment needs to be done. The present analysis, that will be employed in the project validation and future project verifications, is going to be done in a conservative approach, keeping the project consistent.
The TdX aims for the following objectives: environmental benefits through a successful monitoring system; economic benefits resulting in regional development through investments in local communities. To execute the installation of this project and to achieve its objectives the VCU generation is very important. A baseline reduction of 1,565,285.35 tCO2e of GHG is expected over six years, associated with the avoided deforestation of 6,167.07 ha.

title: Selva de Urundel REDD+ Project
description:
The Selva de Urundel REDD+ Project, seeks to enforce the protection of the native forest and the biodiversity of the Urundel forest located in the Province of Salta, Department of Oran, in northern Argentina. 
The Project started in January 2021 and is expected to reduce emissions by 3,513,643.40 tCO2eq in the first 10 years through 9,647 hectares of avoided deforestation, at an average of 351,364.34 tCO2eq per year. 
The project is expected to generate emission reductions through the reduction of deforestation and forest cover loss by implementing several activities that include the prevention and control of fires, the control of illegal activities occurring in the property (hunting, logging, grazing), the training and capacity building, as well as the cooperation with different institutions to promote alternative activities in the property including among others ecotourism and scientific research. 
This project is particularly relevant as it aims to preserve a territory which is part of the Yungas Biosphere Reserve, included in UNESCO’s Man and Biosphere Program (MAB) thanks to the arrangement of the Yungas mountain ranges which present a discontinuous and insular distribution that creates conditions for the coexistence of great biological diversity.

title: Upscaling Livelihoods and Biodiversity Through Community mobilization and lagoon restoration in Anawasala Kalpitiya
description:
The carbon sequestered and stored in the coastal wetland ecosystems; mangroves, tidal marshes and seagrass meadows are called blue carbon. Sri Lankan coastline consists of blue carbon ecosystems predominating by mangrove ecosystems. The Puttalam lagoon is the second largest lagoon with the largest mangrove extent in Sri Lanka. The heaviest destruction of mangroves also exists in the Puttalam lagoon. As a response to the mass degradation of mangroves, the conservation and restoration process has been activated in this area. The GMSL together with Arinma Holdings commenced a pilot operation to rehabilitate 6000 mangrove plants in selected plots in Anawasala lagoon. The project was done in two phases, phase one we decided that the Rhizophora species was suitable. The number of plants available from both nurseries was 1300, and those plants were used for first round planting in March 2021. Phase two, the fishing community suggested that it would be better to plant propagules, therefore it was confirmed that 3000 plants will be purchases. Those 3000 plants were planted in zone A. After the commencement of the project A dedicated individual was appointed to look after the planted plants for two months. As the two months were coming to an end, the president of the village fishermen's association volunteered to take care of the plants. As of now information given by the Fisheries Society, states the plants planted have grown successfully thus far. 
Objectives:
• As a member of the United Nations global compact, Arinma holdings wishes to align with UN’s SDG hence promote life under water. This project adapted being to our company goals “under Water Stewardship” in order to mitigate climate change.
• Monitor carbon secretion by mangrove eco-systems and to find supporting data for future use.
• It is an untouched topic of research; hence it gives the students at the university the opportunity to engage in research.
• Provide the community with lively hood and food security.

ARINMA HOLDINGS PVT (LTD

title: Distributed Renewable Energy Program for People and Planet
description:
Smart Power India (SPI), a wholly owned subsidiary of the Rockefeller Foundation, extends clean and reliable electricity to those without sufficient access, with the goal of ending energy poverty and transforming the livelihoods of the underserved. 

SPI is implementing distributed solar power solutions across India mainly by different modes – 1) mini grids for catering to the power needs of households, shops and small commercial applications in rural areas, 2) rooftop solar in commercial and industrial establishments and 3) off-grid solar for anchor loads such as telecom towers.

This grouped activity covers distributed renewable energy installations across states of India.
VCS Proponent:
GEAPP ServiceCO (India) Private Limited
Delhi, India

title: RE.GREEN ATLANTIC FOREST REFORESTATION/RESTORATION PROJECT
description:
The Grouped project aims to implement forest restoration activities throughout the Brazilian Atlantic Forest Biome (hereinafter project zone), mainly in substitution of exotic grasslands formerly used for cattle raising, but also on lands used for annual agriculture (e.g. soy, sugarcane, etc), perennial agriculture of low carbon stocks (coffee, citrus, etc) and/or other non-native ecosystems. The project zone comprises 17 States of the Brazilian territory and is located within climatic/edaphic conditions suitable for plant growth and encompasses a region of high value for biodiversity conservation.
The initial objective is to restore approximately 88,400 hectares of forest cover within the project zone and the subsequent sequestration and storage of carbon in several carbon pools, such as aboveground biomass, belowground biomass, litter, dead wood, and soil organic carbon. Net greenhouse gas removals are estimated in approximately 47,634,218 tCO2e over 100 years, equivalent to the annual removal of 476,342 tCO2e.
The removal of GHG (CO2) by the project’s activities is a consequence of the biological sequestration through plant’s photosynthesis, which potential is increased by the implementation of a continuum of human induced forest restoration activities, ranging from assisted natural regeneration to full planting, including sometimes the use of commercial woody from native species to trigger initial restoration process.
In the absence of the project, the project areas would remain dominated by land-uses of low-carbon stock and/or continue to be occupied by non-native ecosystems as a consequence of anthropic activities practiced without properly sustainable management.
The project’s first instance has 346.5 hectares,is located in the municipality of Eunápolis-Bahia/Brazil, and it is expected to generate 181,451 tCO2 over 50 years, equivalent to 3,629 tCO2/ha/year. As part of the Grouped Project dynamics, other project instances will be added within the project zone
State/Province: Multiple States within Atlantic Forest Biome

title: Enexor Impact USA
description:
The Enexor Impact USA Project is a grouped project that creates emission reductions through the installation of Enexor’s novel Bio-CHP systems, also referred to as “project units,” at “Client Facilities” to reduce emissions via cleaner energy production and waste diversion. The Enexor Bio-CHP is a modular, on-site, renewable energy system that converts organic waste and/or non-recyclable plastic waste into renewable electricity and thermal energy. The project targets large organic and plastic waste streams generated by Client Facilities located within the United States. Enexor’s Client Facilities will primarily include industrial, manufacturing, and food processing companies that generate a significant volume of organic and/or plastic waste in their daily operations. By partnering with Enexor, these waste streams will be diverted from their current end-destination of landfills and/or dump sites to instead being converted into renewable electricity and thermal energy to power the Client Facilities’ operations. 

Enexor’s Bio-CHP systems can be monitored in real-time, remotely from Enexor’s headquarters in Franklin, Tennessee using Beckhoff’s cloud-based platform, TwinCAT. Feedstock input, energy output, maintenance metrics, and other project activity data will be measured and stored through TwinCAT, allowing for constant tracking, impact assessment, and reporting.

title: NaturAll Carbon Program – Conservation Agriculture and Land Management in Brazil
description: The project “NaturAll Carbon Program – Conservation Agriculture and Land Management in Brazil” belongs to NaturAll Carbon Limited and is located in Brazil, South America. The area is located in 23 states, covering a total area of 414.8 million hectares. The extension of the project covers four Brazilian biomes, Caatinga, Cerrado, Atlantic Forest and Pampa. It is very important to highlight that in order to preserve forests and swamps, lands from Amazon and Pantanal biomes will not be part of this project. As the leading causes of high GHG emissions and agricultural soil degradation have already been identified and are linked to inadequate management practices. But, although there are several studies and research data from all over Brazil, until now, there has been no efficient program to raise awareness and support rural producers in the transition to conservationist soil management on their agricultural property. Adopting conservation practices in the areas of agricultural and livestock activities, the goal will be to help reduce and remove GHG from the atmosphere, increase Soil Organic Carbon (SOC), avoid soil degradation (physical, chemical, and biological), improving soil fertility and productivity, creating a better resilience to extreme weather events, providing food security and preserving natural resources and their ecosystem services. The choice of instances inserted in the project will be based on implementing one or more regenerative or conservationist practices from November 1st, 2019, which are not common in the region, and there is additionality. The project intends to expand over time and reach multiple instances, and a range of agriculture and livestock activities in the four Brazilian biomes described previously to help drive resilient and sustainable agropastoral systems in these locations.
VCS Proponent:
NaturAll Carbon Limited
Warwick, United Kingdom
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Hongze-1 Water Management with Rice Cultivation
description: The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded conditions during rice cultivation is conducted in the north of Hongze District, Huai’an City, Jiangsu Province, China, with a total acreage of 12,843 ha of single-cropping rice. A total of 3,672 households (16,157 farmers) were involved in the project. Without the project, there would be no ditches, pumps, valves, and reservoirs to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously flooded method would be continued. The original scenario in which rice was cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Due to the anaerobic decomposition of organic matter in the paddy soil under flooded conditions, a large amount of methane can be released, so the intermittently flooded method is more conducive to saving water, improving rice yield and reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded method.

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in Dayi County
description:
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Dayi County within Chengdu City, Sichuan Province of China,
with a total acreage of 12,514 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of
this project, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice
was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic
matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4)
because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to
water conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction than the
continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which
results in not only large amount of methane (CH4) emissions but also low rice productivity
by replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which
shortens the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH4
emission can be declined by an average of 48%1. Hence, with the proposed project activity,
an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.58 tCO2e/ha for single-cropping rice is
expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity
is 57,352 tCO2e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 573,520 tCO2e during the
fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Increase the number of local individuals who have relevant skills due to diversified
educational opportunities from trainings;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.
VCS Proponent:
Sichuan Huixiang Ecological Agriculture Co., Ltd.
Sichuan Province, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: OLIVE GROVES FOR CARBON FARMING
description:
The “Olive Groves for Carbon Farming” Project consists in new super-high-density organic trees crop plantations in Centre and South of Italy for olive cultivation with the implementation of innovative precision organic agriculture practices as Climate Change adaptation and mitigation Natural Based Project.
The Project activities take place in several Italian farms of Central and Southern Regions which are located in the Mediterranean Climate Area. Since “The Mediterranean region is a hotspot for highly interconnected climate risks” (IPCC 2021) and for this area it is expected a faster warming with respect to global temperature average rise (UN environment program 2020), The Project builds new resilient crops contributing to the climate mitigation through carbon reduction and removal, securing in the long-term food production and cultural identity.
The Project consists of crop change on agricultural land, from annual crops to perennial organic tree plantations with a super-high-density of 1,200/1,600 olive trees per hectare, with respect to traditional olive groves density of less 200 trees per hectare.
The Project involves changes and improvements of traditional and local common agriculture practices as: improved water management with new water dripline irrigation system, tillage reduction, fertilizer reduction, cover crops implementation like green manures and precision farming by vegetation monitoring with satellites and drones.
The Project started in 2019 in some farms, it was then implemented in others and its accomplishment is expected for all the remaining farms by 2025 for a total estimated area of around 2,500 hectares.
VCS Proponent:
Santo Stefano Srl
Tuscany, Italy
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Mindanao Forests for People and Sustainable Livelihoods (MinFor)
description: MinFor is a long-term rural sustainable development project primarily concerned with managing forests and forming partnerships with Indigenous Peoples. It reaches a sizable number of recipient households and municipalities in the Philippines' Mindanao Region. The project involved forest protection and conservation in close partnership with the rightful indigenous land owners. Ancestral domains are territories that are declared as territories of tribal groups, and these domains are indiscriminate of political boundaries. These domains are delineated by identifying territorial boundaries acknowledged by tribes members since time immemorial. MinFor aims to achieve sustainable development, social empowerment, conservation and restoration in an equitable partnership with communities.

title: Boomitra Carbon Farming in East Africa through Soil Enrichment
description:
This project aims to help farmers deploy improved cropland management and regenerative agricultural practices in the croplands of Kenya. Over time, these croplands have undergone severe degradation due to anthropological factors, environmental conditions, and recurring natural calamities.

Around 75% of the population of Kenya is dependent on agriculture, and the sector supports a majority of the country’s food requirements. However, since agricultural production is largely rain-fed and around 80% of Kenya’s geography comprises arid and semi-arid regions, the occurrence of erratic rains and frequent droughts has imposed constraints on its productivity and stability.

In addition to natural disasters like droughts, degradation of land is greatly accelerated by unsustainable land use and management practices. Furthermore, in several parts of the country, soils are deficient in nitrogen, phosphorous and potassium, thereby resulting in poor vegetation cover. In this context, the opportunity to introduce improved cropland management practices will significantly help the croplands of the region and restore soil organic matter to their land, creating carbon removals while improving overall soil health.

The project activities include the adopt of practices such as no-till or reduced tilling, mulching with crop residues, reduced synthetic fertilizer application, using organic manures, water management, improved crop planting and harvesting methods, and agroforestry activities. These practices are proven ways to increase soil organic carbon, preventing further degradation of croplands and their soils, and enabling farmers to improve their productivity.

title: Silvopastoral carbon project of Uruguay
description:
This grouped project consists of afforestation and reforestation activities, with an innovative silvopastoral system design taking place in Uruguay. The project activity involves the inclusion of exotic and native trees on grassland, which is in a degraded state due to a long history of overgrazing. Trees are introduced at a low density with a unique plantation frame so that both livestock grazing and forestry activities are integrated without displacing any previous activity. Some instances also include a novel intensive grazing management. 
The main aim is to sequester atmospheric carbon through photosynthesis, to be stored in aboveground and belowground tree biomass, as well as dead wood, litter, and soil organic carbon pools. The most common tree species will be Eucalyptus grandis (W.Hill), however alternative species including various native species will be included as part of the project.
This system is an alternative to the conventional high-density, large-scale plantations for pulp or sawn wood that are the most common forestry activities in the country. Despite the numerous barriers for its implementation, management, and harvesting, it is an option for farmers who want to include trees as shelter and shadow without leaving behind animal husbandry and replacing the native grass cover. Because of the low volume of production, normally the labor during planting and forest management is done by local people and the timber is sold to nearby small-scale sawmills, contributing to the local communities by providing a source of qualified jobs in the primary and secondary sectors. 
This project does not only contribute to the local and regional economy but also has a net positive impact on social and environmental aspects. With the utilization of native species, new job positions will be created in existing or new-to-exist nurseries, among other social benefits.

title: SCALA LAOS AGROFORESTRY PROJECT 2
description:
The proposed grouped project “SCALA 2 Laos Agroforestry Project’ is seeking carbon credits for carbon removal within an area of 31,500 ha in Nakathing-Nongkapath and Phou Talava Production Forests Areas (PFA) in Lao PDR.  These areas present a dynamic landscape consisting of a mosaic of settlements, agricultural land, regenerated or fallow forest and remnant forest ranging from high altitude mountainous areas to riverine valleys. The first instance, called ‘SCALA Laos Agroforestry Project 2.1 - Phase 1’ will be implemented in an area of 4,713 ha.  The remaining area will be implemented in subsequent project instances. 

The reforestation project aims to establish eucalyptus plantations consisting of ~90% of plantations with the remaining ~10% set aside for conservation management. The project follows a participatory approach to identify suitable areas for plantations including frequent consultations with the communities according to the FPIC principle. The Plantation Model is based on agroforestry systems allowing for agriculture crops to be grown between the tree rows. The project areas have been heavily impacted by logging and shifting cultivation. The area is also heavily impacted by use of defoliants, carpet bombing and chemical spraying during the American-Vietnam war, causing degradation of forest landscapes. The project will make productive use of degraded land and provide significant local and regional employment opportunities across operations. Plantation establishment will require UXO clearance which will provide community health and safety benefits over large areas and unlock the land for use beyond the life of the project. 

The project will increase carbon sequestration and reduce GHG emissions by establishing forest cover in degraded land areas. It is estimated that over a crediting period of 30 years, the project will generate  9,229,270 tCO2e of removals, with an estimated  1,386,148 tCO2e removals from the first project instance.
VCS Proponent:
SilviCarbon Lao Sole Company Ltd.
Vientiane, Lao
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Foumbouni-Mitsamiouli solar farm
description:
Foumbouni-Mitsamiouli solar farm involves the construction and operation of two solar photovoltaic parks of 4 MWp each in Foumbouni and Mitsamiouli, respectively in the south and north regions of the island of Ngazidja, Comoros. The solar power plants are equipped with 10,080 modules of 405 Wp each mounted on tracker single array, with a backtracking system. They are coupled with 1 MW / 2 MWh batteries that allow the solar farm to operate under 2 modes: hybridization and islanding to export power to the national grid.
The bundled project is the first solar power plant on the island and its power generation is off-taken and distributed by SONELEC (national power utility company) that was prior to the implementation of the project activity only relying on fossil fuel fired power plants. Therefore, the clean and renewable energy produced by the power plant is substituting to the grid electricity and cut down GHG emissions from baseline fossil fuel intensive grid mix. Apart from emission reductions, the benefits of the project comprise, among others, improvement of energy self-sufficiency of the country, as well as creation of local employment.
Today, electricity in the Union of Comoros is produced mostly by diesel generators. Besides its use of fossil fuels, this system fails in providing the local population with electricity: energy access remains below 60 %. Thus, the project’s 12.7 GWh/plant/year power generation will result in global emissions reductions of 9,384 tons CO2eq per year on average.
VCS Proponent:
INNOVENT COMORES S.A
Ngazidaja, Comoros

title: Ground-Truth® Australian Orchards
description:
Regenerative farming practices are attracting significant interest within Australia's tree crop industries. Practices that are being trialled and introduced include: Reduced reliance on chemical fertilisers and pesticides, cover cropping, improved water use efficiency, establishment of new permanent tree crops, revegetation of areas surrounding orchards and adoption of carbon improvement management programs.
Implementing such practice changes are challenging as it requires up-front investment with considerable delay in financial return. This is particularly the case in: Non producing orchards during the establishment phase, where no or little income is generated for the first seven years and producing orchards in an environment of falling prices and rising input costs.  
This programme aims to provide additional economic support to farmers to fund, implement and maintain new regenerative farming practices that would alternatively not have been implemented, scaled up or maintained if it was not for this additional financial support. 
This programme is designed as a grouped project, focussing on tree crops in Australia, with the specific aim to generate carbon offset revenue from non-producing and producing orchards to finance regenerative agricultural practices.  These practices will improve SOC levels, but also lead to a reduction of chemical and energy inputs per unit of production. 
The potential of these practices is not being realised, as there is not a clear cost-benefit proposition, which this programme now aims to address. 
This project will also account for the additional biomass carbon generated in qualifying orchards established after the project start date, in accordance to the guidance under this option in VM0042.
Pilot assessments have shown that implementing the practices listed above can generate significant improvements in soil carbon levels. These improvements could amount to approximately 20 tonnes of CO2e reductions and removals/ha/year
VCS Proponent:
Carbon Friendly Pty Ltd.
Queensland, Australia
+61 417 743 402
mariki@carbonfriendly.com.au
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Sichuan Nanjiang Improved Forest Management Project
description:
Sichuan Nanjiang Improved Forest Management Project is located in Nanjiang County, Sichuan Province, China. It is implemented by the representative project ownerDingfeng State-owned Assets Investment (Group) Co. LTD . The project is to protect the forest that will be logged.
Nanjiang County belongs to Bazhong City, Sichuan Province, is located in the northeast edge of Sichuan Province, covering an area of 3,382.8 square kilometers. The area of natural forest is 3.21 million mu, and the area of artificial forest is 1.87 million mu. The dominant tree species are mainly cypress and masson pine.
The project is implemented in the key location commercial forest of Nanjiang County, which distributes in the 9 towns. For the convenient of VCS registration and issuance application, they selected the Sichuan Dingfeng State-owned Assets Investment (Group) Co. LTD to represent them as project proponent to implement the GHG related work. 
The project has about 8，286.84 ha commercial forest, which is nearly mature or mature. Before the implement of the project, the forest in the project area shall be planted according to the design of commercial forest, and logged annually according to the timber logging and managing plan issued by the local forest authority. The main object of the project is to improve the forest coverage rate, protect local ecological environment, reduce carbon emissions and carbon sequestration by enhance the management level and converse logged to protected forest in the project area. The implementation of the project will result in significant carbon sequestration and improve the sustainable development of ecological system.  The project is expected to generate 2,124,823.45 tCO2e emission reductions within the crediting of 20 years starting from  October 1, 2019 with the average annual emission reductions of 106,241.17 tCO2e; without buffer deduction, the annual and the total emission reductions are 79,680.88 and 1,593,617.58 tCO2e respectively.
VCS Proponent:
Sichuan Dingfeng State-owned Assets Investment (Group) Co. LTD
Sichuan Province, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in North of Dianjiang County in Chongqing City
description:
Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in North of Dianjiang County in Chongqing City (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is a project that changes the water regime during the rice cultivation period from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded on rice paddy fields located in the north of Dianjiang County in Chongqing City, China. The project involves 17,477 hectares of single cropping rice within the project boundary.
The project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by replacing continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) due to anaerobic decomposition. Without the implementation of this project, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario.
VCS Proponent:
Chongqing Tanray Technology Co.,Ltd.
Nan’an District, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in South of Dianjiang County in Chongqing City
description:
Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in South of Dianjiang County in Chongqing City (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is a project that changes the water regime during the rice cultivation period from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded on rice paddy fields located in the south of Dianjiang County in Chongqing City, China. The project involves 16,236 hectares of single cropping rice within the project boundary.
The project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by reducing the flooding time flooded during the rice cultivation period. Since soil organic matters emits a large amount of methane (CH4) under flooded conditions because of anaerobic decomposition, when the flooded time of rice fields in the whole growth cycle is reduce, CH4 emissions are hence reduced; in addition, it provides other benefits such as creation of job opportunities, water saving and yield increase compared to the traditional continuously flooded cultivation.
VCS Proponent:
Chongqing Tanray Technology Co.,Ltd.
Nan’an District, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in Jintang County
description:
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Jintang County within Chengdu City, Sichuan Province of China,
with a total acreage of 12,776 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of
this project, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice
was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic
matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4)
because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to
water conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction than the
continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which
results in not only large amount of methane (CH4) emissions but also low rice productivity
by replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which
shortens the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH4
emission can be declined by an average of 48%1. Hence, with the proposed project activity,
an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.44 tCO2e/ha for single-cropping rice is
expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity
is 56,664 tCO2e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 566,640 tCO2e during the
fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Increase the number of local individuals who have relevant skills due to diversified
educational opportunities from trainings;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.
VCS Proponent:
Sichuan Huixiang Ecological Agriculture Co., Ltd.
Sichuan Province, China

Sichuan Province, China

title: Chirisa REDD+ Project
description:
This is a VCS-large scale project class implemented to protect the Chirisa Safari Area in the Midlands province of Zimbabwe. The project area of 144,796 hectares is owned by the Zimbabwe Parks and Wildlife Management Authority (ZPWMA) and is leased to Carbon Green Africa (CGA) and Carbon Green Investments (CGI) for the purposes of establishing and running a REDD+ project. The partnership of CGA and CGI, hereinafter Carbon Green, is the project proponent. The main objective of the agreement is to establish a REDD+ project, with the aims of:
●	REDD+ carbon credit generation
●	Contribution to sustainable conservation in Zimbabwe
●	Development of a strategy for invasive species management
●	Fire and roads management
●	Game, water and habitat management
●	Strengthening antipoaching law enforcement
●	Wildlife population management
●	Promoting wildlife tourism and related activities
●	Community livelihoods enhancement 
The project proponent works in partnership with ZPWMA and adjacent communities in 12 wards across the surrounding 3 districts of Gokwe North, Gokwe South and Binga in a REDD+ scheme. Together the protected Safari Area and surrounding communal land make a project zone of 490,710 Ha. The project zone forms part of the last remaining corridor for animal movement and migration. 
The project aims to generate GHG emission reductions through 4 main strategic approaches:
1.	Direct forest and wildlife conservation to stop clearing and cutting of wood and wildlife poaching by implementing standard monitoring activities such as patrols
a.	Training to support law enforcement.
b.	Regular forest monitoring and carbon accounting will be done through aerial (remote sensing) and ground methods.
c.	Biodiversity assessments will be done via aerial methods supported by ground transects-based observations and citizen science. 
2.	Engagement and capacity building with key community and government stakeholders to willfully participate in one climate change mitigation goal
3.	Distribution of performance-based benefits to project zone communities delivered through local institutions 
4.	Implementation of sustainable alternative livelihood activities identified through a robust gender and inter-generationally sensitive participatory rural appraisal process
a.	Livelihood activities will include both subsistence and entrepreneurial initiatives in the fields such as agriculture, small scale, high-intensive controlled environment growing systems (greenhouses) 
b.	Vocational training on manufacturing of products for export
The baseline (without-project) scenario is unplanned deforestation due to the continual clearing of land for small-scale agricultural expansion and land degradation caused by overgrazing of cattle, driven by increasing populations and decreasing yields. The livelihoods of communities continue to decline, increasing the threat on the already declining biodiversity of the project zone due to erratic weather conditions. 
The project's clear CCB objectives are:
Climate – Avoided emissions of 14,280,937 tCO2e over a 30-year period at an average of 476,031 tCO2e per year, and in the process assist the human and wildlife population of the project zone to adapt to climate change impacts through income diversification, climate smart agricultural techniques, and habitat protection. 
Community - Alleviate poverty for more than 21,000 households, total of more than 90,000 individuals, specifically targeting women, vulnerable, and marginalized people. The project will also improve health, education and general social and infrastructure services within the project zone.
Biodiversity - Enhancement of the population of plant and wildlife species by conserving and maintaining vulnerable, threatened, and endangered species through habitat protection, controlled law enforcement, as well as rehabilitation and wildlife restocking.

title: Painted Forest Carbon Project
description:
The Painted Forest Carbon Project creates GHG offsets and forest health benefits through the purchase and management of 59,846 ha (147,882 acres) of private forest land, located in the District of Algoma near Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, Canada. The property is in a unique geographic location that will contribute to landscape level forest connectivity between the already established Lake Superior Provincial Park and Algoma Headwaters Provincial Park. The project avoids GHG emissions that would occur from harvesting the existing forestland. In the project scenario, significant carbon stocks are retained and sequestered through the preservation and continuing growth of the forest, creating substantial net benefits for Ontarians, and providing biodiversity benefits from the conservation and management of the area’s forest ecosystem.

The project scenario is improved forest management, wherein PFLP undertakes the forest carbon project and associated ecosystem protection and enhancement activities. The project scenario includes a low level of timber harvesting as part of forest management activities for the purposes of forest health, incidental infrastructure, ecosystem resilience, biodiversity and other conservation objectives.

ON, Canada

title: MOTOR VERDE FORESTRY CARBON PROJECT - GRANDAS DE SALIME (SPAIN)
description:
The Motor Verde Forestry Carbon Project – Grandas de Salime (Spain) consists in the reforestation of 86.94 ha in Grandas de Salime, Principality of Asturias, Spain. 
The land over which reforestation is set to occur is part of the “Sierra de la Cuesta and Villarpedre” communal forest and is owned by the Grandas de Salime City Council. The area was affected by two wildfires in April and October 2017 that devastated the forest. Since then, no-human induced measures to restore the forest have been implemented. Furthermore, natural regeneration has been and continues to be impeded by the shrubland that now covers the area, thereby preventing natural regeneration.
Being an area with steep slopes and shallow soils, the land has been devoid of any forest vegetation since the fire and rainfall is now causing soil loss due to surface runoff. The hillside on which the works were carried out is located on the banks of the Salime Reservoir, which pours its waters directly into the Navia River.
The reforestation work consisted in extracting the burned material by using either the walking excavator felling head or a chainsaw. The burned material was then moved to the forest/logging trail and then a clearing was made using the felling head coupled to the walking excavator, whilst digging was underway. Then, the plots were treated, and seedlings planted by hand. A 10-metre wide strip adjacent to the clearing was made to serve as an auxiliary strip for fire-fighting purposes.
The project will remove a total amount of 50,370 tCO2 over a 100-year period, which works out at an average reduction of 504 tCO2 per year.
The project is part of Motor Verde initiative (see below). In Grandas de Salime, by means of recovering the forest that was lost in April and October 2017, the project will yield economic, social and environmental benefits. It will sequester carbon, it will restore ecosystems, and it will provide the local population with training and subsequent employment.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Chestnut Carbon Conservation Project
description:
The importance of American forests to the global ecosystem and climate is central to the work of Chestnut Carbon, LLC, a US-based company that seeks to conserve and restore functional forestland throughout the United States for the primary purpose of increasing carbon sequestration. By the year 2030, Chestnut Carbon anticipates conserving up to 500,000 acres of land using long-term carbon management. This ambitious plan contrasts with regional common practice among the sellers of these lands: extractive timber harvesting to compensate for decreasing revenues from adjacent agricultural and ranching operations over time due to soil compaction and degradation. By extending rotation ages on these at-risk forests, the project increases carbon storage relative to the baseline case, as well as increases biodiversity and diversity in forest structure. 
To extend rotation ages across the project area, the project activity includes transitioning forestland into sustainable, uneven-aged silvicultural systems, where appropriate. These transition activities include the application of special silvicultural treatments that accelerate the recruitment of trees into standing dead wood, among other treatments. Estimated average GHG emission reductions are 221,312 tons CO2 equivalent per year, with total reductions over the first project crediting period of 5,532,801 CO2e. PAIs will be located across the contiguous United States and southern Alaska. To ensure sustainability in management, Forest Carbon Works requires PAI forestland to be certified by the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) prior to commercial harvesting under the group certificate managed by Forest Carbon Works (SCS-FM/COC-009247). Approved management plans shall meet both FSC requirements and the requirements specified by the management policies of Forest Carbon Works related to the promotion of even-aged management, biodiversity, water quality and wildlife habitat.

title: BOUTILI AFFORESTATION & AGROFORESTRY PROJECT
description: The Boutili Afforestation and Agroforestry Project (B2A Project), located northwest of the capital in Central African Republic (CAR), is made up of a mosaic of more or less wooded savannas and gallery forests. The human activities are traditional: slash-and-burn subsistence farming, collection of firewood, pastoralism. Their impact is increasing due to the proximity of the capital, Bangui. For many years, and the phenomenon is accelerating, these activities have been consuming forest areas faster than they are regenerating, leading to deforestation and degradation of wooded areas. The B2A Project aims to place local communities at the heart of a vast sustainable development program, aimed at revitalizing the socio-economic fabric of the region while restoring the forest cover.

title: Samaúma REDD+ Project
description:
The project will be developed in the municipality of Apuí, in the state of Amazonas, Brazil - within the Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU) sector under the Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD) category. The project will conserve 71,822.56 hectares of native Amazon Rainforest in a region where deforestation pressure is mainly due to pasture activities, part of which will be designated to Avoiding Unplanned Deforestation (AUD) (56,349.96 ha), other to Avoiding Planned Deforestation (APD) (14,158.28 ha) and the remaining hectares corresponding to water resources (314.32 ha). For the total area (AUD+APD) and by the end of the project, it is estimated a total avoided emissions of 23,452,633.10 tons of Greenhouse Gases (tCO2e). 
The project will follow the CCB Standards, with benefits for Climate, Community, and Biodiversity. As benefits for climate, the maintenance of forest cover results in exceptional benefits for adaptation to the impacts caused by climate change, such as changes in rainfall regime, as the area presents a dense hydrographic network that contributes to the provision and quality of water in the Amazon River basin.
As quantifiable benefits for Communities, the project will implement groundwater collection and distribution systems, installation of solar panels for electricity generation and provision of satellite internet service in  low-income's extractive communities residences. 
The maintenance of forest cover ensures the conservation of biodiversity, the maintenance of ecosystem functioning (e.g., nutrient cycling) and of ecosystem services provisioning (e.g., carbon sequestration) performed by living organisms. It is noteworthy that the project includes a high priority area for biodiversity conservation, in compliance with the vulnerability criteria of the CCB Gold Level, as it presents species classified as Critically Endangered (CR) and Endangered (EN) according to the IUCN.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Type: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation

title: DEVELOPING VOLUNTARY CARBON MARKET  PROJECT FOR FARMERS ADOPTNG  ALTERNATE WETTING AND DRYING (AWD)  METHOD FOR RICE CULTIVATION
description:
Flooding conditions in rice fields emit the most CH4, while intermittently flooded rice fields create a high quantity of N2O. Emissions of GHGs from rice fields can be reduced by modifying irrigation patterns, regulating organic additives, and using suitable rate and quantity of Nitrogen fertilizer. Irrigation practice such as Alternate wetting and drying (AWD) method has been observed to reduce GHG emissions in comparison to the traditional method 
of flooding. The time intervals between dry and wet conditions help in the transition from aerobic to anaerobic soil conditions, thus alternate wetting, and drying method leads in a significant reduction in methane generation1. Thus, the project employs AWD method to reduce the CH4 emissions. This will also lead to reduction in the water consumption, thus decreasing the input cost of the farmer. Before implementation of the project activity, the farmers were following the traditional flooding method, leading to the emissions of methane in the atmosphere. The project proponent conducted training programs and meeting with the farmers to make them aware about the benefits of adopting AWD, followed by the distribution and installation of AWD pipe in the fields of enrolled farmers. The first instance of the project is located in Haryana state covering an area of 4973 hectares. Furthermore, as it is a grouped project, the project activity will be implemented in other rice growing states of India in the future instances. Annual average emissions from the project are 48,853 tCO2eq.
VCS Proponent:
Varaha ClimateAg Private Limited
Delhi, India
+91-9619776814
madhur.jain@varahaag.com
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Reforestation for multiple purposes as a means of sustainable development
description:
The grouped project “Reforestation program for multiple purposes as a means of sustainable development”, also known as “Plante com a Klabin” (Plant with Klabin), has as its stated goal the promotion of sustainable reforestation in Southern Brazil, specifically in the states of Paraná and Santa Catarina, aiming to achieve net removals of greenhouse gases from the atmosphere. 
The land use that has historically predominated in these states is agriculture and cattle raising. The project proposes a change in the traditional land use of this region, promoting reforestation practices as a sustainable alternative, either to produce wood for multiple purposes based on rapid-growth species (for example, Pinus.spp or Eucalyptus.spp), and/or to restore areas based on native species. 
Through an integrated approach, the project has established a set of incentives to make reforestation activities more attractive, with the aim to achieve important synergies between production and restoration, contributing to the strengthening of the low carbon economy and promotion of sustainable development.
VCS Proponent:
Klabin SA
São Paulo, Brazil
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Solar Powered Irrigation Services by Claro Energy, India
description: The grouped project aims to install state of the art solar irrigation systems in India to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions and assist farmers adapt to these changing climate conditions. With easier access to water for irrigation, the project helps in irrigating the crops even during the dry season (i.e. throughout the year) and planting new crops, thereby increasing the productivity and revenue to the farmers.

title: Sichuan Yuexi Afforestation Project

title: THE FOREST CARBON PROJECT AGROREFORESTADORA RANCHO VICTORIA S. A
description:
The Rancho Victoria forestry project is projected in the next 20 years to have a growth in the forest cover of regional commercial species in 3,618 hectares, distributed as follows:
-	P. caribeae 
-	 Eucalitus sp. 
-	A. mangium y mezcla con otras especies nativas 
The plant material needed for planting will be produced in a transitory nursery installed on the project premises, using high-quality seeds.
The planting density has several proposals that vary between 1,040 trees per ha (3.1 x 3.1) up to 1,200 trees per ha.
It is noteworthy that all the lots within the property will be surrounded by firebreak corridors that mitigate the mobility risk of the fire to other lots or land.

title: Wanzhou Water Management with Rice Cultivation
description:
The project is to change from continuously flooded regimes to intermittently flooded regimes during rice cultivation in Wanzhou District, Chongqing City, China, with a total acreage of 18,723 ha of single-cropping rice. A total of 8,466 households (36,234 farmers) were involved in the project. Without the project, local villagers would not have access to intermittently flooded technology and intact facilities to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the traditional continuously flooded method would be continued. The original scenario in which rice was cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Due to the anaerobic decomposition of organic matter in the paddy soil under flooded conditions, a large amount of methane can be released, so the intermittently flooded method is more conducive to water efficiency, improving rice yield and reducing methane emissions than the continuously flooded method.
The implementation activities of the project include promoting intermittently flooded technology, technical training for the farmers, facility repair and replacement, etc. According to the needs of rice growth, farmers use pumps and valves to control irrigation and drainage, which not only saves water resources but also reduces methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions. Through the pumps and valves, the necessary water can be supplied to the rice paddies in time in the dry season, and the excess water can be drained from the rice paddies in the rainy season.
The project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions by 414,785 tCO2e in the first seven-year period, with an average annual GHG emission reduction of 59,255 tCO2e. The project aims to reduce GHG and mitigate climate changes, increase rice productivity resulting in higher living standards for local farmers and provide more job opportunities.
VCS Proponent:
Chongqing Gengfang Agricultural Development Co., Ltd.
Yuzhong District, China

title: Fangchenggang Mangrove afforestation project
description: Fangchenggang Mangrove Afforestation Project is located in Gangkou District and Fangcheng District of Fangchenggang City, Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, China. The purpose of the project is to increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by planting mangroves in degraded mangrove habitats. The project proponent is Fangchenggang Xinggang Agricultural Development Co., Ltd.The purpose of the project is to restore the degraded local mangrove ecosystem and increase forest cover by planting a variety of species of native mangrove, and establish a healthy local ecological and economic system by involving residents in the implementation of the projects directly. Totally 221.9 ha of mangroves have been planted with 5 native mangrove species (such as Avicennia marina, Kandelia candel, Aegiceras corniculatum, Rhizophora stylosa, Bruguiera gymnorrhiza). The implementation of the afforestation project will generate GHG emission removals, improve the local environment, enhance the capabilities of local communities and residents by providing them with relevant technical skills. In addition, the project has restored the degraded mangrove ecosystem and increased forest coverage, provided a suitable habitat for animals, especially for endangered birds which mainly live in mangroves. The project is estimated to generate GHG emission removals of 111,592 tCO2e in 40 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 2,789.8tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Fangchenggang Xinggang Agricultural Development Co., Ltd

title: FUTURE GREEN CARBON PROJECT
description:
Future Green Carbon Project is an AFOLU initiative to be implemented in the Central West
region of Brazil, specifically in the state of Mato Grosso do Sul (MS). It is a voluntary action of
Eldorado Brasil Celulose S/A, aiming at the reforestation of more than
100,000 hectares with new and additional eucalyptus plantations , established exclusively on
non forested and anthropized areas . In addition to the creation of carbon stocks through
reforestation activities for production purposes , the project will also enable the recovery and
conservation of carbon stocks based on native species for conservation purposes. Even tho ugh
the restoration of such areas will be enabled by the project, resulting in direct climate benefits,
VCUs will not be claimed for such activities.
VCS Proponent:
Eldorado Brasil Celulose S.A.
São Paulo, Brazil
+55 11 2505-0200
sustentabilidade@eldoradobrasil.com.br
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Reforestation of land for multiple uses
description:
The grouped project “Reforestation of land for multiple uses” is a voluntary action to promote
sustainable tree planting in the Central-West region of Brazil, specifically in the states of Mato
Grosso (MT), Mato Grosso do Sul (MS) and Goiás (GO), on non-forested lands. Its objective is to
generate net removal of greenhouse gases through converting traditional land use in the region
– e.g. non-forested/agricultural areas – into reforestation actions, based on the engagement of
investors and independent rural producers. Also, the project proposes the restoration of nonforested
lands with the purpose of enhancing carbon stocks of native vegetation, including
protected areas, i.e. Permanent Preservation Areas, Legal Reserves, and other
lands, as applicable to each case.
VCS Proponent:
Lacan Investimentos e Participações Ltda
São Paulo, Brazil
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Guangdong Huaiji IFM (conversion  of  logged  to  protected  forest)  Project
description:
The Guangdong Huaiji IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project (hereafter “the project activity”) is implemented in Huaiji County, Guangdong Province of China by Huaiji County Weizhou Construction Investment and Development Group Co., Ltd, the geo-coordinate of the project is 23°28′07″N～24°23′30″N, 110°52′09″E～112°30′49″E, the total area is 355,661.39 ha, which includes the Improved Forest Management (IFM) of the forests in the conversion of logged to protected forest.
The area of the project activity is 14,870.98 ha, including 3,561 subcompartments. All these forests are state-owned forests or privately-owned forests or collective-owned forests, and have the legal right to forest ownership. All the owners authorized the project proponent to access the project to their behalf. The species involved in the project are Pinus massoniana, Chinese Fir and Pinus elliottii. The forest of the project was older plantations under managing. The age of Pinus Massoniana was 20-31, Chinese Fir was 21-39, Pinus Elliottii was 21-38. Before the implantation of the project, the usual type of management was clearcutting.
Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged based on a valid and verifiable government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 2,123,753 tCO2e in 20 years, the average annual emission reduction is 106,187 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 1,635,281 tCO2e in 20 years, and average annual VCUs with buffer deduction is 81,764 tCO2e.
The project activity will contribute to the environment (biodiversity conservation, rocky desertification prevention and soil erosion control), thus contribute to sustainable development.
VCS Proponent:
Huaiji County Weizhou Construction Investment and Development Group Co., Ltd
Guangdong province, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
