title: Community-based Mangrove Restoration Initiative – Lep Lep
description:
The objective of this project is to restore degraded mangrove sites in Kafoutine in Senegal. The project will create a healthy mangrove ecosystem in degraded lands.
The components of the project are reforestation, providing important ecosystem services, climate change mitigation, socio-economic improvements, and active participation of the local community.
Under this grouped project degraded mangroves are restored and enriched. In the first project activity, up to 1.9 million mangroves will be planted in an area of 750 ha, starting in 2023. The species selected for this reforestation project are indigenous and local, namely Rhizophora mangle and Avicennia germinans.
Training and awareness-raising of the local communities are crucial for the success for the project. From the start of the project, stakeholders potentially affected by the project have been involved in the process. This included providing information on all project activities and teaching basics on forest management, monitoring, forest protection activities, climate change, and carbon sequestration. Depending on the given conditions, up to 3,500 seedlings per hectare will planted. The project will sequestrate an estimated 355,000 tCO2 in the 750 ha over a period of 20 years.
The empowerment of the communities is central to the project. The labor requirement for the project will be fulfilled with local employment. Therefore, most of the budget for labor and an additional 50/50 share of carbon credit revenues will remain in the country. The project will promote a working family model where more than 50% of women can actively participate in the project.
Mangrove restoration will further increase fish populations and improve biodiversity. To measure the positive impact on biodiversity, annual biomonitoring will be conducted using eDNA.
Over the 20-year period, the project team will create a healthy mangrove ecosystem, improve the socio-economic status of the community, and foster climate change mitigation.
VCS Proponent:
Vlinder Austria GmbH
Hallein, Austria
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Hubei Badong IFM (conversion of logged to protected forest) Project
description:
The Hubei Badong IFM (conversion of logged to protected  forest) Project (hereafter “the project activity”) is implemented in Badong County, Enshi Tujia and Miao Autonomous Prefecture, Hubei Province of China by Hubei Yangfan Tourism Development Co., Ltd and Guangzhou Guotan Assets Management Co., Ltd, the geo-coordinate of the  project proponent is 110°04'E -110°32'E and 30°28'N - 31°28'N, the total area is 3348.75km2, which includes the Improved Forest Management (IFM) of the forests in the conversion of logged to protected forest.
The area of the project activity is 6584.77 ha, including 875 subcompartments spreading over Chadianzi Town, Dazhiping Town, Dongrangkou Town, Guandukou Town, Lvcongpo Town, Qingtaiping Town, Xinling Town, Shuibuya Town, Yanduhe Town, Yesanguan Town, Jinguoping Township, Xiqiuwan Township, Bashan Forest Farm of Hubei Badong. All these forests are state-owned forests or privately-owned or collective-owned, and have the legal right to forest ownership. The species involved in the project are all native species and the species involved in the project are Chinese Fir, Coniferous Broad Mix and Coniferous Mix.
Before the implementation of the project activity, the trees are logged based on a valid and verifiable government-approved timber management plan for harvesting the project area. The implementation of the project activity converses the trees to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 706,125 tCO2e in 20 years, the average annual emission reduction is 35,306 tCO2e and Verified Carbon Units with buffer deduction is about 557,829 tCO2e in 20 years, and average annual VCUs with buffer deduction is 27,891 tCO2e.
The project activity will contribute to the environment (biodiversity conservation, rocky desertification prevention and soil erosion control), thus contribute to sustainable development.
State/Province: Enshi Tujia and Miao Autonomous Prefecture
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Household Biogas Project in Madhya Pradesh & Jharkhand
description: The purpose of the project is to replace the commonly used inefficient wood fired mud stoves technology, with clean, sustainable, and efficient biogas. Each household utilizes cattle dung to feed the digester to produce biogas for cooking purpose. This leads to reduction of greenhouse gas emissions by displacing conventionally used non-renewable biomass with renewable biogas and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions related to animal manure which is left to decay anaerobically. In addition, the hygienic conditions in the rural areas will be improved by an appropriate disposal of waste. Further, residue from the bio digesters can be used as organic fertilizer for land application. Project activity will contribute towards sustainable development by replacing non-renewable source of energy with biogas generated from the biodigesters. The Project is operational in India in the rural areas of Madhya Pradesh and Jharkhand.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents

title: RESTORATION OF HOMESTEAD LAND OF POOR RURAL COMMUNITIES IN ASSAM & MEGHALAYA
description: The proposed Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR) VCS project in the districts  of these two states, aims at bringing sustainable development of the local communities contributing to the whole carbon offset mitigation by restoring 9000 Ha. of farmland. The area will be treated with plantations in Kamrup and Goalpara districts in the state of Assam and Ri Bhoi district in the state of Meghalaya. The project aims to improve its agriculture practices by incorporating crop diversification, inter-cropping, progressive reduction in the use of synthetic chemicals and further replacing it with organic compost like vermiwash, handikhatta, jibaamrit, etc while setting up composting units to promote the recycling of biomass.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Mangrove restoration project in Wenchang and Changjiang, Hainan
description:
Mangrove restoration project in Wenchang and Changjiang, Hainan (hereafter as “the project”) is located in coastal areas of Dongge town, Wenjiao Town, Dongjiao Town, Wencheng Town, Puqian town and Jinshan Town of Wenchang city in the Northest Hainan Island, and Zhubijiang estuary of Changjiang Li Autonomous County in the west Hainan Island.
The project is aimed to increase carbon sequestration and contribute to local sustainable development by planting trees on degraded mangrove ecosystem. 352.89 ha of mangrove is to be restored by plantation of mangrove seedlings on intertidal areas where mangroves had been lost in past decades in Wenchang city and Zhubijiang estuary of Changjiang Li Autonomous County which located in Hainan Province.
The project has expanded the mangrove area and improved the quality of mangroves through the artificial afforestation of mangroves on the beach, which will effectively protect the mangrove ecosystem, save and protect the mangrove germplasm resources and rare and endangered wildlife resources. At the same time, the implementation of the project will also improve the ecological functions of mangroves in wind and wave prevention, siltation and beach protection, bank consolidation and embankment protection, disaster prevention and mitigation, and ensure the safety of people's lives and property.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
CCB Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Status: Registration and verification approval request denied
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
CCB Project Status: Validation and verification approval request denied

title: Guizhou Jinsha CMM Power Generation Project
description: Guizhou Jinsha CMM Power Generation Project (hereinafter referred to as the Project) is located in Taoyuan community, Liutang town, Jinsha County, Bijie City, Guizhou Province, China. The purpose of the Project is to utilize the extracted CMM with low concentration methane concentration to produce electricity. No coal bed methane (CBM) or ventilation air methane (VAM) utilization is involved. Twenty sets of CMM power generators are installed with a total installed capacity of 18MW, destroying 27.2 million m3 of methane annually. After the full operation of the Project, the expected annual exported electricity is 94,656 MWh, which is supplied to the coal mine through the electricity distribution network in Guiyuan coal mine area, and to China Southern Power Grid (CSPG) if there is any electricity surplus, replacing the electricity that would otherwise have been purchased from the CSPG and displace part of the electricity generated by CSPG dominated by fossil fuel-fired power plants. The emissions reduction of the Project comes from two sources: 1) Methane (CH4) emissions as a result of the previously vented gas that will be captured and destroyed in the project scenario; 2) CO2 emissions from the production of the equivalent amount of electricity replaced by the Project that would otherwise have been purchased from the CSPG.
VCS Proponent:
Jinsha Yonder Southwest New Energy Development Co., Ltd.
Guizhou Province, China

title: Barutçuoğlu Landfill Gas to Electricity Power Plant
description:
The project activity includes capture and utilization of landfill gas (landfill gas (LFG) contains approximately 50% methane and is a potent greenhouse gas (GHG)) for power generation, that would have been vented to the atmosphere in the pre-project/business as usual scenario. The landfill site is estimated to receive around 126 thousand tons of municipal solid waste (MSW) annually during 2021 followed by annual increment in receipt of waste quantity and is expected to reach around 152 thousand tons by the end of first crediting period (2028). About 59.58% of this waste consists of organic materials such as pulp, paper and cardboard, and food waste.
The technology measures deployed under the project activity includes covering of landfill area, landfill gas capture unit, and gas engine. Gas engine with an installed capacity of 2.906 MWm/2.828 MWe1 utlises collected landfill gas for power generation. Electricity generated is fed to the National Grid of Turkey. The electricity generating unit was commissioned on May 26th, 2021 and is regarded as the project start date2.

title: LA GIOIA CARBON FARMING IN NORTHERN ITALY
description:
La Gioia farm is located in La Gioia, Alessandria in Northern Italy. The coordinates are attached as a KML file.  Several agricultural practices will be implemented or modified on the land. Taken together, the goal is to reduce the carbon emissions currently emitted by this farm and raise the carbon stored in the soil. In addition, the selected measures will contribute to improving crop yields and soil health. 

To do so, the following methods will be applied on site; Reduction of the inorganic fertilizer application, change of irrigation system, Incorporation of crops residues into the soil, Tillage reduction, Cover crop implementation, Reduction of the fossil fuel use, Switch from crops to woody biomass

The sectoral scope 14 – Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU) is applicable to the project. Within this sector, this project has been developed under the scope of the methodology for improved agricultural land management (VM0042 VCS methodology).

The project has been found eligible under the scope of the VCS program as it meets all requirements established by the program. 

The crediting period chosen for this project is of 25 years, renewable 4 times. The period lasts from the 01/06/22 to the 1/6/2047. We estimated that 211,7 tCO2/year will be stored in the soil or not emitted.
VCS Proponent:
Rivulis Pte. Ltd.
Sharon, Israel
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: NEC AND SAKYU IFM -THE 1ST PILOT FOR FSC FOREST IN JAPAN-
description:
This project is being conducted in Miyagi, Japan by Sakyu Corporation. The geographical coordinates of the project are 38.67769, 141.43124 (Asahidate), 38.67559, 141.40869 (Nashinokiyama), 38.65726, 141.4349 (Uchiyama) with a total area of 14.63 ha, protecting forests in the target area that were previously harvested for commercial timber (The forest management will be improved in the form of protecting the forest in the target area, which was previously harvested for commercial timber (applying methodology VM0010).
Prior to implementation of the project activities, trees in the target area were harvested for commercial timber in accordance with the forest management plan approved by Miyagi Prefecture. With the implementation of the project activities, trees in the target area will be converted into a protected forest to reduce GHG emissions.
Over the 20-year period, GHG emissions are reduced by 4,988 tCO2e, with an average annual emission reduction of 249 tCO2e and a VCU net of buffers of approximately 4,539 tCO2e over 20 years.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents

title: Fujian Wuping Improved Forest Management Project
description:
The Fujian Wuping Improved Forest Management Project (“the project”) is located in Wuping County, Longyan City, Fujian Province, P.R.C. The geo-coordinated of Wuping County is 115°51′E～116°23′E, 24°47′N～25°29′N. It is implemented by Jiangxi Huapeng Low-carbon Technology Limited (PP) to protect the once logging forest. The proposed project is implemented in 17 Towns, Wuping County. This project aims to protect 62,694 ha commercial forest from logging. 

Prior to the implementation of the project, the forests in the project area were harvested following the guidelines in Timber Harvest Plan approved by the local forestry authority. In order to protect the forest ecosystem, improve the ecological environment, increase carbon sinks, reduce GHG emission reductions and slow down climate change, PP decided to implement this IFM project activities from March 2020 to March 2050. And from the Project Start Date, PP has stopped the commercial logging in the project area.

The Forest Conservation Project activities will be focused on forest resource supervision and monitoring. This ecosystem will then continue to provide its services to all the communities and entities that depend on it. 

The project reduces greenhouse gas emissions by preventing logging, avoiding any kind of commercial harvest and other linked to logging activities, as decomposition of harvested tree, bark burning, emissions due to carbon fraction sequestered from wood products over time.

The project activity will significantly improve the forest management conditions within the project area, and benefit local ecological environment. The implementation of the project will not only achieve a reliable measurable carbon sequestration by reducing commercial timer, but also contribute to sustainable development of the local community, host country.

The project is expected to generate approximately 13,856,024 tCO2e during the 30 years’ crediting period, with the annual emission reductions of 461,867 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Jiangxi Huapeng Low-carbon Technology Limited
Jiangxi Province, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Grouped Sustainable Agroforestry Project
description:
ClimeTrek Limited (hereinafter referred as ClimeTrek) and GKF Agroforestry (P) Limited (hereinafter referred as GKF) are proposing a Grouped Agroforestry Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation (ARR) project in fallows agricultural, and wastelands owned by individual farmers and communities with low plant cover (hereinafter referred as project activity), located in the geographical boundary of India.
The project activity is a grouped project where various horticultural tree species including fruit bearing tree species, commercial tree species and shrubs will be planted. During the first three years, around 31,984 Ha will be planted in the first project instances covering States of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana; the potential land available within the project region for future project instances reaches whole of India. All project instances within this grouped project activity will consist of Agroforestry projects across India.
Based on ex-ante estimates the project will sequester around 4.02 million tonnes of CO2e over 30-years (tree/ shrub biomass carbon and soil carbon).
The overall objective grouped project activity is to mitigate climate change while contributing to sustainable environmental management, community development and poverty alleviation of farmers in India. The grouped project activity is to utilize the fallows agricultural and wastelands by establishing agroforestry systems consisting of both forest trees and fruit trees.
The additional trees in the landscape will enhance the wildlife habit value and biodiversity. In addition, the soil water storage capacity will increase, and soil erosion will be reduced. Consequently, the climate change resilience of the land use systems, related to droughts, will be increased.
These activities will significantly contribute to livelihood improvement through creation of employment and improved food and nutrition security. The establishment of forest and fruit trees will increase carbon sinks hence more carbon

title: REGENERATIVE LIVESTOCK CARBON PROJECT WITH A PARTICIPATORY APPROACH IN COLOMBIA
description:
The regenerative livestock farming carbon project in Colombia is developed by the project developers Sosty S.A.S and Carbono Local+ GmbH. The project titled “Regenerative Livestock Carbon Project with a Participatory Approach in Colombia” is a comprehensive initiative developed by the project developers encompassing a variety of activities aimed at improving grazing practices, restoring soil health, and enhancing the resilience and well-being of farmers.
 
The primary objectives of the project are to reduce overall emissions through carbon sequestration in the soil while simultaneously improving farm productivity and conserving biodiversity in grazing areas. These goals will be achieved by enhancing livestock production practices, specifically by ceasing 
grassland burning and implementing adaptive multi-paddock grazing. The project will also 
promote the diversity of forages rather than the monoculture of pastures. This includes the 
management of native savannahs and introduced pastures, incorporating nitrogen-fixing species, 
and integrating silvo pastoral systems. The grouped project is developed within the Colombian agricultural frontier (located in five different eco-regions), which is the delimited area defined by the government, where livestock husbandry and agricultural activities are allowed to be developed. The project’s start date is 20.01.2020 and its crediting period goes on to 40 years. It targets a total 250,000 ha that can generate an annual average and total GHG emission reductions and removals of 292,050 tCO2eq per year and a total of 11,802,000 tCO2eq of emission reductions by 2060.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use
VCS Project Validator: TUV SUD South Asia Private Limited

title: Fujian Wuyishan Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation
description: The project to change rice planting from continuous flooding to intermittent flooding was carried out in Wuyishan City, Nanping City, Fujian Province, with a single season rice planting area of 10,492 hectares. Without this project providing ditches to conduct intermittent flooded method, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario  that  rice  was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission removal than the continuously flooded.

title: Tianpeng Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation
description:
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice
cultivation is conducted in Southern Pengzhou City within Chengdu City, Sichuan Province
of China, with a total acreage of 12,437 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the
implementation of this project, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the
scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario.
Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of
methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is
more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction
than the continuously flooded.
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results
in not only large amount of methane (CH4) emissions but also low rice productivity by
replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens
the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. Hence, with the proposed
project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.55 tCO2e/ha for singlecropping
rice is expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the
project activity is 56,539 tCO2e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 565,390
tCO2e during the fixed 10 years crediting period.
This project aims to:
- Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes;
- Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers;
- Increase the number of local individuals who have relevant skills due to diversified
educational opportunities from trainings;
- Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.
VCS Proponent:
Sichuan Huixiang Ecological Agriculture Co., Ltd.
Sichuan Province, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in Cangxi County in Sichuan Province
description:
Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in Cangxi County in Sichuan province (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is a project that changes the water regime during the rice cultivation period from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded on rice paddy fields located in Cangxi County in Sichuan province, China. The project involves 24,159 hectares of single cropping rice within the project boundary.
The implementation activities of the project include original ditch repair and rebuild, reservoir repair and rebuild, higher efficient drainage facilities purchase and necessary training for farmers to help them to conduct the intermittent flooded water regime during rice cultivation, which replaces the traditional flooded method. Controllable irrigation and drainage can not only save water resources, but also reduce methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions (flooded state).
VCS Proponent:
Sichuan Cangxi Urban Investment Carbon Sink Technology Co., Ltd.
Sichuan Province, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in Zhijiang City
description:
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation is conducted in Zhijiang City within Yichang City, Hubei Province of China, with a total acreage of 9,102.53 ha for single-cropping rice. Without the implementation of this project, the continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittent flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission reduction than the continuously flooded. 
This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results in not only large amount of methane (CH4) emissions but also low rice productivity by replacing the continuously flooded method with intermittent flooded method, which shortens the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. Hence, with the proposed project activity, an estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 4.72 tCO2e/ha for single cropping rice is expected. Annual average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity is 42,981 tCO2e/year, and the total GHG emission reductions are 429,810 tCO2e during the fixed 10 years crediting period. 
This project aims to: 1、Sequester greenhouse gas and mitigate climate changes; - Increase the rice productivity resulting in higher living standard of local farmers; 2、Increase the number of local individuals who have relevant skills due to diversified educational opportunities from trainings; 3、Provide more job opportunities, especially women workers.
VCS Proponent:
Sinochem Agriculture Holdings
Beijing, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Inner Mongolia Alihe-Jiwen Afforestation Project
description:
The Inner Mongolia Alihe-Jiwen Afforestation Project (hereafter “the project”) is located in northern part of the eastern side of Greater Khingan Mountains, Oroqen Autonomous Banner , Hulun Buir City, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, P.R.C. The project is jointly implemented by Alihe Forest Industry Co. LTD and Jiwen Forest Industry Co. LTD, both of which belong to the China Inner Mongolia Forest Industry Group. The project is designed to establish forests on degraded barren lands previously deforested and/or converted croplands.
Most of the lands to be planted were deforested since 193050s. Significant deforested lands were converted to croplands to support livelihood for increased residents. Other land remained as barren lands and have never been reforested since then. Due to human disturbance, desertification and sandification as well as soil erosion, the barren lands are degraded and degrading which would continue under the without project scenario.
1659.73 ha of forest is to be established by direct planting on degraded lands in 13 forestry farm of Alihe Forestry Bureau and 8 forestry farms of Jiwen Forestry Bureau. 61.4% of afforestation activities are carried out in a mixture of different tree (shrub) species for a purpose of enhancing resilience.
Major species and afforestation models include 26.29 ha of Korean pine (Pinus koraiensis Sieb. et Zucc.), 163.90 ha of Mongolian Scotch pine (Pinus sylvestris var. mongolica Litv.), 393.37 ha of spruce (Picea koraiensis Nakai), 57.63 ha of larch (Larix gmelinii (Rupr.) Kuzen), 312.70 ha of mixture of spruce and larch, 202.21 ha of  mixture of spruce and Seabuckthorn (Hippophae sp), 35.03 ha of mixture of Mongolian Scotch pine and Korean pine, 30.37 ha of mixture of Mongolian Scotch pine and Seabuckthorn, 437.83 ha of mixture of Mongolian Scotch pine and spruce. It is expected that the project would produce 532,455 tCO2e of GHG removals in 60 years, with an average annual GHG removals of 8,874 tCO2e
VCS Proponent:
INNER MONGOLIA DAXING’ANLING CARBON SINK TECHNOLOGY CO.LTD
Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China

VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: VALLE LAGUNARE - VAL DOGA', CAPOSILE - VENICE CARBON CREDIT ASSESSMENT IN CONTROLLED LAGOON ENVIRONMENT
description:

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in North Anyi
description:
The project changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded conditions during rice cultivation is conducted in Nanchang City， Jiangxi Province of China. Anyi County is located in the west part of Nanchang, with a total acreage of 6949.6 ha for double-cropping rice. Without implementing this project, which provides ditches to conduct the intermittently flooded method, the backward continuously flooded method would be continued, so the scenario that rice was cultivated by the continuously flooded method is the baseline scenario. Since the organic matter in rice soil under flooded conditions can emit a large amount of methane (CH4) because of anaerobic decomposition, the intermittently flooded method is more beneficial to water conservation, production increase and methane emission removal than the continuously flooded. 

This project solved the problems of excessive water used during rice cultivation which results in not only a large amount of methane (CH4) emissions but also low rice productivity by replacing the continuously flooded method with the intermittently flooded method, which shortens the period of anaerobic decomposition of soil organic matter. In this case, the CH4 emission can be declined by an average of 48% . 

The implementation of the project is expected to reduce the GHG emissions amounting to 1,603,490 tCO2e in 21 years, with an average annual GHG emission removal of 76,356.6 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Jiangxi Green Energy Agricultural Development Co., Ltd
Jiangxi Province, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: involtor Future Agriculture, East-Europe
description: The Involtor Future Agriculture East-Europe is a grouped project gathering under the same program major agricultural areas from five Eastern European countries and aiming at the scientific implementation of modern agricultural practices that helps preserve the Planet's climate, increase the resilience of agriculture and food security to climate change. The project provides a wide range of support for farmers, aiming for a safe transition to regenerative agriculture by implementing effective practices that sequester carbon in the soil, reduce / remove the emissions of CH4, N2O, CO2 that agriculture emits today in significant quantities, and in exchange for the performance monitored by this Project, farmers will receive income from verified carbon credits. The project pursues the implementation of 8 of UN SDG’s seeking certification with VERRA's SD ViSta - Verified Impact Standard. The initial phase of Project considers 1st of December 2019 as the baseline date in which the first agricultural practices implementation started.

title: Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in West of Fuling District in Chongqing City
description:
Adjusted Water Management in Rice Cultivation in West of Fuling District in Chongqing City (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is a project that changes the water regime during the rice cultivation period from continuously flooded to intermittently flooded on rice paddy fields located in the West of Fuling District in Chongqing City, China. The project involves 16,472.7 hectares of single cropping rice within the project boundary.
The project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by reducing the flooding time during the rice cultivation period. Since soil organic matters emits a large amount of methane (CH4) under flooded conditions because of anaerobic decomposition, when the flooded time of rice fields in the whole growth cycle is reduce, CH4 emissions are hence reduced; in addition, it provides other benefits such as creation of job opportunities, water saving, and yield increase compared to the traditional continuously flooded cultivation.
VCS Proponent:
Chongqing Tanray Technology Co.,Ltd.
Nan’an District, China
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: MILOPRI PROJECT - PRECISION MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS FOR SUSTAINABLE ORCHARDS
description:
The VCS Milopri project - Precision Management Systems for Sustainable Avocado Orchards, is the flagship project of We-Agri’s Regenerative Carbon Credit Network (RCCN) initiative - an intelligent platform designed to provide a holistic solution to endorse commercial fruit orchards and vineyards around the world. 

Fruit trees have great structural characteristics (e.g., long-life cycle; permanent organs such as the trunk, branches, and roots; minimum soil tillage; high quality and yield) which allow them to accumulate a significant amount of carbon (Sharma et al. 2021). Hence, the motivation to establish a sustainable agricultural system in orchards and vineyards that can further minimize emissions and is capable of efficiently sequestering carbon within the atmosphere.

This is a pioneering project that follows the SCOVY (i.e., Sustainable Carbon Orchards and Vineyards) methodology, which is currently being developed by We-Agri. This methodology will be the object of future works that will encompass different fruit crops. The main goal is to shift commercial fruit orchards into sustainable agricultural systems endorsed for the issuance of high-quality carbon credits by implementing smart-climate agricultural practices.

The Milopri grouped project is situated within the western Galilee region in the northern part of Israel. The project location has an overall area of circa 3,000 hectares which are owned by 25 different Israeli agricultural cooperative villages. These farms are consolidated into one Centralized packhouse & logistic center - Milopri Agricultural Cooperative. 

The project activities aim at increasing the capacity of soil to sequester carbon and reducing nitrogenous fertilizer-related greenhouse gas emissions. The project also holistically aims at achieving sustainable management practices which not only improve soil health and productivity but can also achieve socio-economic development in the project area.

title: Inner Mongolia Yitulihe-Genhe Afforestation Project
description:
The Inner Mongolia Yitulihe-Genhe Afforestation Project (hereafter “the project”) is located in northern part of the western side of Greater Khingan Mountains, Hulun Buir City, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, P.R.C. The project is jointly implemented byInner Mongolia Yitulihe Forestry Co. LTD and Genhe Forest Industry Co. LTD, both of which belong to the China Inner Mongolia Forest Industry Group. The project is designed to establish forests on degraded lands previously deforested and/or converted (croplands or settlements).
Most of the lands to be planted were deforested since 1950s. Significant deforested lands were converted to croplands and settlements to support livelihood for increased residents. Other land remained as barren lands and have never been reforested since then. Due to human disturbance, desertification and sandification as well as soil erosion, the barren lands are degraded and degrading which would continue under the without project scenario.
2,059.4 ha of forest is to be established by direct planting on degraded lands in 12 forestry farm of Yitulihe Forestry Bureau and 12 forestry farms of Genhe Forestry Bureau. 66.3%% of reforestation activities are carried out in a mixture of different tree species for a purpose of enhancing resilience.
Major species and Afforestation models include 480.64 ha of Spruce (Picea meyeri Rehd.et Wils), 214.6 ha of Mongolian Scotch pine (Pinus sylvestris var. mongolica Litv.), 546.0 ha of mixture of spruce and larch (Larix gmelinii (Rupr.) Kuzen), 43.8 ha of mixture of spruce, Scotch pine and elm (Ulmus macrocarpa Hance), 187.2 ha of spruce and elm, 459.9 ha of mixture of spruce and Scotch pine, and 127.3 ha of mixture of Mongolian Scotch pine and elm. It is expected that the project would produce 800,326 tCO2e of GHG removals in 60 years, with an average annual GHG removals of 13,339 tCO2e, starting in 2020. All species are native. No invasive alien species or genetically modified organisms are involved. All lan

title: MEM OSB-1 SOLAR POWER PROJECT
description: MEM OSB-1 SOLAR POWER PROJECT includes installation of rooftop solar photovoltaic systems with the objective of generating clean energy (electricity) for the purpose of inhouse/captive consumption in the commercial facilities of the project owners. Consumption of clean electricity generated in the project activity by harnessing renewable energy (solar) resources has resulted in avoidance of grid power that was used by the project facility/project owner in the pre-project scenario. The project activity has therefore resulted in curbing emission of greenhouse gas, which would have been emitted from generation of equivalent amount of electricity in the grid tied power plant, that has been avoided due to the project activity. The project activity encompasses a rooftop solar power project with the capacity of 10.3 MWe. The proposed project activity deployed in Turkey by MEM Tekstil Sanayi ve Ticaret Anonim Şirketi. The project is expected to result in an average annual supply of 8,974 MWh/year. The average annual emission reduction from the project is estimated to be around 5,822 tCO2e/annum and a cumulative emission reduction of 40,753 tCO2e for the entire crediting period of 7 years.

title: CARBON GROUP PROGRAM FOR SUSTAINABLE LOW CARBON CROP AND GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT IN ARGENTINA
description:
The project intends to include producers dedicated to extensive agriculture (corn, soybeans, wheat, sunflower, cotton, and other crops), and extensive cattle ranching, mostly cattle and grazing grasslands, pastures, agropastoral, and silvo-pastoral. Given the characteristics of the country, farm and ranch  production dates from no more than 200 years ago.
During most of the 20th century, the farms were managed in a rather extensive manner and with aggressive tillage systems, which caused widespread declines in the organic matter content of the soils. This lasted until the end of that century, when for different reasons the producers adopted zero tillage systems, which are what predominate today (more than 90%).
The projects to be implemented are expected to mitigate climate change both by reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and by capturing atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) and storing it as stable carbon in the soil, which must be recarbonized. The greatest efforts to reduce GHG emissions will be due to the adoption of better nitrogen fertilization technologies, which include alternative sources of nitrogen and variable rate fertilization that reduce nitrous oxide (N2) emissions from fertilized soils, the intensification of agricultural rotations with greater incorporation of winter crops, nitrogen fixing species and cover crops, and improved grazing management in livestock, which increase carbon stocks and with improvements in digestibility that reduce methane (CH4) emissions due to enteric fermentation. 
It is estimated that with these improvements, which are not currently widespread even among producers, it will be possible to reduce between 0.5 and 3 tons of CO2e/ha/year. Obviously, the total amount will depend on the area committed by the producers. This area is expected to reach more than 160 thousand hectares. If this is so, it is expected to mitigate almost 2 million tons CO2e at the end of this project.
VCS Proponent:
Carbon Group Agro-Climatic Solutions LLC
Florida, United States
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Family Forest Carbon Program - Central Appalachia
description:
The Family Forest Carbon Program (FFCP), administered by the Family Forest Impact Foundation (FFIF), is an innovative, incentive-based program engaging private family and other non-industrial private forest landowners throughout the United States in improved forest management practices, promoting forest health, carbon sequestration and storage, and other environmental conservation and protection practices. 

Through its grouped project design, the FFCP is able to engage and achieve economies of scale with smaller non-industrial forestland owners, reaching ownerships that have been largely unrepresented in voluntary carbon markets. The FFCP solves challenges to small forest holdings participation in carbon projects, by reducing cost and complexity of participation. 

FFCP provides incentive payments to forest landowners to implement climate-smart practices that increase sequestration and storage of carbon. The FFCP further connects enrolled landowners with technical assistance from local consulting foresters, helping family landowners transition to long-term, sustainable forest management. 

The first project activities implemented in the FFCP program (directed towards the U.S. Central Appalachia region) include: Growing Mature Forests (GMF) –20-year, renewable agreement to limit timber harvest (with imposition of minimum residual basal area and riparian buffers and prohibition on high-grading/diameter limit cuts), thereby increasing net growth. The GMF practice, compared to common practice high-grading in the region, is expected to generate net emission reductions of ~1.6 t CO2e/acre/year. total GHG emission reductions and removals.

title: Avcıkoru Landfill Gas to Electricity Project
description: The project activity is a Landfill Gas Power Generating Plant. Electricity production will be done by burning the landfill gas. Landfill gas will be burned in gas engines and electrical energy will be obtained from the ends of the generator coupled to gas engines. Electrical energy to be taken from the ends of the generator will be increased to medium voltage level in transformers and given to the interconnected system. Whilst providing sustainable development benefits to the host communities and the host country, the project activity reduces greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions mainly by preventing GHG emissions, methane in particular, from being emitted directly to the atmosphere from waste at the solid waste disposal site that would be otherwise left to be decomposed; and by replacing the electricity that would have otherwise been generated by the national grid which is primarily dependent on fossil-fuel-based resources.

title: Agroforestry For Livelihoods Project
description: The project aims to address widespread land and agro-ecosystem degradation and climate-change related hazards across the landscapes of Rulindo and Bugesera districts in northern and eastern provinces of Rwanda respectively. The project will undertake a number of activities including: 1) planting of around four million functional tree species on both smallholders’ farm plots and public suitable lands to restore degraded ecosystems, protect watersheds, sequester carbon, conserve biodiversity, and provide farmers with a diversified income streams, e.g., from fruits and timber; 2) establishing seedling nurseries to provide quality materials for tree planting 3) provide trainings to enhance knowledge to a wide range of key stakeholders, including farmer groups, the youth, community advisors, Community Extension Officers, nursery managers, project’s staff, etc. 4) promoting specific livelihoods activities, e.g., horticulture package, livestock husbandry, Village-based Savings & Loan Associations (VSLA), local investments, etc.; 5) facilitating market access for farmers products/produce by encouraging farmers to organize into cooperatives/ other community structures, and when possible, entering into supply agreements with off-takers; 6) engaging farmers in sustainability agreements - committing them to sustain the implementation of the project activities for the long-term, beyond the project’s crediting period (≥20 years). The project activities aim to address this land and agro-ecosystem degradation and directly contribute to climate mitigation through increased carbon storage in tree biomass and in soils within the agricultural landscapes. The new VERRA’s Verified Carbon Standard carbon methodology called Methodology for Afforestation, Reforestation, and Revegetation Projects will be used. The ex-ante annual average GHG emission reductions of the project are estimated at 70,470 tCO2e, and total GHG emission reductions over 20 years are estimated at 1,414,808 tCO2e.
VCS Proponent:
Livelihoods Fund SICAV SIF
Paris, France
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Zambia Agroforestry Grouped Project
description:
The project “Zambia Agroforestry Grouped Project” is comprised of the cashew plantation execution started as of January 2020 to 2021 for 5.5million of cashew nuts seedlings in the total of 72,000 hectares in ten districts (Mongu, Limulunga, Lukuku, Metete, Kalabo, Sikongo, Nalolo, Senanga, Sioma and Shangombo) in Western Province in Zambia. The project at the beginning initiated under the contract with CIDP in Western Province, in partnership with the Empowering Farmers Foundation, it is our intention to develop our project areas into a voluntary carbon project through the GHG emissions removals by such planting activities, which should in turn allow to perform regular gap filling, continue the plantations, thereby expanding the planted areas significantly.
We intend to perform a comprehensive environmental study, covering the feasibility of expanding the cashew plantations beyond the current project areas potentially to Eastern Province, in collaboration with ETG group companies and partners.
In the Eastern Province in Zambia, EFF had also executed 1 million (1.043.425) of cashew seedlings plantation in six districts namely: Nyimba, Petauke, Sinda, Chadiza, Mambwe, Lundazi.

title: Bundled Solar Power Project by AMP Energy - 01
description: The project involves the installation of bundled Solar Photovoltaic (SPV) power plant with a cumulative capacity of 9.51 MW primarily to meet the captive demand of the premises owners and export of surplus power to the grid through the mechanism of net metering. All the solar panel units involved in the project are implemented under the DBFOT model, i.e., Design, Build, Finance, Operate, and Transfer. The premises owners are the customers of the power generated from the solar panels which purchase the power under long-term power purchase agreements signed for 25 years. Before installation of the rooftop solar units, the Kochi Metro premises, Subros Ltd., SECI rooftop premises owners used to meet the electricity demand from the national grid of India. The project thus replaces fossil fuel-dominated grid electricity thereby reducing the equivalent amount of GHG emission.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents

title: The Native Ecosystem Restoration in Nicaragua Project
description: The objective of the Native Ecosystem Restoration in Nicaragua Project is to reforest an area of around 20,000 hectares, starting with the acquisition of 6,000 hectares of unused or under-used, degraded land in Nicaragua currently managed as abandoned or cattle pasture grazed at very low densities, and restore this ecosystem with native trees in order to sequester carbon dioxide. The degraded land will thus be rehabilitated with native tree cover, and over time biodiversity and local hydrology will be restored. The grouped Project will control erosion, regenerate soil health, and increase water infiltration, consequently improving ground water levels in the area, as well as provide local employment opportunities. Most land being considered is in the Central and Pacific regions of Nicaragua, but all regions of the country with degraded cattle pasture are eligible.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Macaúba as a Productive Second Floor
description:
The “Macaúba as a Productive Second Floor” is a VCS AFOLU (Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use) grouped project, Scope 14, and, specifically, it falls under the ARR (Afforestation, Reforestation and Revegetation) category. 
The project works with local farmers to implement integrated systems in previously degraded pastures and/or croplands. The main project activity consists of the planting of Macaúba trees. This will be done considering two possible arrangements: (i) Macaúba intercropped with pasture (silvipastoral) or (ii) macuaba intercropped with agriculture (agrisilvicultural).
Through the planting of Macaúba trees the project will contribute to an increase in carbon stocks and associated GHG removals. The project activity will also improve the livelihood of local farmers and provide other ecosystem services, such as: maintaining the local microclimate, preventing erosion, conserving soil and moisture.
State/Province: Minas Gerais, São Paulo and Pará States

title: Terraligna Afforestation Over Degraded Grasslands
description: The project activity “Terraligna Afforestation over degraded grasslands” is an afforestation project over extensive cattle grazing pastures areas using exotic species (mostly Eucalyptus dunnii) aiming to produce biomass for energy and/or pulp. The Terraligna project eligible for the VCS standard is circumscribed to 4,282 ha effectively planted after the trust fund operation starting date, carried out in 8 properties (7 entire plots and 90% of the effectively planted area of the 8th). The area corresponding to the other 19 of the trust fund properties (5,896 ha) will not be presented as part of the project as it does not meet the requirements of the VCS Standard boundaries. The project activity is carried out on degraded land as a consequence of many decades of intensive cattle grazing. This degradation is expected to continue in the absence of the project. The project utilizes 2 species: mostly Eucalyptus dunnii and Eucalyptus smithii in a lesser extent, 95.9% and 4.1% of the planted area, respectively. The project sequesters CO2 through forest plantation in grassland areas, generating net anthropogenic removals by sinks. The long-term average GHG benefit (LTA) is determined by averaging the expected total GHG benefit for the length of the project (100 years: from 21/12/2019 – until 21/12/2119). The total GHG benefit for the length of the project is 1,112,972 tCO2e, when divided by 100 years results in 11,130 tCO2e.
State/Province: Cerro Largo, Durazno and Treinta y Tres

Fideicomiso Financiero Forestal Terraligna
Montevideo, Uruguay

description:

title: Amazon Biome Conservancy Grouped REDD+ Project
description: The Amazon Biome Conservancy Grouped REDD+ Project (hereinafter also referred to as “ABC”) has as its main objective to contribute to the preservation with the biggest tropical forest of the world in the Brazilian territory, while providing significant improvements in the social interface. The project for this validation process has only one project activity instance located in the Itacoatiara municipality, state of Amazonas near its capital of Manaus. According to the geo-referencing data, the total area of the project is established at 5,140 ha, which is composed of native Amazon Rainforest vegetation, without the existence of secondary vegetation since the land has not been cleared of native ecosystems within the last 10 years before the project start date. The project area consist of the ABC project is equivalent to the 20% of the landowner property area that he could legally suppress, according to the Brazilian forest code (Law 12.651, 2012). This project will be eligible under the Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD) category, using the VM0007 methodology for Avoiding Planned Deforestation (APDD). The crediting period of the project is 30 years. The start date is on 19/11/2022 and the crediting period is expected to end on 18/11/2052. To execute the installation of this project and to achieve its objectives the VCU generation is very important. A reduction of 2,605,773.23 t CO2-e of GHG is expected over the next ten years for the first baseline developed and presented in this Project Description - PD (average of 260,577.32 t CO2-e per year).

title: AgreenaCarbon Project
description: The AgreenaCarbon Project aims to reduce agricultural GHG emissions through the implementation of activities that are central principles of regenerative agriculture. The Project intends to help farmers transition to regenerative agriculture by applying sustainable agricultural land management practices (ALM) in order to maintain yields while ensuring long-term viability of their farms and land. Regenerative agriculture describes holistic farming practices that improve the soil fertility and enhance the storage of soil organic carbon (SOC) and ‘focuses on the regeneration of living soil, improved micro hydrology, and conserving biodiversity at all levels while enhancing inputs use-efficiency and ecosystem system services.’  The AgreenaCarbon Project assists farmers in the transition from conventional, intensive farming practices to ones that avoid soil disturbances and increase the amount of organic soil amendments all while reducing the use of synthetic fertilisers. The focal point of these practices is reducing tillage to reduce soil disturbance with the addition of the other activities as a combined suite of activities that contribute to soil fertility. The Project facilitates the transition through a carbon payment programme which provides economic incentives to change existing agricultural practices, described as project activities. The programme is located across Europe and is based in temperate climates.
VCS Proponent:
Agreena ApS
Byen København, Denmark
+44 (0)20 8089 5835
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Strengthening rural livelihoods of smallholder farmers in tribal districts of Odisha,India
description: The fragile ecosystem of the upland tribal regions in Keojhar and Mayurbhanj districts of Odisha have been affected by deforestation and rampant shifting cultivation practices causing extensive soil erosion, reducing the capacity of land to rejuvenate and affecting natural vegetation and water resources.In order to address some of the issues of the communities it becomes pertinent to adopt interventions based on improved land use planning, soil-moisture conservation measures and improved farming based agroforestry practices. This will not only strengthen the agrarian livelihoods of the tribal households, but also increase their food and nutritional security.The proposed project in the two districts of Keonjhar and Mayurbhanj is aimed at improving the livelihoods of the tribal communities by restoring 4000 hectares of barren uplands through plantation of forest and fruit tree species mostly in private lands. Additional components include land development, soil-moisture conservation, crop diversification and intercropping and promoting organic farm and pest management practices. The project will be implemented in 4000 hectares covering 3 blocks of Keonjhar district (Harichandanpur, Jhumpura and Champua) and 2 blocks of Mayurbhanj district (Udala and Khunta). The project aims for economic upliftment of the small holder famers through improved land use planning, increase in production and productivity, social empowerment of women along with enhancement of the carbon sequestration potential through such interventions.
VCS Proponent: Multiple Proponents
VCS Project Type: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

title: Angola Caraculo PV Plant
description:
The proposed project activity aims to generate renewable electricity through a 25MWp photovoltaic power plant located in Caraculo, Nambibe province, in Angola Southern Region, which currently relies mainly on diesel thermal plants for electricity production. The project is implemented by Solenova, a company jointly owned by Sonangol and Eni Angola.
This project activity represents the first phase of a larger photovoltaic project having a total capacity of up to 50 MWp. The overall project is implemented in following phases as requested by the Rede Nacional de Transporte (“RNT”) as the sole offtaker, taking into consideration the current load and the need to ensure the full dispatchability of the energy produced.
The area identified for the project is located 2 km west from Caraculo village (Namibe Province), adjacent to the EN 280 road and the South Transmission Grid. The area covers about 165 ha and was proposed for this initiative by the Province Authorities.
The scope of Caraculo project is to ensure a reliable production of electrical renewable power to be dispatched into the Southern Transmission Grid of the Country, which currently relies mainly
on diesel thermal plants for its supply. The expected annual average energy production over the 24 years project technical lif etime is up to 59 GWh/year. The scope of works also includes the construction of a MV/HV substation inside the project area.
The project first phase implementation (25 MWp) will permit a diesel consumption reduction of about 18.000 m3/year. The average annual GHG emission reduction expected with the implementation
of the project activity is around 50,000 tCO2e per year.

description:

District, Magway Region, Myanmar. The project is divided into 4 phases with a capacity of 50WMp
for phases 1-3 and 70MWp for phase 4. Currently, phase 1 has been operated since 27 September

title: Agropalma REDD+ Project
description: The Agropalma REDD+ Project is a partnership between Biofílica Ambipar Environment and Agropalma Group and its purpose is to promote forest conservation, maintenance of carbon stocks and mitigation of climate change through the reduction of Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions from land use change. In addition to the climate benefits, the Project also intends to generate social benefits based on sustainable economic development practices and improved well-being of the surrounding communities, as well as environmental benefits through actions aimed at the conservation of local flora and fauna. The Project area covers 50,519 hectares of Amazon forest and is located almost entirely in the northeastern mesoregion of Pará State, including the municipalities of Tailândia, Moju, Tomé Açu and Acará. The region has great relevance in relation to its biodiversity, since it is located in the Belém Center of Endemism (CEB), a place with a large concentration of rare and endemic species. The predominant vegetation is Dense Ombrophylous Forest with a high density of medium and large trees, besides woody lianas and epiphytes.

title: EVI BAMBOO AFFORESTATION PROJECT IN INDIA
description:
The project activity focuses on the development of Bamboo as a key resource for catalyzing an inclusive green economy. In this project, different types of bamboo species will be planted to restore degraded lands. It will help the local communities and farmers generate income by involving them in different livelihood activities like making of bamboo handicraft and furniture. In addition, it will help to sequesters atmospheric carbon dioxide, which aids in climate change mitigation, as well as improving soil in the project area through conservation practices. 

The project activity will be implemented across states of India. This is a grouped project.

First project activity instance:
The Konkan Bamboo & Cane Development Centre (KONBAC) is a not-for-profit company, facilitated by the International Network for Bamboo and Rattan (INBAR) through the Centre for Indian Bamboo Resource and Technology (CIBART). 

The KONBAC organization planted bamboo species with the collaboration of local farmers in 24 districts (Ahmednagar, Akola, Amravati, Aurangabad, Beed, Bhandara, Buldhana, Chandrapur, Dhule, Jalna, Kolhapur,	Latur, Nagpur, Nanded, Nandurbar, Nashik, Palghar, Parbhani, Pune, Sangli, Satara, Solapur, Thane & Wardha) of Maharashtra, India. The area covered in the project is about 595.5 hectare.

The techniques used for the plantation are vegetative propagation, rhizome & the seedlings. This seedling are sourced from the various designated nurseries and planting from various empty and barren locations in the project.  KONBAC provides hands-on training to farmers in the scientific processes of propagation, cultivation and harvesting.

The first VPA is estimated to sequester average 26,292 tCO2e annually.

title: 26MWp Solar Photovoltaic Power Plant in Bavet City, Cambodia
description:
26MWp Solar Photovoltaic Power Plant in Bavet City, Cambodia (hereafter referred to as “the 
project”) is a solar power project with total installed capacity of 26MWp, located in Monourom 
village, Bavet City, Svay Rieng Province, the Kingdom of Cambodia. The project is invested by 
Green Sustainable Ventures (Cambodia) Co., Ltd. (hereafter referred to as “the project owner”).
The purpose of the project is to utilize the solar energy at the project site to generate and supply 
electricity to Electricite Du Cambodge Grid (EDC) which is dominated by coal-fired power stations.
Prior to the implementation of the project, the electricity delivered to the grid by the project 
activity would be generated by the operation of grid-connected power plants and by the addition 
of new generation sources into the EDC. This is the scenario that existed prior to the 
implementation of the project activity and is also the baseline scenario.
The project is a renewable energy project and is expected to supply an annual average of 37,085
MWh of zero-emission electricity to EDC during the whole project lifetime of 25 years, which 
replace the power generation of those fossil fuel-fired power plants delivered to the EDC under 
the baseline scenario. 
The project started construction on 13-Apr-2021 and commissioned on 27-Jan-2022. The 
expected total emission reductions are 185,314 tCO2e during the first crediting period from 27-
Jan-2022 to 26-Jan-2029, with average annual emission reductions of 26,473 tCO2e.

title: Cauaxi REDD+ Grouped Project
description:
The Cauaxi REDD+ Grouped Project (hereafter called GPD) aims to conserve forests in several private properties located in northeast portion of Pará, close to the border with Maranhão. The Cauaxi River, which gives the project its name, is one of the tributaries of the Capim River, located in the central portion of the project's reference region, at Paragominas municipality.
The GPD aims to create positive economic incentives for landowners to conserve rainforests in private areas that are vulnerable to degradation and deforestation, while contributing to net positive climate impacts as well as benefit to traditional communities and conserve biodiversity. By joining BRcarbon (hereafter known as BRC), forest owners can access funds from the carbon voluntary market to develop conservation and monitoring efforts in their forests. A partnership between BRC and landowners will result in the legal protection of forests, forest monitoring using satellite images, biodiversity inventory (including fauna e flora species), and forest biomass inventory in a broad scale, using 
a upscaling approach based on field collection, drone-borne and satellite sensors such as LiDAR (light detection and ranging). In addition, we will involve surveillance of property, wildfire monitoring, fire prevention and fighting, threatened species protection and social activities with traditional communities. 
As a result, BRC expects to enhance the climate impact of carbon projects, helping communities and biodiversity. The Cauaxi REDD+ Grouped Project is part of the company's initiative to promote forest conservation using the financial flows of the carbon market. This project is related to climate-positive impacts caused by the reduction of emissions 
caused by deforestation and avoided degradation (REDD+).

title: ENHANCING LIVELIHOOD OF TRIBAL COMMUNITIES THROUGH AGROFORESTRY IN SOUTH INDIA
description:
Adoption of agroforestry approach is a viable alternative solution for the local communities in India to increase the fertility of their land and create livelihood opportunities to overcome extreme poverty. It is a system that can provide both food and income sources while preserving and rehabilitating the ecosystem. The proposed ARR VCS project aims to support tribal communities of ASR district in Andhra Pradesh, India. For the first project instance, approximately 12,500 hectares of area under agroforestry has been considered. The different species included in the proposed ARR project activity includes mango, silver oak, teak, jackfruit, cashew, and several other local tree species. The project area is located in 22 Mandals of ASR district in Andhra Pradesh state. The project aims to improve the livelihood of small and marginalized tribal communities in the  Alluri Sitarama Raju (ASR) district in the state of Andhra Pradesh by generating additional income via carbon credits. The project plans to generate carbon credits for the voluntary market under the VCS standard. 
The project is expected to sequester 140,864 tCO2 annually. The Project Proponent along with the implementation partner organized workshops in the forest  dwelling community areas and advised the community members to grow native trees with commercial importance in a sustainable manner to earn carbon revenue.

title: IMPROVING LIVELIHOOD OF FARMERS VIA CARBON FINANCE PROJECT IN NEPAL
description:
The project area is in Nepal which is a home to a plethora of flora and fauna which spread across Terai to the middle to mountain of the country. Around 5962.03 (000 ha) of land was under forest cover in 2020. Forest Act 1993 recognizes two essential kinds (national and private) and five auxiliary kinds of forest beneath national forest (Government Managed, Community Managed, Protected Forests, Leasehold Forest, Religious Forest, and Private Forest). Deforestation, degradation and fragmentation of natural habitat of wildlife are a serious threat to forests of the country which alarm the need for protection of biodiversity. Adopting agroforestry practices is the best possible solution as this system can avail basic needs of an individual and rehabilitate the lost ecosystem. The primary objectives of agroforestry are to produce food, fodder, fuel-wood, and/or timber. There can also be co-benefits such as carbon sequestration, water quality enhancement, soil protection, and biodiversity conservation. 
Agroforestry system in Nepal is a traditional and ancient practice. Farmers in the hills have expanded the number of agroforestry trees on their farmland in response to forest degradation and deforestation, to meet their immediate demand for fodder, fuelwood, and small-sized timber products. The agroforestry systems deliver several forest products, agriculture products and ecosystem services which may enhance social well-being of the local farmers, national and global community. The small and marginal farmers are almost unaware of the scientific importance (economic and environmental aspects) of agroforestry, short- and long-term benefits, and technical requirements. There awareness efforts to educate farmers on the benefits of agroforestry practice in their farmlands.

title: CLIMATE SUSTAINABILITY THROUGH HORTICULTURE PROJECT IN INDIA
description:
This is an Afforestation/Reforestation Project on degraded and fallow land and lies within the boundaries of India. The purpose of this grouped project is to promote the restoration of degraded and fallow land and improve the living conditions of farmers by planting horticulture and commercial species (indigenous species preferred). This is a grouped project.

The first project activity instance under the program is located in the state of Maharashtra, district Nandurbar in India. TATA Communications Limited (TCL) has implemented the VPA01 from 01-April-2022 with the coordination of implementing entity Collectives for Integrated Livelihood Initiatives (CINI). The area covered in this VPA is up to 303 hectare with an average land holding of approximately 0.40 hectare or one acre per farmer.
The villages under the project area predominantly have an agrarian economy. The conditions of lands covered under the project are either barren & fallow land with seasonal crops grown. The plantation under the project activity will lead to the sequestration of CO2 at a faster pace. 

The technology used for the tree plantation is simple as it just involves procurement of saplings from designated nurseries and planting various empty and barren locations of the districts. The first VPA is estimated to sequester average 5,645 tCO2e annually over 20 years.

title: MITIGATING CLIMATE CHANGE AND ENHANCING RURAL LIVELIHOODS THROUGH PLANTATIONS RAISED TO PROVIDE RAW MATERIAL TO THE PAPER INDUSTRY
description:
The proposed project activity under VCS will mobilize resource-poor farmers to raise tree plantations on vacant farmlands. It proposes to link resource poor farmers and end users of wood products in order to optimize the land use and to facilitate the co-ordination of wood producers, agronomists, industry, social enterprises and non-governmental organizations to improve the livelihood opportunities of rural households. The project activity is implemented on the degraded farmlands or lands used for rainfed subsistence agriculture. 
Various environment friendly technology-based agroforestry practices and Natural Climate Solutions (NCS) will be adopted to help climate change adaptation and mitigation as part of sustainable land management.

This project will optimise the land use and generate Emission Reductions (ERs). The amount of carbon sequestered through the project activity will be measured and  quantified with reference to a baseline to determine the Emission Reductions (ERs) generated. The ERs will be calculated through quantifying  Above Ground Biomass, Below Ground Biomass and Soil Organic Carbon. In the absence of the project, the lands would have remained degraded and the resource poor farmers would have continued to practice subsistence agriculture. 

The participation of small and marginal farmers as part of the VCS project makes this initiative unique in contributing to their land use choice, improvement of livelihood opportunities and in promoting their capacity to organize and implement climate change mitigation initiatives.

The project implements reforestation on 13,500 ha of degraded private lands in the states of Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and Orissa. The reforestation activities under the project were initiated after 1 April 2020. 

The project is estimated to generate 94,200 credits / year on average over a period of 20 years.

title: Guangzhou Xingfeng landfill gas to LNG Project
description:
Guangzhou Xingfeng landfill gas to LNG Project (hereafter referred to as the project) is located at Xingfengemergency landfill site in Baiyun district, Guangzhou City, Guangdong Province, P.R.China. The project is implemented by Guangzhou Huantou Environment Service Co.,Ltd (hereafter referred to as the project owner).
The purpose of the project is to utilize landfill gas (LFG), which consists mainly of methane, for LNG production for sale and electricity generation for self use. It includes LFG collection system, LFG pre-treatment system, and, liquefaction, by-product recovery, storing, loading, electricity generation, flare system, etc. LFG collected will be used for LNG production for sale and electricity generation with internal combustion generators for self use. The project started to construct on21/Feb/2020 and operated on 04/Aug/2021.The landfill gas treatment capacity of the project is 300,000 m3 per day(200,000 m3for LNG production and 100,000 m3for electricity generation). Greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions will be reduced by avoiding GHG emissions from releasing LFG into atmosphere at the landfill site. Meanwhile supplying liquefied LFG to consumers using trucks reduce GHG emissions from the use of natural gas. The expected average annual emission reductions are 392,583 tCO2e during the fixed 10 years crediting period.

title: VCS PROJECT FOR FARMERS ADOPTING ALTERNATE WETTING AND DRYING (AWD) METHOD FOR RICE CULTIVATION IN MADHYA  PRADESH
description:
Rice is the country's most significant agricultural product; it is grown on 43.86 million hectares in India and contributes to more than 20% of world rice output (158.2 Tg in 2013).
Rice is farmed in practically every state in India, and its production is directly related to the country's food security. Additionally, it is a significant source of income and employment. Rice production, on the other hand, is a substantial source of critical and long-lasting GHGs such as CH 4 and N 2 O, posing a huge threat to sustainable agriculture. Rice fields provide approximately 30% and 11% of total agricultural CH 4 and N 2 O emissions, respectively. According to early US-EPA study, paddy in India produced around 37.8 Tg CH 4 per year. GHG emissions from rice fields may be minimized by changing irrigation patterns, managing organic additions, and utilizing the appropriate rate and amount of nitrogen fertilizer. Irrigation practices such as alternate wetting and drying (AWD) have been shown to lower GHG emissions when compared to typical flooding methods. The time intervals between dry and wet circumstances aid in the shift from aerobic to anaerobic soil conditions,
resulting in a considerable reduction in methane output. As a result, the project adopts the AWD approach to minimize CH 4 emissions. This will also result in a reduction in water use, lowering the farmer's input costs. Prior to the execution of the project activity, the farmers used the traditional flooding approach, which resulted in methane emissions into the atmosphere. The project proponent along with local implementation partner held training sessions and meetings with farmers to educate them on the benefits of using AWD, which was followed by the distribution and installation of AWD pipe in the fields of registered farmers. Location: The first instance of the project is located in Madhya Pradesh (Hoshangabad, Raisen, Sehore and Bhopal districts). The annual average emissions is 53,369 tCO 2 eq.

Varaha ClimateAg Private Limited
Delhi, India

title: Heilongjiang Nehe Improved Agricultural Land Management Project
description:
Heilongjiang Nehe Improved Agricultural Land Management Project (hereinafter referred to as “the project”) is a project that change the pre-existing agricultural management activities (conventional tillage with synthetic fertilizer) to no tillage or straw returning with organic fertilizer application in fields located in Nehe city in Heilongjiang province, China. The project involves 60,360 ha corn field and 82,341 ha soybean field.
The project is expected to reduce GHG emissions by no tillage and applying organic fertilizer, since no-tillage can reduce soil disturbance and reduce the loss of soil organic carbon (SOC) compared to conventional tillage. And applying organic fertilizer can reduce nitrous oxide emission compared to synthetic fertilizer. Moreover, the project is expected to increase SOC by straw returning, since straw contains a large amount of organic matter and trace elements such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium, returning straw to the field can effectively increase soil organic matter (SOM). Straw returning to the field also can improve soil physical and chemical properties, enhance soil aggregate structure, and increase soil permeability.

title: Amazon Bluecarbon Grouped REDD Project
description:
The primary objective of the Amazon Bluecarbon Grouped REDD Project is to avoid the unplanned deforestation (AUD) within its 3,242.18-ha area, consisting of 100% of mangrove forest. The Project Area is located within a private property in the municipality of São João de Pirabas, Pará State. This Project was designed as a grouped project, in order to be able to increase its contribution with the protection of the mangrove ecosystem, through the addition of new project activity instances in the future.

It is expected that, with the present carbon project, it will be possible to expand the area’s surveillance, by hiring new professionals to work in the farm as well as to monitor it. In addition to the project’s ecological and carbon benefits, a proportion of the carbon credits generated will be dedicated to improving the social and environmental conditions in the project region, specifically contributing to improving deforestation control, aiming at the propagation of environmental awareness, generation of alternative sources of income and environmental education actions.

The present Bluecarbon REDD project is expected to avoid a predicted 290.46 ha of deforestation, equating to 100,918 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime, with an annual average of 3,364 tCO2e.

Future Carbon Holding S.A.
São Paulo, Brazil

The project area is located within 2 private properties, which are located in municipalities of Feijó, Manoel Urbano and Santa Rosa do Purus in the State of Acre. 

It is expected that, with the carbon project, it will be possible to expand the monitoring of the area, hiring new professionals to work on the farms. In addition to the project’s ecological and carbon benefits, a proportion of the carbon credits generated will be dedicated to improving the social and environmental conditions in the project region, specifically contributing to improving deforestation control, aiming at the propagation of environmental awareness, generation of alternative sources of income and environmental education actions. 

The AUD REDD project is expected to avoid a predicted 6,807 ha of deforestation, equating to 679,673 tCO2e in emissions reductions over the 30-year project lifetime (07-October-2020 to 06-October-2020), with an annual average of 22,656 tCO2e.

title: Fazenda Boa Vista afforestation project
description:
The Fazenda Boa Vista Afforestation Project (FBV Project) established  Eucalyptus plantations in the Municipality of Ponto dos Volantes in the north-eastern part of Minas Gerais state (Brazil). The Project is located in a transition zone of Atlantic Rainforest and Cerrado Biome.

The project area was composed by degraded lands because of the extensive and traditional cattle breeding and remnants of natural forest. In this farm (and commonly in all other farms of the region) such pastures have been historically subject to burns that took place with the objective to reduce tree covers, expand pastures, and stimulate the regrowth of tender and nutritious sprouts during the dry season when pasture becomes fibrous in order to develop extensive cattle ranching activities.  

The Project is expected to capture 428,486 tCO2e in 20 years, with an average annual GHG removal of 21,424 tCO2e.

The geographical coordinates of the project area are 120°39′30″E~122°47′05″E, 50°25′10″N~51°45′20″N, with a forest coverage rate of 93.78%.
